subsection.text: In this article the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County” means a county of the State and, unless expressly provided otherwise, Baltimore City.
“Includes” or “including” means includes or including by way of illustration and not by way of limitation.
“Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, or representative of any kind and any partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.
“State” means:

paragraph.text: a state, possession, or territory of the United States;
the District of Columbia; or
the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“House” means the House of Delegates of Maryland.
“President” means the President of the Senate.
“Senate” means the Senate of Maryland.
“Speaker” means the Speaker of the House.
“Standing committee” means:

paragraph.text: a standing committee of the Senate, as set forth in the Senate rules; or
a standing committee of the House, as set forth in the House rules.

subsection.text: The State shall provide the members of the General Assembly with reasonable office space and services, equipment, and secretarial services, as provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: A municipal corporation, county, or other political subdivision or its governing body may not subsidize a member of the General Assembly in the maintenance of the space, services, or equipment.
This subsection does not prohibit the establishment of an office by a political subdivision to maintain liaison between the subdivision and the General Assembly.

subsection.text: In this section, “permanent part–time legislative employee” means an individual who, for at least 130 days a year, is employed by the General Assembly.
A permanent part–time legislative employee shall receive employment rights, privileges, and benefits that:

paragraph.text: equal at least 50% of the employment rights, privileges, and benefits of a permanent full–time employee of the Department of Legislative Services; and
for an individual who is employed for at least 50% of a full workweek, are prorated in proportion to the number of hours worked.

subsection.text: For auditing purposes, permanent time records shall be kept for each permanent part–time legislative employee.
The President and the Speaker shall administer this section.

paragraph.text: All full–time permanent employees of the General Assembly of Maryland and the Department of Legislative Services shall be considered as full–time permanent State employees for the purposes of transferring to a position in the Executive or Judicial Branch of State government.

These employees shall receive credit for service with the General Assembly for the purposes of transferring accumulated sick and vacation leave, service credit in the Employees’ Retirement System, and all other benefits.
These employees shall be granted the same salary consideration that would be provided to an employee transferring within the Executive or Judicial Branch.

subsection.text: On the transfer of a General Assembly employee or an employee of the Department of Legislative Services to a position in the Executive Branch, the Secretary of Budget and Management may request that the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Delegates or their representative certify as to the full–time permanent status of that employee. The certification shall be satisfactory evidence for the purposes of subsection (a) of this section.

If any employee of the General Assembly transferred to a position in the Executive or Judicial Branch on or after July 1, 1977, and suffered any loss of compensation or benefits solely as a result of the employee’s prior service with the General Assembly not being recognized as full–time permanent service, the employee’s compensation and benefits shall be reinstated at the appropriate level and the employee shall be reimbursed for any loss in salary from the effective date of the transfer.

Any full–time permanent employee of the General Assembly of Maryland or the Department of Legislative Services who separates from State service and returns to State service in the Executive or Judicial Branch within 3 years from the time of separation from active duty shall be eligible for reinstatement and shall receive full credit for any prior State service.

section.text: While the General Assembly is in session, each member or employee of the General Assembly who also is employed by the State or any of its political subdivisions:

paragraph.text: is entitled automatically to a leave of absence from the other employment; and

except for a right to a salary or wages, may not be deprived of or otherwise have impaired any incident of the employment, including tenure, seniority, annual or sick leave, promotional rights, or rights to salary increments.

subsection.text: In this section, “Force” means the Legislative Security Force.
There is a Legislative Security Force.
The Force consists of the members of the Department of State Police who are assigned for duty with the General Assembly.
Under the guidance of the presiding officers of the General Assembly, the Force shall maintain order during the conduct of the legislative process.
In this section, “relative” means:

paragraph.text: a spouse;
a parent or stepparent;
a sibling or step sibling;
a child, stepchild, foster child, or ward;
a mother–in–law or father–in–law;
a son–in–law or daughter–in–law;
a grandparent; or
a grandchild.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a member of the General Assembly may not employ for legislative business the member’s own relative, or the relative of another member from the same legislative district, using public funds over which the member has direct control.
Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply to a member of the General Assembly who:

subparagraph.text: has a physical impairment that necessitates the employment of a particular relative; and
discloses the employment to the Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics.

subsection.text: Public resources may be used by members of the General Assembly only for public purposes.
This section does not prohibit incidental use of public resources for nonpublic purposes.
The State of Maryland is divided into 47 districts for the election of members of the General Assembly of Maryland.
Each legislative district shall elect 1 Senator and 3 Delegates.
Each legislative district may be subdivided into 3 single member delegate districts or into 1 single member delegate district and 1 multimember delegate district.
In any legislative district which contains more than 2 counties:

paragraph.text: where Delegates are to be elected at large by the voters of the entire district, a county, or part of a county, may not have more than 1 Delegate residing in that district; and

where Delegates are to be elected by the voters of a multimember subdistrict which contains more than 2 counties or parts of more than 2 counties, a county or a part of a county may not have more than 1 Delegate residing in that subdistrict.
The descriptions of legislative districts in this subtitle, including all references to:

subparagraph.text: election districts and wards are to the geographical boundaries of the election districts and wards as they existed as of April 1, 2010; and

precincts are to the geographical boundaries of the precincts as reviewed and certified by the local board of supervisors of elections or their designees, before they were reported to the U.S. Bureau of the Census as part of the 2010 Census Redistricting Data Program and as those precinct lines are specifically indicated in the P.L. 94–171 data or shown on the P.L. 94–171 census block maps provided by the U.S. Bureau of the Census and as reviewed and corrected by the Maryland Department of Planning.

paragraph.text: Where precincts are split between legislative districts, census tract and block numbers, as indicated in the P.L. 94–171 data or shown on the P.L. 94–171 census block maps provided by the U.S. Bureau of the Census and referred to in § 2–202 of this subtitle, are used to define the boundaries of legislative districts.

subsection.text: For purposes of elections, the provisions of this subtitle shall be applicable to elections for members of the General Assembly beginning with the primary and general elections of 2014 and, for purposes of representation, shall be applicable beginning with the second Wednesday of January 2015.

section.text: All provisions of this article, and all other laws or parts of laws, public general or public local, inconsistent with the provisions of this subtitle, are repealed to the extent of any such inconsistency.

If any part of this subtitle, including any section or subsection or portion of it, shall be held to be unconstitutional or invalid for any reason, the unconstitutionality or invalidity may not affect the remaining parts of this subtitle. It is the intention that the remaining parts of this subtitle would have been enacted into law if that unconstitutionality or invalidity had been known. To this end, all parts of this subtitle are declared to be severable.
The population count used after each decennial census for the purpose of creating the legislative districting plan for the General Assembly:

paragraph.text: may not include individuals who:

subparagraph.text: were incarcerated in State or federal correctional facilities, as determined by the decennial census; and
were not residents of the State before their incarceration; and

paragraph.text: shall count individuals incarcerated in the State or federal correctional facilities, as determined by the decennial census, at their last known residence before incarceration if the individuals were residents of the State.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Committee” means the Legislative Policy Committee.
There is a Legislative Policy Committee.

subsection.text: The Legislative Policy Committee consists of the following 28 members:

paragraph.text: from the Senate:

subparagraph.text: the President;
the President Pro Tem;
the Majority Leader;
the Chairman of the Budget and Taxation Committee;
the Chairman of the Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs Committee;
the Chairman of the Finance Committee;
the Chairman of the Judicial Proceedings Committee;
the Minority Leader; and

sub-subparagraph.text: 6 other Senators, appointed by the President and approved by majority vote of the Senate; or

if a Senator simultaneously serves in 2 of the positions set forth in items (ii) through (vii), inclusive, of this paragraph, 7 other Senators, appointed by the President and approved by majority vote of the Senate; and

paragraph.text: from the House:

subparagraph.text: the Speaker;
the Speaker Pro Tem;
the Majority Leader;
the Chairman of the Appropriations Committee;
the Chairman of the Health and Government Operations Committee;
the Chairman of the Economic Matters Committee;
the Chairman of the Environmental Matters Committee;
the Chairman of the Judiciary Committee;
the Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee;
the Minority Leader; and

sub-subparagraph.text: 4 other Delegates, appointed by the Speaker and approved by majority vote of the House; or

if a Delegate simultaneously serves in 2 of the positions set forth in items (ii) through (ix), inclusive, of this paragraph, 5 other Delegates, appointed by the Speaker and approved by majority vote of the House.

paragraph.text: As far as possible, the Senators appointed by the President, under subsection (a)(1)(ix) of this section, shall be representative of the various sections and interests of the State.
As far as possible, the Delegates appointed by the Speaker, under subsection (a)(2)(xi) of this section, shall be representative of the various sections and interests of the State.

section.text: The President and the Speaker are cochairmen of the Committee.

subsection.text: This section applies only to a vacancy on the Committee that occurs while the General Assembly is not in session.

paragraph.text: If a vacancy occurs in one of the offices of cochairmen of the Committee, a successor shall be elected:

subparagraph.text: for the Senate cochairman, by the Senators on the Committee; and
for the House cochairman, by the Delegates on the Committee.

paragraph.text: If vacancies occur in both offices of the cochairmen of the Committee, the successors shall be elected from among the remaining members of the Committee by those members. One of the cochairmen shall be a Senator, and one shall be a Delegate.
If a vacancy occurs among the Senators on the Committee, a successor shall be appointed by the President.
If a vacancy occurs among the Delegates on the Committee, a successor shall be appointed by the Speaker.
A majority of the full authorized membership of the Committee is a quorum.
The Committee may not act unless at least 8 members concur.
The Committee shall meet as often as necessary, at the times and places that its cochairmen determine.

Any member of the General Assembly may attend a meeting of the Committee and present views on any matter that the Committee is considering. However, only a member of the Committee may vote in any decision of the Committee.
The Committee shall keep minutes of its meetings.

subsection.text: The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staff assistance to the Committee.
The Committee has the following functions:

paragraph.text: to review the work of the standing committees;
to collect information about the government and general welfare of the State;
to study the operation of and recommend changes in the Constitution, statutes, and common law of the State;
to study the rules and procedures of the Senate and the House and recommend changes that would improve and expedite the consideration of legislation by the General Assembly;
to coordinate and supervise generally the work of the General Assembly when it is not in session;
to prepare or endorse a legislative program that includes the bills, resolutions, or other recommendations of the Committee that are to be presented to the General Assembly at its next session; and
to carry out its powers and duties under the Maryland Program Evaluation Act.

subsection.text: To carry out its functions, the Committee:

paragraph.text: shall receive, from any source, suggestions for legislation or investigation;
may hold a hearing on any matter;
may appoint a special committee and delegate to that committee the authority specified in § 2–408 of this subtitle;
may refer a matter for study and report to any of its special committees or any committee of the General Assembly;
shall consider the reports of standing, statutory, and special committees;
may have any bill or resolution prepared to carry out its recommendations; and
when the General Assembly is not in session:

subparagraph.text: may accept a gift or grant of money from a person or public agency for any purpose that relates to the activities of the Legislative Policy Committee or of any other standing, statutory, or special committee; and
may spend the money for that purpose, in accordance with the State budget.

subsection.text: In carrying out any of its functions or powers, the Committee may:

paragraph.text: issue subpoenas;
compel the attendance of witnesses;
compel the production of any papers, books, accounts, documents, and testimony;
administer oaths; and
cause the depositions of witnesses, who reside in or outside of the State, to be taken in the manner provided by law for taking depositions in a civil case.

If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this section or fails to testify on any matter on which the person lawfully may be interrogated, on petition of a member of the Committee, a circuit court may pass an order directing compliance with the subpoena or compelling testimony and may enforce the order by proceedings for contempt.
Venue and procedures for a proceeding under paragraph (1) of this subsection to direct compliance with a subpoena or compel testimony are as provided in § 2–1803 of this title.

subsection.text: False swearing by a witness before the Committee is perjury.

Subject to § 2-1246 of this title, the Committee shall submit to the General Assembly periodic reports to keep the members of the General Assembly fully informed about matters that come before the Committee.

paragraph.text: The Committee shall compile the bills, joint resolutions, and other recommendations that are submitted to it by its special committees and by the committees of the General Assembly and are intended for submission to the General Assembly at its next session.
Before that session of the General Assembly, the Committee shall prepare a report that includes those bills, resolutions, and recommendations and the reports that relate to them.
The Committee shall:

subparagraph.text: subject to § 2-1246 of this title, submit this report to the General Assembly; and
send this report to each other elected State officer and to the State Law Library.

section.text: Within the amounts made available by appropriation, each officer and unit of the State government shall conduct any study that the Committee requests.
In this subtitle, “Committee” means the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review.
There is a Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review, which is a joint committee of the Senate and the House.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of 20 members.
Of the 20 Committee members:

subparagraph.text: 10 shall be Senators, appointed by the President with the approval of the Senate; and
10 shall be Delegates, appointed by the Speaker with the approval of the House.

paragraph.text: The Senators appointed by the President shall be chosen so that each political party is represented in approximately the same proportion as the party is represented in the Senate.
The Delegates appointed by the Speaker shall be chosen so that each political party is represented in approximately the same proportion as the party is represented in the House.

subsection.text: Members shall be appointed at the beginning of each regular session of the General Assembly and shall serve until the beginning of the following regular session.

section.text: The Senate Chairman and the House Chairman of the Committee shall be appointed by the President and the Speaker, respectively, from the membership of the Committee. One shall be a Senator appointed by the President, and the other shall be a Delegate appointed by the Speaker. The presiding chairmanship and cochairmanship shall be alternated annually between the Senate and the House.

subsection.text: A majority of the full authorized membership of the Committee is a quorum.
The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staff assistance to the Committee.
In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Committee may:

paragraph.text: review proposed or adopted regulations of a unit of the Executive Branch of the State government;
consider requests for emergency adoption of regulations;
inquire into an alleged failure of an officer or employee of any branch of the State government to comply with the laws of the State; and
review the operations of any unit of the Executive Branch of the State government.
At least once a year, the Committee shall submit a report to the Legislative Policy Committee and, subject to § 2-1246 of this title, to the General Assembly.
The report shall:

subparagraph.text: describe the studies and other work of the Committee; and
include any recommendations of the Committee on:

sub-subparagraph.text: more effective operation of the branches of the State government, in accordance with the laws of the State; and
legislative action that is needed to change or reverse a regulation of a unit of the Executive Branch of the State government.

subsection.text: The failure of the Committee to comment on or to object to a proposed or adopted regulation is not an indication that:

paragraph.text: the Committee approves the regulation;
the statute under which the regulation is adopted authorizes the adoption; or
the regulation conforms to the legislative intent of the statute.

subsection.text: In carrying out any of its functions or powers, the Committee may:

paragraph.text: issue subpoenas;
compel the attendance of witnesses;
compel the production of any papers, books, accounts, documents, and testimony;
administer oaths; and
cause the depositions of witnesses, who reside in or outside of the State, to be taken in the manner provided by law for taking depositions in a civil case.

If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this section or fails to testify on any matter on which the person lawfully may be interrogated, on petition of a member of the Committee, a circuit court may pass an order directing compliance with the subpoena or compelling testimony and may enforce the order by proceedings for contempt.
Venue and procedures for a proceeding under paragraph (1) of this subsection to direct compliance with a subpoena or compel testimony are as provided in § 2–1803 of this title.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Committee” means the Joint Audit Committee.
There is a Joint Audit Committee, which is a joint committee of the Senate and the House.

subsection.text: The Committee consists of 10 members of the Senate, appointed by the President, and 10 members of the House, appointed by the Speaker.

paragraph.text: Members of the Committee shall be appointed on the basis of demonstrated ability and interest in the functions of the Committee.
In making appointments from time to time, the President and the Speaker shall provide for representation from the major areas of the State.

Members shall be appointed after the 2 houses and their committees organize during each regular session of the General Assembly and shall serve until the houses and committees organize during the following regular session.

subparagraph.text: If a vacancy occurs among the Senators on the Committee, a successor promptly shall be appointed by the President.
If a vacancy occurs among the Delegates on the Committee, a successor promptly shall be appointed by the Speaker.

section.text: The President and the Speaker jointly shall appoint the chairman and the vice chairman of the Committee.
In addition to any powers and duties set forth elsewhere, the Committee shall:

paragraph.text: review audit reports issued by the Legislative Auditor and submit findings and recommendations to the General Assembly with respect to issues in audit reports; and

review the audit process and procedures and provide comment and recommendations to the President and the Speaker, the Executive Director of the Department of Legislative Services, and the Legislative Auditor.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Committee” means the Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics.
There is a Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics, which is a joint committee of the Senate and the House.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of the following 12 regular members:

subparagraph.text: six Senators appointed by the President; and
six Delegates appointed by the Speaker.

The Senators appointed by the President shall be chosen so that each political party is represented in approximately the same proportion as the party is represented in the Senate. Minority party members shall be appointed upon the recommendation of the minority leader of the Senate.

The Delegates appointed by the Speaker shall be chosen so that each political party is represented in approximately the same proportion as the party is represented in the House. Minority party members shall be appointed upon the recommendation of the minority leader of the House.

paragraph.text: A member appointed by the President serves at the pleasure of the President.
A member appointed by the Speaker serves at the pleasure of the Speaker.

subsection.text: The President and the Speaker shall be nonvoting ex officio members of the Committee.
The President and the Speaker:

paragraph.text: jointly shall appoint a chairman and a vice chairman of the Committee; or
each shall appoint a cochairman of the Committee.

subsection.text: Appointees serve at the pleasure of the appointing authority.

section.text: The Committee shall meet at the times and places that it determines.

subsection.text: The Committee shall:

paragraph.text: perform all duties assigned to it by law or by legislative rules;
from time to time, recommend to the presiding officers any changes in or amendments to the rules of legislative ethics;
on request of a member of the General Assembly, issue an advisory opinion regarding the legislative ethics of an action taken or contemplated to be taken by the member;
on its own motion, issue advisory opinions as it deems necessary;
at the request of the President or the Speaker, make recommendations concerning matters referred to the Committee;
as it deems necessary, issue guidelines and establish procedures for the implementation of the rules of legislative ethics; and
maintain public records as the rules require.

The Committee shall maintain the statements filed by members of the General Assembly under Title 15, Subtitle 5 of this article and, during normal office hours, make the statements available to the public for examination and copying.
The Committee shall maintain a record of:

subparagraph.text: the name and home address of each individual who examines or copies a statement filed with the Committee by a member of the General Assembly; and
the name of the member whose statement was examined or copied.

paragraph.text: On the request of the member whose statement was examined or copied, the Committee shall forward to the member a copy of the record maintained by the Committee under paragraph (2)(i) of this subsection.
The Committee may propose the adoption, amendment, or repeal of rules of legislative ethics.

Changes to the rules shall be presented in the form of a joint resolution and shall become effective after adoption of the joint resolution by a constitutional majority of each house voting separately.
Before presenting a change to the rules, the Committee shall conduct a public hearing.

subsection.text: The rules may supplement but may not be inconsistent with the provisions of the Maryland Public Ethics Law that relate to members of the General Assembly.
The rules are effective whether or not the General Assembly is in session and shall be binding on each member of the General Assembly.

section.text: The President and the Speaker may refer to the Committee any matter that they consider appropriate.

subsection.text: The Executive Director of the Department of Legislative Services, subject to the approval of the President and Speaker, shall appoint an attorney to serve as Counsel to the Committee.
The Counsel:

paragraph.text: shall devote full time to the duties of the Committee, but may not participate in any investigatory or prosecutorial function;
may provide information to any person regarding laws, rules, and other standards of ethical conduct applicable to members of the General Assembly;
shall carry out any duties prescribed under Title 15, Subtitle 5 of this article;
shall meet individually with each member of the General Assembly each year to:

subparagraph.text: advise the member regarding the requirements of any applicable ethics law, rule, or standard of conduct; and
assist the member in preparing statements and reports required to be filed with the Committee under Title 15, Subtitle 5, Part II of this article; and

paragraph.text: shall conduct seminars, workshops, and briefings for the benefit of members of the General Assembly, as directed by the Committee, the President, or the Speaker.

subsection.text: The assistance of the Counsel to members of the General Assembly:

paragraph.text: is subject to the attorney client privilege, as set forth in § 9-108 of the Courts Article;
is subject to confidentiality under § 15-516 of this article; and
is intended as a service to the members and may not be deemed to diminish a member’s personal responsibility for adherence to applicable laws, rules, and standards of ethical conduct.

subsection.text: The Committee shall have other staff assistance as requested by the Committee and as provided in the budget of the General Assembly.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Committee” means the Joint Committee on the Management of Public Funds.
There is a Joint Committee on the Management of Public Funds, which is a joint committee of the Senate and the House.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of 8 members.
Of the 8 members:

subparagraph.text: 4 shall be Senators, appointed by the President; and
4 shall be Delegates, appointed by the Speaker.

paragraph.text: A member appointed by the President serves at the pleasure of the President.
A member appointed by the Speaker serves at the pleasure of the Speaker.

section.text: The President and the Speaker jointly shall appoint the chairman and the vice chairman of the Committee.

subsection.text: A majority of the full authorized membership of the Committee is a quorum.
The Committee shall meet:

paragraph.text: at the times and places that it determines; and
at the call of its chairman or, if the chairman is absent, at the call of its vice chairman.

subsection.text: The Committee has the function to review the investment and management policies and procedures:

paragraph.text: of the Treasurer with respect to State funds in the State Treasury;
of any officer or unit with respect to State funds that are not in the State Treasury and are not under the jurisdiction of a retirement system; and
of local governments with respect to public funds.

subsection.text: Subject to § 2-1246 of this title, on or before the 1st day of each regular session, the Committee shall submit an annual report to the General Assembly on any recommendations as to the office of Treasurer.
The function and authority of the Treasurer as a member of the Board of Public Works are not subject to the review of the Committee.
In carrying out any of its functions or powers, the Committee may:

paragraph.text: issue subpoenas;
compel the attendance of witnesses;
compel the production of any papers, books, accounts, documents, and testimony;
administer oaths; and
cause the depositions of witnesses, who reside in or outside of the State, to be taken in the manner provided by law for taking depositions in a civil case.

If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this section or fails to testify on any matter on which the person lawfully may be interrogated, on petition of a member of the Committee, a circuit court may pass an order directing compliance with the subpoena or compelling testimony and may enforce the order by proceedings for contempt.
Venue and procedures for a proceeding under paragraph (1) of this subsection to direct compliance with a subpoena or compel testimony are as provided in § 2–1803 of this title.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Committee” means the Joint Committee on Federal Relations.
There is a Joint Committee on Federal Relations, which is a joint committee of the Senate and the House.

subsection.text: The Committee consists of 16 members.
Of the 16 Committee members:

paragraph.text: 8 shall be Senators, appointed by the President; and
8 shall be Delegates, appointed by the Speaker.

subsection.text: The President and the Speaker jointly shall appoint a chairman and a vice chairman of the Committee.

paragraph.text: The President shall appoint a chairman of the Senate members of the Committee.
The Speaker shall appoint a chairman of the House members of the Committee.

section.text: The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staff assistance to the Committee.

subsection.text: The Committee shall:

paragraph.text: as to the relations between the State and the federal government:

subparagraph.text: monitor and evaluate the relations;
monitor proposals to change the relations;
evaluate the impact of the proposals on the State and its citizens and on local governments; and
keep officials of the Executive and Legislative branches of the State government and others informed about the relations and the potential impact of proposals to change the relations;

paragraph.text: serve as a forum for consideration of certain State-local issues;
try to advance the cooperation between the State and other units of government by proposing or facilitating any actions that the Committee considers advisable, including:

subparagraph.text: the adoption of compacts;
the enactment of uniform statutes;
the enactment of reciprocal statutes;
the adoption of uniform administrative rules or regulations;
the adoption of reciprocal administrative rules or regulations;
the informal cooperation between government offices;
the personal cooperation between officials and employees of governments; and
the exchange of information; and

paragraph.text: do any other thing that the Legislative Policy Committee assigns.

subsection.text: Subject to § 2-1246 of this title, the Committee shall submit to the General Assembly:

paragraph.text: an annual report, within 15 days after the General Assembly convenes for a regular session; and
any other report that the Committee considers appropriate.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Committee” means the Spending Affordability Committee.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that State expenditures for operating and capital programs must be controlled so that the level of State spending is consistent with the economic growth of the State.

paragraph.text: The control of spending shall be exercised through the budgetary process as well as through legislative oversight and program review.

The budget focuses on spending for the next fiscal year and provides careful scrutiny of new programs or expansion of existing programs and services and weighs the incremental cost of the State budget in light of the priority needs of the citizens.

Legislative oversight seeks to eliminate inefficiencies in governmental activities and to evaluate programs in order to eliminate those no longer required and to avoid overlap and duplication of services and activities.

The Legislative Policy Committee shall be responsible for coordinating the spending affordability program of the General Assembly by appointment of a Spending Affordability Committee and by selection of program evaluation projects and direction of oversight activities.
The goal of the spending affordability program is to limit the rate of growth of State spending to a level that does not exceed the rate of growth of the State’s economy.

subsection.text: On or before June 1 of each year, the Legislative Policy Committee shall create a Spending Affordability Committee comprised of an equal number of Senators and Delegates. The Committee membership includes:

paragraph.text: the President and the Speaker;
the chairmen of the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee and the House Appropriations Committee;
the majority and minority leaders of the Senate and the House or their designees; and
other members of the Senate and the House who may be appointed by the President and the Speaker.

subsection.text: The chairman of the Committee shall be designated jointly by the President and the Speaker.
The President and the Speaker may appoint an advisory committee of citizens to assist the Committee in its deliberations.
The Committee shall review in detail the status and projections of the revenues and expenditures of the State and the status and projections of the economy of the State.
In evaluating future State expenditures, the Committee shall consider economic indicators such as personal income, gross State product, or other data.

On or before December 1 of each year, the Committee shall submit, subject to § 2-1246 of this title, to the Legislative Policy Committee and the Governor a report with recommendations on fiscal goals for the State budget to be considered at the next regular session of the General Assembly, including:

paragraph.text: a recommended level of State spending;
a recommended level of new debt authorization;
a recommended level of State personnel;
a recommended use of any anticipated surplus; and
other findings or recommendations that the Committee considers appropriate.

subsection.text: If the report recommends expenditures in excess of the annual increase in personal income, gross State product, or other data that the Committee used to measure the growth of the State’s economy, the Committee shall provide the Senate and the House with an analysis as to the extent the recommendation exceeds those economic indicators.

section.text: The Senate and the House budget committees:

paragraph.text: in considering a proposed State budget, shall consider the recommendations of the Spending Affordability Committee; and
shall:

subparagraph.text: report a budget bill that conforms to those recommendations; or

if the level of the budget bill in the report is above those recommendations, provide, with the report, an analysis stating the extent to which the budget bill exceeds the recommendations and explaining the budget committee’s rationale for exceeding the recommendations.

subsection.text: The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staff services for the Committee.
Units in the Executive Branch of the State government shall cooperate with the Committee and provide information to the Committee and its staff as requested.

section.text: On or before June 1 of each year, the Department of Legislative Services shall report, subject to § 2-1246 of this title, to the Legislative Policy Committee the extent to which the State budget as enacted by the General Assembly conformed to the recommendations of the Spending Affordability Committee.

On or before June 1 of each year, the Legislative Policy Committee shall select units or programs that the Legislative Policy Committee believes should be subject to legislative review and assign the selected units and programs to an appropriate committee for review and recommendations during that legislative interim.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Internal Revenue Code” means Title 26 of the United States Code.
“Private activity bond” has the meaning stated in § 141 of the Internal Revenue Code.
“State issuer” means the State of Maryland or any agency of the State of Maryland with authority to issue private activity bonds.

subsection.text: On or before January 15 of each year, any State issuer of private activity bonds shall report, subject to § 2–1246 of this title, to the Committee:

paragraph.text: the actual level of private activity bonds issued in the prior year; and
the projected level of private activity bonds to be issued in the current year.

subsection.text: There is a Joint Committee on the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of 10 members.
Of the 10 members:

subparagraph.text: 5 shall be members of the Senate appointed by the President of the Senate; and
5 shall be members of the House of Delegates appointed by the Speaker of the House.

subsection.text: The members of the Committee serve at the pleasure of the presiding officer who appointed them.
The President and the Speaker shall jointly appoint a Senator and a Delegate each to serve as cochairman.
The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staff assistance to the Committee.

The Critical Area Commission for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays shall meet with the Committee periodically as the Committee requests to review development and implementation of the criteria for program development.

The Committee may study and make recommendations to the Legislative Policy Committee on any other area of the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Protection Program the Committee considers appropriate.

The Committee shall meet with the Critical Area Commission for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays, representatives of counties and municipalities having land within the critical areas, and any other interested parties to study and determine:

paragraph.text: whether adequate flexibility exists under the current criteria to meet the special characteristics and needs of the individual counties and municipalities having land within the critical areas;

whether the current timetable for review of approved local critical area protection programs is adequate to meet the special characteristics and needs of the individual counties and municipalities having land within the critical areas; and

whether the criteria need to be strengthened in any area so as to make the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area Protection Program more effective in the protection of the water quality and habitat of the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries.

subsection.text: The Committee shall study and determine the appropriate future role of the Critical Area Commission for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays, including:

paragraph.text: whether the Critical Area Commission for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays should remain an autonomous organization or be incorporated into an existing executive agency;
how long the current oversight role of the Critical Area Commission for the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays should continue; and
whether the current appeal process is the most effective appeal process to meet the goals of the Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Critical Area protection law.
The Committee shall report its preliminary findings and recommendations to the Legislative Policy Committee on or before January 1, 1989.
The Committee shall report its final findings and recommendations to the Legislative Policy Committee on or before January 1, 1990.

subsection.text: There is a Joint Committee on Health Care Delivery and Financing.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of 14 members.
Of the 14 members:

subparagraph.text: 7 shall be members of the Senate appointed by the President of the Senate; and
7 shall be members of the House of Delegates appointed by the Speaker of the House.

subsection.text: The members of the Committee serve at the pleasure of the presiding officer who appointed them.
The President and the Speaker shall jointly appoint a Senator and a Delegate each to serve as cochairman.
The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staff assistance to the Committee.
The Committee shall provide oversight and study, as necessary, issues relating to health care delivery or financing, including but not limited to:

paragraph.text: access to health care;
retention of the Medicare waiver;
the Medicaid program and population;
cost containment mechanisms;
the provision of health insurance coverage;
health manpower shortages; and
any other issue relating to the health care delivery and financing system in Maryland.

subsection.text: The Committee shall submit an annual report to the General Assembly on or before January 1 of each year.
There is a Joint Committee on Workers’ Compensation Benefit and Insurance Oversight.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of 16 members.
Of the 16 members:

sub-subparagraph.text: 2 shall be members of the Senate appointed by the President of the Senate; and
2 shall be Delegates appointed by the Speaker of the House of Delegates; and

subparagraph.text: 12 shall be appointed jointly by the President and the Speaker as follows:

sub-subparagraph.text: 1 representative of the business community;
1 representative of the Maryland labor organizations;
1 representative of the Maryland building and construction labor organizations;
1 representative of a self–insured local government entity;
2 members of the public;
1 member of the insurance industry;
1 member of the Medical and Chirurgical Faculty of Maryland;
1 member of a workers’ compensation rating organization;
2 members of the Bar of the Court of Appeals of Maryland, 1 of whom represents plaintiffs in workers’ compensation cases and 1 of whom represents defendants in workers’ compensation cases; and
1 member who is certified by the Workers’ Compensation Commission as a Maryland rehabilitation service provider.

subsection.text: The members of the Committee serve at the pleasure of the presiding officer who appointed them.
The President and the Speaker shall jointly appoint a Senator and a Delegate each to serve as cochair.

paragraph.text: The Committee shall examine and evaluate:

subparagraph.text: the condition of the workers’ compensation benefit and insurance structure in the State; and
the effect of Chapters 590 and 591 of the Laws of Maryland of 1987 on that structure.

paragraph.text: This examination shall include the regulations adopted by the Workers’ Compensation Commission that are to be used by physicians to measure impairment when preparing medical evaluations of claimants.

subsection.text: The Insurance Commissioner and the Workers’ Compensation Commission shall:

paragraph.text: cooperate fully with the Committee;

keep the Committee fully informed as to the condition of workers’ compensation benefits and workers’ compensation insurance in the State and the effect of Chapters 590 and 591 of the Laws of Maryland of 1987 on those benefits and that insurance; and
submit an annual report, subject to § 2–1246 of this title, to the Committee on or before October 1 of each year that incorporates the information described in item (2) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The Committee shall report to the Governor and the Legislative Policy Committee on December 31 of each year.
There is a Joint Committee on Welfare Reform.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of 10 members.
Of the 10 members:

subparagraph.text: five shall be members of the Senate appointed by the President of the Senate; and
five shall be members of the House of Delegates appointed by the Speaker of the House.

subsection.text: The members of the Committee serve at the pleasure of the presiding officer who appointed them.
The President and the Speaker shall jointly appoint a Senator and a Delegate each to serve as cochairman.
The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staff assistance to the Committee.
The Committee shall provide oversight of and study, as necessary, issues relating to the provision of FIP and related benefits and services, including:

paragraph.text: the provision of food stamps and housing benefits;
the provision of medical benefits to the FIP-eligible population;
current welfare demonstration projects; and
development and implementation of additional welfare demonstration projects.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Human Resources, in conjunction with the Secretary of Housing and Community Development and the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene, shall:

paragraph.text: cooperate fully with the Committee;
keep the Committee fully informed as to the delivery in the State of FIP and related services; and
submit an annual report, subject to § 2-1246 of this title, to the Committee on or before October 1 of each year that incorporates the information described in subsection (f) of this section.

subsection.text: The report required under subsection (g)(3) of this section shall include:

paragraph.text: evaluations of any demonstration projects currently in operation; and
descriptions of any plans of the Secretary of Human Resources to establish additional demonstration projects.

subsection.text: The Committee shall submit an annual report to the General Assembly on or before January 1 of each year.
In this section, “Committee” means the Joint Committee on Access to Mental Health Services.
There is a Joint Committee on Access to Mental Health Services.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of ten members.
Of the ten members:

subparagraph.text: five shall be Senators, appointed by the President; and
five shall be Delegates, appointed by the Speaker.

paragraph.text: Of the five Senators:

subparagraph.text: two shall be members of the Finance Committee;
one shall be a member of the Budget and Taxation Committee;
one shall be a member of the Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs Committee; and
one shall be a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee.

paragraph.text: Of the five Delegates:

subparagraph.text: two shall be members of the Health and Government Operations Committee;
one shall be a member of the Appropriations Committee;
one shall be a member of the Economic Matters Committee; and
one shall be a member of the Judiciary Committee.

subsection.text: The members of the Committee serve at the pleasure of the presiding officer who appointed them.

paragraph.text: From among the membership of the Committee, the President shall appoint a Senator to serve as the Senate Chair of the Committee, and the Speaker shall appoint a Delegate to serve as the House Chair of the Committee.
The Senate Chair and the House Chair shall alternate annually as presiding chairs and cochairs of the Committee.

subsection.text: The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staff assistance to the Committee.
The Committee shall monitor access to:

paragraph.text: public mental health services for eligible individuals; and
medically necessary mental health services for individuals covered by private insurance.

subsection.text: The Committee shall submit an annual report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of this title, to the General Assembly, regarding:

paragraph.text: systemic barriers to access to mental health services; and
recommendations to mitigate these barriers.

subsection.text: In this section, “conditions of well–being” means the desired results identified by the Maryland Partnership for Children, Youth, and Families based upon identified needs and used to improve quality.
There is a Joint Committee on Children, Youth, and Families.
The Committee consists of the following 20 members:

paragraph.text: from the Senate:

subparagraph.text: the majority leader;
the minority leader; and
two members from each of the four standing committees; and

paragraph.text: from the House:

subparagraph.text: the majority leader;
the minority leader; and
eight other Delegates appointed by the Speaker from among the members of the House committees that deal with issues affecting children, youth, and families.

paragraph.text: Members of the Committee shall be appointed on the basis of demonstrated ability and interest concerning issues affecting children, youth, and families.
In making appointments, the President and the Speaker shall provide for representation from:

subparagraph.text: the committees that deal with issues affecting children, youth, and families; and
the major areas of the State.
A member appointed by the President serves at the pleasure of the President.
A member appointed by the Speaker serves at the pleasure of the Speaker.
If a vacancy occurs among the Senators on the Committee, a successor promptly shall be appointed by the President.
If a vacancy occurs among the Delegates on the Committee, a successor promptly shall be appointed by the Speaker.

paragraph.text: From among the membership of the Committee, the President shall appoint a Senator to serve as the Senate chairman of the Committee and the Speaker shall appoint a Delegate to serve as the House chairman of the Committee.
The Senate chairman and the House chairman shall alternate annually as presiding chairman and cochairman of the Committee.

subsection.text: A majority of the full authorized membership of the Committee is a quorum.
The Department of Legislative Services, Office of Policy Analysis, shall provide staff assistance to the Committee.
The Committee shall hold:

paragraph.text: an organizational meeting promptly after the appointment of its members; and
any other meetings that the Committee considers necessary to carry out its duties efficiently.

subsection.text: The Committee may:

paragraph.text: hold a hearing on any matter relating to the functions of the Committee; and
consider a vote on a bill or resolution referred to it by the President or the Speaker.

subsection.text: In addition to any powers and duties set forth elsewhere, in an endeavor to achieve conditions of well–being for Maryland children, youth, and families, the Committee shall:

paragraph.text: investigate the problems that jeopardize the well–being of Maryland children, youth, and families;

identify State policies and actions that, in conjunction with public and private partners and in support of families and communities, can work to achieve conditions of well–being for Maryland children, youth, and families;
review and make recommendations to align State statutes, regulations, programs, services, and budgetary priorities with the State policies and actions described in paragraph (2) of this subsection;
search for any interdepartmental gaps, inconsistencies, and inefficiencies in the implementation or attainment of the State policies and actions described in paragraph (2) of this subsection;
identify any new laws, regulations, programs, services, and budgetary priorities that are needed to ensure and promote desired conditions of well–being for Maryland children, youth, and families;
serve as an informational resource for the Senate and the House on legislative policy matters concerning children, youth, and families; and
perform other activities, including improving public awareness of the special needs of Maryland children, youth, and families.
Subject to § 2–1246 of this title, the Committee shall submit an annual report to the General Assembly on or before December 1 of each year.
The report shall include:

subparagraph.text: a description of the work of the Committee; and
any recommendations of the Committee.

subsection.text: There is a Joint Committee on the Port of Baltimore.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of 15 members.
Of the 15 members:

sub-subparagraph.text: 2 shall be members of the Senate of Maryland appointed by the President of the Senate;
2 shall be members of the House of Delegates appointed by the Speaker of the House;

subparagraph.text: 10 shall be appointed jointly by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House as follows:

sub-subparagraph.text: 1 representative of the Maryland Port Administration;
2 representatives of Maryland labor organizations;
1 representative of the maritime/steamship industry;
1 pilot licensed by the State Board of Pilots;
1 docking master licensed by the State Board of Docking Masters;
1 representative of a towing boat company serving the Port of Baltimore; and
3 members of the public; and

subparagraph.text: 1 shall be a representative of the United States Coast Guard, to be appointed by the Captain of the Port, United States Coast Guard, Baltimore.

subsection.text: The members of the Committee serve at the pleasure of the presiding officer who appointed them.
The President and the Speaker shall jointly appoint a Senator and a Delegate each to serve as cochairman.

paragraph.text: The Committee shall examine and evaluate issues affecting the competitive position of the Port of Baltimore within the international port industry.
This examination shall include the regulations adopted by the State Board of Pilots, the State Board of Docking Masters, and the Maryland Port Commission.

subsection.text: The Secretary of the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, the Secretary of the Department of Transportation, and the Executive Director of the Maryland Port Administration shall:

paragraph.text: cooperate fully with the Committee; and
keep the Committee fully informed as to issues affecting the Port of Baltimore.

subsection.text: The Committee shall report to the Governor and the Legislative Policy Committee on or before December 31 of each year.
There is a Joint Committee on Fair Practices and State Personnel Oversight.

paragraph.text: The Joint Committee consists of eight members.
Of the eight members:

subparagraph.text: four shall be members of the Senate, appointed by the President of the Senate; and
four shall be members of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House.

subsection.text: The members of the Joint Committee serve at the pleasure of the presiding officer who appointed them.
The President and the Speaker jointly shall appoint a Senator and a Delegate to serve as cochairs.
The Joint Committee shall have oversight over:

paragraph.text: employment policies and personnel systems in the Executive Branch of State government, including:

subparagraph.text: the State Personnel Management System;
the Maryland Department of Transportation’s Human Resources Management System; and
the personnel systems of State institutions of higher education;

paragraph.text: matters in State government of equal employment opportunity policies and practices; and
procurement practices made under executive order.

subsection.text: The purposes of the Joint Committee are to:

paragraph.text: review reports;
evaluate the effectiveness of programs, policies, and practices; and
identify areas of concern and, as appropriate, recommend corrective measures to the Governor and the General Assembly.

subsection.text: There is a Joint Committee on Unemployment Insurance Oversight.
The Committee consists of the following 15 members:

paragraph.text: three members of the Senate, appointed by the President of the Senate;
three members of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House of Delegates;
the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Business and Economic Development, or the Secretary’s designee;
a representative of the Maryland Retailers Association, designated by the Maryland Retailers Association;
a representative of the Maryland Chamber of Commerce, designated by the Maryland Chamber of Commerce;
a representative of the National Federation of Independent Business, designated by the National Federation of Independent Business;
a representative of the Job Opportunities Task Force, designated by the Job Opportunities Task Force;
two representatives of union labor, designated by the Maryland State and District of Columbia AFL–CIO; and
a representative of the academic profession who is knowledgeable in unemployment insurance law, designated jointly by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Delegates.

subsection.text: The members of the Committee serve at the pleasure of the presiding officer who appointed them.
The President and the Speaker shall appoint a Senator and a Delegate, respectively, each to serve as cochair.

paragraph.text: The Committee shall examine the condition of the unemployment insurance system in the State as a result of the implementation of Chapter 169 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 2005.

The Committee may examine the need for additional alterations to the unemployment insurance system, including the charging and taxation provisions and the eligibility and benefit provisions, in consideration of the fairness of the system and in order to maintain the Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund at a level sufficient to ensure that benefits will be paid from the Fund.
The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staffing for the Committee.
The Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation shall report to the Committee on the condition of unemployment insurance in the State.

subsection.text: A member of the Committee may not receive compensation for serving on the Committee, but is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
The Committee shall report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and, subject to § 2–1246 of this title, the General Assembly on December 31 of each year.
There is a Joint Committee on Base Realignment and Closure.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of 16 members.
Of the 16 members:

subparagraph.text: eight shall be members of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate; and
eight shall be members of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House.

subsection.text: From among the membership of the Committee, the President of the Senate shall appoint a Senator to serve as the Senate Chair of the Committee, and the Speaker of the House shall appoint a Delegate to serve as the House Chair of the Committee.
The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staff assistance to the Committee.
The Committee shall provide continuing legislative oversight of the State’s response to changes and opportunities occurring as a result of the Base Realignment and Closure process.

The Committee shall oversee and participate, in cooperation with State and local units, in the development of systems and processes that, with the intent of accelerating planning and development so that the State is prepared to receive the influx of jobs and personnel associated with the Base Realignment and Closure process, fast track the approval of:

paragraph.text: transportation infrastructure;
water and sewer infrastructure;
State and local planning processes;
affordable housing options;
education facilities, including public school and community college construction; and
health care facilities and infrastructure.

subsection.text: There is a Joint Information Technology and Biotechnology Committee.
The Committee consists of the following 12 members:

paragraph.text: six members of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate; and
six members of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House.

subsection.text: The members of the Committee serve at the pleasure of the presiding officer who appointed them.
The President and the Speaker shall appoint jointly a Senator and a Delegate to serve as cochairs who shall alternate in serving as the presiding chair of the Committee each year.

paragraph.text: The Committee shall work to broaden the support, knowledge, and awareness of information technology and biotechnology to benefit the people of Maryland.
The Committee may examine and evaluate additional information technology– or biotechnology–related issues as designated by the cochairs of the Committee.

subsection.text: The Committee shall report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of this title, the Legislative Policy Committee, the Senate Finance Committee, and the House Economic Matters Committee on or before December 1 of each year.
There is a Joint Committee on Transparency and Open Government.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of 12 members.
Of the 12 members:

subparagraph.text: 6 shall be members of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate; and
6 shall be members of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House.

subsection.text: From among the membership of the Committee, the President of the Senate shall appoint a Senator to serve as the Senate Chair of the Committee, and the Speaker of the House shall appoint a Delegate to serve as the House Chair of the Committee.
The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staff assistance to the Committee.
The purposes of the Committee are to:

paragraph.text: provide continuing legislative oversight regarding transparency and open government; and
make recommendations regarding initiatives that will increase citizen access to government resources, publications, and actions.

subsection.text: The Committee shall hold:

paragraph.text: an organizational meeting promptly after the appointment of its members; and
any other meetings that the Committee considers necessary to carry out its duties efficiently.

subsection.text: The Committee may:

paragraph.text: hold a hearing on any matter relating to the functions of the Committee; and
consider a vote on a bill or resolution referred to it by the President or the Speaker.

subsection.text: The Committee shall:

paragraph.text: identify areas in which the State can improve its technology and Web sites to increase transparency and citizen engagement;
make recommendations regarding State transparency goals and policies;
consult with State entities that foster transparency, including the Governor’s StateStat office:

subparagraph.text: when developing State transparency goals and policies; and
to identify methods of coordinating transparency policies across State government;

paragraph.text: review State laws, programs, services, and policies and make recommendations to align them with State transparency policies and goals;
determine whether there are interdepartmental gaps, inconsistencies, and inefficiencies in the implementation or attainment of State transparency policies and goals;
identify laws, programs, services, or budgetary priorities that need to be adopted to ensure and promote transparency and open government in the State;
survey transparency initiatives in other states that have proven effective at saving public funds and resources and assess whether those policies should be modified and adopted for use by the State;
serve as an informational resource and liaison for advocates and citizens with ideas and suggestions for tools and practical implementation of initiatives that will increase transparency;
review and make recommendations regarding actions suggested by advocates and citizens to increase citizen access to government resources, publications, and actions;
recommend methods of increasing public awareness of government resources, publications, and Web sites; and
perform any other activity that is required to fulfill the purposes of the Committee.
Subject to § 2–1246 of this title, the Committee shall submit a report to the General Assembly on or before December 1 each year.
The report shall include:

subparagraph.text: a description of the work of the Committee; and
any recommendations of the Committee.

subsection.text: When the General Assembly is not in session, any decision that relates to or affects a member of a committee of the General Assembly shall be made:

paragraph.text: as to a Senate member, by the President; and
as to a House member, by the Speaker.

subsection.text: The responsibilities of the President and the Speaker under this section include:

paragraph.text: appointing members of committees;
appointing officers of committees; and
setting the dates, times, and places for committee meetings.

section.text: Each standing committee continues when the General Assembly is not in session.

subsection.text: While the General Assembly is not in session, each standing committee may:

paragraph.text: study and prepare recommendations and reports on any matter that is within the usual and customary jurisdiction of the standing committee; and
otherwise exercise the usual and customary powers that the standing committee has when the General Assembly is in session.

subsection.text: If time permits, each standing committee shall send to the Legislative Policy Committee a copy of each proposed bill and joint resolution that the standing committee intends to introduce in the General Assembly.
With the prior approval of the Legislative Policy Committee, a standing committee, in carrying out any of its functions or powers, may:

paragraph.text: issue subpoenas;
compel the attendance of witnesses;
compel the production of any papers, books, accounts, documents, and testimony;
administer oaths; and
cause the depositions of witnesses, who reside in or outside of the State, to be taken in the manner provided by law for taking depositions in a civil case.

If a person fails to comply with a subpoena issued under this section or fails to testify on any matter on which the person lawfully may be interrogated, on petition of a member of the standing committee, a circuit court may pass an order directing compliance with the subpoena or compelling testimony and may enforce the order by proceedings for contempt.
Venue and procedures for a proceeding under paragraph (1) of this subsection to direct compliance with a subpoena or compel testimony are as provided in § 2–1803 of this title.

subsection.text: False swearing by a witness before a standing committee is perjury.

section.text: Within the amounts made available by appropriation, each officer and unit of the State government shall conduct any study that a standing committee requests.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of Legislative Services.
“Executive Director” means the Executive Director of the Department.

section.text: There is a Department of Legislative Services in the Legislative Branch of the State government.

subsection.text: The head of the Department is the Executive Director, who shall be appointed jointly by the President and the Speaker.
The Executive Director:

paragraph.text: serves without a fixed term and may be removed by the Legislative Policy Committee on the recommendation of the President and the Speaker;
is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget;
shall devote full time to the duties of the Office; and
shall serve in a nonpartisan capacity and ensure that the activities of the Department are conducted in a nonpartisan manner.

subsection.text: Subject to the policies and directives of the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House and the Legislative Policy Committee, the Executive Director has general administrative control of the operation of the Department and its units.

section.text: The Executive Director, under the direction of the President and the Speaker, shall:

paragraph.text: oversee the activities of the Department to ensure that its functions are performed correctly, efficiently, and in a timely and nonpartisan manner;
coordinate the activities of the components of the Department to maximize cooperation among the Department’s employees and achieve the greatest efficiency in the use of personnel and other resources;
prepare the annual budget for the Department after consultation with the office directors;
conduct an annual evaluation of the performance of each office director and the Legislative Auditor;
communicate the opinions, needs, and concerns of the Department’s employees to the President and the Speaker; and
perform any other function required by the President and the Speaker.

subsection.text: The Department shall employ a staff and engage other staff and consultant services in accordance with the State budget.
Positions in the Department are subject to the personnel guidelines established under subsection (c) of this section.
The Legislative Policy Committee shall adopt guidelines that are not inconsistent with law and that, for employees of the Department, govern:

paragraph.text: hiring;
probationary periods;
tenure;
promotion;
overtime compensation;
discrimination;
compensatory work for absences due to religious beliefs;
holidays;
part-time employment;
grievance procedures;
removal; and
political activity.

subsection.text: The provisions of § 2-304 of the State Personnel and Pensions Article do not apply to an employee of the Department.

section.text: The following units are in the Department:

paragraph.text: the Office of the Executive Director;
the Office of Legislative Audits;
the Office of Legislative Information Systems;
the Office of Policy Analysis; and
any other offices as may be designated by the President and the Speaker.

section.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Department shall provide:

paragraph.text: budget and fiscal review, analysis, research, studies, and reports;
legislative drafting and statutory revision services;
legal research, review, analysis, studies, and reports;
general research and policy analysis;
fiscal/compliance, financial statement, and performance audits of units of the State government;
legislative research, legislative document and material collection and preservation, and other library services;
public information services about legislative activities;
document preparation and publication services;
legislative information systems maintenance, development, and support; and

administrative support services for the Department and, where appropriate, for the General Assembly relating to finance, personnel, distribution, telecommunications, printing and copying, supplies, housekeeping, and maintenance.

subsection.text: The staff and facilities of the Department shall be available to prepare fiscal, legal, and policy reports for and otherwise help:

paragraph.text: any standing committee;
any statutory committee;
any special committee of the Legislative Policy Committee; and
with the consent of the President and the Speaker, any joint legislative and executive body that the Governor appoints.

subsection.text: The Executive Director shall assign, to the staff of the Department or to a special research or consulting agency, the preparation of any fiscal, legal, or policy report that the Legislative Policy Committee or a standing committee requests.

section.text: As used in this Part III, “Office” means the Office of the Executive Director.

subsection.text: There is an Office of the Executive Director in the Department.
The head of the Office is the Executive Director.
The Office shall have the staff determined by the Executive Director and as provided in the State budget.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the staff of the Office is subject to the guidelines as provided in § 2-1205 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Office shall receive and analyze requests from members of the General Assembly for reimbursement and from other persons for payment of legislative expenses, including:

subparagraph.text: office rent;
secretarial and other services;
telephone and other communication expenses;
equipment;
supplies; and
travel.

paragraph.text: The Office shall provide the reimbursement or make payments as provided in the State budget and account for the reimbursements and payments.
The Office shall make payments and reimbursements consistent with the policies of the President and the Speaker, the Management Subcommittee, and the Legislative Policy Committee.

The President and the Speaker may authorize the Office to create accounts for revenues received from payment of fees or charges and to utilize the funds to provide services to individuals, organizations, or other units of State or local governments.
Funds in the accounts may only be expended in accordance with the budget or by budget amendment.
On directive by the President and the Speaker, unexpended revenues in the accounts may revert to the State or may be retained for expenditure in a subsequent budget.
The Comptroller’s Office shall be notified of accounts created in accordance with this section.

subsection.text: The Office shall manage all personnel activities of the Department and generally carry out the duties set forth in § 2-1205 of this subtitle.
The Office shall manage the personnel activities of the General Assembly as assigned by the President and the Speaker.

section.text: In addition to any other duties set forth elsewhere, the Office shall:

paragraph.text: provide for the preparation and publication of legislation, session laws, journals of proceedings, indexes, and other documents; and
carry out any other function related to document preparation and publication required by the Executive Director.

section.text: The Office shall:

paragraph.text: directly supervise support services to the General Assembly that are not assigned to one of the Department’s other offices; and
perform any other function required by the Executive Director, the President and the Speaker, or the Legislative Policy Committee.

section.text: There is an Office of Legislative Audits in the Department.

subsection.text: The head of the Office of Legislative Audits is the Legislative Auditor, who shall be appointed by the Executive Director, subject to the approval of the President and the Speaker.
The Legislative Auditor must:

paragraph.text: be licensed as a certified public accountant in the State;
at the time of appointment, have at least 3 years’ auditing experience; and
while in office, be covered by a surety bond in the form and amount required by law.

subsection.text: The Legislative Auditor serves without a fixed term and may be removed by the Executive Director, subject to the approval of the President and the Speaker.
The Legislative Auditor is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.

Subject to the policies and directives of the President and the Speaker, the Joint Audit Committee, and the overall supervision and control of the Executive Director, the Legislative Auditor has general administrative control of the operation of the Office of Legislative Audits.
The Legislative Auditor shall devote full time to the duties of office and shall serve in a nonpartisan capacity.

With the approval of the Executive Director, the Legislative Auditor shall appoint a Deputy Legislative Auditor and other professional staff and may contract with consultants as authorized representatives.

paragraph.text: The Deputy Legislative Auditor must be licensed as a certified public accountant in the State.
The Deputy Legislative Auditor:

subparagraph.text: has the duties delegated by the Legislative Auditor; and
may be designated by the Executive Director to act as Legislative Auditor if the office is vacant or the Legislative Auditor is unable to perform the duties of office.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Executive Director, the Legislative Auditor shall appoint professional staff to conduct audits of local school systems in accordance with § 2-1220(e) of this subtitle.

section.text: In this subtitle, “examination” includes all authorized work and required audits under § 2-1220 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “unit” includes each State department, agency, unit, and program, including each clerk of court and each register of wills.

subparagraph.text: At least once every 3 years, the Office of Legislative Audits shall conduct a fiscal/compliance audit of each unit of the State government, except for units in the Legislative Branch.
In determining the audit schedule for a unit, the Office of Legislative Audits shall take into consideration:

sub-subparagraph.text: the materiality and risk of the unit’s fiscal activities with respect to the State’s fiscal activities;
the complexity of the unit’s fiscal structure; and
the nature and extent of audit findings in the unit’s prior audit reports.

subparagraph.text: Each agency or program may be audited separately or as part of a larger organizational unit of State government.

paragraph.text: Performance audits or financial statement audits shall be conducted when authorized by the Legislative Auditor, when directed by the Joint Audit Committee or the Executive Director, or when otherwise required by law.

subparagraph.text: In addition to the audits required under paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Office of Legislative Audits may conduct a review when the objectives of the work to be performed can be satisfactorily fulfilled without conducting an audit as prescribed in § 2-1221 of this subtitle.

sub-subparagraph.text: The Office of Legislative Audits has the authority to conduct a separate investigation of an act or allegation of fraud, waste, or abuse in the obligation, expenditure, receipt, or use of State resources.
The Legislative Auditor shall determine whether an investigation shall be conducted in conjunction with an audit undertaken in accordance with this subsection or separately.
