paragraph.text: If, on request of the Comptroller, the Joint Audit Committee so directs, the Office of Legislative Audits shall audit or review a claim that has been presented to the Comptroller for payment of an expenditure or disbursement and that is alleged to have been made by or for an officer or unit of the State government.

The Office of Legislative Audits shall conduct an audit or review to determine the accuracy of information about or procedures of a unit of the State government, as directed by the Joint Audit Committee or the Executive Director.

subsection.text: If the General Assembly, by resolution, or the Joint Audit Committee so directs, the Office of Legislative Audits shall conduct an audit or review of a corporation or association to which the General Assembly has appropriated money or that has received funds from an appropriation from the State Treasury.
The Office of Legislative Audits may audit any county officer or unit that collects State taxes.

paragraph.text: The Office of Legislative Audits shall review any audit report prepared under the authority of:

subparagraph.text: Article 19, § 40 of the Code, with respect to a county, municipal corporation, or taxing district; or
§ 16-315 of the Education Article, with respect to a community college.

paragraph.text: The results of any review made by the Office of Legislative Audits under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be reported as provided in § 2-1224 of this subtitle.

At least once every 6 years, the Office of Legislative Audits shall conduct an audit of each local school system to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of the financial management practices of the local school system.
The audits may be performed concurrently or separately.
The Office of Legislative Audits shall provide information regarding the audit process to the local school system before the audit is conducted.

At least once every 3 years, the Office of Legislative Audits shall conduct a performance audit of the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of the management practices of the Board and of the economy with which the Board uses resources.
The performance audit shall focus on operations relating to liquor inspections, licensing, disciplinary procedures, and management oversight.

subsection.text: A fiscal/compliance audit conducted by the Office of Legislative Audits shall include:

paragraph.text: examining financial transactions and records and internal controls;
evaluating compliance with applicable laws and regulations;
examining electronic data processing operations; and
evaluating compliance with applicable laws and regulations relating to the acquisition of goods and services from Maryland Correctional Enterprises.

subsection.text: A performance audit conducted by the Office of Legislative Audits may include:

paragraph.text: evaluating the efficiency, effectiveness, and economy with which resources are used;
determining whether desired program results are achieved; and
determining the reliability of performance measures, as defined in § 3–1001(g) of the State Finance and Procurement Article, identified in:

subparagraph.text: the managing for results agency strategic plan developed under § 3–1002(c) of the State Finance and Procurement Article; or
the StateStat agency strategic plan developed under § 3–1003(d) of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: The purpose of financial statement audits conducted by the Office of Legislative Audits shall be to express an opinion regarding the fairness of the presentation of a unit’s financial statements.
The audits referred to in subsections (a), (b), and (c) of this section shall be conducted in accordance with generally accepted government auditing standards.

paragraph.text: Upon approval of the Joint Audit Committee, the Office of Legislative Audits shall develop and use a rating system that is based on the results of a fiscal/compliance audit to determine an overall evaluation of a unit’s financial transactions, records, and internal controls and compliance with applicable laws and regulations as a means of comparing the various units of State government.
When an evaluation is issued, it shall be provided to the unit and shall be available to the Joint Audit Committee and the Budget Committees of the Maryland General Assembly.

subsection.text: An examination conducted by the Office of Legislative Audits shall generally be made at the offices of the State unit, county officer or unit, corporation, association, or local school system that is subject to examination.

paragraph.text: If considered appropriate and after consultation with the unit or body being examined, the Legislative Auditor may authorize all or a portion of an examination to be conducted at the offices of the Office of Legislative Audits.
Before the original or only copy of any record is removed from the State unit’s premises, the prior approval of the State unit for the removal is required.

Except as prohibited by the federal Internal Revenue Code, during an examination, the employees or authorized representatives of the Office of Legislative Audits shall have access to and may inspect the records, including those that are confidential by law, of any unit of the State government or of a person or other body receiving State funds, with respect to any matter under the jurisdiction of the Office of Legislative Audits.

In conjunction with an examination authorized under this subtitle, the access required by paragraph (1) of this subsection shall include the records of contractors and subcontractors that perform work under State contracts.
The employees or authorized representatives of the Office of Legislative Audits shall have access to and may inspect the records, including those that are confidential by law, of:

subparagraph.text: any local school system to perform the audits authorized under § 2–1220 of this subtitle or in accordance with a request for information as provided in § 5–114(d) of the Education Article; and
the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City to perform the audits authorized under § 2–1220(f) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Each officer or employee of the unit or body that is subject to examination shall provide any information that the Legislative Auditor determines to be needed for the examination of that unit or body, or of any matter under the authority of the Office of Legislative Audits, including information that otherwise would be confidential under any provision of law.

paragraph.text: The Legislative Auditor may issue process that requires an official who is subject to examination to produce a record that is needed for the examination.
The process shall be sent to the sheriff for the county where the official is located.
The sheriff promptly shall serve the process.
The State shall pay the cost of process.

If a person fails to comply with process issued under this subsection or fails to provide information that is requested during an examination, a circuit court may issue an order directing compliance with the process or compelling that the information requested be provided.

section.text: On the preliminary completion of an examination of a public senior higher education institution by the Office of Legislative Audits, the Legislative Auditor shall send a copy of the discussion notes of the examination relating to any preliminary findings of substantial fiscal impropriety to the following individuals and governing boards of the respective institutions that were subject to the examination:

paragraph.text: the Chancellor of the University System of Maryland and the University System of Maryland Board of Regents Audit Committee;
the President of Morgan State University and the Finance and Facilities Committee of the Board of Regents of Morgan State University; or
the President of St. Mary’s College of Maryland and the Finance, Investment, and Audit Committee of the Board of Trustees of St. Mary’s College of Maryland.

subsection.text: In this section, “unit” includes the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City.

Except with the written approval of the Legislative Auditor, an employee or authorized representative of the Office of Legislative Audits shall submit any report of findings only to the Legislative Auditor.

paragraph.text: On the completion of each examination, the Legislative Auditor shall submit a full and detailed report to the Joint Audit Committee.
A report shall include:

subparagraph.text: the findings;
any appropriate recommendations for changes in record keeping or in other conduct of the unit or body that is the subject of the report; and
any response of that unit or body, subject to procedures approved by the Joint Audit Committee.

subsection.text: The Legislative Auditor shall send a copy of the report to:

paragraph.text: the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Delegates;
the Chairmen of the Senate Budget and Taxation and House Appropriations Committees;
members of the General Assembly, subject to § 2–1246 of this subtitle;
the Governor, unless the report is of the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City;
the Comptroller;
the State Treasurer, unless the report is of the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City;
the Attorney General, unless the report is of the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City;
the unit or body that is the subject of the report;
the Secretary of Budget and Management, unless the report is of the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City;
the Executive Director; and
any other person whom the Joint Audit Committee specifies.

subsection.text: In addition to the requirements of subsection (d) of this section, each report of:

paragraph.text: a local school system shall be distributed to the chair of the House Ways and Means Committee and the cochairs of the Joint Committee on the Management of Public Funds; and
the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City shall be distributed to the chair of the Baltimore City delegation and the chair of the Baltimore City senators.

subsection.text: After the expiration of any period that the Joint Audit Committee specifies, a report of the Legislative Auditor is available to the public under §§ 10–602 and 10–611 through 10–628 of this article.

paragraph.text: The Legislative Auditor shall review each unit’s response and advise the unit of the results of the review. The Legislative Auditor shall advise the Joint Audit Committee when:

subparagraph.text: a unit does not make a response to a recommendation;
a unit does not indicate action to be taken in response to a recommendation;
a unit has not taken the action the unit indicated in its response to a recommendation;
a unit requests a waiver from a recommendation; or
the response by the unit is not considered appropriate to carry out the recommendation.

paragraph.text: The Executive Director or the Joint Audit Committee may direct the Legislative Auditor to undertake a review to determine the extent to which action has been taken by a unit to implement a report recommendation.

With respect to findings and recommendations of a fiscal/compliance nature, the Committee may recommend to the Governor and the Comptroller that the unit take the corrective action the unit indicates would be taken or take action to correct the findings in the report or the Committee may grant a waiver from the recommended action.
Within 45 days after receipt of the recommendation the Governor shall advise the Committee as to the action taken with respect to the recommendation.

Without concurrence of the Comptroller, the Committee may not waive a recommendation of the Legislative Auditor with respect to fiscal and financial record keeping, a uniform system of accounting, or the submission of fiscal and financial reports by the units.

With respect to findings and recommendations of a performance nature, the Committee may make recommendations to the Governor or propose legislation after reviewing a unit’s response to a recommended action.

The Legislative Auditor shall review each local school system’s response to an audit conducted under § 2–1220(e) of this subtitle and advise the local school system of the results of the review. The Legislative Auditor shall advise the Joint Audit Committee when a local school system:

subparagraph.text: does not make a response to a recommendation;
does not indicate action to be taken in response to a recommendation;
has not taken the action the local school system indicated in its response to a recommendation; or
responds in a manner that is not considered appropriate to carry out the recommendation.

paragraph.text: The Executive Director or the Joint Audit Committee may direct the Legislative Auditor to undertake a review to determine the extent to which action has been taken by a local school system to implement a report recommendation.

With respect to findings and recommendations made to a local school system, the Joint Audit Committee may make recommendations to the Governor, State Superintendent of Schools, the local school governing board, or local school officials after reviewing a local school system’s response to a recommended action.

The Governor and the Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals shall implement systems and processes to monitor the efforts of the Executive Departmental Units and the Judiciary, respectively, to correct audit findings reported by the Office of Legislative Audits.
Within 9 months of the most recent audit report, any unit that has five or more repeat audit findings shall report to the Office of Legislative Audits for each finding in that audit report:

subparagraph.text: the corrective actions taken; or
a schedule for when specific corrective actions will be implemented.

paragraph.text: Each unit required to report to the Office of Legislative Audits under paragraph (2) of this subsection shall continue to report to the Office of Legislative Audits on a quarterly basis after the initial report until the actions reported by the agency indicate that satisfactory progress has been made to address all findings.

In addition to the reports under § 2-1224 of this subtitle, the Legislative Auditor shall report an apparent violation of any law on use of State funds by the unit of the State government or other body that is examined.
A report under this subsection shall be submitted to:

subparagraph.text: the Joint Audit Committee;
the Executive Director;
the unit or body that is the subject of the report; and
the Office of the Attorney General.

paragraph.text: If the Legislative Auditor discovers any alleged criminal violation by a person during the course of an examination, the Legislative Auditor shall report the alleged violation to the Attorney General and an appropriate State’s Attorney.
A report under this subsection shall ask the Attorney General and State’s Attorney to take appropriate action.

Unless the Attorney General or State’s Attorney decides to prosecute an alleged criminal violation reported under this subsection, the Attorney General and State’s Attorney shall keep the report of the Legislative Auditor under this subsection confidential.

The Attorney General may investigate and prosecute any alleged criminal violation reported under this subsection and has all the powers and duties of a State’s Attorney, including the use of a grand jury in any county or Baltimore City, to investigate and prosecute the alleged violation.
The Office of the Attorney General shall respond, in writing, to a report received from the Legislative Auditor under this section.
The response of the Attorney General shall include what actions, if any, were taken as a result of the findings of the Legislative Auditor.
The response of the Attorney General shall be submitted to:

subparagraph.text: the Joint Audit Committee;
the Executive Director;
the unit or body that is the subject of the report; and
the Legislative Auditor.

subsection.text: Except as provided in § 2-1225 of this subtitle and subsection (b) of this section, information that an employee or authorized representative of the Office of Legislative Audits obtains during an examination:

paragraph.text: is confidential; and
may not be disclosed except to another employee or authorized representative of the Office of Legislative Audits.

subsection.text: The Legislative Auditor may authorize the disclosure of information obtained during an examination only to the following:

paragraph.text: another employee of the Department, with the approval of the Executive Director;

federal, State, or local officials, or their auditors, who provide evidence to the Legislative Auditor that they are performing investigations, studies, or audits related to that same examination and who provide justification for the specific information requested; or
the Joint Audit Committee, if necessary to assist the Committee in reviewing a report issued by the Legislative Auditor.

subsection.text: Except as provided in § 2-1225 of this subtitle, if information that an employee or authorized representative obtains during an examination also is confidential under another law, the employee, authorized representative, or the Legislative Auditor may not include in a report or otherwise use the information in any manner that discloses the identity of any person who is the subject of the confidential information.

section.text: A person is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 if the person:

paragraph.text: fails to comply promptly with process that the Legislative Auditor issues under this Part IV of this subtitle; or
violates any provision of § 2–1224(b) or § 2–1226 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this Part V the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Director” means the Director of the Office.
“Office” means the Office of Legislative Information Systems.

section.text: There is an Office of Legislative Information Systems in the Department.

subsection.text: The head of the Office is the Director, who shall be appointed by the Executive Director, subject to the approval of the President and the Speaker.
The Director serves without a fixed term and may be removed by the Executive Director, subject to the approval of the President and the Speaker.
The Director is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.
Subject to the policies and directives of the President and the Speaker and the overall supervision and control of the Executive Director, the Director shall oversee the operation of the Office.
The Director, after consultation with the Executive Director, shall appoint qualified individuals to serve in management functions in the Office.
The Director shall serve in a nonpartisan capacity and conduct the affairs of the Office in a nonpartisan manner.

section.text: In addition to any other duties set forth elsewhere, the Office shall:

paragraph.text: develop, coordinate, support, and maintain computer services and automated data processing and information systems for the General Assembly and the Department;
provide training for employees of the General Assembly and the Department who use the information systems;
plan for the future information systems needs of the General Assembly, its staff, and the Department;
as approved by the Executive Director and the Legislative Policy Committee, upgrade the information systems of the General Assembly and the Department; and
carry out any other function required by the Executive Director.

subsection.text: There is an Information Systems Planning Team in the Department.
The Information Systems Planning Team consists of:

paragraph.text: the Executive Director;
the Director of the Office of Legislative Information Systems;

an appropriate number of Department employees who are familiar with and are frequent users of the Department’s information systems, selected by the Executive Director and the Director of the Office of Policy Analysis;
a member of the library staff;
a representative of the Legislative Auditor, selected by the Executive Director and the Legislative Auditor;
a representative of the staff of the President of the Senate; and
a representative of the staff of the Speaker of the House of Delegates.

subsection.text: The Information Systems Planning Team shall:

paragraph.text: receive and evaluate the needs of the users of the Department’s information systems;
develop an integrated plan for the information systems needs of all aspects of the Department’s activities;
recommend priorities for the information systems needs of the Department’s employees; and
generally plan for and develop the information systems needs of the Department.

subsection.text: In this Part VI the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Director” means the Director of the Office.
“Office” means the Office of Policy Analysis.

section.text: There is an Office of Policy Analysis in the Department.

subsection.text: The head of the Office is the Director, who shall be appointed by the Executive Director, subject to the approval of the President and the Speaker.
The Director serves without a fixed term and may be removed by the Executive Director, subject to the approval of the President and the Speaker.
The Director is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.
Subject to the policies and directives of the President and the Speaker and the overall supervision and control of the Executive Director, the Director shall oversee the operation of the Office.
The Director shall serve in a nonpartisan capacity and conduct the affairs of the Office in a nonpartisan manner.
The Director, after consultation with the Executive Director, shall appoint an appropriate number of qualified individuals to serve in management functions in the Office.

The Director shall facilitate the creation and oversee the operation of functional, subject matter, special project, and any other workgroups to achieve maximum cooperation and the greatest efficiency in the use of staff and resources in the Office.
In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Office shall:

paragraph.text: conduct studies, develop options, and make recommendations on fiscal matters that relate to the State budget including:

subparagraph.text: taxes and revenues;
finances;
financial policies of public agencies; and
grants to individuals and private entities;

paragraph.text: conduct studies, develop options, and make recommendations on financial and other matters of the State government;
conduct studies, develop options, and make recommendations on organization and management improvement in State government;
study all matters that relate to the efficient and effective operation of the State government, whether or not the matter is a direct budgetary concern;
propose statutory changes to effect operational economy or effective administration;
perform the following duties with respect to the review of expenditures:

subparagraph.text: review each item in the proposed State budget so as to be able to report on the justification of a unit for that item;
review the proposed State budget at each stage of its consideration;
during consideration of the proposed State budget, identify each of the items that:

sub-subparagraph.text: provides for a new function; or
has been disapproved previously by the General Assembly;

subparagraph.text: evaluate each proposal of a unit of the State government for an appropriation, including any proposal, that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is in the proposed State budget;
is considered with the proposed State budget; or
involves State financing of a capital improvement;

subparagraph.text: evaluate the activities of each unit of the State government as these activities relate to a proposed or actual expenditure of public money;

paragraph.text: report, subject to § 2-1246 of this subtitle, on the public debt of the State, including the effect of an additional debt authorization or issue on State finances;
after each session of the General Assembly, summarize the effect of the legislative program on the financial condition of the State;
provide to the General Assembly and its committees information on fiscal matters;
exchange, with federal and State units, information on taxation, revenues, expenditures, and related matters;
conduct studies on the fiscal relationships of the State with its units and with local governments;
conduct studies on the operation, administration, staff, and physical plants of each unit of the State government;
as directed by the General Assembly, the Legislative Policy Committee, the Joint Audit Committee, or other legislative committees:

subparagraph.text: subject to § 2-1246 of this subtitle, submit reports on the studies on units of the State government; and
conduct other special studies and prepare other special reports;

paragraph.text: review the financial reports received from each political subdivision in accordance with Article 24, § 2-101 of the Code as to completeness and accuracy. If the report needs revision, the political subdivision shall be advised and shall submit the requested information within 15 days. The financial reports of political subdivisions shall be available for public inspection and certified copies shall be provided by the Office for a reasonable fee;
subject to § 2-1246 of this subtitle, publish an annual report on the revenues and expenditures of each county, municipal corporation, and special taxing district created by law; and
carry out any other functions related to budget and fiscal affairs required by the Executive Director.

subsection.text: The Executive Director shall dedicate an appropriate number of employees of the Department and an adequate level of Department resources to the year-round performance of the following functions:

paragraph.text: analyzing the State budget;
forecasting trends in the State budget;
identifying significant financial policies of public agencies in the State budget;
reviewing proposed amendments to the State budget approved by the General Assembly; and
conducting revenue forecasts.

section.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Office shall:

paragraph.text: on request of a member of the General Assembly, analyze and report on:

subparagraph.text: the laws of any state on a specific subject and all of the available information about the practical operation and effect of those laws; and
the acts and records of any state;

paragraph.text: compile information on and analyze any matter that is the subject of proposed legislation;
on request of a member of the General Assembly, prepare or help to prepare a bill or resolution that, unless the member specifies otherwise, conforms to the style manual of the Office;
provide analyses of proposed and emergency regulations of Executive Branch agencies;
make recommendations for the reclassification, rearrangement, renumbering, rewording, and other formal revision of the public general laws of Maryland;
make recommendations for appropriate systems to collect and publish:

subparagraph.text: the public local laws;
executive orders; and
the regulations of units of the Executive Branch of the State government;

paragraph.text: carry on continuous full time formal revision of statutory law for the General Assembly by preparing and submitting to the General Assembly recommendations for the repeal or modification of statutes that are obsolete, inconsistent with another statute, unconstitutional, or otherwise in need of formal revision;

correct manifest spelling, grammatical, or clerical errors or errors of addition or omission in the Code maintained by the Department, and include any such correction in the annual corrective bill for ratification by the General Assembly;
maintain the clarity, simplicity, and consistency of style of statutory law;
have a style manual for statutory law;

include in the style manual a drafting rule that requires, to the extent practicable, the use of words that are neutral as to gender except for a subject matter that specifically applies only to one gender and except for a name or organizational title;

assign a chapter number to each bill, and a joint resolution number to each joint resolution, that, by operation of law, becomes law without the signature of the Chief Executive, and notify the Secretary of State in writing of these assignments; and
carry out any other function related to legal affairs required by the Executive Director.

section.text: In addition to any other duties set forth elsewhere, the Office shall:

paragraph.text: prepare analyses of the fiscal, legal, and policy impact of proposed legislation;
research and prepare comprehensive assessments and evaluations of issues of concern to the General Assembly; and
carry out any other function related to research services required by the Executive Director.

section.text: In addition to any other duties set forth elsewhere, the Office shall:

paragraph.text: provide professional staffing services, as required by the Executive Director, to any standing committee, statutory committee, or special joint or unicameral committee or subcommittee of the General Assembly;
with the consent of the President and the Speaker, provide professional staffing services, as required by the Executive Director, to any joint legislative and executive body; and
carry out any other function related to committee staffing services required by the Executive Director.

section.text: In addition to any other duties set forth elsewhere, the Office shall:

paragraph.text: provide library and information services to the General Assembly and the general public;
index and preserve all information prepared as a result of the provisions of § 2-1238 of this subtitle; and
carry out any other function related to library and public information services required by the Executive Director.
After each regular session, the Department shall compile and index:

subparagraph.text: the laws that are enacted during that session;
the executive orders that have been adopted pursuant to Article II, § 24 of the Maryland Constitution since the last compilation;
the certificates of the State Board of Elections as to the referendum vote on a law, if the vote has not been published previously; and
the titles of laws and statements of referendum on laws of each municipal corporation, code county, and charter county that have been delivered to the Department as required by law.

paragraph.text: After each special session, the Department shall compile and index the laws that are enacted during that session.

After completion of the compilation and index, the Department shall deliver copies of the laws, executive orders adopted pursuant to Article II, § 24 of the Maryland Constitution, certificates, and titles to the printer who is designated to print the session laws.
The printer shall print promptly:

subparagraph.text: the documents delivered under this section; and
with the compilation for a regular session, the statement of receipts and expenditures of public money delivered under § 2-103 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

paragraph.text: The printer shall deliver the volumes to the Executive Director.
The Department shall publish other executive orders delivered to it in accordance with § 3-406(b) of this article.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: create and maintain, in the form of a statutory database, a code comprising the public general laws of the State; and
maintain the structural integrity and textual accuracy of that code.

subsection.text: The Department shall sell, exchange, or otherwise distribute bound volumes of the laws, the Senate journal, and the House journal.

Distribution under this section shall include provision of 1 copy of a volume to each public, circulating library or library association that requests the volume if, when the request is made, the Department has at least 26 copies of the requested volume.

section.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: keep a current list of the public local laws of the State;
keep the list accessible to the members of the General Assembly at all times; and
subject to § 2-1246 of this subtitle, annually submit the list to the General Assembly.

subsection.text: In this section, “publication” includes any report, study, or notification.

For each publication that an official or unit of the State government intends to distribute or submit to the General Assembly or to any committee, staff agency, or employee of the General Assembly, the official or unit shall:

paragraph.text: submit one copy to the President and one copy to the Speaker in the format requested by the President and the Speaker;
submit five printed copies to the library of the Department; and
in the case of a publication to be distributed to a committee of the General Assembly:

subparagraph.text: unless the publication is being submitted to the committee as specifically required by law, obtain approval for the distribution from the committee chair; and
comply with the distribution requirements of the committee.

subsection.text: An official or unit:

paragraph.text: shall submit to the library of the Department, in addition to the copies of a publication required under subsection (b)(2) of this section, any additional copies of the publication requested by the library on behalf of a member of the General Assembly; and
may give a publication directly to a member of the General Assembly only if:

subparagraph.text: the President and the Speaker have given written approval for distribution of the publication to each member of the General Assembly; or
the member asks for the publication.

subsection.text: To assist the Department in carrying out its duties under subsection (f) of this section, each publication submitted to the General Assembly or to any committee, staff agency, or employee of the General Assembly in fulfillment of a duty imposed by law shall specify the law under which the publication is being submitted.
The Department shall:

paragraph.text: keep a list of the publications of the officials and units;
periodically send the list to each member of the General Assembly; and
on request of a member of the General Assembly, obtain a publication of an official or unit for the member.

subsection.text: The library of the Department shall:

paragraph.text: catalog and preserve the publications that officials and units submit as required by law; and
collect, catalog, and preserve any other publication that the Department considers necessary or that the Department is directed by the President or the Speaker to collect, catalog, and preserve.

subparagraph.text: On request of a member of the General Assembly, the Department shall provide the member with an annotated code of the public general laws of Maryland that is published by a publisher and produced in a format to be selected by the Executive Director.
An annotated code shall be provided to a member under this subsection only during the term of the member, at the end of which the annotated code shall be returned to the Department.
The Department shall keep the annotated code provided under this subsection current.

paragraph.text: On request, the Department shall provide one additional copy of an annotated code of Maryland to each:

subparagraph.text: presiding officer;
pro tempore officer;
chairman of a standing committee;
majority leader; and
minority leader.

subsection.text: A member shall return to the Department the code provided by the Department on or before the expiration of the member’s final term of office. If a member resigns or is removed from office before the expiration of the member’s term, the member shall promptly return the code to the Department.

section.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: annually make:

subparagraph.text: a list that includes the name, position, term of office, and salary of each civil officer whom the Governor appointed during the preceding calendar year; and
a list that includes the name, position, term of office, and salary of each civil officer whose term expires during the current calendar year;
send a copy of each list to each member of the General Assembly; and
make the lists available to any person who requests them; and

paragraph.text: include on the lists only civil officers whom the Governor appoints, subject to the approval of the Senate or the House of Delegates.

section.text: The Department is the sole determiner of the form of public records released pursuant to Title 10, Subtitle 6, Part III of this article.

subsection.text: In this Part I of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Bill” includes a joint resolution.
“Mandate” means a directive in a bill requiring a local government unit to perform a task or assume a responsibility that has a discernible fiscal impact on the local government unit.
“Mandated appropriation” means a requirement in a bill that the Governor provide a certain level of funding in the annual budget bill for a specific program in the State.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of Legislative Services.
“Prefile” means to direct the Department, before a regular session of the General Assembly, to file a bill for introduction during that session.

subsection.text: A member or member-elect of the General Assembly may prefile a bill, as provided in this section.

paragraph.text: In a year when an election for members of the General Assembly is held:

subparagraph.text: a bill may be prefiled only by an individual elected or re-elected to the General Assembly at that election;
the deadline for directing the Department to file a bill for introduction is December 10;
the deadline for requesting the Department to prepare a bill for prefiling is November 20; and
an individual first elected at that election may not request the Department to prepare a bill until after the election.

paragraph.text: In any other year, a member may prefile a bill at any regular session by:

subparagraph.text: on or before the preceding November 15, requesting the Department to prepare the bill; and
on or before the second Friday following Thanksgiving, directing the Department, in writing, to file the bill for introduction.

subsection.text: A directive to file a bill for introduction shall be in writing and shall state the name of each sponsor of the bill.

paragraph.text: On the first day of each regular session, the Department shall send to the Secretary of the Senate and the Chief Clerk of the House, as appropriate, copies of each bill, in the form that the Senate rules set for introduction in the Senate or that the House rules set for introduction in the House.
Each bill that is sent under this subsection shall be considered as filed for introduction.

section.text: A bill that a standing committee recommends as a result of its work when the General Assembly is not in session shall be introduced with the standing committee as sponsor.

subsection.text: For each regular or special session of the General Assembly, the Department of Legislative Services shall prepare and distribute, in serial order:

paragraph.text: a synopsis of each Senate bill that is introduced; and
a synopsis of each House bill that is introduced.

subsection.text: If the Department determines that a bill imposes a mandate on a local government unit, the synopsis shall include a statement that “This bill imposes a mandate on a local government unit.”
If the Department determines that a bill requires a mandated appropriation, the synopsis shall include a statement that “This bill requires a mandated appropriation in the annual budget bill.”
Except as otherwise provided in this section, a committee may not vote on a bill unless:

paragraph.text: a fiscal note accompanies the bill; and
if the bill affects the funding of a State pension system, an actuarial analysis of the bill is attached to or summarized in the note or the analysis is waived.

If a bill affects the funding of a State pension system and the standing committee to which the bill is referred determines that the fiscal impact on the State warrants an actuarial analysis of the bill, the standing committee shall ask the Department of Legislative Services to obtain the actuarial analysis.
The standing committee may waive the actuarial analysis if the standing committee certifies that prompt action on the bill is needed to conduct legislative business.
The Executive Director of the Department of Legislative Services shall have that Department prepare a fiscal note for each bill.

If the chairman of the committee to which a bill is referred certifies that prompt committee action on the bill is needed to conduct legislative business and, before the Department prepares the fiscal note for the bill, holds a hearing on the bill, the Department shall prepare the note as soon after the hearing as possible.
When a standing committee asks for an actuarial analysis of a bill that affects a State pension system, the Department of Legislative Services shall:

subparagraph.text: obtain the analysis; and
summarize the analysis in the fiscal note or attach the analysis to the note.

paragraph.text: The Department of Legislative Services shall send a copy of a fiscal note for a bill to the committee to which the bill is referred and to the primary sponsor of the bill.

subsection.text: Upon request of the Department of Legislative Services, a unit of State or local government promptly shall provide any information requested by the Department for preparing a fiscal note.

paragraph.text: A fiscal note for a bill shall contain an estimate of the fiscal impact of the bill on the revenues and expenditures of the State government and of local governments:

subparagraph.text: during the year in which the bill is to become effective and the next 4 years after that year; and
if the full fiscal impact of a bill is not expected to occur during those years, during each year until and the first year during which that impact is expected to occur.

paragraph.text: If a bill, as introduced or amended, imposes a mandate on a local government unit, the fiscal note for the bill shall contain:

subparagraph.text: a statement that clearly identifies the imposition of the mandate; and
an estimate of the fiscal impact of the mandate and, if applicable and if data is available, the effect on local property tax rates.

paragraph.text: If a bill, as introduced or amended, requires a mandated appropriation, the fiscal note for the bill shall contain:

subparagraph.text: a statement that clearly identifies the imposition of the mandated appropriation; and
an estimate of the fiscal impact of the mandated appropriation.

paragraph.text: A fiscal note shall identify the sources of the information that the Department used in preparing the estimates of fiscal impact.

subsection.text: As soon as possible after the adoption of an amendment that changes the fiscal impact of a bill, the Department of Legislative Services shall:

paragraph.text: prepare a revised fiscal note for the bill; and
send the revised note:

subparagraph.text: to the chairman of the committee to which the bill is referred in the house of origin;
if the bill has reached the opposite house, to the chairman of the committee to which the bill is referred in that house;
if the bill is in the custody of either the Secretary of the Senate or the Chief Clerk of the House, to that officer; and
to the primary sponsor of the bill.

paragraph.text: The Department of Legislative Services shall keep a copy of each fiscal note for 3 years after preparation of the note.
The copies shall be reasonably available for public inspection.

subsection.text: Fiscal notes need not be published in the Senate journal or House journal.

paragraph.text: A bill may be introduced without a fiscal note accompanying the bill.
The validity of an enactment is not affected by the presence, absence, or content of the fiscal note.

subparagraph.text: In its summary report of legislation enacted by the General Assembly that has a fiscal impact, the Department of Legislative Services shall include a list of legislation that:

sub-subparagraph.text: affects local government units; or
requires a mandated appropriation in the annual budget bill.

subparagraph.text: In the list of legislation described in subparagraph (i)1 of this paragraph, the Department of Legislative Services shall indicate which legislation imposes mandates on local government units.

paragraph.text: Where applicable and if data is available, the report shall indicate:

subparagraph.text: the fiscal impact of the bill on local government units;
the impact of the bill on local property tax rates;
the cumulative fiscal impact of all legislation imposing mandates on more than one local government unit; and
the cumulative fiscal impact of all legislation requiring mandated appropriations.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Economic impact analysis” means an estimate of the cost or the economic benefit to small businesses that may be affected by a proposed bill introduced at a session of the General Assembly.
“Economic impact analysis rating” means an estimate that a proposed bill will have:

subparagraph.text: minimal or no economic impact on small businesses; or
meaningful economic impact on small businesses.

paragraph.text: “Small business” means a corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship, or other business entity, including its affiliates, that:

subparagraph.text: is independently owned and operated;
is not dominant in its field; and
employs 50 or fewer full-time employees.

paragraph.text: An economic impact analysis rating and an economic impact analysis, as appropriate, shall be prepared by the appropriate Executive Branch agency for each bill that is introduced at the request of the administration or a department, agency, or commission of the Executive Branch of State government.
A copy of the economic impact analysis rating and the economic impact analysis required under this subsection shall be submitted by the Governor’s office:

subparagraph.text: to the Department of Legislative Services within a reasonable time frame prior to the hearing on the bill to allow the Department to comment on the economic impact analysis rating and the economic impact analysis; and
to the committee to which the bill is referred prior to the hearing on the bill.

paragraph.text: An economic impact analysis rating and an economic impact analysis, as appropriate, shall be prepared by the Department of Legislative Services for each bill that is introduced by a member of the General Assembly.
A copy of the economic impact analysis rating and the economic impact analysis required under this subsection shall be submitted by the Department of Legislative Services:

subparagraph.text: to the primary sponsor of the bill; and
to the committee to which the bill is referred prior to the hearing on the bill.

paragraph.text: If the appropriate Executive Branch agency or the Department of Legislative Services determines that a bill will have minimal or no economic impact on small businesses, the agency or Department shall indicate that determination by a brief written statement.

If the appropriate Executive Branch agency or the Department of Legislative Services determines that a bill will have a meaningful economic impact on small businesses, the agency or Department shall develop a complete written economic impact analysis.

subparagraph.text: If the appropriate Executive Branch agency or the Department of Legislative Services determines that a bill will have a meaningful economic impact on small businesses and is unable to provide a complete written economic impact analysis, the agency or Department shall provide a written explanation of why the agency determined that the bill will have a meaningful economic impact.
The explanation may identify the impact in general terms and need not quantify the specific economic impact.

subsection.text: The economic impact analysis rating and the economic impact analysis required under this section shall include estimates directly relating to the following factors, as appropriate:

paragraph.text: cost of providing goods and services;
effect on the workforce;
effect on the cost of housing;
efficiency in production and marketing;
capital investment, taxation, competition, and economic development; and
consumer choice.

The Executive Branch agency or the Department of Legislative Services preparing the economic impact analysis rating and the economic impact analysis required under this section shall consult with, as appropriate:

subparagraph.text: other units of State government;
units of local government; and
business, trade, consumer, labor, and other groups impacted by or having an interest in the legislation.

paragraph.text: On request of the Executive Director of the Department of Legislative Services, a unit of the State or a local government shall provide the Department with assistance or information in the preparation of an economic impact analysis rating and economic impact analysis.

The Department of Legislative Services may include an economic impact analysis rating and economic impact analysis prepared by the Department or by the appropriate Executive Branch agency as part of a fiscal note.
The Department of Legislative Services may comment on the economic impact analysis rating and economic impact analysis prepared by the appropriate Executive Branch agency.

subsection.text: The Department of Legislative Services may revise the economic impact analysis rating and economic impact analysis consistent with an amended version of a bill.

paragraph.text: The Department of Legislative Services shall keep a copy of each economic impact analysis rating and economic impact analysis for 3 years after preparation of the rating or the analysis.
The copies shall be reasonably available for public inspection.

subsection.text: Economic impact analysis ratings and economic impact analyses need not be published in the Senate journal or House journal.
The validity of an enactment of a bill is not affected by the presence, absence, or content of an economic impact analysis rating or an economic impact analysis.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Committee” means the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review.

“Economic impact analysis” means an estimate of the cost or the economic benefit to small businesses that may be affected by a regulation proposed by an agency pursuant to Title 10, Subtitle 1 of this article.
“Economic impact analysis rating” means an estimate that a proposed regulation will have:

subparagraph.text: minimal or no economic impact on small businesses; or
meaningful economic impact on small businesses.

paragraph.text: “Small business” means a corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship, or other business entity, including its affiliates, that:

subparagraph.text: is independently owned and operated;
is not dominant in its field; and
employs 50 or fewer full-time employees.

paragraph.text: An economic impact analysis rating and an economic impact analysis, as appropriate, shall be prepared by the appropriate Executive Branch agency for each regulation that the agency proposes for adoption pursuant to Title 10, Subtitle 1 of this article.
A copy of the economic impact analysis rating and the economic impact analysis required under this subsection shall be submitted by the appropriate agency:

subparagraph.text: to the Department of Legislative Services no later than the time the agency submits the regulation to the Committee to allow the Department to comment on the economic impact analysis rating and the economic impact analysis; and
to the Committee at the time the agency submits the regulation to the Committee.

paragraph.text: If the appropriate Executive Branch agency or the Department of Legislative Services determines that a regulation will have minimal or no economic impact on small businesses, the agency or Department shall indicate that determination by a brief written statement.

If the appropriate Executive Branch agency or the Department of Legislative Services determines that a regulation will have a meaningful economic impact on small businesses, the agency or Department shall develop a complete written economic impact analysis.

subparagraph.text: If the appropriate Executive Branch agency or the Department determines that a regulation will have a meaningful economic impact on small businesses and is unable to provide a complete written economic impact analysis, the agency or Department shall provide a written explanation of why the agency determined that the regulation will have a meaningful economic impact.
The explanation may identify the impact in general terms and need not quantify the specific economic impact.

subsection.text: The economic impact analysis rating and the economic impact analysis required under this section shall include estimates directly relating to the following factors, as appropriate:

paragraph.text: cost of providing goods and services;
effect on the workforce;
effect on the cost of housing;
efficiency in production and marketing;
capital investment, taxation, competition, and economic development; and
consumer choice.

The Executive Branch agency or the Department of Legislative Services preparing the economic impact analysis rating and the economic impact analysis required under this section shall consult with, as appropriate:

subparagraph.text: other units of State government;
units of local government; and
business, trade, consumer, labor, and other groups impacted by or having an interest in the regulation.

paragraph.text: On request of the Executive Director of the Department of Legislative Services, a unit of the State or a local government shall provide the Department with assistance or information in the preparation of an economic impact analysis rating and economic impact analysis.

subsection.text: The Department of Legislative Services shall:

paragraph.text: comment on the economic impact analysis rating and economic impact analysis prepared by the appropriate Executive Branch agency; and
transmit its comment to the Committee.

subsection.text: The Department of Legislative Services shall revise the economic impact analysis rating and economic impact analysis consistent with an amended version of a regulation.

paragraph.text: The Department of Legislative Services shall keep a copy of each economic impact analysis rating and economic impact analysis for 3 years after preparation of the rating or the analysis.
The copies shall be reasonably available for public inspection.

subsection.text: Economic impact analysis ratings and economic impact analyses shall be published in the Maryland Register at the same time as:

paragraph.text: a notice of proposed adoption of a regulation is published in the Maryland Register; or
a notice of emergency adoption for a regulation is published in the Maryland Register.

subsection.text: The validity of an enactment of a regulation is not affected by the presence, absence, or content of an economic impact analysis rating or an economic impact analysis.

section.text: When the General Assembly passes a bill, it shall be returned to the house of origin.
In this Part II of this subtitle, “bill” does not include a joint resolution.

subsection.text: As soon as practicable after a bill is returned to the house of origin, the presiding officer shall have the State seal affixed to the bill and shall present the bill to the Governor or a designee of the Governor.
The presiding officer who presents the bill or the clerk designated by the presiding officer shall:

paragraph.text: in the presence of the individual to whom the bill is presented, make and sign, on the back of the bill, a written memorandum of the day and hour of presentment; and
have a corresponding entry made in the Senate journal or the House journal.

subsection.text: The Governor may designate another individual to receive bills while the Governor is ill or necessarily absent from the seat of the State government.
A designation under this section:

paragraph.text: shall be in writing;
shall be sent to the presiding officer of the Senate and the presiding officer of the House;
on receipt by those officers, shall be entered in full in the Senate journal and the House journal; and
is effective during the period that the Governor specifies.

subsection.text: The Governor shall deliver to the Secretary of State or a designee in the Secretary’s office:

paragraph.text: each bill that the Governor approves, immediately after the approval;
each bill that becomes law without the approval of the Governor, on the day the bill becomes law;
each bill that the Governor vetoes; and
each executive order effective under Article II, § 24 of the Maryland Constitution.

Subject to § 2-1238 of this title, the Secretary of State shall assign a chapter number to each bill that becomes law and to each executive order issued pursuant to Article II, § 24 of the Maryland Constitution.
Chapter numbers shall be assigned in the order in which the bills become law.

subsection.text: The Secretary of State shall keep, for each session, a permanent record of the bills and executive orders that the Governor delivers to the Secretary under this subtitle. The record shall be known as the record of chapter numbers.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of State shall enter, in the record, the chapter number of each bill that becomes law and each executive order.
Near the chapter number, the Secretary of State shall enter:

subparagraph.text: the Senate bill number, the House bill number, or the executive order number;
a brief summary of the subject of the bill or executive order;
as to a bill, the date of its presentment to the Governor; and
the date on which the bill or order was approved by the Governor or otherwise became law.

paragraph.text: After the last chapter number, the Secretary of State shall enter, by Senate bill number or House bill number, a list of the bills that the Governor vetoed.
Near the bill number, the Secretary of State shall enter:

subparagraph.text: a brief summary of the subject of the bill;
the date of presentment to the Governor; and
the date of veto.

subsection.text: The Secretary of State shall deliver to the clerk of the Court of Appeals each bill that becomes law.
With respect to bills that the Governor vetoes, the Secretary of State shall deliver:

paragraph.text: to the house of origin, each bill that the Maryland Constitution requires to be returned to that house; and
to the State Archives, every other bill.

subsection.text: If the General Assembly adopts a joint resolution that asks the Governor or an official of a unit of the Executive Branch of the State government to take any action, the Governor or the official shall give the Legislative Policy Committee and each sponsor of the resolution notice of the action taken under the resolution.
Notice under this section shall be given on or before any date established by the resolution.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Hearing” means a meeting that an investigating committee holds, during an investigatory proceeding, to take testimony or to receive other evidence.
“Hearing” does not include a preliminary conference or interview at which testimony is not taken under oath.

subsection.text: “Investigating committee” means any of the following bodies that may obtain, for the use of the General Assembly, information on a specific subject by compelling the attendance and testimony of witnesses or the production of books, documents, papers, and records:

paragraph.text: a standing committee or a subcommittee of a standing committee;
a joint committee of the Senate and the House or a subcommittee of a joint committee; or
the Legislative Policy Committee or any of its committees or subcommittees.

subsection.text: This subtitle establishes a code of fair procedures for the operation of an investigating committee so that it may hold hearings and otherwise properly carry out its powers and duties fairly, impartially, and consistently with:

paragraph.text: the constitutional rights of a person who is involved in a proceeding of the investigating committee; and
the public good.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not limit the acquisition of information or evidence by an investigating committee through a lawful means other than as provided in this subtitle.

This subtitle does not limit the authority of a committee of the General Assembly or any subcommittee of a committee of the General Assembly to exercise the power to administer oaths and subpoena witnesses and records as otherwise authorized by law.
An investigating committee may be established only by a resolution of the Senate or the House.
The resolution shall state the investigating committee’s:

paragraph.text: purpose;
powers;
duties;
duration;
subject matter;
scope of investigatory authority; and
size.

section.text: An investigating committee shall have at least 5 members.

subsection.text: An investigating committee shall have the chairman and vice chairman who:

paragraph.text: are appointed by the resolution that establishes the investigating committee; or
if the resolution does not appoint these officers, are elected by affirmative vote of a majority of all of the members of the investigating committee.

subsection.text: The rules of an investigating committee shall provide for the selection of a presiding officer to act if the chairman and the vice chairman are absent or unable to act.

paragraph.text: At a hearing of an investigating committee, the presiding officer shall be:

subparagraph.text: the chairman of the investigating committee;
if the chairman is absent or otherwise unable to preside, the vice chairman; or
if the chairman and vice chairman are absent or otherwise unable to preside, the individual who is selected under the rules of the investigating committee.

paragraph.text: At a hearing, the presiding officer:

subparagraph.text: shall examine the witnesses or supervise the examination by any other member of the investigating committee or by staff who are authorized to examine witnesses; and
may direct a witness to answer a relevant question or to provide a relevant book, document, or paper.

paragraph.text: A majority of the full authorized membership of an investigating committee is a quorum.
Unless there is a quorum, an investigating committee may not act at any meeting or hold a hearing.
Unless a greater vote expressly is required in this subtitle, an investigating committee may act by a majority vote of its members who are present at a meeting and vote.

subsection.text: Subject to the requirements of law and any rule of the General Assembly, an investigating committee may employ necessary staff for which funds are available.
An investigating committee may exercise its powers:

paragraph.text: when the General Assembly is in session; and
when the General Assembly is not in session, if the investigating committee is authorized to do so:

subparagraph.text: by law;
by the resolution that establishes the investigating committee; or
by the law or resolution from which the investigating committee derives its investigatory powers.

paragraph.text: An investigating committee shall adopt rules that govern its procedures, including the conduct of hearings.
The rules may not be inconsistent with law or any applicable rules of the General Assembly.

By a majority vote of all of the members of an investigating committee, the investigating committee may issue a subpoena that requires the appearance of a person, the production of relevant records, and the giving of relevant testimony.
A request to appear, appearance, or submission of evidence does not limit the subpoena power of the investigating committee.

subsection.text: The subpoena shall be served:

paragraph.text: in the manner provided by law for service of a subpoena in a civil action;
at least 7 days before the time that the subpoena sets for appearance or production of records; and
with the following documents:

subparagraph.text: a copy of the resolution that establishes the investigating committee;
a copy of the rules of the investigating committee;
a statement of the subject of the investigation or inquiry of the investigating committee; and
if the subpoena requires the appearance of a person, notice that counsel may accompany the person.

subsection.text: A person who is subpoenaed to appear at a hearing is entitled to receive the fees and allowances that are provided for a person who is subpoenaed by a circuit court.

paragraph.text: A person may be held in contempt if the person unjustifiably:

subparagraph.text: fails or refuses to comply with a subpoena for appearance;
appears but fails or refuses to testify under oath; or

unless the directive is overruled by a majority vote of the members of the investigating committee who are present at the hearing, disobeys a directive of the presiding officer at the hearing to answer a relevant question or to produce a relevant book, document, or paper that has been subpoenaed.

paragraph.text: If an investigating committee fails, in any material respect, to meet the requirements of this subtitle and the person who is subpoenaed is prejudiced by the failure:

subparagraph.text: the person need not comply; and
the failure is a complete defense in a proceeding against the person for contempt or other punishment.

paragraph.text: By a majority vote of all of the members of an investigating committee, the investigating committee may apply for a contempt citation:

subparagraph.text: when the General Assembly is not in session, to a circuit court; and
when the General Assembly is in session:

sub-subparagraph.text: to the General Assembly;
to the Senate, if the Senate established the investigating committee; or
to the House, if the House established the investigating committee.

paragraph.text: The General Assembly, the Senate, or the House:

subparagraph.text: may consider the application as though the alleged contempt had been committed in or against that body; and
in addition to any penalty that a court imposes, may impose any other punishment that the body has the inherent power to impose.

subsection.text: An investigating committee may hold any hearing that the investigating committee considers appropriate, at the times and places that it determines.

paragraph.text: The rules of an investigating committee shall provide for written notice of a hearing to be given to the members:

subparagraph.text: at least 3 days before the hearing, if it is held when the General Assembly is in session; and
at least 7 days before the hearing, if it is held when the General Assembly is not in session.

paragraph.text: Notice of a hearing shall include a statement of the subject matter.
A hearing and action that is taken at a hearing are not invalid only because notice is not given as provided in this subsection.

subsection.text: A hearing shall be public unless, by a majority vote of all of the members of the investigating committee, the investigating committee determines otherwise.

paragraph.text: With the consent of a majority of the members of an investigating committee who are present at a hearing, a witness or counsel for the witness may submit to the investigating committee a sworn statement that is relevant to the purpose, subject, and scope of the investigation or inquiry.
If an investigating committee believes that a person may be affected adversely because the person is named or otherwise identified at a hearing, the person may:

subparagraph.text: on request of the person or a member of the investigating committee, testify in the person’s behalf; or
with the consent of the investigating committee, submit a sworn statement or other documentary evidence.

paragraph.text: With the consent of a majority of the members of the investigating committee, any other person may testify or submit a sworn statement or other documentary evidence.
At a hearing, a person shall testify under oath unless, by a majority vote of the members who are present at the hearing, the investigating committee waives the requirement for the person.
Any member of the investigating committee may administer an oath.
Counsel may accompany a witness at a hearing and advise the witness of the rights of the witness.
An investigating committee may set limits to prevent obstruction of or interference with the orderly conduct of the hearing.
A witness at a hearing or counsel for the witness may submit to the investigating committee a proposed question, for the witness or any other witness.
The investigating committee shall ask the question if the investigating committee considers the question appropriate to the subject matter of the hearing.
An investigating committee shall have a record made of each hearing.
The record shall include:

subparagraph.text: each ruling of the presiding officer;
each question of the investigating committee and its staff;
the testimony and responses of each witness;
each sworn statement or other documentary evidence that the investigating committee permits a person to submit; and
any other matter that the investigating committee or its chairman directs.

paragraph.text: The investigating committee shall provide to a witness a certified transcript of the witness’ testimony, if the witness asks in advance and pays for the transcript.
This subsection does not:

subparagraph.text: prevent the disclosure of evidence by the person who gives evidence, if only that person could claim a privilege against disclosure; or
limit any power of the General Assembly, the Senate, or the House to discipline a member or employee or to impose a penalty if a State’s Attorney or court does not act under this subsection.

paragraph.text: If a hearing of an investigating committee is closed to the public, testimony and other evidence that is given at the hearing may not be made public unless, by a majority vote of all of the members of the investigating committee, the investigating committee permits disclosure and specifies the form and manner of disclosure.

On application of a person who claims to have been injured or prejudiced by an unauthorized disclosure or on motion of a State’s Attorney, the State’s Attorney may begin proceedings for imposition of penalties under this subsection.
A person who violates any provision of this subsection is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or both.

subsection.text: A person who is not a member of the General Assembly may not operate an electrical voting machine to vote on a question before the Senate or the House.

In addition to any penalty that the Senate or the House sets, a person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment for not more than 5 years.

A person may not willfully disrupt, interfere with, attempt to disrupt, or attempt to interfere with a session, meeting, or proceeding of the General Assembly, the Senate, or the House or any of their committees, by:

paragraph.text: making, alone or with another person, a noise that tends to be disruptive;
using abusive or obscene language;
making an obscene gesture;
engaging in violent, tumultuous, or threatening behavior;
refusing to comply with the lawful order of the police to disperse; or
doing any other disruptive or interfering act.

subsection.text: A person may not picket willfully in a building where:

paragraph.text: the Senate or the House has a chamber;
a member of the General Assembly has an official office; or
a committee of the General Assembly, the Senate, or the House has an office.

subsection.text: A person may not prevent or attempt to prevent, willfully and with force, the performance of a function, power, or duty by a member, officer, or employee of the General Assembly, the Senate, or the House or any of their committees.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: willfully and without legal authority, obtain, withhold, destroy, deface, or alter an official document or record of the General Assembly, the Senate, or the House or any of their committees; or
without legal authority, possess, withhold, destroy, or deface real or personal property that the General Assembly, the Senate, or the House or any of their committees owns or uses.
This subsection does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: a law enforcement officer of any state or of the federal government who is carrying out duties of the office; or
a person whom the officer summons to help in making an arrest or in preserving the peace.

paragraph.text: A person may not willfully bring an assault weapon or other firearm or destructive device, as defined in § 4-501 of the Criminal Law Article, into or have an assault weapon or other firearm or destructive device in a building where:

subparagraph.text: the Senate or the House has a chamber;
a member, officer, or employee of the General Assembly has an official office; or
a committee of the General Assembly, the Senate, or the House has an office.

subsection.text: A person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
Privileges from testifying for members of the General Assembly are found in § 9-122 of the Courts Article.
Provisions relating to civil immunity for acts and omissions in the performance of constituent services by members of the General Assembly are found in § 5-525 and § 5-526 of the Courts Article.

Papers, books, accounts, documents, testimony, and records sought in accordance with a subpoena issued under § 2–408, § 2–507, § 2–807, § 2–1104, or § 2–1608 of this title in connection with a lawfully authorized legislative inquiry or examination must be pertinent to the inquiry or examination.
For purposes of subsection (a) of this section, papers, books, accounts, documents, testimony, or records are considered pertinent if they:

paragraph.text: relate to the matters under inquiry or examination;
assist in assessing the credibility of a witness;
contradict or corroborate the testimony of a witness; or
demonstrate the existence of undue influence on a witness.

subsection.text: This section applies to a petition for an order directing compliance with a subpoena or compelling testimony under § 2–408, § 2–507, § 2–807, or § 2–1104 of this title.
The petition shall be filed in the Circuit Court for Anne Arundel County or, at the election of the petitioner, in any county in which venue would be appropriate under § 6–201 of the Courts Article.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the petition shall set forth the questions or requests that were asked or made of the party whose conduct necessitated the petition and, if any, the answers or objections provided or raised by that party.
The petitioner may satisfy the provisions of paragraph (1) of this subsection by attaching the relevant portions of a transcript to the petition.
The petitioner need not comply with the provisions of paragraph (1) of this subsection if there has been no response to the subpoena.

subsection.text: Any response to the petition shall be filed by the party served with the petition within 15 days after being served with the petition, unless that time period is shortened by order of the court.

paragraph.text: A response to a petition filed by the party whose conduct necessitated the petition is the only pleading that an objecting party may file to object to a subpoena.
The party whose conduct necessitated the petition may not file a motion to quash or a petition for an injunction with respect to the subpoena.
Except for cases that the court considers to require a higher priority, a proceeding under this section, including any subsequent appellate judicial review, shall:

subparagraph.text: take precedence on the court’s docket;
be heard at the earliest practicable date; and
be expedited in every way.

paragraph.text: In any hearing on the petition in a proceeding under this section, the court may not allow any additional evidence.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a party to a proceeding under this section may appeal the decision of the circuit court only by a petition to the Court of Appeals for the issuance of a writ of certiorari.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Personal information” means an individual’s:

subparagraph.text: Social Security number; or
driver’s license number.

paragraph.text: “Publicly post or display” means to intentionally make available to the public.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, on or after June 1, 2010, the General Assembly, to the extent practicable, may not publicly post or display on an Internet website maintained or paid for by the General Assembly an individual’s personal information.

section.text: There are a Governor and a Lieutenant Governor of the State, as provided in Article II of the Maryland Constitution.
For the term of office beginning on January 19, 2011, the annual salaries of the Governor and Lieutenant Governor are:

paragraph.text: Governor: $150,000; and
Lieutenant Governor: $125,000.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Governor-elect” means the individual whom the Board of State Canvassers declares to be the successful candidate for Governor after a general election for that office.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that, since a disruption of continuity in the conduct of the affairs of the State government could be detrimental to the safety and welfare of the State and its people, the transfer of executive power, in connection with the expiration of the term of a Governor and the inauguration of another Governor, must be carried out in a manner that ensures continuity.
The purpose of this subtitle is to promote the orderly transfer of executive power.
The General Assembly intends that:

paragraph.text: appropriate action be taken to avoid or to minimize any disruption of continuity in the conduct of the affairs of the State government; and
in addition to the specific provisions of this subtitle, each State officer, in conducting the affairs of the State government:

subparagraph.text: consider the problems that result from a transfer of executive power;
take appropriate and lawful action to avoid or to minimize any disruption; and
otherwise promote an orderly transfer of executive power.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply if the Governor-elect is the incumbent Governor.

subsection.text: To inform career civil servants about program goals and new policies and to establish communication with the administration of the incumbent Governor, the Governor-elect may circulate questionnaires or otherwise obtain information from the administration.
The Governor-elect may ask any question that will help to carry out the purpose of this subtitle, including a question that is intended to obtain:

paragraph.text: a description of a program;
a recommendation and justification for expansion, limitation, or elimination of a service;
a projection of future developments or needs in a program;
a recommendation for an administrative change;
a comment on anticipated federal developments that might affect a program or the State budget; or
