paragraph.text: keep a book in which the Secretary records each commission that the Governor issues to a civil officer; and
send the commission of each civil officer to the individual before whom the officer is to qualify.
The Secretary of State shall keep the records on qualification of civil officers that the clerks of court file as provided by law.
The Secretary of State may certify to the qualification of a civil officer to the same extent that a clerk of court may certify.

subsection.text: The Secretary of State shall have a seal for the authentication of copies of records in the Office of the Secretary.
Except as otherwise provided by law, the Secretary of State may charge a person:

paragraph.text: for the authentication of a copy of a record in the custody of the Secretary, a fee of not more than $5; and
if the person does not provide the copy for authentication, 50 cents a page.

section.text: The Secretary of State’s annual salary shall be:

paragraph.text: $78,750 for the first year of appointment beginning January, 2003;
$81,667 starting on the first anniversary after appointment;
$84,583 starting on the second anniversary after appointment; and
$87,500 starting on the third anniversary after appointment and thereafter.

subsection.text: In this section, “affidavit” means a written statement:

paragraph.text: made to the best of the affiant’s knowledge, information, and belief; and
the contents of which are affirmed under the penalties of perjury.

subsection.text: A nonprofit association, corporation, or other organization that has been in existence for at least 5 years and promotes social welfare and general civic improvement may register with the Secretary of State as a community association by filing an affidavit that the organization meets the requirements of § 5-406(a)(7) of the Courts Article.

section.text: The Office of the Secretary of State shall assume lead responsibility with respect to the maintenance and development of sister-state relationships.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administrator” means the Administrator of the Division.
“Code of Maryland Regulations” means the Code of Maryland Regulations and its permanent supplements.
“Committee” means the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review.
“Division” means the Division of State Documents.
“Executive order” has the meaning stated in § 3-401 of this article.
“Register” means the Maryland Register.
“Regulation” has the meaning stated in § 10-101 of this article, unless the context clearly requires otherwise.

paragraph.text: “Unit” means an officer or unit in the Executive Branch of the State government that is authorized by law to adopt regulations or to adjudicate contested cases.
“Unit” does not include a board of license commissioners.

section.text: There is a Division of State Documents in the Office of the Secretary of State.

subsection.text: The head of the Division is the Administrator, who shall be appointed by the Governor.

paragraph.text: The Administrator holds office during good behavior.
Subject to the hearing requirements of this subsection, the Governor may remove the Administrator for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or misconduct in office.
Before the Governor removes the Administrator, the Governor shall:

subparagraph.text: prepare written charges; and
give the Administrator a copy of the charges and an opportunity for public hearing.

paragraph.text: Notice of the hearing shall be given to the Administrator at least 10 days before the hearing.
The Administrator may be represented at the hearing by counsel.

subsection.text: The Administrator exercises the powers and performs the duties under this subtitle and Title 10, Subtitle 1 of this article subject to the general supervision of the Secretary of State.
The Division shall compile and edit:

paragraph.text: the Code of Maryland Regulations; and
as a temporary supplement, the Maryland Register.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in this subtitle, the Administrator is responsible for the publication and distribution of the Code of Maryland Regulations and the Register.
Except as otherwise provided by law, the Code of Maryland Regulations shall contain the text of:

paragraph.text: each executive order that is generally permanent in nature;
each regulation;
each document that the General Assembly requires to be published with a regulation; and
unless otherwise privileged, each other document that the Committee permits to be published in the Code of Maryland Regulations.
At least once each year, the Division shall integrate into the Code of Maryland Regulations each document that:

subparagraph.text: is required to be included in the Code of Maryland Regulations; and
has not previously been integrated or included in the Code of Maryland Regulations.

paragraph.text: This integration may be carried out by:

subparagraph.text: publication of looseleaf pages for insertion in the Code of Maryland Regulations; or
other appropriate permanent supplements to the Code of Maryland Regulations.

paragraph.text: Each part of the Code of Maryland Regulations and each issue of its permanent supplements shall contain a certification of the Administrator that the part or issue includes all of the documents that are effective and have been codified, as of the date set by the Administrator.
Each issue of the permanent supplements shall contain its issue date, which shall be its date of deposit in the United States mail. This date shall appear prominently on the first page.

If the Committee permits a unit to publish a document in the Code of Maryland Regulations and publication otherwise would not be required, the Committee may require the unit to reimburse the Division for the cost of the publication.
The Division shall bill for and collect the reimbursement.

subsection.text: An issue of the Register shall contain:

paragraph.text: on the first page:

subparagraph.text: the closing date and hour of the issue; and
the issue date, which shall be the date of deposit in the United States mail and shall appear prominently;

paragraph.text: the text of each of the following documents that has been submitted to the Division before the closing date and hour and has not been published previously:

subparagraph.text: during each session of the General Assembly:

sub-subparagraph.text: a synopsis of each bill that is introduced; and
a synopsis of each bill that is enacted;

subparagraph.text: each proposed rule of court that the Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals directs to be published;
each rule of court that the Court of Appeals adopts or permits to be adopted;
the hearing calendar of the Court of Appeals;
each administrative order or memorandum of the Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals or of the Administrative Office of the Courts that the Chief Judge directs to be published;
the hearing calendar of the Court of Special Appeals;
each administrative regulation that the Chief Judge of the District Court adopts;
each executive order;
each designation of an official State agency under a federal program;
except for notaries public and special police, a list of gubernatorial appointments that states:

sub-subparagraph.text: the office;
the name of the appointee;
the county where the appointee resides;
the effective date of appointment;
the term of office; and
the salary;

subparagraph.text: for a proposed regulation:

sub-subparagraph.text: the notice of the proposed adoption of the regulation; and
the text of the proposed regulation;

subparagraph.text: each notice of a public hearing that a unit issues;
unless otherwise exempted, each other document that is required by law to be published in the Code of Maryland Regulations;
each other document that is required to be published in the Register;
each notice or other document issued by an agency of a county or municipal government that the Committee permits to be published in the Register; and
unless otherwise privileged, each other document that the Committee permits to be published in the Register;

paragraph.text: a table of contents; and
an index to each title of the Code of Maryland Regulations that a document in the issue affects.

Each issue of the Register shall contain a certification of the Administrator that the issue contains all of the documents that have been submitted to the Division as of the closing date and hour of the issue.
The certification of the Administrator in the Register is conclusive evidence of this fact.

If the Committee permits a unit or an agency of a county or municipal government to publish a document in the Register and publication otherwise would not be required, the Committee may require the unit or agency to reimburse the Division for the cost of the publication.
The Division shall bill for and collect the reimbursement.

subsection.text: The Division may arrange for data bases derived from publications issued by the Division to be made available to the public for direct online searching by contracting with third–party or value–added resellers.
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Division shall make available to the public, at no cost, direct online searching of:

paragraph.text: the Code of Maryland Regulations (COMAR);
the Maryland Register; and
any other material the Division determines to be in the public interest.

subsection.text: The receipt of any material made available to the public under the terms of subsection (b) of this section shall be preceded by a legend stating that:

“The information you are about to receive is made available for personal use only. By proceeding beyond this point you agree that you will not use the information for any prohibited commercial purpose, as defined in § 7–206.2(e) of the State Government Article, including, by way of example and not in limitation, the downloading of this information for resale in any other electronic or printed form.”.
The legend referenced in subsection (c) of this section shall be presented to the recipient in a manner that affords the recipient an opportunity to refuse to access the material.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “prohibited commercial purpose” includes any use that involves the resale or other compensated transfer of information made available under subsection (b) of this section.

“Prohibited commercial purpose” does not include the incorporation of portions of information made available under subsection (b) of this section into documents commenting upon or advising persons of the legal effect of that information, even though the person incorporating the information may be compensated for the comments or advice.
Data or material obtained under subsection (b) of this section may not be used for any prohibited commercial purpose.

subsection.text: A person who violates subsection (e) of this section is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 for each violation.

paragraph.text: Unless the Committee provides otherwise, the Code of Maryland Regulations and the Register may not reprint any text from:

subparagraph.text: the Annotated Code of Maryland;
the Session Laws;
the United States Code;
the United States Statutes at Large;
the Code of Federal Regulations;
the Federal Register; or
any other generally available publication that the Administrator specifies.

paragraph.text: State statutes as described under paragraph (1)(i) and (ii) of this subsection need not be incorporated by reference.

subparagraph.text: Federal laws as described under paragraph (1)(iii), (iv), (v), and (vi) of this subsection may be incorporated by reference.
Federal law incorporated by reference after October 1, 2005, shall be identified by using the phrase “incorporated by reference”.
The unit incorporating federal law may:

sub-subparagraph.text: incorporate only a specified version of that law by specifying a date; or
incorporate future versions of that law by using the phrase “as amended”.

subparagraph.text: Other publications as described in paragraph (1)(vii) of this subsection may be incorporated by reference by:

sub-subparagraph.text: satisfying the requirements of § 23-303 of the Education Article, except as determined by the Administrator; and
complying with Title 10, Subtitle 1 of this article and with other requirements specified by the Administrator.

subparagraph.text: Incorporated documents shall be identified by using the phrase “incorporated by reference”.
The incorporation shall specify an edition number, year, or other specific indication of the version being adopted.
Prospective incorporation is not permitted for this category of document.

Agency generated documents have the additional requirement of providing the Division with an electronic version ready for publication on the Division website as required by § 7-206.2 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If the Administrator determines that publication would be in the public interest, nothing in this section prohibits the Administrator from publishing factual information concerning:

subparagraph.text: documents published or to be published in the Code of Maryland Regulations and the Register; or
the Code of Maryland Regulations and the Register.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this subtitle or Title 10, Subtitle 1 of this article, the Code of Maryland Regulations and the Register may not include news material or a press release, speech, or other comment.

subsection.text: The Administrator may include in the Code of Maryland Regulations and the Register annotations of judicial decisions and other explanatory materials that relate to a document in the Code of Maryland Regulations or the Register.
The Administrator may prepare the annotations or obtain them by contract.

section.text: With the consent of the Attorney General, the Administrator may remove from the Code of Maryland Regulations:

paragraph.text: a provision of a regulation that a court of final appeal has declared to be unconstitutional; or
a regulation if the unit that adopted the regulation has been abolished and the regulation does not transfer to a successor.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, an issue of the Register complying with the requirements of § 7-206 of this subtitle shall be published at least once every 2 weeks.

subparagraph.text: To avoid a conflict with a State or national holiday, with the approval of the Committee, the Administrator may alter the publication date of an issue of the Register by not more than 3 days.
At least 30 days before a change of publication date occurs, the Administrator shall publish, as appropriate, notice of the change in the Register.

paragraph.text: The Committee may provide for more frequent publication of all or any part of the Register.
An index shall be published at least quarterly for the Register.
For the Register, the last index for a calendar year shall be a cumulative index of that publication for that year.

subsection.text: A supplement to the index to the Code of Maryland Regulations or a new index shall be published at least once a year.

Subject to the conditions that the Board of Public Works sets, the Administrator shall contract for the prompt printing and distribution of the Code of Maryland Regulations, including its permanent supplements, and the Register.

The contract shall provide for a typographical arrangement that permits a unit or court to obtain, at reasonable cost, pamphlet reprints of the regulations of the unit or the rules of court that are published in the Code of Maryland Regulations.

paragraph.text: The Administrator may adopt a codification system and set editorial standards for the Code of Maryland Regulations and the Register, including a numbering system and captions or tag lines.
The numbering system, captions, or tag lines are not part of the official text of a document.

subsection.text: Except for rules of court, each document that is submitted for publication in the Code of Maryland Regulations and the Register shall conform to the codification system and editorial standards.
After consultation with the unit that adopted a regulation, the Administrator may conform a regulation or other document to the codification system and editorial standards.

Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section and § 3-405(b) of this article, each document to be published in the Code of Maryland Regulations or the Register shall be submitted to the Administrator, who:

paragraph.text: for 1 year after the publication of the document, shall keep and permit inspection of the document; and
then shall deliver the document to the State Archives.
The Clerk of the Court of Appeals shall submit to the Administrator:

subparagraph.text: each rule of court that the Court of Appeals adopts or permits to be adopted; and
each administrative order or memorandum of the Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals or the Administrative Office of the Courts that the Chief Judge directs to be published.

paragraph.text: The Chief Clerk of the District Court shall submit to the Administrator each administrative regulation that the Chief Judge of the District Court adopts.

subsection.text: The Administrator may require that any document required or permitted to be published in the Register be submitted electronically or on paper, or both.
This subtitle does not affect any other requirement as to notice, including a time that is specifically set for the publication of the notice.

paragraph.text: A unit shall submit a notice that sets a date for a hearing or meeting or for the termination of the opportunity to be heard in time for publication in an issue of the Register that will be published:

subparagraph.text: on or before the date set by law for publication of the notice; or
if the date for publication is not set by law, at least 15 days before the date for the hearing or meeting or for the termination of the opportunity to be heard.

paragraph.text: As to a notice that paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection governs, publication of the notice less than 15 days before the date for a hearing or meeting or the termination of the opportunity to be heard does not prejudice the effectiveness of the notice, if notice of less than 15 days is reasonable.

Unless notice by publication is insufficient in law, a notice that sets a date for a hearing or meeting or for the termination of the opportunity to be heard and that is submitted as required by this subsection constitutes, on publication, notice to:

subparagraph.text: each person who resides in the State; or
each person who holds an interest in property in the State.

subsection.text: Publication of a notice as required by this subtitle and as required by any other provision of the Code are both necessary to constitute full compliance with law.

section.text: The Administrator may require a unit to reimburse the Division for the cost of a publication of a document in an issue of the Register if the unit submits, withdraws, or changes the document after the closing date and hour of that issue.

paragraph.text: The Committee shall adopt guidelines for the Administrator to:

subparagraph.text: sell a subscription list for any publication of the Division; and
set the price for:

sub-subparagraph.text: a copy of or a subscription to the Code of Maryland Regulations and the Register; and
a copy of a database or other computer readable information on magnetic tape or some other electronic media.

paragraph.text: The Committee may allow:

subparagraph.text: a volume discount; and
the free, reciprocal exchange of publications by the State and other jurisdictions.

subsection.text: A copy of the Code of Maryland Regulations and the Register shall be available to the public at the price set under this section.
The Administrator shall provide, without charge:

paragraph.text: to each member of the General Assembly each issue of the Register;
to the Enoch Pratt Library and the State Law Library, 1 copy of:

subparagraph.text: the Code of Maryland Regulations;
each issue of the permanent supplements to the Code of Maryland Regulations; and
each issue of the Register; and

paragraph.text: to a judge of a State court except the orphans’ court, 1 copy of:

subparagraph.text: the current Code of Maryland Regulations; and
each issue of the Register that the judge requests.

subsection.text: Unless authorized by the Committee, the Administrator may not allow public access to a document that is to be included in the Register earlier than the date immediately following the issue date of the Register in which the document is published.
There is a special fund in the Division of State Documents.
The purpose of the fund is to pay the costs of publishing and distributing the products of the Division.
The Administrator of the Division shall administer the fund.

paragraph.text: The fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Treasurer shall hold the fund separately and the Comptroller shall account for the fund.

subsection.text: The fund consists of revenue received by the Division in payment of its products.
The fund may be used only for the expenses of production and distribution of its products and to support the operations of the Division.

paragraph.text: The Treasurer shall invest the money in the fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings in the fund shall be credited to the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: Expenditures from the fund may be made only in accordance with the State budget.

Money expended from the fund for the production and distribution of the Division’s products is supplemental to and is not intended to take the place of funding that otherwise would be appropriated for the production and distribution of the Division’s products.
The official text of a document is:

paragraph.text: until incorporation in the Code of Maryland Regulations, the text of the document in the most recent form in the Register; or
after incorporation in the Code of Maryland Regulations, the text of the document in the most recent form in the Code of Maryland Regulations.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any discrepancy between the official text and any other text of a document, the official text is the only valid and enforceable text.
Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the Administrator shall correct an error in the official text of a document in the Code of Maryland Regulations or the Register by:

paragraph.text: inclusion of the correction in an errata list in the Register; or
publication of a corrected form of the affected part of the document in the Code of Maryland Regulations or the Register.
An error that is made in publication of a document under this subtitle and that changes the legal effect of a provision of the document invalidates only:

subparagraph.text: that provision; and
any other provision of the document that then is so incomplete that it cannot be carried out in accordance with the purpose of the document.

paragraph.text: If the error changes the legal effect of a proposed or adopted regulation, the regulation shall be published anew as provided in § 10-112 of this article.

section.text: Unless notice by publication is insufficient in law or unless otherwise specifically provided by law, publication of a document under this subtitle gives a person who is subject to or affected by the document notice of the contents of the document.
Publication of a document in the Code of Maryland Regulations or the Register creates a rebuttable presumption that:

paragraph.text: the document:

subparagraph.text: was issued, prescribed, repealed, or adopted properly; and
if the document is a regulation, was approved as to legality by the Attorney General; and

paragraph.text: the requirements of this subtitle and of §§ 10-111(a), 10-112 through 10-117, and 10-129 of this article have been met.

section.text: The provisions of a document in the Code of Maryland Regulations and the Register are severable, unless the document expressly states otherwise.

A rule of court, administrative memorandum of a court, administrative order of a court, or administrative regulation of the Chief Judge of the District Court in the Code of Maryland Regulations or the Register has the effective date set in the document.
In this subtitle, “Council” means the Governor’s Executive Council.
There is a Governor’s Executive Council.
The Council includes:

paragraph.text: the Governor;
the Lieutenant Governor;
the Secretary of State;
the secretary of each principal department of the Executive Branch of the State government;
the State Superintendent of Schools; and
the Secretary of Higher Education.

section.text: The purposes of the Council are coordination and effective direction and supervision of the State government.
The Governor may appoint an executive secretary for the Council.

subsection.text: The Executive Branch of the State government shall have not more than 21 principal departments, each of which shall embrace a broad, functional area of that Branch.
The principal departments of the Executive Branch of the State government are:

paragraph.text: Aging;
Agriculture;
Budget and Management;
Business and Economic Development;
Disabilities;
the Environment;
General Services;
Health and Mental Hygiene;
Housing and Community Development;
Human Resources;
Information Technology;
Juvenile Services;
Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
Natural Resources;
Planning;
Public Safety and Correctional Services;
State Police;
Transportation; and
Veterans Affairs.

Unless placed by law or expressly exempted from placement by law, the officers and units in the Executive Branch of the State government that are not principal departments may be placed by the Governor in any principal department.
Unless expressly exempted from placement by law, an interstate, regional, or other intergovernmental unit in which the State participates shall be placed in the appropriate principal department.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding the placement of a unit in a principal department:

paragraph.text: the powers and duties that are assigned by law to the unit are not changed;

a State officer or State employee who is not in the State Personnel Management System and is transferred with the unit remains exempt from the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article unless the officer or the employee is placed in the State Personnel Management System in accordance with those provisions; and

the head of a unit who is in the State Personnel Management System or holds the position other than at the pleasure of the Governor does not cease to be in the State Personnel Management System or to hold the position other than at the pleasure of the Governor.

subsection.text: The head of each principal department is a secretary, who shall be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The Governor shall select, on the bases of professional and administrative knowledge and experience, a secretary who has the qualifications required by law.

Unless otherwise provided by law, the secretary of a principal department or, with the approval of the Governor, a designee of the secretary shall represent the State and coordinate its participation in an interstate, regional, or other intergovernmental unit that is in the department.

section.text: Under the direction of the Governor, the secretaries of the principal departments are responsible for the prevention and elimination of duplication and overlapping of activities in and among their departments, by coordinating those activities.

subsection.text: The secretary of each principal department serves at the pleasure of the Governor unless otherwise provided by law.
A secretary shall:

paragraph.text: receive the salary and have the assistants, employees, and professional consultants provided in the budget, unless otherwise provided by law;
be responsible for establishing policy to be followed by the units of State government within the secretary’s department;
be responsible for the efficient and orderly administration of the department;

be responsible for the comprehensive planning of programs and services within the secretary’s jurisdiction and for reviewing and approving the plans of all units of State government within the secretary’s jurisdiction;
be responsible for the budget of the secretary’s office and for the budgets of other units of State government within the secretary’s jurisdiction;

be responsible for the organization of the secretary’s office and for recommending to the Governor changes in the organization and placement of units of State government within the secretary’s jurisdiction; and
recommend to the Governor any modification, abolition, and transfer of advisory bodies within the secretary’s jurisdiction.

subsection.text: A secretary may:

paragraph.text: appoint officers and employees in the secretary’s office as provided in the budget and review the personnel action taken by any unit of State government within the secretary’s jurisdiction; and
create the citizen advisory bodies that may be necessary for the operation of the secretary’s department.

section.text: The secretary of each principal department has authority and responsibility to adopt regulations for all units within the secretary’s jurisdiction, except as otherwise provided by law.

subsection.text: The Governor is responsible for a continuing review of the organization of the Executive Branch of the State government.

paragraph.text: In addition to any reorganization under Article II, § 24 of the Maryland Constitution, the Governor may order any other reorganization of the Executive Branch that is considered by the Governor to be necessary and desirable and that is not inconsistent with law.
A reorganization under this subsection may include:

subparagraph.text: the reorganization of the principal departments;
the placement of a unit in a principal department; and
the transfer of a unit or function from 1 principal department to another.

paragraph.text: A reorganization under this subsection may be effected through the issuance of an executive order or the approval of a recommendation that the secretary of a principal department submits. An approval shall be treated as an executive order. However, notwithstanding any other provision of law, the recommendation is not effective unless approved or issued as an executive order.

Notwithstanding any other law that relates to organization of the Executive Branch of the State government, if a program involves more than 1 principal department and cannot be carried out efficiently through cooperation of the departments, the Governor may establish a task force to integrate the services of the departments so as to carry out the program.
A task force established under this subsection may exist for not more than 1 year unless the Governor expressly extends the existence of the task force.

subsection.text: The Governor shall recommend to the General Assembly the placement of any new program or new unit within an appropriate principal department.

section.text: Each secretary of a principal department is responsible for recommending to the Governor:

paragraph.text: any change in the organization, placement, or name of a unit in the department;
any change, abolition, or transfer of an advisory body in the department; and
any centralization or coordination of administrative staff or clerical services in the department, for efficiency and effectiveness.

section.text: If the name of a unit in the Executive Branch of the State government is set by statute, the name may be changed only by another statute.
The Governor shall:

paragraph.text: make the designation of a unit as the official State agency for participation in a federal program by a written designation that includes the name of the unit and of the program;
give the General Assembly notice of the designation; and
deliver a copy of the designation to the Administrator of the Division of State Documents.

section.text: The secretary of each principal department and the head of each other unit in the Executive Branch of the State government that is not in a principal department shall include on the website for the department or unit:

paragraph.text: an organizational chart that:

subparagraph.text: shows the major subunits in the unit; and
lists the name and title of each individual who heads a subunit; and

paragraph.text: a concise description of the department or unit and each subunit.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “Change the use, purpose, or function” means an abrupt and material change in the type of clients or inmates served in a facility, the licensed purpose of a facility, or the principal activities carried out within a facility.
“Change the use, purpose, or function” does not mean a gradual change in clients, inmates, or activities due to societal trends or needs.
“Public hearing” means an informational hearing, the sole purpose of which is to obtain public comment and answer public questions.
“Public hearing” does not mean a contested case hearing under Title 10, Subtitle 2 of this article.

paragraph.text: “State facility” means a facility that is owned, leased, or operated by the State for the purpose of providing health, juvenile, or correctional services to clients or inmates.

subsection.text: A principal department of the Executive Branch of the State government may not change the use, purpose, or function of a State facility without giving notice as required in subsection (c) of this section.

paragraph.text: Before a principal department changes the use, purpose, or function of a State facility, the principal department shall hold a public hearing on the proposed change.
The principal department shall give notice of the proposed change and the hearing:

subparagraph.text: to the public, by publication once a week for 2 consecutive weeks before the hearing in a regularly published newspaper of general circulation in any county that may be affected by the change; and
to each member of the General Assembly in whose district the facility is located, by certified mail.

paragraph.text: Before a principal department leases or purchases land, buildings, or office space to be used for the purpose of providing health, juvenile, or correctional services to clients or inmates, the principal department shall give written notice of the proposed use of the land, buildings, or office space to each member of the General Assembly in whose legislative district the property is located.

subparagraph.text: A member of the General Assembly may request that the department hold a public hearing on the proposed use.
The department on whose behalf the property is being procured or leased shall hold a public hearing on the proposed use upon the request of a member of the General Assembly.
The department shall give notice of the hearing to the public as provided in subsection (c)(2)(i) of this section.

paragraph.text: If, after a principal department ceases its use of a State facility, the principal department or any other principal department plans to recommence operation of the facility as a State facility, and the proposed operation of the facility would change its use, purpose, or function, the principal department shall hold a public hearing on the proposed operation.
The principal department shall give notice of the hearing to the public as provided in subsection (c)(2)(i) of this section.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Appointing authority” has the meaning stated in § 1–101(b) of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.

“Office” means the Appointments Office in the Office of the Governor that performs the function of recommending to the Governor the appointment or nomination of an individual to serve as a member of a State or local board, commission, council, committee, authority, task force, or other entity that by law requires the membership to be appointed in whole or in part by the Governor, whether or not the appointment or nomination is with the advice and consent of the Senate or House of Delegates.

subsection.text: The Office may not direct or overrule an appointing authority, the Secretary of Budget and Management, or any unit of the Department of Budget and Management, on any decision to appoint, promote, transfer, reassign, discipline, or terminate an employee under the jurisdiction of the appointing authority.
Only an appointing authority may delegate in writing the authority to act on the appointing authority’s behalf, but only to an employee or officer under the jurisdiction of the appointing authority.
An appointing authority may not delegate the authority to make the final decision on the termination of an employee.
An appointing authority shall notify the Secretary of Budget and Management of any delegation of authority authorized under this section by providing the Secretary a copy of the delegation.
On or before December 1 of each gubernatorial election year:

paragraph.text: the Secretary of Budget and Management shall compile a list of the position, pay grade, and title of each employee in the State Personnel Management System who is employed with regard to political affiliation, belief, or opinion under § 4–201(c)(2)(ii) of the State Personnel and Pensions Article; and

the Secretary of Transportation shall compile a list of the position, pay grade, and title of each employee in the Maryland Department of Transportation’s Human Resource System who is employed with regard to political affiliation, belief, or opinion under § 2–103.4(b)(2)(ii) of the Transportation Article.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Transportation shall provide the list of employees required under subsection (a)(2) of this section to the Secretary of Budget and Management on or before December 15 of each gubernatorial election year.

In accordance with § 2–1246 of this article, on or before December 31 of each gubernatorial election year, the Secretary of Budget and Management shall submit a report to the Governor, the President of the Senate, and the Speaker of the House of Delegates on the total number of State employees employed with regard to political affiliation, belief, or opinion under this section.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Evaluation” means the process of legislative review of a governmental activity or unit for which this subtitle provides.
“Evaluation committee” means a committee that is appointed to carry out an evaluation.
“Evaluation date” means the date on which an evaluation of a governmental activity or unit is to be completed.
“Governmental activity” means a program, service, or other function of government.
“Preliminary evaluation” means the process by which the Legislative Policy Committee determines whether a governmental activity should undergo an evaluation.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: a system for periodic, legislative review of the regulatory, licensing, and other governmental activities of the Executive Branch of the State government is essential for the maintenance of a government in which the citizens have confidence and of a healthy State economy; and
this legislative review is consistent with other activities and goals of the General Assembly.

subsection.text: The purposes of this subtitle are to:

paragraph.text: establish a system of legislative review that will:

subparagraph.text: determine whether a governmental activity is necessary for the public interest; and
make units that are responsible for necessary governmental activities accountable and responsive to the public interest; and

paragraph.text: ensure that the legislative review takes place by establishing, by statute, dates for the review and other legislative action.

subsection.text: On or before December 15 of the 2nd year before the evaluation date of a governmental activity or unit, the Legislative Policy Committee, based on a preliminary evaluation, may waive as unnecessary the evaluation required under this section.

On or before December 15 of the second year before the evaluation date, the Department of Legislative Services shall prepare a preliminary evaluation report on each governmental activity or unit to be evaluated.
The preliminary evaluation report shall include:

subparagraph.text: significant legislative changes that affect the governmental activity or unit after the last evaluation;
changes in technology that impact the conduct of the profession or occupation regulated by the governmental activity or unit;
changes in the regulatory environment;
registered complaints and complaint outcomes in the time period after the last evaluation;
a 5-year revenue and expenditure comparison, including indirect costs as part of the expenditures of the activity or unit; and
a recommendation whether a full evaluation should be undertaken.

subsection.text: On request of the Department of Legislative Services, the governmental activity or unit shall provide the Department with the information required to undertake the preliminary evaluation.
Evaluation of a governmental activity or unit shall be completed:

paragraph.text: by an evaluation committee for the Senate, appointed by the President of the Senate, and an evaluation committee for the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House; or
by an evaluation committee appointed jointly by the President and Speaker.

subsection.text: Each evaluation committee for a governmental activity or unit shall be appointed on or before May 31 of the year before the evaluation date of that governmental activity or unit.
On or before June 30 of the year before the evaluation date of a governmental activity or unit, each evaluation committee for that governmental activity or unit shall:

paragraph.text: consult with:

subparagraph.text: the Department of Legislative Services; and
the unit under evaluation or responsible for the governmental activity under evaluation; and

paragraph.text: then prepare a plan for the evaluation.

subsection.text: Each evaluation committee shall provide, in the plan, for periodic consultation with the Department of Legislative Services.

section.text: During an evaluation, the unit under evaluation or responsible for the governmental activity under evaluation shall:

paragraph.text: provide promptly any information that the Department of Legislative Services or an evaluation committee requests; and
otherwise cooperate with the Department and the evaluation committee.

Subject to § 2-1246 of this article, on or before October 31 of the year before the evaluation date of a governmental activity or unit, the Department of Legislative Services shall submit to the General Assembly an evaluation report on the governmental activity or unit.
The Department of Legislative Services shall make copies of the report available.

subsection.text: The report on a governmental activity or unit designated for evaluation under § 8-403 of this subtitle, to the extent appropriate to the evaluation of that governmental activity or unit and consistent with the plan for evaluation, shall:

paragraph.text: discuss the purpose for which the governmental activity or unit was established;
discuss the manner in which the unit under evaluation or responsible for the governmental activity under evaluation operates to carry out this purpose;
discuss changes in conditions that have occurred since the governmental activity or unit was established and that suggest a need for change in the governmental activity or unit;
discuss whether the public health, safety, or welfare would be affected significantly if the governmental activity or unit did not exist;
discuss whether the costs of any goods or services have changed because the governmental activity or unit was established;
discuss whether the statute provides a clear regulatory mandate;
discuss whether the unit under evaluation or responsible for the governmental activity under evaluation complies with this mandate;
discuss whether that unit has clear objectives;
discuss the extent to which that unit accomplishes these objectives;
discuss whether other governmental activities of the State have similar objectives and, if so, compare the cost and effectiveness and identify duplication in these governmental activities;
discuss whether federal or local governmental activities or programs or services in the private sector have similar objectives;
state the source of funds of the governmental activity or unit;

discuss whether the budget and staff resources and the enforcement authority of the unit under evaluation or responsible for the governmental activity under evaluation meet or exceed the resources and authority that are needed to carry out the statutory mandate of the unit;
discuss, as to a governmental activity for licensing of a profession or occupation, whether the unit responsible for the governmental activity has:

subparagraph.text: restricted access to the profession or occupation unduly;
processed applications for licenses efficiently and fairly; and
licensed only qualified applicants;

paragraph.text: discuss whether the unit under evaluation or responsible for a governmental activity under evaluation operates in an open and accountable manner, with:

subparagraph.text: public access to its records and meetings; and
safeguards against conflicts of interest;

paragraph.text: discuss the extent to which that unit encourages participation of the public, as opposed to participation only of persons whom the unit regulates, and include a discussion of the role of the consumer representatives on the unit;
discuss whether that unit processes efficiently and fairly formal public complaints that are submitted to it;
discuss whether that unit gathers and keeps sufficient information about its activities and regulated persons and interests:

subparagraph.text: to carry out the duties of the unit;
to inform the public; and
to enable evaluation of the success of the governmental activity or unit;

paragraph.text: discuss whether that unit gathers or keeps superfluous information;
discuss alternative methods to carry out the governmental activity, including methods used successfully in other states;
discuss suggestions for statutory changes; and
include any other information that the plan for evaluation requires or the Department of Legislative Services considers appropriate.

subsection.text: A report on a governmental activity or unit designated for evaluation under § 8-404 of this subtitle, to the extent appropriate to the evaluation of that governmental activity or unit and consistent with the plan for evaluation, shall:

paragraph.text: discuss the public purpose for which the governmental activity or unit was established and whether that purpose is still a public need;
discuss whether the purpose of the governmental activity or unit has changed and, if so, the consistency of changes with legislative intent and public need;
discuss whether the governmental activity or unit substantially duplicates other State, federal, or local governmental activities or programs or services in the private sector;
discuss whether laws or policies, including budgetary or personnel policies, impede the effectiveness of the governmental activity or unit;
discuss whether the unit under evaluation or responsible for the governmental activity under evaluation operates:

subparagraph.text: efficiently and effectively;
in an open and accountable manner, with public access to records and meetings, safeguards against conflicts of interest, and opportunity for public participation;
in a fair and nondiscriminatory manner that complies fully with law and State policy; and
in a manner that imposes on the citizens and economy of the State the least burden necessary to carry out the purpose for which the governmental activity or unit was established;

paragraph.text: discuss whether changes in operation or law are desirable to improve efficiency and effectiveness; and
include any other information that the plan for evaluation requires or the Department of Legislative Services considers appropriate.

section.text: On or before December 14 of the year before the evaluation date of a governmental activity or unit, the evaluation committee shall hold a public hearing to receive, from the unit under evaluation or responsible for the governmental activity under evaluation and the public, testimony as to the evaluation report.

subsection.text: Subject to § 2-1246 of this article, on or before the 20th day of the regular session of the General Assembly in the year of the evaluation date of a governmental activity or unit, the evaluation committee for the governmental activity or unit shall submit a report to the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: The report shall recommend:

subparagraph.text: as to a governmental activity or unit designated for evaluation under § 8-403 of this subtitle, whether the governmental activity or unit should be reestablished, with or without changes, or allowed to terminate; or
as to a governmental activity or unit designated for evaluation under § 8-404 of this subtitle, whether the statute for the governmental activity or unit should be repealed or changed.

paragraph.text: The report shall be accompanied by each bill that is needed to accomplish the recommendations in the report.

The reestablishment of a governmental activity or unit designated for evaluation under § 8-403 of this subtitle is for a 10-year period unless the law that provides for reestablishment sets another period.
After the period of reestablishment expires, the governmental activity or unit terminates as provided by law unless the governmental activity or unit is reestablished again.

subsection.text: The term of office of a member of a unit under evaluation or responsible for a governmental activity under evaluation is not affected by reason of reestablishment of the governmental activity or unit unless the law that reestablishes the governmental activity or unit provides otherwise.
The termination of a governmental activity or unit or repeal of its statute in accordance with this subtitle is not a reason for dismissal of any claim or right of:

paragraph.text: the unit that is terminated or is responsible for the governmental activity that is terminated; or
any person against that unit.

subsection.text: The State shall assume these claims and rights.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Program Evaluation Act”.

subsection.text: A member of a State board or commission appointed by the Governor who fails to attend at least 50% of the meetings of the board or commission during any consecutive 12-month period shall be considered to have resigned.
Not later than January 15 of the year following the end of the 12-month period the chairman of the board or commission shall forward to the Governor:

paragraph.text: the name of the individual considered to have resigned; and
a statement describing the individual’s history of attendance during the period.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, after receiving the chairman’s statement the Governor shall appoint a successor for the remainder of the term of the individual.
If the individual has been unable to attend meetings for reasons satisfactory to the Governor, the Governor may waive the resignation if the reasons are made public.

paragraph.text: A member of a State board or commission shall be suspended without pay from participation in the activities of the board or commission if the member is convicted of or enters a plea of nolo contendere to any crime that:

subparagraph.text: is a felony; or
is a misdemeanor related to the member’s public duties and responsibilities and involves moral turpitude for which the penalty may be incarceration in any penal institution.

paragraph.text: The suspension shall continue during any period of appeal of the conviction.
If the conviction becomes final, the member shall be removed from the office and the office shall be deemed vacant.

subsection.text: If the conviction of the member is reversed or otherwise vacated:

paragraph.text: the member shall be reinstated to the office for the remainder, if any, of the term of office during which the member was so suspended or removed; and
all pay and benefits shall be restored from the date of the suspension or removal.

section.text: The official letterhead stationery of each department, agency, or instrumentality of the State shall include the telephone number of the individual public office that uses the stationery.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means a principal department of the Executive Branch of State government.
“Independent unit” means a unit in the Executive Branch of State government that is not in a department.
“Mask” means to redact from public view those portions of a public record that contain personal information, without permanently altering the original public record.

“Official custodian” means an officer or employee of the State who, whether or not the officer or employee has physical custody and control of a public record, is responsible for keeping the public record.
“Person in interest” means:

subparagraph.text: an individual that is the subject of personal information contained in a public record or a designee of the individual; or
if the individual has a legal disability, the parent or legal representative of the individual.

paragraph.text: “Personal information” means an individual’s:

subparagraph.text: Social Security number; or
driver’s license number.
“Public record” means the original or any copy of any documentary material that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is made by a unit or instrumentality of the State government or received by the unit in connection with the transaction of public business; and
is in any form, including:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: a card;
a computerized record;
correspondence;
a drawing;
film or microfilm;
a form;
a map;
a photograph or photostat;
a recording; or
a tape.

subparagraph.text: “Public record” includes a document that lists the salary of an employee of a unit or instrumentality of the State government.
“Public record” does not include a digital photographic image or signature of an individual, or the actual stored data thereof, recorded by the Motor Vehicle Administration.

paragraph.text: “Publicly post or display” means to intentionally make available to the public.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, on or after June 1, 2010, a department or an independent unit, to the extent practicable, may not publicly post or display on an Internet website maintained or paid for by the department or independent unit an individual’s personal information.

paragraph.text: A person in interest may request an official custodian to mask personal information in the Internet version of a public record.
A request made in accordance with this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing; and
provide an adequate description of the public record including a name and address or type and location of the public record.

paragraph.text: Within 30 days after receiving a request under this section, an official custodian shall:

subparagraph.text: mask the personal information in the Internet version of the record; and
give the person in interest written notice of the action taken.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to a public record after 72 years from the date it was made or received by a unit or instrumentality of the State government.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agency” means the State Lottery and Gaming Control Agency.
“Commission” means the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission.
“Director” means the Director of the Agency.
“Governmental unit” means:

paragraph.text: an instrumentality of the State;
a county or municipal corporation of the State; or
an instrumentality of a county or municipal corporation of the State.

subsection.text: “License” means a license issued by the Director to act as a licensed agent.
“Licensed agent” means a person or governmental unit licensed by the Director to act as a State lottery sales agent.
“State lottery” means the lottery established and operated under this subtitle.

section.text: Another law that prohibits the sale of lottery tickets or shares or other acts relating to a lottery does not apply to the State lottery.
There is a State Lottery and Gaming Control Agency.
There is a State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission in the Agency.

paragraph.text: The Commission consists of seven members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The presiding officer of either house of the General Assembly may recommend to the Governor a list of individuals for appointment to the Commission.
At the time of appointment, each member of the Commission shall be:

subparagraph.text: at least 25 years old;
a resident of the State who has resided in the State for at least 5 years;
a qualified voter of the State;
an individual who has not been convicted of or granted probation before judgment for a serious crime or a crime that involves moral turpitude or gambling; and
knowledgeable and experienced in fiscal matters and shall have substantial experience:

sub-subparagraph.text: as an executive with fiduciary responsibilities in charge of a large organization or foundation;
in an academic field relating to finance or economics; or
as an accountant, economist, or financial analyst, or as a professional in a similar profession relating to fiscal matters or economics.

paragraph.text: A member of the Commission may not:

subparagraph.text: have a direct or indirect financial interest, ownership, or management, including holding any stocks, bonds, or other similar financial interests in any gaming activities, including horse racing, video lottery terminals, table games, or lottery;
have an official relationship to a person who holds a license under Subtitle 1A of this title;
be an elected official of State or local government;
receive or share in, directly or indirectly, the receipts or proceeds of any gaming activities, including horse racing, video lottery terminals, table games, or lottery; or

have a beneficial interest in any contract for the manufacture or sale of gaming devices, the conduct of any gaming activity, or the provision of any independent consulting services in connection with any gaming establishment or gaming activity.

paragraph.text: No more than five members may be of the same political party.
The members of the Commission shall reflect the geographic, racial, and gender makeup of the State.
A member of the Commission shall file a financial disclosure statement with the State Ethics Commission in accordance with Title 15, Subtitle 6 of this article.
The term of a member is 5 years.

subparagraph.text: The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Commission on October 1, 2012.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member may not serve for more than two full terms.

paragraph.text: Subject to the hearing requirements of this subsection, the Governor may remove a member for cause.
Before the Governor removes a member, the Governor shall give the member notice and an opportunity for a public hearing.

subsection.text: The Governor shall appoint one member of the Commission to serve as a liaison to the State Racing Commission established under Title 11 of the Business Regulation Article.
The Commission shall include at least one member who resides in a local jurisdiction in which a video lottery facility is located.

section.text: From among its members, the Commission annually shall elect a chairman.

subsection.text: With the advice and consent of the Senate, the Governor shall appoint the Director of the Agency, who is the executive officer of the Agency and secretary of the Commission.
The Director serves at the pleasure of the Governor.
The Director must have the training and experience needed to direct the work of the Agency.
The Director shall devote full time to the duties of office and may not engage in another profession or occupation.
In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere in this subtitle, the Director shall have immediate supervision and direction over the Agency.
The Director is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: A majority of the full authorized membership of the Commission is a quorum.
The Commission may not act unless at least 4 members concur.

subsection.text: The Commission shall determine the times and places of its meetings.

paragraph.text: The secretary of the Commission promptly shall send the Governor a certified copy of the minutes of each meeting of the Commission.
The minutes shall include a copy of each regulation of the Agency that is adopted.
Each member of the Commission is entitled to:

subparagraph.text: the salary provided in the budget of the Commission; and
reimbursement for reasonable expenses:

sub-subparagraph.text: incurred in the performance of the Commission member’s duties; and
as provided in the budget of the Commission.

paragraph.text: Each member of the Commission shall be paid biweekly.
Each member is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the budget of the Commission.
With the advice of the Commission, the Director may employ deputy directors and other staff in accordance with the State budget.
Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection or otherwise by law, the staff of the Commission is in the State Personnel Management System.

A deputy director is in the executive service of the State Personnel Management System. However, a deputy director may be removed only for cause after being given notice and an opportunity for a hearing.

subparagraph.text: The Governor shall include in the State budget sufficient money for the Commission to hire, develop, and organize a staff to perform the functions of the Commission.
As deemed necessary by the Commission, the Commission shall hire experts including economists, gaming specialists, and lawyers.

sub-subparagraph.text: The Commission shall contract with an outside consultant to provide continual analysis of the gaming industry both within and outside the State and support the licensing activities of the Commission and the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission.
The cost of the consultant required under this subparagraph may be divided proportionally among the video lottery operation licensees as determined by the Commission.

subsection.text: In addition to the specific powers granted and duties imposed by this subtitle, the Commission has the powers and duties set forth in this section.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall conduct studies of the State lottery and gaming program to:

subparagraph.text: identify any defect in this subtitle, Subtitle 1A of this title, or the regulations of the Agency that may allow abuses in the operation and administration of the State lottery and gaming program or any evasion of this subtitle, Subtitle 1A of this title, or the regulations;
guard against the use of this subtitle, Subtitle 1A of this title, and the regulations of the Agency as a means of conducting organized crime;
ensure that the regulations of the Agency are proper and that this subtitle, Subtitle 1A of this title, and the regulations are administered to serve the purpose of this subtitle; and
analyze the gaming industry within and outside the State to determine whether Maryland’s gaming program is competitive and maximizing revenues for the State.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall conduct studies of:

subparagraph.text: the operation and administration of similar laws in other states or countries;
federal laws that may affect the operation of the State lottery or gaming activities;
literature on lotteries and gaming activities, including problem gambling programs; and
the reaction of citizens of the State to existing and potential features of the State lottery and gaming program.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall submit to the Governor and, subject to § 2–1246 of this article, to the General Assembly the reports required under this subsection.
The Commission shall submit monthly a report that states the total State lottery and gaming revenues and the total prize disbursements and other expenses for the preceding month.
The Commission shall submit annually a report that states the total State lottery and gaming revenues and the total prize disbursements and other expenses for the preceding year.
The Commission shall submit a report whenever a matter requires an immediate change in a State law to:

subparagraph.text: prevent an abuse or evasion of this subtitle, Subtitle 1A of this title, or a regulation of the Agency; or
rectify an undesirable condition in the operation or administration of the State lottery and gaming program.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Commission, the Director may adopt regulations of the Agency.
The regulations of the Agency shall provide for:

paragraph.text: all matters that are necessary or desirable for the efficient and economical operation and administration of the State lottery; and
the convenience of buyers of State lottery tickets and shares and of the holders of a winning ticket or share.

subsection.text: The Director shall:

paragraph.text: supervise and administer the State lottery in accordance with the regulations of the Agency and this subtitle;
confer, at least once a month, with the Commission on the operation and administration of the State lottery;
make available to the Commission any record or other information of the Agency that the Commission requests;
advise the Commission about any change needed to improve the operation or administration of the State lottery;
with the approval of the Commission and subject to Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article, contract for:

subparagraph.text: the operation of all or any part of the State lottery; and

the use of space, for advertising or promotional purposes, on tickets or publications distributed by the Agency, if, in the Director’s discretion, the action is fiscally prudent and in the best interest of the State lottery;

paragraph.text: submit monthly to the Comptroller and to the Commission a certified statement of the total State lottery revenues and the total prize disbursements and other expenses for the preceding month; and

with the approval of the Commission, contract for the promotion of the State lottery and enter into private sector cooperative marketing project agreements as provided for in § 11-203(a)(1)(xiv) of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Commission and the Legislative Policy Committee, the Director may enter into agreements to operate multijurisdictional lotteries with:

paragraph.text: any other political entity outside the State or outside the United States that operates a lottery; or
a private licensee of a state or a foreign nation.

subsection.text: The Commission may advise the Director on the operation and administration of the State lottery.
In accordance with the regulations of the Agency and this subtitle, the Director may:

paragraph.text: arrange for a person to perform any activity, function, or service in connection with the operation of the State lottery which shall constitute a lawful activity, function, or service of the person; and
authorize the Agency to sell lottery tickets for a temporary period at any promotional or special event being held in the State if:

subparagraph.text: in the Director’s determination, no licensed agent is available to conduct the sale; and
the person holding the promotional or special event has authorized the Agency to sell lottery tickets at the event.

subsection.text: In this section, “veterans’ organization” means an organization that is tax exempt and organized as a veterans’ organization under § 501(c)(19) or § 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code.

Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, in accordance with the regulations of the Agency and this subtitle, the Director shall issue licenses to the persons and governmental units that will best serve the public convenience and promote the sale of State lottery tickets or shares.
Before issuing a license to an applicant, the Director shall consider such factors as:

paragraph.text: the financial responsibility and security of the applicant and the business or activity of the applicant;
the accessibility of the place of business or activity to the public;
the sufficiency of existing licenses to serve the public convenience; and
the volume of expected sales.
This subsection does not apply in:

subparagraph.text: Caroline County;
Cecil County;
Dorchester County;
Kent County;
Montgomery County;
Queen Anne’s County;
Somerset County;
Talbot County;
Wicomico County; and
Worcester County.

Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the Director may issue a license under this subtitle for not more than five instant ticket lottery machines to an applicant that is a veterans’ organization.

A veterans’ organization that is issued a license under this subsection shall locate and operate its instant ticket lottery machines at its principal meeting hall in the county in which the veterans’ organization is located.

paragraph.text: After deduction of any commission and validation prize payout as provided under § 9–117 of this subtitle, a veterans’ organization issued a license under this subsection shall credit the remaining receipts from the sale of tickets from instant ticket lottery machines to the State Lottery Fund established under § 9–118 of this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a veterans’ organization issued a license under this subsection shall purchase or lease from the Agency the instant ticket lottery machines to be used by the veterans’ organization.

An organization may not use receipts from the sale of tickets from instant ticket lottery machines that would otherwise be credited to the State Lottery Fund for the costs of purchasing or leasing instant ticket lottery machines.

paragraph.text: The Director may adopt regulations to implement the provisions of this subsection that included restricting the location of instant ticket lottery machines in areas of a veterans’ organization’s public meeting hall that is accessible to the public.

The State Lottery and Gaming Control Agency shall ensure that the conduct of the gaming and the operation of the instant ticket lottery machines as established under this subsection are consistent with the holding in the case of Chesapeake Amusements Inc. v. Riddle, 363 Md. 16 (2001).

subsection.text: The Director may not issue a license to:

paragraph.text: a person or governmental unit to engage in business primarily as a licensed agent; or
an individual who is under the age of 21 years.

subsection.text: The Commission may hear and decide an appeal of a denial of a license.

section.text: A license authorizes the licensee to act as a State lottery sales agent while the license is effective.

subsection.text: The Director may require any lottery agent granted a license to post either an appropriate surety bond, irrevocable letter of credit, or cash security deposit in the amount that the regulations of the Agency set.

paragraph.text: In lieu of a surety bond, irrevocable letter of credit, or cash security deposit, the Agency, at the discretion of the Director, may provide a blanket bond covering all or selected agents in accordance with the availability of bonds and the financial status of an individual or a corporation.
A bond provided by the Agency shall be:

subparagraph.text: provided at the agent’s expense; and
based upon a financial evaluation of the agent conducted by the Director.

section.text: Each licensed agent shall display prominently the license or a copy of it, as the regulations of the Agency require.
The Commission may suspend or revoke a license, on the recommendation of the Director.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraphs (ii) and (iii) of this paragraph, a licensed agent shall receive regular commissions of 5.5% of the licensed agent’s gross receipts from ticket sales.
For fiscal year 2012 through December 31, 2012, only, a licensed agent shall receive regular commissions of 5.0% of the licensed agent’s gross receipts from ticket sales.

If a video lottery operation license for a video lottery facility in Baltimore City is issued, a licensed agent shall receive regular commissions of 6% of the licensed agent’s gross receipts from ticket sales.

paragraph.text: A licensed agent may further receive a cashing fee not to exceed 3% of valid prizes paid for services rendered in cashing winning tickets.
The Commission may authorize the payment of special bonuses or incentives to licensed agents and their employees.
The total of the bonuses and incentives may not exceed one–half of 1% of the gross receipts from ticket sales for the year for which the bonuses or incentives are awarded.
Lottery sales agents may not offer patrons inducements of alcoholic beverages to purchase or redeem lottery tickets.

subsection.text: Unless otherwise expressly provided by a lease for premises on which lottery tickets are sold, whenever lottery tickets are sold by a licensed agent on premises subject to rent that is wholly or partially based on a percentage of gross sales or receipts, the tenant responsible for payment of the rent may calculate that portion of the rent arising from the sale of lottery tickets solely on the basis of:

paragraph.text: the commission received by the licensed agent on the sale of those tickets; and
in the case of instant lottery tickets, the difference between the price paid by the licensed agent in purchasing the tickets from the Agency and the price for which they were sold by the agent.

subsection.text: There is a State Lottery Fund.
Except as otherwise specifically provided by law:

paragraph.text: the Agency shall account to the Comptroller for all of the revenue under this subtitle; and
the Comptroller shall credit the revenues to the State Lottery Fund.

subsection.text: A system of voucher deposits may be used for:

paragraph.text: payout of prizes;
payout of commissions; and
reimbursement for money paid out for prizes or commissions.

subsection.text: Except for the commission of a licensed agent, all of the receipts from the sale of State lottery tickets or shares are due to the Agency:

paragraph.text: on the due date that the Agency sets; or
at the times and within the intervals prescribed by Agency regulations.

subparagraph.text: The Director shall require all licensed agents to deposit, with a bank that the licensed agent selects and to the credit of the State Lottery Fund, all of the receipts from the sale of State lottery tickets or shares less any commission and validation prize payout.

sub-subparagraph.text: A licensed agent may commingle proceeds from the sale of State lottery tickets or shares with business receipts of the licensed agent.

Proceeds, including cash proceeds of the sale of any lottery products less any commission and validation prize payout, shall be remitted and paid directly or through the Agency’s authorized collection representative.

subparagraph.text: Licensed agents and each person who is a guarantor or indemnitor of a licensed agent’s financial obligations to the Agency shall be liable for all proceeds from the sale of lottery tickets or shares.
The Director may adjust the time, interval, or method of collection for collections of proceeds of any licensed agent.

sub-subparagraph.text: Nothing in this subsection may be construed to impose obligations or liability on any bank in which proceeds from the sale of State lottery tickets or shares are deposited.

This subparagraph does not affect the rights and obligations of any financial institution that has issued an irrevocable letter of credit or holds any cash security deposit as provided in § 9-114 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Director may require any or all licensed agents to submit to the Director or a designee of the Director a report that:

subparagraph.text: is in the form that the Director requires; and
gives the information that the Director requires as to the transactions in and receipts from the sale of State lottery tickets or shares.

paragraph.text: The Agency may impose a service charge if the payor bank dishonors:

subparagraph.text: a check that is given to the Agency by a licensed agent; or
an electronic transfer of funds to the State lottery account from the account of a licensed agent for money received from the sale of State lottery tickets or shares.

paragraph.text: The service charge under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be sufficient to cover the Agency’s costs associated with the dishonored return.
The Director shall adopt regulations specifying the costs and the methodology for determining the costs that are associated with a dishonored return.
The service charge imposed under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be in addition to any other fees or charges authorized to be charged under this article.

subsection.text: A licensed agent shall be charged:

paragraph.text: as provided in § 13-604(a) of the Tax - General Article, interest on the money that is not paid to the Agency within 10 days after the due date; and

if the Agency refers the debt to the Central Collection Unit of the Department of Budget and Management, an additional fee sufficient to cover administrative and collection costs, in an amount equal to any fee charged by the Central Collection Unit in accordance with § 3-304(a)(2) of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The amount, including any interest or penalty charge, due to the Agency from a licensed agent, as of the time that notice of the lien is filed:

subparagraph.text: is a lien on the property of that licensed agent; and
subject to paragraph (5) of this subsection, has the same effect as a judgment lien.

paragraph.text: The Agency shall:

subparagraph.text: file a notice of the lien with the clerk of the circuit court for the county where the property is located; and
mail a copy of the notice to the business address of the licensed agent.

paragraph.text: The clerk of court promptly shall enter in the judgment docket of the court:

subparagraph.text: the name of the licensed agent;
the amount of the lien; and
the date of the lien.

paragraph.text: Within 30 days after the lien is filed, the licensed agent may petition the court for a hearing as to the amount that is due to the Agency.
Until an officer of a court levies on personal property, the lien is not effective against an innocent buyer for value.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall distribute the State Lottery Fund to pay:

paragraph.text: on a pro rata basis for the daily and nondaily State lottery games, the expenses of administering and operating the State lottery, as authorized under this subtitle and the State budget; and
then, except as provided in § 10–113.1 of the Family Law Article and § 11–618 of the Criminal Procedure Article, the holder of each winning ticket or share.
