subparagraph.text: An application submitted for a video lottery operation license under this section shall provide for at least $25,000,000 in direct investment by the applicant in construction and related costs for each 500 video lottery terminals contained in the proposed application that shall be prorated based on the exact number of video lottery terminals contained in the application.

For an application submitted for a video lottery operation license in Allegany County, the purchase price for the Rocky Gap Lodge and Resort shall be counted in the calculation of the applicant’s direct investment under this paragraph, as determined by the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission.

paragraph.text: In awarding a video lottery operation license, the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission shall evaluate the factors under this subsection in the manner specified.
The decision by the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission to award a license shall be weighted by 70% based on business and market factors including:

subparagraph.text: the highest potential benefit and highest prospective total revenues to be derived by the State;
the potential revenues from a proposed location based on a market analysis;
the extent to which the proposed location encourages Maryland gaming participants to remain in the State;
the extent to which the proposed location demonstrates that the facility will be a substantial regional and national tourist destination;
the proposed facility capital construction plans and competitiveness of the proposed facility;
the amount of gross revenues to be allocated to the video lottery operator over the term of the license;
the percent of ownership by entities meeting the definition of minority business enterprise under Title 14, Subtitle 3 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
the extent to which the proposed location will preserve existing Maryland jobs and the number of net new jobs to be created; and
the contents of the licensee’s plan to achieve minority business participation goals in accordance with the requirements described under § 9–1A–10(a)(1) and (2) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The decision by the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission to award a license shall be weighted by 15% based on economic development factors, including:

subparagraph.text: the anticipated wages and benefits for new jobs to be created; and
any additional economic development planned in the area of the proposed facility.

paragraph.text: The decision by the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission to award a license shall be weighted by 15% based on location siting factors, including:

subparagraph.text: the existing transportation infrastructure surrounding the proposed facility location;
the negative impact, if any, of a proposed facility location on the surrounding residential community; and
the need for additional public infrastructure expenditures at the proposed facility.

paragraph.text: If an applicant is seeking investors in the entity applying for a video lottery operation license, it shall take the following steps before being awarded a license by the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission:

subparagraph.text: make serious, good–faith efforts to solicit and interview a reasonable number of minority investors;

as part of the application, submit a statement that lists the names and addresses of all minority investors interviewed and whether or not any of those investors have purchased an equity share in the entity submitting an application; and

if an applicant is awarded a license by the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission, the applicant shall sign a memorandum of understanding with the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission that requires the awardee to again make serious, good–faith efforts to interview minority investors in any future attempts to raise venture capital or attract new investors to the entity awarded the license.

paragraph.text: The Governor’s Office of Minority Affairs, in consultation with the Office of the Attorney General, shall provide assistance to all potential applicants and potential minority investors to satisfy the requirements under paragraph (1)(i) and (iii) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The Video Lottery Facility Location Commission may not award a video lottery operation license to a person that is not qualified under this section or this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Video Lottery Facility Location Commission shall refer to the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission the name and all relevant information concerning a person that makes an application under this section.

On receipt of the information in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission shall evaluate whether an applicant is qualified to hold a video lottery operation license under this subtitle.

On completion of its determination, the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission shall notify the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission of its evaluation as to whether an applicant is qualified to hold a video lottery operation license under this subtitle.

subsection.text: After an award of a video lottery operation license under this section, the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission shall notify the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission of the successful applicants.
After an award of a video lottery operation license under this section, the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission shall:

paragraph.text: issue the video lottery operation license; and
be responsible for all matters relating to regulation of the licensee.

An unsuccessful applicant for a video lottery operation license under this section may seek, under Title 15 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, review by the State Board of Contract Appeals of the awarding of the video lottery operation license by the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission.
A proceeding under this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: take precedence on the Board’s docket;
be heard at the earliest practicable date; and
be expedited in every way.

paragraph.text: Nothing in this subtitle may be construed to require the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission to award all six video lottery operation licenses authorized under this subtitle.

Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this subtitle, the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission may not award a video lottery operation license under this subtitle unless the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission determines and declares that an applicant selected for award of the license is in the public interest and is consistent with the purposes of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Video Lottery Facility Location Commission may award a video lottery operation license that is revoked or surrendered utilizing the criteria established in this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission shall terminate on January 1, 2015.

The Governor may reconstitute the Video Lottery Facility Location Commission, which shall include the appointment of new members based on the criteria established under subsections (b) and (c) of this section:

subparagraph.text: one year prior to the expiration of a video lottery operation license; or
following the revocation or surrender of a video lottery operation license.

paragraph.text: The Commission may consider and make recommendations on proposed changes to this subtitle, Subtitle 1 of this title, and any provisions of Article 2B of the Code that relate to the regulation of alcoholic beverages at video lottery facilities.

On request of the Governor or the presiding officer of either house of the General Assembly, the Commission shall consider and make recommendations on proposed changes to this subtitle, Subtitle 1 of this title, and any provisions of Article 2B of the Code that relate to the regulation of alcoholic beverages at video lottery facilities.

A video lottery facility may request that the Commission consider and make recommendations on proposed changes to this subtitle and any provisions of Article 2B of the Code that relate to the regulation of alcoholic beverages at video lottery facilities.
The Commission may recommend or propose legislation on any matter within or related to the jurisdiction of the Commission.
The Commission shall review and comment on any legislation introduced during a session of the General Assembly that relates to a matter within the jurisdiction of the Commission.

Subject to paragraphs (2) through (5) of this subsection, if a video lottery operation license is awarded to a video lottery facility in Prince George’s County, the Commission may increase for a video lottery facility located in:

subparagraph.text: Anne Arundel County, by not more than 2% of the proceeds from video lottery terminals at the video lottery facility, the percentage under § 9–1A–27(a)(8) of this subtitle; and
Baltimore City, by not more than 3% of the proceeds from video lottery terminals at the video lottery facility, the percentage under § 9–1A–27(a)(8) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If the Commission increases the percentage of proceeds from video lottery terminals for the video lottery facility in Anne Arundel County under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Commission shall increase the percentage of proceeds for the video lottery facility in Baltimore City by at least the same percentage point increase as for Anne Arundel County.

subparagraph.text: If a video lottery operation license is awarded to a video lottery facility in Prince George’s County, the Commission may increase for a video lottery facility in Cecil County, by not more than 5% of the proceeds from video lottery terminals at the video lottery facility, the percentage under § 9–1A–27(a)(2) of this subtitle.
Any increased distribution of video lottery terminal proceeds under this paragraph for a video lottery facility in Cecil County shall be used for:

sub-subparagraph.text: marketing, advertising, and promotional costs required under § 9–1A–23 of this subtitle; and
capital improvements at the video lottery facility.

subparagraph.text: On or before January 1, 2019, the Commission shall determine any adjustment authorized under paragraph (1) of this subsection to the percentage under § 9–1A–27(a)(8) of this subtitle or under paragraph (3) of this subsection.
Any adjustment authorized under this subsection may not take effect:

sub-subparagraph.text: until a video lottery operation license is issued to a video lottery facility in Prince George’s County; and
earlier than July 1, 2019.

paragraph.text: Before the Commission may make a determination on any adjustment under this subsection, the Commission shall report to the Governor and the General Assembly, in accordance with § 2–1246 of this article, on:

subparagraph.text: the impact on existing facilities from a video lottery facility located in Prince George’s County;
unexpected monetary gains to licensees from factors including the delayed opening of other facilities;
the monetary benefit to existing licensees from the removal of statutory or regulatory restrictions on video lottery operations;
increased revenue to licensees from the authorization of table games;
the impact of any adjustments to the Education Trust Fund;
the tax implications, if any, and cost of the ownership of the video lottery terminals by video lottery facilities; and
any other factors related to the gaming market in Maryland and the ability of the State gaming program to compete with surrounding states.

subsection.text: There is a Joint Committee on Gaming Oversight.

paragraph.text: The Committee consists of the following eight members:

subparagraph.text: four members of the Senate, appointed by the President of the Senate; and
four members of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House.

paragraph.text: At least one Senator and one Delegate appointed under this subsection shall be a member of the minority party.

subsection.text: The members of the Committee serve at the pleasure of the presiding officer who appointed them.
The President and the Speaker of the House shall appoint a Senator and a Delegate, respectively, to serve as cochairs.

paragraph.text: The Committee shall examine:

subparagraph.text: the status of the State’s gaming program; and
the implementation of new laws relating to gaming.

paragraph.text: The Committee shall make recommendations for potential improvements to the State’s gaming program.

subsection.text: The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staffing for the Committee.

A member of the Committee may not receive compensation for serving on the Committee, but is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
On or before December 31 of each year, the Committee shall report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of this article, the General Assembly.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commission” means the State Commission on Uniform State Laws.
“National Conference” means the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws.

section.text: There is a State Commission on Uniform State Laws in the Executive Department.

subsection.text: The Commission consists of:

paragraph.text: 3 members appointed by the Governor; and

as an ex officio member, any individual elected to life membership in the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws, after service as an appointed member of the Commission from this State.
The term of an appointed member is 4 years and begins on June 1 of the year in which the term of the Governor begins.
At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.
A member of the Commission may not receive compensation.

Members of the Commission and the associate member of the National Conference from the State are entitled to reimbursement for expenses incurred in the performance of their duties, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: In accordance with the State budget, the Commission may:

paragraph.text: employ a staff; and
make necessary expenditures.

section.text: The Commission may contribute to the expenses of the National Conference, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Commission shall:

paragraph.text: represent the State in the National Conference;
meet with representatives of other states in the National Conference;
draft uniform laws and model acts for submission to and adoption by the states;
recommend the best action to accomplish uniformity in legislation; and
otherwise seek the best means to obtain uniformity in the laws of the states.
Before each regular session of the General Assembly, the Commission shall submit an annual report:

subparagraph.text: to the Governor; and
subject to § 2-1246 of this article, to the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: The annual report shall:

subparagraph.text: describe the activities of the Commission; and
include recommendations on appropriate subjects.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Interdepartmental Committee” means the Interdepartmental Advisory Committee on Minority Affairs.

paragraph.text: “Minority person” means:

subparagraph.text: an individual who has been deprived of the opportunity to develop and keep a competitive position in the economy because of a social or economic disadvantage that arises from cultural, racial, or other similar causes; or
a sheltered workshop for individuals with disabilities.

paragraph.text: “Minority person” includes:

subparagraph.text: an Aleut;
an American Indian;
a Black;
an Eskimo;
a Hispanic;
an Oriental;
a Puerto Rican; or
a woman.

subsection.text: “Office” means the Office of Minority Affairs.
“Special Secretary” means the Special Secretary for the Office of Minority Affairs.

section.text: There is an Office of Minority Affairs in the Executive Department.

subsection.text: The head of the Office of Minority Affairs is the Special Secretary, who shall be appointed by and serves at the pleasure of the Governor.
The Special Secretary shall receive the salary provided in the State budget.
There is an Interdepartmental Advisory Committee for Minority Affairs.
The Interdepartmental Committee is composed of:

paragraph.text: the secretary of each principal department of the Executive Branch of government, or the secretary’s designee;
the State Superintendent of Schools, or the Superintendent’s designee;
the Secretary of Higher Education, or the Secretary’s designee; and
the Special Secretary.

subsection.text: The Interdepartmental Committee shall:

paragraph.text: advise the Special Secretary on proposals to implement and enhance the duties of the Office, including the promotion of employment of minority persons in the State, and the promotion of the growth and participation of minority business enterprises in the State;
gather such information the Committee deems necessary to promote the goals of the Office;
provide such other assistance as may be required to further the purposes of §§ 9-304 and 9-305 of this subtitle; and
meet at the call of the Special Secretary.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Office shall conduct necessary and appropriate research to determine the nature and extent of the problems concerning black males and offer recommendations exclusively pertinent to black males in the areas of:

paragraph.text: unemployment;
criminal justice;
education; and
health.

subsection.text: As authorized by the Governor, the Special Secretary may create an Advisory Committee on Black Males to assist and advise the Office in developing recommendations in accordance with subsection (a) of this section.

The Office shall submit its findings and recommendations in accordance with this section to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of this article, the General Assembly on or before January 1, 1995 and annually thereafter.

section.text: Subject to the limitations of any law that governs the activities of other units of the Executive Branch of the State government, the Special Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: advise the Governor on:

subparagraph.text: the activities of the State government that are intended to promote the employment of minority persons in the State; and
each other matter that affects the rights and interests of minority persons and the communities in which they live; and

paragraph.text: as authorized by the Governor:

subparagraph.text: provide help to minority persons and the communities in which they live;
represent the Governor in any matter that relates to minority persons or generally to the promotion of equality among the people of the State; and
perform any other responsibility that the Governor assigns.

subsection.text: This section applies to the following minority business enterprises:

paragraph.text: a publicly owned business if 1 or more minority persons own at least 51% of the stock of the business; or
any other business if 1 or more minority persons own at least 50% of the business.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations of any law that governs the activities of other units of the Executive Branch of the State government, the Special Secretary shall:

paragraph.text: carry out each State or federal program that is created to promote the growth of or participation in minority business enterprises;
promote and coordinate training regarding the requirements of the Minority Business Enterprise Program;

promote, coordinate, and participate in the plans, programs, and operations of the State government that promote or otherwise affect the establishment, preservation, and strengthening of minority business enterprises;
promote activities and the use of the resources of the State government, local governments, and private entities for the growth of minority business enterprises;
coordinate the effort of private entities and public agencies to develop minority business enterprises;
establish a system to develop, collect, summarize, and give out information that would help a person to:

subparagraph.text: establish a minority business enterprise;
operate a minority business enterprise successfully; or
promote the establishment and successful operation of minority business enterprises; and

paragraph.text: subject to the limitations of law and the availability of funds:

subparagraph.text: provide technical and managerial assistance to minority business enterprises;
provide the managerial and organizational framework for private entities and units of the State government to plan and carry out joint undertakings that relate to minority business enterprises; and
pay, wholly or partly, the costs of a pilot or demonstration project that is intended to overcome the special problems of minority business enterprises.

subsection.text: On or before the 15th day of each regular session of the General Assembly, the Special Secretary shall send an annual report on the Office of Minority Affairs:

paragraph.text: to the Governor; and
subject to § 2-1246 of this article, to the General Assembly.

subsection.text: The annual report may be prepared in conjunction with the report required under § 14-305(b) of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Commission” means the State Commission on the Capital City.
There is a State Commission on the Capital City.

subsection.text: The Commission consists of:

paragraph.text: one individual appointed by the Governor;
the Governor;
the State Senator who represents the legislative district in which Annapolis is located;
the Delegates who represent the legislative district in which Annapolis is located;
the County Executive of Anne Arundel County;
the Mayor of Annapolis; and
the Superintendent of the United States Naval Academy.
The term of the appointed member is 4 years.
At the end of a term, the appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

section.text: The appointed member shall serve as chairman of the Commission.
The Commission shall meet at a regular time and place to be determined by the Commission.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall study possible ways to preserve and improve Annapolis as the capital of the State, with particular emphasis on the location of State offices and buildings and county and city buildings.
As part of these studies, the Commission may:

subparagraph.text: inventory current residential, commercial, and governmental uses of land in Annapolis and adjacent areas;
study the landmark resources of Annapolis and adjacent areas;
study the relationship between the needs of governmental activities and the resources of the community; and
study the fiscal implications of:

sub-subparagraph.text: any program that the Commission investigates; and
any recommendation that the Commission supports.

subsection.text: The Commission may cooperate with public agencies to:

paragraph.text: develop plans for the physical development of Annapolis and adjacent areas; and
ensure adequate access to and transportation facilities for Annapolis and adjacent areas.

subsection.text: The Commission may make specific recommendations on the following community needs or projects in Annapolis and adjacent areas:

paragraph.text: arterial highways;
building codes;
economic development;
federal and State assistance programs;
housing;
industrial and commercial growth;
parking facilities;
space for public buildings;
traffic control;
urban renewal; and
any other community need or project that the Commission believes may improve:

subparagraph.text: the facilities and development of Annapolis and adjacent areas; and
the facilities and development of any unit of the State government.

paragraph.text: A study or recommendation of the Commission is advisory only.
The Commission may not require or compel the adoption or implementation of any recommendation.

section.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Commission:

paragraph.text: may accept money from a private or public agency for use in carrying out the powers and duties of the Commission; and
for that purpose, may give the money to a private or public agency or otherwise spend the money.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Trust” means the State House Trust.
There is a State House Trust.

paragraph.text: The Trust consists of the following 4 ex officio members:

subparagraph.text: the Governor;
the President of the Senate;
the Speaker of the House of Delegates; and
from the Maryland Historical Trust, the Chairman or the Chairman’s designee, who may be another trustee, the Director, or the State Historic Preservation Officer.

paragraph.text: The Trust may include not more than 3 associate members appointed by the members.
Each associate member must have experience and interest in historic preservation.
An associate member may not vote.

section.text: The Trust shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Trust shall:

paragraph.text: be responsible for the restoration and preservation of the State House; and
disapprove or approve and supervise:

subparagraph.text: any proposed repair, improvement, or other change to the State House or to any other building within State Circle, including any change to the furnishings or fixtures of those buildings; and
any proposed landscaping of the grounds of those buildings.

subsection.text: The Trust shall retain an architect as a consultant.
The consultant must:

paragraph.text: be registered by the State Board of Architects;
be familiar with all phases of 18th century architecture; and
have the professional experience that is needed to restore the State House in a way that befits its majestic history and its current role as the Capitol.

subsection.text: The consultant is entitled to the compensation provided in the State budget.
The consultant shall:

paragraph.text: prepare measured drawings of the State House;
publish the drawings and a descriptive text;
send copies of the drawings to the National Trust for Historic Preservation; and
subject to § 2-1246 of this article, submit to the General Assembly a report on the drawings.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Trust” means the Government House Trust.
There is a Government House Trust.

subsection.text: The Trust shall consist of the following voting members:

paragraph.text: the Governor;
the President of the Senate;
the Speaker of the House of Delegates;
the Secretary of General Services; and
the Director of the Maryland Historical Trust.

subsection.text: The Trust shall consist of the following advisor nonvoting members:

paragraph.text: the Director of the Baltimore Museum of Art;
the Director of the Maryland Historical Society;
the Director of the St. Mary’s City Commission;
the Director of the Talbot County Historical Society;
the Director of the Walters Museum of Art;
the Director of the Washington County Museum of Fine Arts;
the Chairman of the History Department of the University of Maryland, College Park;
the Horticulturist from the Paca House and Gardens;
the State Archivist; and
up to three members of the general public appointed by the Governor.

subsection.text: A voting or nonvoting member may designate another individual to represent the member at the Trust.

section.text: The Secretary of General Services is the Chairman of the Trust.

subsection.text: The Trust shall meet at least twice a year or as necessary as determined by the Trust.
A voting and nonvoting member of the Trust:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Trust may:

paragraph.text: adopt bylaws for the regulation of its affairs and the conduct of its business; and
appoint committees to carry out the purposes of the Trust.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “Furnishings” means personal property and fixtures.
“Furnishings” includes furniture, art objects, and accessories.

paragraph.text: “State room” means any of the following rooms of the Government House:

subparagraph.text: the center hall;
the conservatory;
the private reception room;
the State dining room;
the State drawing room;
the State parlour; and
the State reception room.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Trust shall:

paragraph.text: be responsible for the renovation of the State rooms, including their design and furnishings;
supervise and direct any improvement or other change in the internal design or furnishings of a State room;
be responsible for any proposed landscaping of the grounds of the Government House;
be responsible for the conservation and restoration of objects in a State room; and
be responsible for and carry out the maintenance of the State rooms.

subsection.text: The Department of General Services shall maintain an inventory of furnishings in the Government House.
In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Trust, on behalf of the State, may:

paragraph.text: accept and receive a gift or loan of property for use in a State room; and
accept and receive a gift of money for maintenance and restoration of a State room.

subsection.text: Unless the Trust approves, the internal design and furnishings of a State room may not be changed.
Before the renovation, furnishing, and decoration of a State room, the Trust shall consult with and obtain the input of the Board of Trustees and the Council of the Maryland Historical Society.
There is a Commission to Coordinate the Study, Commemoration, and Impact of Slavery’s History and Legacy in Maryland.
The purpose of the Commission is to:

paragraph.text: network museums, cultural organizations, cultural parks and centers, and private collections in order to support the cataloging, preservation, and presentation of cultural resources relative to the history and legacy of slavery in Maryland;

work with grass roots organizations, foundations, and government agencies in publicizing and seeking support for initiatives relating to the history and legacy of slavery, with special attention to the development of initiatives aimed at and benefitting Maryland youth;

target funding for the identification and maintenance of library and archival resources relevant to the history and legacy of slavery, in order to produce guides and maintain online databases of relevant holdings, especially holdings not appropriately cataloged and documented;
identify historical sites throughout the State that relate to the history and legacy of slavery and monitor the preservation and development of those sites;
keep the State informed of how best to support programs and initiatives to commemorate the middle passage, slavery, indentured servitude, and the underground railroad;
keep the State informed of the latest research on the lingering psychological, sociological, and economic impacts of slavery and its legacy, including the impact on crime and crime control; and

work cooperatively with private and public tourist agencies and organizations to oversee and monitor the allocation of public resources to sites and undertakings relating to the history and legacy of slavery in Maryland, and ensure that there is a fair allocation of resources for African American businesses and institutions.

subsection.text: The Commission consists of 11 members.
The membership of the Commission includes:

paragraph.text: one member of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President;
one member of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker;
the State Archivist or a designee of the State Archivist;
the Director of the Maryland Historical Trust; and
the following individuals, appointed by the Governor:

subparagraph.text: two historians who are knowledgeable about Maryland history, and particularly about the middle passage, slavery, Reconstruction, and the Jim Crow era;
two anthropologists or sociologists who are knowledgeable about African American culture and society;
two representatives of African American organizations; and
a member of the public, who shall serve as the chair of the Commission.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member of the Commission is 4 years.
The terms of the appointed members of the Commission are staggered as provided on October 1, 2000.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the remainder of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: A member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Commission; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Maryland Historical Trust and the State Archives shall provide for the staffing of the Commission.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Commission” means the Financial Education and Capability Commission.
There is a Financial Education and Capability Commission.

subsection.text: The Commission consists of the following members:

paragraph.text: two members of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate;
two members of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House;
the State Superintendent of Schools, or the Superintendent’s designee;
the Secretary of Housing and Community Development, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Commissioner of Financial Regulation in the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, or the Commissioner’s designee;
the Executive Director of the Family Investment Administration in the Department of Human Resources, or the Executive Director’s designee;
the Chief of the Consumer Protection Division of the Office of the Attorney General, or the Chief’s designee;
the State Treasurer, or the State Treasurer’s designee;
the Comptroller, or the Comptroller’s designee; and
the following members, appointed by the Governor:

subparagraph.text: one member of the Board of Trustees of the Maryland Teachers and State Employees Supplemental Retirement Plans;
one member of the College Savings Plans of Maryland Board;
one member of the Maryland Higher Education Commission;
one member of the Maryland State Education Association who teaches a course involving principles of financial education;
one representative of the Maryland CASH Campaign;
one representative of a community–focused nonprofit organization that provides free financial education in the State;
one representative of a philanthropic organization that provides funding for financial education in the State;
one representative of the Maryland Council on Economic Education or the Maryland Coalition for Financial Literacy;
one representative of a bank, whether or not State–chartered, that has a branch in the State;
one representative of a credit union, whether or not State–chartered, that has a branch in the State;
one licensed mortgage broker holding the Maryland Association of Mortgage Brokers’ “Lending Seal of Integrity”; and
one member of the Maryland Association of CPAs.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member of the Commission is 4 years.
The terms of the appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for appointed members of the Commission on October 1, 2012.
At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the remainder of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The President of the Senate shall designate one of the members appointed from the Senate as co–chair of the Commission.
The Speaker of the House of Delegates shall designate one of the members appointed from the House as co–chair of the Commission.

subsection.text: The Maryland CASH Campaign shall provide staff for the Commission.
A member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Commission; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Commission shall meet at least two times each year at the times and places determined by the Commission.
The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: monitor the implementation of public and private initiatives to improve the financial education and capability of residents of the State; and
make recommendations on the coordination of financial education and capability efforts across State agencies.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, on or before December 1 each year, the Commission shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of this article, the General Assembly on its recommendations and the status of efforts undertaken by State agencies or in partnership with State agencies to improve the financial education and capability of residents of the State.

Every 3 years, the report of the Commission required under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall include a comprehensive discussion of statewide efforts to improve the financial education and capability of residents of the State, including initiatives funded by the State or a local government and those undertaken in the private sector by nonprofit organizations, financial institutions, and other persons.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL SEPTEMBER 30, 2014 PER CHAPTERS 537 AND 538 OF 2009 //

subsection.text: There is a Commission on the Establishment of a Maryland Women in Military Service Monument.
The Commission consists of the following members:

paragraph.text: one member of the Senate of Maryland who serves on the Maryland General Assembly’s Veteran’s Caucus, appointed by the President of the Senate;
one member of the House of Delegates who serves on the Maryland General Assembly’s Veteran’s Caucus, appointed by the Speaker of the House;
the Secretary of Veterans Affairs or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of General Services or the Secretary’s designee; and
the following members, appointed by the Governor on or before September 1, 2009:

subparagraph.text: two representatives of the Maryland Veterans Commission; and
four representatives of women’s veterans organizations.

subsection.text: The members of the Commission shall elect the chair from among the Commission’s members.
The Department of Veterans Affairs shall provide staff for the Commission.
A member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Commission; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: refer to the “Report to the Governor and the General Assembly on Women Veterans Monument” submitted by the Task Force on the Establishment of a Maryland Women Veterans Monument on December 31, 2005;

monitor compliance with the recommendations made in reports of the Commission issued under Chapters 281 and 282 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 2006 regarding the funding, design, construction, and placement of an appropriate monument dedicated to women from Maryland who served in the uniformed forces of the United States of America; and
coordinate and monitor the effort to erect the Maryland Women in Military Service Monument described in item (2) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The Commission may enter into a written agreement or memorandum of understanding regarding the funding, design, construction, or placement of an appropriate monument with other government entities, including the federal government, a unit of State government, a county, or a municipality.

The Commission shall submit a final report on its activities, including a report on the status of the Maryland Women in Military Service Monument and any additional recommendations to the Governor and, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly on or before September 30, 2014.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of Veterans Affairs.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Veterans Affairs.

Except as otherwise provided in §§ 9-906 and 9-907 of this subtitle, “veteran” means an individual who served on active duty in the armed forces of the United States, other than for training, and was discharged or released under conditions other than dishonorable.
There is a Department of Veterans Affairs, established as a principal department of the State government.
The head of the Department is the Secretary of Veterans Affairs who shall be:

paragraph.text: a veteran who has an honorable discharge from active service with a uniformed service of the United States; and
appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.

The Secretary serves at the pleasure of the Governor and is responsible directly to the Governor. The Secretary shall advise the Governor on all matters assigned to the Department and is responsible for carrying out the Governor’s policies on these matters.
The Secretary is responsible for the operation of the Department and shall establish guidelines and procedures to promote the orderly and efficient operation of the Department.

Subject to the provisions of this subtitle, the Secretary may establish, reorganize, or consolidate areas of responsibility in the Department as necessary to fulfill the duties assigned by the Secretary.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations necessary to carry out the provisions of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Secretary is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.

section.text: The Attorney General is the legal adviser to the Department.

paragraph.text: The Department may:

subparagraph.text: establish service centers that the Department considers necessary or advisable to facilitate and expedite the servicing of claims of veterans and dependents; and
close any service center that the Department no longer considers necessary.

paragraph.text: The Department shall try to locate each service center centrally in the area to be served so that the greatest number of veterans:

subparagraph.text: have access with the least possible delay, travel, and inconvenience; and
receive, as far as possible, personal attention.

subsection.text: There shall be a Director of Veterans Service Centers responsible for the supervision of veterans service centers, whose duties shall include maintaining contact with the appropriate governmental unit regarding the status of each claim of a veteran or eligible dependent of a veteran.

section.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: help veterans and their dependents to receive promptly and regularly all of the benefits to which veterans or dependents are entitled under federal law;
help veterans and their dependents in:

subparagraph.text: preparing, in proper form, claims for benefits;
presenting the claims to the appropriate governmental unit;
trying to prevent and to relieve congestion in the processing of the claims; and
obtaining and expediting action on the claims; and

paragraph.text: on request, provide a veteran with a document certifying veteran status.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“State veterans’ cemetery” means a cemetery that the Department establishes under this section.
In this section and in § 9–907 of this subtitle, “veteran” means an individual who:

subparagraph.text: served other than dishonorably on active duty in the armed forces of the United States; or
served other than dishonorably as a member of the State militia ordered into active service of the United States by order of the President and was killed in the line of duty.

paragraph.text: “Washington Cemetery” means the Civil War cemetery grounds authorized by Chapter 213 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1870.

subsection.text: The Department may establish one or more cemeteries in the State for the burial of veterans and their eligible spouse or dependents as authorized by the Secretary.
The Department may accept land, on behalf of the State or a political subdivision of the State, or otherwise acquire land for a State veterans’ cemetery, if the Department has the approval of:

paragraph.text: the governing body of the county where the State veterans’ cemetery is to be located;
the delegation in the General Assembly for the county where the State veterans’ cemetery is to be located; and
the Board of Public Works.
The Department shall maintain and supervise each State veterans’ cemetery.
The Washington Cemetery shall be under the supervision of the Department.

subsection.text: The Department shall provide a plot in a State veterans’ cemetery, without charge, to a veteran who meets the requirements of this section.
To qualify for a plot in a State veterans’ cemetery:

paragraph.text: the applicant must be a veteran who meets the requirements for burial at a national veterans’ cemetery or an eligible spouse or dependent of a veteran who meets the requirements of this subsection; and
if a veteran, the veteran must also have been a resident of the State:

subparagraph.text: when the veteran entered the armed forces;
when the veteran died; or
for 2 years, unless, for a reason that the Department finds compelling, the Department waives the time period.

subsection.text: To obtain a plot in a State veterans’ cemetery, an applicant shall submit to the Department an application on the form that the Department provides.

paragraph.text: In a plot that is allotted to a veteran, the Department shall bury:

subparagraph.text: the veteran; and
any member of the immediate family who is an eligible spouse or dependent of the veteran if the family member can be buried in a space above or below the veteran or in the next available plot.
With each plot, the Department shall provide one grave liner.
For an eligible veteran, the Department shall pay for the grave liner.
For an eligible spouse or dependent, the grave liner shall be paid for by the family or estate.

paragraph.text: The Department shall bury the veteran without charge.
For burial of a member of the immediate family who is an eligible spouse or dependent, the Department may set a fee that does not exceed the cost of burial.

section.text: The Department shall keep a registry of the graves of veterans and family members of veterans who are buried in the State veterans cemeteries.

subsection.text: In this section, “veterans’ memorials and monuments” means:

paragraph.text: the Maryland Vietnam Veterans Memorial and Associated Land as established pursuant to Joint Resolution No. 22 of 1983;
the Maryland Korean War Memorial and Associated Land as established pursuant to Joint Resolution No. 3 of 1985; and
the Maryland World War II Memorial and Associated Land.

subsection.text: There is a Veterans’ Memorials and Monuments Program administered by the Department of Veterans Affairs.
The purpose of the Program is to provide for the operation, maintenance, security, and preservation of veterans’ memorials and monuments.
In furtherance of these purposes, the Department may, as provided for in the budget:

paragraph.text: lease land on behalf of the State or a political subdivision of the State; or
acquire land that has been improved by construction of a memorial or monument.

subsection.text: The Secretary may adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this section.

paragraph.text: The Department shall, as provided for in the budget, provide for the management of the veterans’ memorials and monuments as provided in this section.
The Department may delegate any of its powers and duties under this section to a special commission or board created by the Department and approved by the Governor.

subsection.text: The Department may acquire, hold, use, and improve property for the purposes specified in subsection (c) of this section.
Subject to Title 7 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, the Department may:

paragraph.text: accept gifts or grants;
unless otherwise provided, spend the principal and income of a gift or grant; and
invest all or part of the principal income in general obligations of the State or any other security.

section.text: “Home” means the home or homes for veterans that the Department supervises.

subsection.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: maintain and supervise generally the home in accordance with this subtitle; and
adopt any regulation that is needed for management of the home, including regulations for admission, maintenance, and discharge of its residents.
The Department may appoint a Director for the home and employ any other staff that is needed to manage the home properly.
In appointing or employing staff, the Department shall give preference to a veteran who has an honorable discharge from the armed forces.
The Director shall:

subparagraph.text: serve at the pleasure of the Secretary; and
perform any duty that the Department requires.

subsection.text: In accordance with the regulations of the Department and applicable law, the home shall be open:

paragraph.text: to a veteran who:

subparagraph.text: has an honorable discharge from the armed forces; and
is a resident of the State as defined in regulations adopted by the Secretary; or

paragraph.text: to a spouse of an eligible veteran.
The Department may charge an individual a reasonable fee for residence in the home.

The Department shall set the fee in accordance with the ability of an individual to pay. However, the fee may not exceed the cost of maintaining the resident in the home and shall allow the resident enough money for necessary and incidental expenses.

subsection.text: A resident may be discharged in accordance with the regulations of the Department and applicable law.
To carry out the responsibilities and goals of the Department, the Department may acquire, hold, use, improve, and convey property.
In addition to any other power under this section and subject to Title 7 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, to carry out the purposes or goals of the Department, the Department may:

paragraph.text: accept a gift or grant; and
unless the terms of a gift or grant require otherwise, and subject to the approval of the Secretary:

subparagraph.text: spend the principal and income of the gift or grant through grants or loans to:

sub-subparagraph.text: veterans and their families;
public and private programs that support veterans and their families; or
any other programs that the Secretary considers appropriate; or

subparagraph.text: invest all or part of the principal and income in:

sub-subparagraph.text: general obligations of the State; or
any other security.

paragraph.text: Gifts and grants that the Department accepts under subsection (b) of this section shall be deposited in the Maryland Veterans Trust Fund under § 9–913 of this subtitle.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations to implement a program for gifts and grants made under subsection (b)(2) of this section.

In addition to any other power under this section, the Department may lease any part of the home property for use as a concession or other commercial purpose that is consistent with the purposes of the Department. However, the Department may not lease its property merely for investment purposes.
Notwithstanding any other law, unless the lease expressly provides for redemption by the tenant, the lease is not subject to redemption.

subsection.text: Subject to Title 7 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, to carry out the purposes or goals of the Department, the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home may:

paragraph.text: accept a gift or grant for use at the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home; and
unless the terms of a gift or grant require otherwise, and subject to the approval of the Secretary, spend the principal and income of the gift or grant for use at the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home.

subsection.text: Gifts and grants that the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home accepts under subsection (a) of this section for use at the Home:

paragraph.text: shall be administered by the Director of the Veterans Home Program; and
are not subject to reversion under § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

On or before July 31 of each year, the Director of the Veterans Home Program shall submit a report to the Secretary on the status of the gifts and grants accepted for use at the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home.

On or before August 31 of each year, the Secretary shall submit a report to the General Assembly, in accordance with § 2–1246 of this article, on the status of the gifts and grants accepted for use at the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home.
The reports required under this subsection shall include the following information on the gifts and grants accepted for use at the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home during the previous fiscal year:

subparagraph.text: the gross amount of the gifts and grants;
the costs of administration of the gifts and grants; and
a detailed accounting of the use of the gifts and grants.

subsection.text: In this section, “Fund” means the Maryland Veterans Trust Fund.
There is a Maryland Veterans Trust Fund in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The State Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately, and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.
The Secretary shall administer the Fund.
The Maryland Veterans Commission, the Maryland Veterans’ Home Commission, and program directors shall advise the Secretary on the administration of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: gifts and grants that the Department receives under § 9–912(b) of this subtitle; and
contributions to the Fund from the sale of tickets from instant ticket lottery machines under § 9–112(d) of this title.

subsection.text: Money in the Fund may only be used to:

paragraph.text: make grants and loans under § 9–912(b)(2)(i) of this subtitle;
be invested under § 9–912(b)(2)(ii) of this subtitle; and
pay the costs of administering the Fund through distribution to an administrative cost account in the Department.
The State Treasurer shall invest the money in the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be credited to the Fund.

subsection.text: Money expended from the Fund is supplemental to and is not intended to take the place of funding that would otherwise be appropriated to the Department.

paragraph.text: On or before August 31 of each year, the Secretary shall submit a report to the General Assembly, in accordance with § 2–1246 of this article, on the status of the Fund.
The report shall include:

subparagraph.text: the gross amount of gifts and grants credited to the Fund;
the costs of administration of the Fund; and
a detailed accounting of the use of the Fund.

section.text: In this Part II of this subtitle, “Commission” means the Maryland Veterans Commission.
There is a Maryland Veterans Commission in the Department that shall advise the Secretary of all matters pertaining to veterans issues.

paragraph.text: The Commission consists of the following members appointed by the Governor.
Of the members:

subparagraph.text: 1 shall be appointed from each of the 8 congressional districts in the State;
1 shall be a veteran appointed from the State at large;
1 shall be a woman veteran appointed from the State at large;
1 shall be a representative of a retired enlisted organization;
1 shall be a veteran of the Iraq or Afghanistan conflict, as defined in § 1–202(a–1) of the Public Safety Article;
1 shall be appointed from a list of individuals submitted to the Governor by each of the following organizations:

sub-subparagraph.text: the American Ex–Prisoners of War, Inc.;
the American Legion;
the Amvets;
the Catholic War Veterans;
the Disabled American Veterans;
the Fleet Reserve Association;
the Jewish War Veterans;
the Marine Corps League;
the Maryland Military Officers Association of America;
the Military Order of the Purple Heart;
the Polish Legion of American Veterans;
the Veterans of Foreign Wars;
the Vietnam Veterans of America;
the Korean War Veterans Association, Inc.;
the National Association for Black Veterans; and
the Colonial Chapter of the Paralyzed Veterans of America; and

subparagraph.text: 1 shall be an honorary nonvoting member appointed from a list of individuals submitted to the Governor by the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association.

subsection.text: Each member must be a resident of the State and a veteran.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member is 5 years.
The terms of the appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Commission on October 1, 1984.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
When an organization is no longer a part of the Commission, the appointment shall terminate at the end of the current member’s term.

subsection.text: A new organization may not be eligible for representation on the Commission, by appointment of the Governor, unless it is congressionally chartered.
From among the members of the Commission, the Governor shall appoint a chairman.
A vice chairman shall be elected by a simple majority vote of the Commission.
The Commission shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
A member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
if the Commission approves, is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Department shall provide staff support to the Commission in accordance with the State budget.

section.text: There is a Maryland Veterans’ Home Commission in the Department.

subsection.text: The purpose of the Maryland Veterans’ Home Commission is to advise the Department of issues related to State veterans homes.
The General Assembly declares the purpose of the Maryland Veterans’ Home Commission to be of general benefit to the veterans of the State.

section.text: This Part III of this subtitle does not limit any power or activity of:

paragraph.text: a unit of the State government;
a political subdivision of the State; or
any person who is interested in veterans in the State.

subsection.text: The Veterans’ Home Commission consists of the following 14 members:

paragraph.text: 11 individuals appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate; and
as ex officio members:

subparagraph.text: the Governor;
the President of the Senate; and
the Speaker of the House of Delegates.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member is 5 years.
The terms of the appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Veterans’ Home Commission on October 1, 1984.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: As far as is practicable and is consistent with the purposes and goals of the Veterans’ Home Commission, the Governor shall choose appointed members so as to have a broad distribution from among:

paragraph.text: veterans and veterans’ organizations; and
the geographical areas of the State.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Veterans’ Home Commission shall elect a chairman, a secretary, and any other officers that the Commission considers appropriate.
The manner of election of officers and their terms of office shall be as the Veterans’ Home Commission determines.
Seven members of the Veterans’ Home Commission are a quorum to do business.

paragraph.text: The Veterans’ Home Commission shall meet:

subparagraph.text: at least twice a year, at the times and places that it determines; and
at the call of the Chairman, on the Chairman’s initiative or on the request of at least 4 members.

paragraph.text: Unless all of the members of the Veterans’ Home Commission agree otherwise, the secretary of the Commission shall give each member at least 7 days’ written notice of a meeting.
If the President is unable to attend a meeting, the President may designate a Senator or an employee of the General Assembly to represent the President at the meeting.
If the Speaker is unable to attend a meeting, the Speaker may designate a Delegate or an employee of the General Assembly to represent the Speaker at the meeting.
If the Governor is unable to attend a meeting, the Governor may designate another individual to represent the Governor at the meeting.

subsection.text: A member of the Veterans’ Home Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Secretary, the Veterans’ Home Commission may adopt procedures to:

paragraph.text: govern itself; and
carry out the responsibilities of the Veterans’ Home Commission.

subsection.text: The Commission:

paragraph.text: may not incur any expenses without the consent of the Department; and
at each regular meeting of the Commission or more often as it directs, shall submit to the Department a report on any action that the Commission has taken since its last report.
The Veterans’ Home Commission shall through the Department submit an annual report:

subparagraph.text: to the Governor; and
subject to § 2-1246 of this article, to the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: The annual report shall:

subparagraph.text: describe the activities of the Commission; and
include any recommendations for furthering the purposes of the Commission.

subsection.text: As far as practicable, the Veterans’ Home Commission shall cooperate with persons and public agencies to carry out the purposes and goals of the Commission and Department.

section.text: The State is not obligated to provide capital or operating funds for the Veterans’ Home Commission but may appropriate money for the purposes and goals of the Commission.
In this Part IV of this subtitle, “Commission” means the War Memorial Commission.
There is a War Memorial Commission in the Department of Veterans Affairs.

paragraph.text: The Commission consists of 10 members.
Of the 10 Commission members:

subparagraph.text: 5 shall be appointed by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, with the approval of the Governor; and
5 shall be appointed by the Mayor of Baltimore City.

subsection.text: Each member must be a Maryland war veteran.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 5 years.
The terms of a member are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Commission on October 1, 1984.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Commission may elect:

paragraph.text: a chairman;
a vice chairman; and
a secretary and a treasurer or a secretary-treasurer.

subsection.text: The manner of election of officers and their terms of office shall be as the Commission determines.
A member of the Commission may not receive compensation.

If the Commission approves the reimbursement and records the vote in the minutes, a member is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

section.text: The State and Baltimore City jointly shall hold title to the War Memorial Building and the memorial site.

subsection.text: The Commission may provide for management of the War Memorial Building as provided in this section.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall adopt regulations that provide for the management of the War Memorial Building in a manner that:

subparagraph.text: permits the greatest possible use of the building by the people of the State and by patriotic organizations in the State; and
to the extent possible, permits the use by the patriotic organizations without cost.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall enforce the regulations.

subsection.text: The Commission may appoint a custodian and a janitor for the War Memorial Building.
The Commission may use, for the maintenance and administration of the building, any funds that the General Assembly or the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore appropriate for those purposes.
In this part, “Program” means the Outreach and Advocacy Program.
There is an Outreach and Advocacy Program in the Department.
The purpose of the Program is to ensure that:

paragraph.text: veterans are informed of the services, benefits, and assistance available to them from the State and federal government; and
general issues relating to veterans needs are brought to the attention of the Governor and the General Assembly in order for them to be addressed.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall appoint a director for the Program.
The director is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.
The director shall administer and coordinate the Program.
The Outreach and Advocacy Program shall actively help veterans and their dependents become aware of and access any service or benefit to which they are entitled including:

paragraph.text: tax benefits;
health care benefits;
disability benefits;
pension benefits; and
education.

subsection.text: The director of the Program shall:

paragraph.text: support veterans and their dependents through the service or benefit process; and
keep in contact with the appropriate governmental unit as to the status of each claim of a veteran, a veteran’s dependent, or a veteran’s survivor.

For the purposes of reaching any veteran, veteran’s dependent, or veteran’s survivor in need of assistance in obtaining services or benefits granted by the law, the director shall develop and implement an outreach plan.
In order to carry out the director’s responsibilities under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the director may:

subparagraph.text: enter into contracts; and

work with governmental units and community–based organizations, including the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, the Department of Aging, faith–based groups, veterans groups, senior centers, adult day care centers, institutions of higher education, and other entities the director considers appropriate.

paragraph.text: The director shall develop mechanisms for outreach to be disseminated by direct mail and through community–based veterans organizations, the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Department of Human Resources, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, and any other State agency or unit the director considers appropriate.
The mechanisms for outreach shall include:

subparagraph.text: the development of a pamphlet describing the services provided by the Outreach and Advocacy Program;
a regular newsletter;
brochures describing various benefits or any other issue or benefit of interest to veterans or their dependents; and
other measures the director considers appropriate.

subsection.text: The Department shall develop and maintain a database of veterans in the State.

The Department, in conjunction with the types of community–based organizations listed in subsection (a)(2) of this section, shall develop a survey to assist in identifying veterans and dependents who may be eligible for pension programs.
The Program shall:

paragraph.text: in conjunction with other governmental units and community–based groups, seek out veterans and their dependents who may be eligible for pension program benefits; and
provide wounded or disabled veterans with information on available services and benefits and support in obtaining these services and benefits.

section.text: The Secretary shall submit a report by December 31 of each year to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of this article, the General Assembly, that includes:

paragraph.text: the number of:

subparagraph.text: requests for help in obtaining benefits; and
veterans, veterans’ dependents, and veterans’ survivors helped by the Outreach and Advocacy Program by category;

paragraph.text: the benefits obtained through the Outreach and Advocacy Program by category;
the average length of time it takes to process benefit requests and for a recipient to access health benefits;
the average amount of disability and pension benefits received by qualified individuals in this State compared to individuals in other states;
a detailed description of the outreach plan in the Outreach and Advocacy Program;
an account of the costs of operating the Outreach and Advocacy Program;
a status of the accomplishments for, efficacy of, efficiency of, and level of resources available for each of the following programs:

subparagraph.text: cemetery;
memorial;
service;
veterans homes; and
outreach and advocacy;

paragraph.text: a general assessment of the status of veterans in the State;
the estimated impact current military operations are likely to have on the needs of veterans in the future;
the status of federal veterans programs as they relate to Maryland veterans; and
any other issues concerning veterans that the Secretary considers appropriate.

subsection.text: In this Part I of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Archives” means the State Archives.
“Commission” means the Hall of Records Commission.
There is a State Archives in the office of the Governor.
There is a Hall of Records Commission.

section.text: The Commission consists of the following 11 members:

paragraph.text: the Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals;
a member of the Senate appointed by the President of the Senate;
a member of the House of Delegates appointed by the Speaker of the House;
the Comptroller;
the Treasurer who may appoint, as the Treasurer’s designee, a deputy treasurer;
the Secretary of General Services;
the President of The Johns Hopkins University or a designee;
the President of the Maryland Historical Society;
the President of the St. John’s College or a designee;
the Chancellor of the University System of Maryland or a designee; and
the President of the Morgan State University or a designee.

subsection.text: The Commission shall meet at least quarterly at the times and places that the Commission determines.
A member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Archives shall provide staff services for the Commission.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall be an advisory body for the Archives.
The Commission shall review and comment on:

subparagraph.text: the proposed budget of the Archives;
all proposed publications of the Archives; and
all proposed policies pertaining to the use of the Archives by the public.

paragraph.text: After consultation with the Commission, the Governor shall appoint a competent, qualified individual as State Archivist.
The Archivist shall:

subparagraph.text: be knowledgeable in subjects relevant to archival activities; and
possess experience in archival or related fields.

subsection.text: The State Archivist is entitled to a salary as provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: The State Archivist may appoint an Assistant State Archivist.
The Assistant State Archivist has the powers and duties of the State Archivist:

subparagraph.text: to the extent delegated by the State Archivist;
if the office of the State Archivist is vacant; and
if for any other reason the State Archivist is unable to perform the duties of office.

subsection.text: The State Archivist may employ other staff in accordance with the State budget.
In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the State Archivist may:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations to:

subparagraph.text: govern the Archives;
manage the Hall of Records Building and other real and personal property that the Archives acquires;
manage the records under the supervision of the Archives; and
define the categories of records in the report of the Records Management Division under § 10–634 of this article;

paragraph.text: have a seal; and
on request, or at the State Archivist’s discretion, review, evaluate, and make recommendations to the General Assembly regarding State designations under Title 13 of this article.

subsection.text: At the request of the President of the Senate, the Speaker of the House, the Chair of the Senate Education, Health, and Environmental Affairs Committee, or the Chair of the House Health and Government Operations Committee, the State Archivist shall review, evaluate, and make recommendations to the General Assembly regarding State designations under Title 13 of this article.

paragraph.text: The State Archivist may establish reasonable fees for the care and preservation of records and other services provided by the Archives.
Fees may be in the form of:

subparagraph.text: a percentage not to exceed 2% of an existing fee charged at the time of the creation of a record in any form or format; or
a flat rate subscription charge for a publication of the Archives.

paragraph.text: Of the fees collected, 7% shall be deposited in the Archives Endowment Account of the State Archives Fund established under § 9–1013 of this subtitle as an educational and entrepreneurial reserve.

subsection.text: The State Archivist shall submit to the Governor and, subject to § 2–1246 of this article, to the General Assembly an annual report on the activities of the Archives and the Commission during the preceding fiscal year.
The State Archivist may:

paragraph.text: determine, in consultation with the Commission, the types of records and other information that the Archives will accept for safekeeping; and
acquire, as a gift or with money appropriated or given to the Archives for that purpose:

subparagraph.text: any record or other material that, in consultation with the Commission, the State Archivist considers worthy of preservation; and
other real or personal property.

subsection.text: The State Archivist:

paragraph.text: shall supervise and control the use of the State Hall of Records Building;
may equip and furnish the Building in accordance with law; and

subject to Title 2, Subtitles 4 and 5, Title 4, Subtitles 7 and 8, §§ 8–127, 8–128, and 8–129, Part V of Title 8, Subtitle 1, Title 10, Title 12, Subtitle 2, and §§ 13–219 and 13–221 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, shall supervise and control the use of any other real or personal property that the State acquires for use of the Archives.

subsection.text: The State Archivist shall provide the Commissioner of Land Patents with space in the State Hall of Records Building.
The Archives may:

paragraph.text: repair and preserve the records under the supervision of the State Archivist, as provided in the State budget;
make a copy of any record in the Archives; and
certify the copy.

subsection.text: The Archives may publish, electronically or in print, indices to records, descriptions, summaries of record material, or original record material, in whole or in part, that are not otherwise restricted from access under existing law.
The Archives shall index or provide other finding aids for:

paragraph.text: the historical records acquired under § 9–1010 of this subtitle; and
the land records in its custody under § 9–1011 of this subtitle.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Archives may charge a reasonable fee for providing a copy of a record and for certifying the record.

If, with the written approval of a judge of a circuit court, the clerk of court asks for a copy of a land record that a court has transferred to the Commission or Archives, the Archives shall provide, without charge, a micrographic copy of the land record.

subsection.text: The Archives:

paragraph.text: shall collect public and private records and other information that relate to the history of the province and State of Maryland from the earliest times, including church records and newspapers;
may edit and publish these records; and
shall encourage research into the history of the State.

subsection.text: Any records and materials that relate to the history of Maryland and are not needed for the operation of a unit belong to the Archives and shall be under the supervision of the State Archivist.
The Archives is the central depository for and custodian of each deed, title insurance policy, and other record that relates to real property acquired by the State.
The Archives may allow a unit of the State government to have custody of an original record that relates to real property acquired by the State, if the unit:

paragraph.text: needs the record for the daily operation of the unit;
demonstrates to the Archives that the unit will preserve the record adequately; and
deposits with the Archives a security microform copy of the record.

The Archives shall receive, index, and file durable-backed, microfilm aperture card copies or electronic images of plats showing property or rights-of-way acquired or conveyed by the State Roads Commission and the State Highway Administration.

subparagraph.text: The Archives electronically shall post an image of each plat on the Archives website (http://www.plats.net) for the county where the property or right-of-way is located.
The posted image shall conform to a generally accepted archival standard in quality and permanence.
The image shall include or be linked to a certification by the State Archivist that the image is an authentic representation of the plat received by the Archives.
Such certification by the State Archivist shall constitute a recordation of the plat.

The Archives may charge a reasonable fee to the State Roads Commission, the State Highway Administration, and the courts to recover the cost of electronically posting and maintaining the images of plats.
The Archives may charge a reasonable fee, not to exceed $3, to the public for the cost of reproducing a copy of a plat under this subsection.

subsection.text: The Archives may allow a unit of local government or its designee to have custody of an original local record if the unit or designee:

paragraph.text: demonstrates that the unit or designee will preserve the record adequately; and
deposits with the Archives or permits the Archives to make a security microform copy of the record.

subsection.text: The Archives may not destroy a local record unless the Archives:

paragraph.text: offers the record to the appropriate local government or its designee; and
the government or designee declines to accept the record.

subsection.text: There is a State Archives Fund.
The Comptroller shall credit to the State Archives Fund any money that:

paragraph.text: is appropriated or given to the Archives for publication of the series known as “The Archives of Maryland”;
