“Installed electricity generation capacity” means the maximum direct current power output in watts of the array of photovoltaic modules rated under standard test condition.

“Photovoltaic property” means solar energy property with an installed electricity generation capacity of 20 kilowatts or less that uses a solar photovoltaic process to generate electricity and that meets applicable performance and quality standards and certification requirements in effect at the time of acquisition of the property, as specified by the Maryland Energy Administration.
“Program” means the Solar Energy Grant Program.

subparagraph.text: “Solar energy property” means equipment that uses solar energy:

sub-subparagraph.text: to generate electricity;
to heat or cool a structure or provide hot water for use in a structure; or
to provide solar process heat.

subparagraph.text: “Solar energy property” does not include a swimming pool, hot tub, or any other energy storage medium that has a function other than storage.

paragraph.text: “Solar water heating property” means solar energy property that:

subparagraph.text: when installed in connection with a structure, uses solar energy for the purpose of providing hot water for use within the structure; and
meets applicable performance and quality standards and certification requirements in effect at the time of acquisition of the property, as specified by the Maryland Energy Administration.

subsection.text: There is a Solar Energy Grant Program in the Administration.

The purpose of the Program is to provide grants to individuals, local governments, and businesses for a portion of the costs of acquiring and installing photovoltaic property and solar water heating property.
The Administration shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Program;
establish application procedures for the Program; and
award grants from the Program.

subsection.text: A grant awarded under the Program may not exceed:

paragraph.text: for photovoltaic property, the lesser of $2,500 per kilowatt of installed electricity generation capacity or $10,000; and
for solar water heating property, the lesser of $3,000 or 30% of the total installed cost of the solar water heating property.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in subsection (e) of this section, the Administration may adjust the grant amounts under the Program to reflect market conditions and the prevailing prices of photovoltaic property and solar water heating property.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Geothermal heat pump” means a heating and cooling device that is installed using ground loop technology.
“Program” means the Geothermal Heat Pump Grant Program.
“Ton” means 1 standard ton of refrigeration equal to 12,000 British thermal units of heat removal per hour.

subsection.text: There is a Geothermal Heat Pump Grant Program in the Administration.
The purpose of the Program is to provide grants to individuals for a portion of the cost of acquiring and installing a geothermal heat pump.
The Administration shall:

paragraph.text: administer the Program;
establish application procedures for the Program; and
award grants from the Program.

subsection.text: A grant awarded under the Program may not exceed the lesser of:

paragraph.text: $1,000 per ton or $3,000 for a residential system; and
$1,000 per ton or $10,000 for a nonresidential system.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in subsection (e) of this section, the Administration may adjust the grant amounts under the Program to reflect market conditions and the prevailing prices of geothermal heat pump systems.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means the Maryland Energy Administration.
“Borrower” means an eligible local jurisdiction, nonprofit organization, or eligible business that applies and qualifies for a loan under this Program.
“Eligible business” means a commercial enterprise or business:

paragraph.text: that is incorporated in the State; or
whose principal owners are State residents and the business of which is principally carried out in the State.

subsection.text: “Energy cost savings” means the actual reduction in operating expenses resulting from the improved energy efficiency generated by an energy conservation project financed under the Program.
“Fund” means the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Fund.

paragraph.text: “Local jurisdiction” means any county or municipality of the State.
“Local jurisdiction” includes:

subparagraph.text: a board of education of a county or municipality;
a special district that is established by State law and that operates within a single county;
a special district that is established by a county under public general law; and
an office, board, or department that is established in a county under State law and that is funded, under State law, at least in part by the county governing body.

subsection.text: “Municipality” means any municipal corporation in the State that is subject to the provisions of Article XI–E of the Maryland Constitution or any duly authorized agency or instrumentality of the municipality.

“Nonprofit organization” means a corporation, foundation, school, hospital, or other legal entity, no part of the net earnings of which inure to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual holding an interest in the entity.
“Program” means the Jane E. Lawton Conservation Loan Program.

paragraph.text: “Project” means:

subparagraph.text: one or more improvements or modifications that enhance the energy efficiency and reduce the operating expenses of a structure; or
installation of infrastructure for renewable energy generation by local jurisdictions and nonprofit organizations.

paragraph.text: “Project” includes:

subparagraph.text: start–up opportunities for new businesses if the loan would enhance the energy efficiency of the borrower’s business;
installation of equipment to make buildings self–sustaining and of emergency generating units that use renewable energy resources; and
implementation of methane removal at landfills.

paragraph.text: “Project” does not include improvements or modifications for energy conservation or renewable energy generation in structures used primarily for religious or fraternal activities.

subsection.text: “Renewable energy resource” has the meaning stated in § 1–101 of the Public Utilities Article.

section.text: There is a Jane E. Lawton Conservation Loan Program in the Administration.
The purpose of the Program is to provide financial assistance in the form of low interest loans to nonprofit organizations, local jurisdictions, and eligible businesses for projects in order to:

paragraph.text: promote:

subparagraph.text: energy conservation;
the development and use of renewable energy resources in the State;
self–sustaining buildings and emergency generating units that use renewable energy resources; and
the infrastructure for renewable energy generation in the State;

paragraph.text: reduce consumption of fossil fuels;
improve energy efficiency; and
enhance energy–related economic development and stability in business, commercial, and industrial sectors.

section.text: The Administration shall:

paragraph.text: manage, supervise, and administer the Program;
adopt regulations to ensure that loans are provided only to projects that carry out the purpose of the Program;
attach specific terms to any loan that are considered necessary to ensure that the purpose of the Program is fulfilled; and

develop procedures for monitoring projects to assess whether the improvements or modifications made by an eligible entity or business that had received a loan under the Program have resulted in a measurable reduction in energy consumption.
To receive a loan under the Program, a borrower must file an application with the Administration.
If the borrower is an eligible business, the application must be signed by the chief operating officer or an authorized officer of the business.

If the borrower is a local jurisdiction, the application must be signed by the chief elected officer of the county or municipality, or if none, by the governing body of the county or municipality in which the project is located.
If the borrower is a public school, the application must be signed by the board of education of the county in which the project is located.

subsection.text: The application shall contain any information the Administration determines is necessary, including:

paragraph.text: the projected cost to accomplish a proposed project;
if applicable, the amount of energy or fuel a proposed project is expected to save over a defined period of time after completion of the project;
the anticipated environmental benefits in the form of reduced emissions or pollution attributable to the proposed project;
the amount of cost savings expected to be generated over a defined period of time after completion of the proposed project;
a description of the borrower’s contribution to a proposed project as required by § 9–20A–06 of this subtitle; and
any additional information relating to the borrower or the proposed project that may be required by the Administration in order to administer the Program.

subsection.text: Loans from the Fund may be used for:

paragraph.text: the costs of implementing projects, including the costs of all necessary:

subparagraph.text: technical assessments;
studies;
surveys;
plans and specifications; and
start–up, architectural, engineering, or other special services;

paragraph.text: the costs of procuring necessary technology, equipment, licenses, or materials; and
the costs of construction, rehabilitation, or modification, including the purchase and installation of any necessary machinery, equipment, or furnishings.

subsection.text: Each borrower shall make a contribution to a project that is of a type and amount acceptable to the Administration.

If the sole or primary purpose of the project is to reduce energy consumption, the borrower must document that the anticipated energy cost savings over a defined period after the completion of the project are greater than the cost of the project.
Loans made under the Program shall:

paragraph.text: be repayable by the borrower from specified revenues that may include the energy cost savings generated by a project;
bear interest at a rate that the Administration determines to be necessary and reasonable for the project; and
be repayable in accordance with a schedule that the Administration sets, which may be on a deferred payment basis.
A borrower shall provide assurances for the repayment of a loan.
The assurances:

subparagraph.text: shall include a promissory note; and
may include superior or subordinate mortgage liens, guarantees of repayment, or other forms of collateral.

subsection.text: Loans may be made in conjunction with, or in addition to, financial assistance provided through other State or federal programs.

paragraph.text: A loan under the Fund may be deposited into a revolving loan fund of a county’s economic development commission if the county approves the transaction and project for the local jurisdiction.

If a county accepts a loan under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the funds deposited from the Fund may be used only for purposes of providing capital for renewable energy infrastructure projects under this subtitle.

subsection.text: There is a Jane E. Lawton Conservation Fund.
The Administration shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The State Treasurer shall hold the Fund and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the Program;
money received from any public or private source;
interest and investment earnings on the Fund; and
repayments and prepayments of principal and interest on loans made from the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund may be used only:

paragraph.text: to pay the expenses of the Program; and
to provide loans to eligible borrowers and projects.
The State Treasurer shall invest and reinvest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be paid into the Fund.
Any repayment of principal and interest on loans made from the Fund shall be paid into the Fund.
The Administration shall annually reserve a portion of the money from the Fund that is available for financial assistance under the Program for loans to nonprofit organizations.

In a fiscal year in which requests for financial assistance from nonprofit organizations are less than the amount of money reserved under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Administration may make the unencumbered or noncommitted portion of the reserve available to other borrowers in the Program.

section.text: The Administration may enter into contracts with third parties to make, service, or settle loans made under this subtitle.

subsection.text: A project implemented by a local jurisdiction financed by a loan from the Fund, such as a self–sustaining emergency generating unit, that generates electricity in excess of the amount needed for sustaining the unit may offer the extra electricity for trade through markets operated by PJM Interconnection, LLC.
A local jurisdiction that trades electricity under subsection (a) of this section shall use the proceeds to repay its loan obligations under this subtitle.
A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made any false statement or report in any document required to be furnished to the Administration by any agreement relating to financial assistance.

A person applying for financial assistance may not knowingly make or cause to be made any false statement for the purpose of influencing any action of the Administration on an application for financial assistance or for the purpose of influencing any action of the Administration affecting financial assistance already provided.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $50,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means the Maryland Energy Administration.
“Board” means the Strategic Energy Investment Advisory Board established under § 9–20B–07 of this subtitle.
“Fund” means the Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Fund.
“Program” means the Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Program.

section.text: There is a Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Program in the Maryland Energy Administration.
The purpose of the Program is to decrease energy demand and increase energy supply to promote affordable, reliable, and clean energy to fuel Maryland’s future prosperity.
The Administration shall:

paragraph.text: manage, supervise, and administer the Program;
adopt regulations to implement the Program and to ensure that Fund resources are utilized only to carry out the purposes of the Program;
attach specific terms and conditions to any grant, loan, or other form of assistance that are determined by the Administration as necessary to ensure that the purposes of the Program are fulfilled;
develop procedures for monitoring programs, projects, activities, and investments to verify that Fund resources are being used to meet the purposes of the Program; and

provide moneys annually or as needed to the Clean Air Fund managed by the Department of the Environment to fund the costs of the Department’s programs to reduce or mitigate the effects of climate change.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Strategic Energy Investment Fund.
The purpose of the Fund is to implement the Strategic Energy Investment Program.
The Administration shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: all of the proceeds from the sale of allowances under § 2–1002(g) of the Environment Article;
money appropriated in the State budget to the Program;
repayments and prepayments of principal and interest on loans made from the Fund;
interest and investment earnings on the Fund;
compliance fees paid under § 7–705 of the Public Utilities Article; and
money received from any public or private source for the benefit of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Administration shall use the Fund:

paragraph.text: to invest in the promotion, development, and implementation of:

subparagraph.text: cost–effective energy efficiency and conservation programs, projects, or activities, including measurement and verification of energy savings;
renewable and clean energy resources;
climate change programs directly related to reducing or mitigating the effects of climate change; and
demand response programs that are designed to promote changes in electric usage by customers in response to:

sub-subparagraph.text: changes in the price of electricity over time; or
incentives designed to induce lower electricity use at times of high wholesale market prices or when system reliability is jeopardized;

paragraph.text: to provide targeted programs, projects, activities, and investments to reduce electricity consumption by customers in the low–income and moderate–income residential sectors;

to provide supplemental funds for low–income energy assistance through the Electric Universal Service Program established under § 7–512.1 of the Public Utilities Article and other electric assistance programs in the Department of Human Resources;
to provide rate relief by offsetting electricity rates of residential customers, including an offset of surcharges imposed on ratepayers under § 7–211 of the Public Utilities Article;
to provide grants, loans, and other assistance and investment as necessary and appropriate to implement the purposes of the Program as set forth in § 9–20B–03 of this subtitle;
to implement energy–related public education and outreach initiatives regarding reducing energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions; and
to pay the expenses of the Program.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (g–1) of this section, proceeds received by the Fund from the sale of allowances under § 2–1002(g) of the Environment Article shall be allocated to the following accounts:

paragraph.text: 17% shall be credited to an energy assistance account to be used for the Electric Universal Service Program and other electricity assistance programs in the Department of Human Resources;

except as provided in subsection (g–2) of this section, 23% shall be credited to a rate relief account to provide rate relief by offsetting electricity rates of residential customers, including an offset of surcharges imposed on ratepayers under § 7–211 of the Public Utilities Article, on a per customer basis and in a manner prescribed by the Public Service Commission;

at least 46% shall be credited to a low and moderate income efficiency and conservation programs account and to a general efficiency and conservation programs account for energy efficiency and conservation programs, projects, or activities and demand response programs, of which at least one–half shall be targeted to the low and moderate income efficiency and conservation programs account for:

subparagraph.text: the low–income residential sector at no cost to the participants of the programs, projects, or activities; and
the moderate–income residential sector;

paragraph.text: up to 10.5% shall be credited to a renewable and clean energy programs account for:

subparagraph.text: subject to subsection (i) of this section, renewable and clean energy programs and initiatives;
energy–related public education and outreach; and
climate change programs; and

paragraph.text: up to 3.5%, but not more than $4,000,000, shall be credited to an administrative expense account for costs related to the administration of the Fund, including the review of electric company plans for achieving electricity savings and demand reductions that the electric companies are required under law to submit to the Administration.

subsection.text: The proceeds described in subsection (g) of this section from the allowances sold between March 1, 2009, and June 30, 2012, shall be allocated as follows:

paragraph.text: up to 50% shall be credited to an energy assistance account to be used as described in subsection (g)(1) of this section;
23% shall be credited to a rate relief account to be allocated as provided in subsection (g)(2) of this section;

at least 17.5% shall be credited to a low and moderate income efficiency and conservation programs account and to a general efficiency and conservation programs account to be allocated as provided in subsection (g)(3) of this section;
at least 6.5% shall be credited to a renewable and clean energy programs account to be allocated as provided in subsection (g)(4) of this section; and
up to 3.0%, but not more than $4,000,000, shall be credited to an administrative expense account to be allocated as provided in subsection (g)(5) of this section.

subsection.text: Subsection (g)(2) of this section does not apply to residential customers of a small rural electric cooperative, as defined in § 1–101 of the Public Utilities Article.

paragraph.text: Energy efficiency and conservation programs under subsection (g)(3) of this section include:

subparagraph.text: low–income energy efficiency programs;
residential and small business energy efficiency programs;
commercial and industrial energy efficiency programs;
State and local energy efficiency programs;
demand response programs;
loan programs and alternative financing mechanisms; and
grants to training funds and other organizations supporting job training for deployment of energy efficiency and energy conservation technology and equipment.

paragraph.text: Energy–related public education and outreach and renewable and clean energy programs and initiatives under subsection (g)(4)(i) and (ii) of this section include:

subparagraph.text: production incentives for specified renewable energy sources;
expansion of existing grant programs for solar, geothermal, and wind programs;
loan programs and alternative financing mechanisms; and
consumer education and outreach programs that are designed to reach low–income communities.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, compliance fees paid under § 7–705(b) of the Public Utilities Article may be used only to make loans and grants to support the creation of new Tier 1 renewable energy sources in the State.

Compliance fees paid under § 7–705(b)(1)(ii) of the Public Utilities Article shall be accounted for separately within the Fund and may be used only to make loans and grants to support the creation of new solar energy sources in the State.
The Treasurer shall invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be paid into an administrative expense account within the Fund.
Any repayment of principal and interest on loans made from the Fund shall be paid into the Fund.
Balances in the Fund shall be held for the benefit of the Program, shall be expended solely for the purposes of the Program, and may not be used for the general obligations of government.

subsection.text: Expenditures from the Fund shall be made by:

paragraph.text: an appropriation in the annual State budget; or
a budget amendment in accordance with § 7–209 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: An expenditure by budget amendment may be made under subsection (k) of this section only after:

paragraph.text: the Administration has submitted the proposed budget amendment and supporting documentation to the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee, Senate Finance Committee, House Appropriations Committee, and House Economic Matters Committee; and
the committees have had 45 days for review and comment.

subsection.text: On or before December 15, 2008, the Administration shall develop a plan for expenditures from the Fund for fiscal year 2009 and fiscal year 2010.
On or before September 1, 2009, and every 3 years thereafter, the Administration shall develop a plan for expenditures covering the next 3 fiscal years.

paragraph.text: The Administration shall hold one or more public meetings in conjunction with the development of a plan.
The Administration:

subparagraph.text: shall hold at least four public meetings across the State during the development of the initial plan under subsection (a) of this section, in the eastern, southern, central, and western parts of the State, respectively; and
is encouraged to solicit input from all regions of the State in developing subsequent plans under this section.

paragraph.text: The Administration shall submit a plan to the Board for review.

subsection.text: There is a Strategic Energy Investment Advisory Board.

paragraph.text: The Board shall review the Program and the Administration’s proposed uses of and expenditures from the Fund and make recommendations to the Administration concerning any proposed use or expenditure.
The Administration shall consider the Board’s recommendations when making decisions about uses and expenditures from the Fund.

subsection.text: The Board consists of the following members:

paragraph.text: one member of the Senate, appointed by the President of the Senate;
one member of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House of Delegates;
the following members appointed by the Governor:

subparagraph.text: two representatives of Maryland residential customers;
a representative of Maryland commercial customers;
a representative of large electricity users in the State;
a representative of an electric company;
a representative of an electric cooperative;
a representative of electricity suppliers;
a representative of a Maryland environmental group; and
a representative of a renewable electricity industry; and

paragraph.text: the following nonvoting ex officio members:

subparagraph.text: the Chairman of the Public Service Commission or the Chairman’s designee;
the People’s Counsel or the designee of the People’s Counsel; and
the Secretary of the Environment or the Secretary’s designee.

subsection.text: If a regulated lobbyist is appointed to serve as a member of the Board, the lobbyist:

paragraph.text: is not subject to § 15–504(d) of this article with respect to that service; and
is not subject to § 15–703(f)(3) of this article as a result of that service.
The term of a member appointed by the Governor is 3 years.
The terms of the members appointed by the Governor are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on June 1, 2008.
The Board shall meet at least 2 times each year.
The Board may act only by the affirmative vote of at least six voting members.
A member of the Board:

subparagraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Administration shall provide staff support for the Board.
The Administration regularly shall disclose summary information regarding any contract entered into by the Administration that encumbers $100,000 or more from the Fund.
For each of the contracts specified under subsection (a) of this section, the following information shall be posted on the Administration’s website on a quarterly basis:

paragraph.text: the name and business address of the parties of the contract;
a summary of the goods and services to be provided under the contract; and
the maximum amount of moneys from the Fund that may be obligated by the contract.

subsection.text: The Administration shall monitor and analyze the impact of each program, project, activity, and investment to ensure that the outcome of each program, project, activity, or investment achieves the purposes of the Program.

In monitoring and analyzing the impact of a program, project, activity, or investment under subsection (a) of this section, if the Administration finds that the outcome of the program, project, activity, or investment is not achieving the purposes of the Program, the Administration shall take specific measures to address the findings.

section.text: The Administration may enter into contracts with third parties to assist in the development and implementation of programs and projects that will advance the purposes of the Program or to administer the Program, including contracts with third parties to make, service, or settle loans and other assistance or investments made through the Program.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made any false statement or report in any document required to be furnished to the Administration by any agreement relating to a grant, loan, or other financial assistance.

A person applying for a grant, loan, or other financial assistance through the Program may not knowingly make or cause to be made any false statements for the purpose of influencing any action of the Administration on an application or for the purpose of influencing any action of the Administration affecting any grant, loan, or other financial assistance already provided.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $50,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or both.

On or before January 1 of each year, the Administration shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of this article, to the General Assembly on the uses and expenditures of the Fund from the prior fiscal year.
The report shall include:

paragraph.text: a detailed accounting of all amounts received by and disbursed from the Fund;
all amounts used by the Administration for administrative purposes;
programs, projects, and activities included in each category under § 9–20B–05(g) of this subtitle;

the status of programs, projects, activities, and investments implemented with funds from the Fund, including an evaluation of the impact of the programs, projects, activities, and investments that are directed to low–income or moderate–income residential sectors or to other particular classes of ratepayers;
an estimate of electricity savings from the programs, projects, activities, and investments;
the number of allowances sold in each auction;
the average allowance price from each auction;
an estimate of revenue from future auctions; and
recommendations for changes to the allocation of funds under § 9–20B–05(g) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Application service provider” means an entity that provides access to or deployment of business software applications and services over the Internet.
“ASP” means application service provider.
“Board” means the CEO Board of Advisors for E-Commerce.
“Consortium” means the “eMaryland” ASP Consortium.
“E-commerce” means electronic business and commerce.

section.text: The CEO Board of Advisors for E-Commerce and the “eMaryland” ASP Consortium are established under this subtitle to assist in the State’s efforts to create the most advanced electronic business environment in the nation and become an international leader in the deployment of new Internet technologies.

subsection.text: There is a CEO Board of Advisors for E-Commerce.

paragraph.text: The Board may not exceed 12 members and shall be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate and serve at the pleasure of the Governor.
Each member of the Board serves for a period of 3 years and may be reappointed.
The Governor shall designate two representatives of State government to serve as ex officio members of the Board.
The members appointed by the Governor shall be industry leaders who have substantial experience and expertise in electronic commerce.
The Governor shall designate a chairman or cochairmen from among the members.
The Board shall meet at least twice annually.

subsection.text: The Board shall:

paragraph.text: advise the Governor on economic development policies and initiatives to advance the promotion, deployment, and use of e-commerce in the State;
recommend ways to improve the State’s position as an international leader of e-commerce; and
provide policy guidance to the “eMaryland” ASP Consortium and related ASP initiatives.

subsection.text: A member of the Board may not receive compensation as a member but is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations as provided in the State budget.
The Department of Budget and Management and University of Maryland, College Park shall provide staff support to the Board.
There is an “eMaryland” ASP Consortium at the University of Maryland, College Park.

paragraph.text: The general purpose of the Consortium is to promote the deployment of Internet–based technologies in Maryland.
The Consortium shall develop strategic partnerships with the State, institutions of higher education, federal agencies, and world class technology companies to carry out its mission.
The Consortium shall:

subparagraph.text: develop pilot models for the deployment of Internet–based applications for government and educational institutions, such as procurement, financial, and human resource management applications;
participate in collaborations to promote the development and testing of ASP technologies in Maryland;
provide advice and assistance to small start–up companies wishing to utilize ASP technologies; and
work with industry and public agencies to research and develop emerging e–commerce technologies.

paragraph.text: There is a management committee for the Consortium.
The management committee is responsible for approving the activities of the Consortium and providing direction and oversight.
The management committee shall be composed of:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary of Information Technology;
the Chief Information Officer at the University of Maryland, College Park;
the Director of the Supply Chain Management Center at the University of Maryland, College Park;
the Executive Director of the Maryland Technology Development Corporation; and
a member appointed by the Governor.

subsection.text: The definitions in § 1-101 of this article do not apply to the interstate compact set forth in § 9-2303 of this subtitle.

In the interstate compact set forth in § 9-2303 of this subtitle, unless the context clearly requires otherwise, “article”, “section”, and “subsection” mean an article, section, and subsection, respectively, of the interstate compact.

section.text: On behalf of this State, the Governor shall execute, with the City of Baltimore, the Commonwealth of Virginia, and the District of Columbia, an interstate compact substantially as it appears in § 9-2303 of this subtitle.

The Commonwealth of Virginia, the State of Maryland, the District of Columbia, and the City of Baltimore, hereinafter “Signatories,” hereby enter into an interstate compact, as set forth below, for the purpose of hosting the 2012 Olympic Games. This interstate compact shall be known and may be cited as the Chesapeake Regional Olympic Games Authority Act.
The Maryland General Assembly finds that:

subsection.text: For some time now, the State of Maryland (including the City of Baltimore), the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Virginia, through the nonprofit organization known as the Washington/Baltimore Regional 2012 Coalition (WBRC 2012), have been actively engaged in national competition to win the U.S. Candidate City designation and, subsequently, the Host City designation and the right to host the 2012 Olympic Games.
Hosting the Olympic Games will provide several major, lasting, and unique benefits for all of the citizens of the Chesapeake region, including:

paragraph.text: Direct, positive economic impact on our regional economy;
An opportunity to showcase our region to the world;
A catalyst for regional action; and
A renewed sense of pride along with a tangible legacy (e.g. new and improved venues and enhanced transportation infrastructure).

subsection.text: Independent economic studies show that preparing for and hosting the Olympic Games will have a positive economic impact on the region, including:

paragraph.text: Direct and indirect spending in excess of $5,000,000,000;
The creation of approximately 70,000 jobs;
Increased tax revenues resulting from Olympic related economic activity in excess of $130,000,000, without raising or creating any new taxes; and
A lasting improvement in the region’s competitive position within the travel/tourism industry, as well as the region’s ability to attract new businesses.

subsection.text: The citizens of the region have responded positively to WBRC 2012’s efforts and solidly embraced the cause to host the Olympic Games, expressed in part by the endorsement of scores of local business, civic, governmental, academic, and amateur sports organizations, and by survey results that show:

paragraph.text: 82% of the region’s residents support the effort to bring the 2012 Olympic Games to this area; and
86% of area residents believe that the Olympic Games will bring substantial economic benefits to our region.

subsection.text: Through the submission of the region’s official bid proposal to the United States Olympic Committee (USOC) on December 15, 2000, WBRC 2012 reached a milestone in the process of capturing the Olympic Games by providing a 631-page logistical, operational, and financial blueprint for hosting the 2012 Games.
The bid proposal highlights the great venues and vistas found in our region and is developed around key principles, including:

paragraph.text: Building less, not more;
Utilizing mass transit; and
Protecting the environment.

subsection.text: In addition to the region’s bid proposal, the USOC and the International Olympic Committee (IOC) require certain government guarantees and commitments in conjunction with hosting the 2012 Olympic Games, should our region win the U.S. Candidate City designation.
Our unique regional approach to winning the right to host the Olympic Games creates the added complication of determining which entities will provide the necessary guarantees.

It is incumbent upon WBRC 2012 and government leaders to move forward together now to craft the solution that best “lives regionalism” and maximizes the region’s chances of winning the 2012 Olympic Games, and reaping the many benefits that come with this honor.

Given that all four jurisdictions - Virginia, Maryland, the District of Columbia, and Baltimore - will host a significant number of events and reap substantial benefits, the most effective solution for all four jurisdictions is to enter into a single agreement that gives the USOC (and subsequently the IOC) a single focal point and a united front that reflects the regional nature of our bid.

section.text: The purpose of this Act is to create a Regional Authority to oversee the conduct of the 2012 Olympic Games, coordinated and managed by the local Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games (OCOG), and to assure that the region’s guarantees and commitments accepted in conjunction with hosting the Olympic Games are fulfilled.
For the purposes of this Act, the term:

subsection.text: “Bid proposal” shall mean the bid formally submitted by WBRC 2012 to the USOC on December 15, 2000;
“Host City” shall mean the entity which has been selected by the International Olympic Committee to host the 2012 Olympic Games;

“International Olympic Committee” and “IOC” shall mean the International Olympic Committee, a body corporate under international law created by the Congress of Paris of 23rd June, 1894, and having perpetual succession;

“Olympic Games” shall mean any Olympic Games sponsored and governed by the International Olympic Committee and any other educational, cultural, athletic, or sporting events related or preliminary thereto;

“Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games,” and “OCOG” shall mean the Committee formed by WBRC 2012 to organize and conduct the Olympic Games, if WBRC 2012 is selected by the IOC as the “Host City” in 2005;
“Regional Authority” shall mean the Chesapeake Regional Olympic Games Authority;
“Signatories” shall mean the Commonwealth of Virginia, the State of Maryland, the District of Columbia, and the City of Baltimore;
“United States Olympic Committee” and “USOC” shall mean the United States Olympic Committee, incorporated by Act of Congress on September 21, 1950, and having perpetual succession;

“U.S. Candidate City” shall mean the entity which has received the United States Olympic Committee’s endorsement to submit to the IOC the sole bid from the United States for the hosting of the 2012 Olympic Games; and
“WBRC 2012” shall mean Washington/Baltimore Regional 2012 Coalition, a not for profit corporation organized under the laws of the State of Maryland, and its successors.

section.text: The Signatories hereby provide the mechanism for the creation and termination of the “Chesapeake Regional Olympic Games Authority,” hereinafter “Regional Authority,” which shall be an instrumentality of the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Virginia, the State of Maryland, and the City of Baltimore, and shall have the powers and duties set forth herein, and those additional powers and duties conferred upon it by subsequent actions of the Signatories:

subsection.text: The Regional Authority shall come into existence by the force of this Act when and if, and only if, the IOC awards the 2012 Olympic Games in year 2005 to WBRC 2012, as the U.S. Candidate City and the official representative of the Maryland, Virginia, District of Columbia, and Baltimore region; and

The Regional Authority shall, if ever brought into existence, cease to exist by the force of this Act on January 1, 2014, unless extended by substantially similar future legislation enacted by each of the Signatories; and

Until such time as the Regional Authority may be triggered into existence, the combined signatures of the Governors of Virginia and Maryland, and the Mayors of the District of Columbia and the City of Baltimore, on any and all documents necessary and appropriate to the pursuit of the 2012 Olympic Games shall be deemed binding on future actions of the Regional Authority. For the purposes of this subsection:

paragraph.text: The above referenced signatures may be on the same document, on separate but materially and substantially similar documents, or any combination thereof; and
No individual signature shall be deemed effective until such time as all four above referenced signatures are obtained.

subheading1.text: Regional Authority Composition; Terms of Service; Order of Business; Accounting.

paragraph.text: The Regional Authority shall be composed of 11 “voting members,” as follows:

subparagraph.text: The State of Maryland shall be entitled to three voting members, to be appointed by the Governor;
The Commonwealth of Virginia shall be entitled to three voting members, to be appointed by the Governor;
The District of Columbia shall be entitled to three voting members, to be appointed by the Mayor;
The City of Baltimore shall be entitled to one voting member, to be appointed by the Mayor; and

The Washington/Baltimore Regional 2012 Coalition, a not for profit corporation created for the sole purpose of bringing the Olympic Games to the region, or the OCOG, shall be entitled to one voting member, to be appointed in a manner consistent with its usual procedure;

paragraph.text: The Regional Authority shall cause to be formed a Regional Authority Advisory Committee, which shall be comprised of representatives (“advisory members”) from each of the local jurisdictions substantially impacted by hosting the Olympic Games in the region, in a manner to be determined by the Regional Authority;
Reasonable efforts should be made to ensure that appointments of voting members and advisory members:

subparagraph.text: Are residents of the regional community with relevant and useful experience, and with sufficient time to devote to the duties of the Regional Authority, to help facilitate the successful hosting of the Olympic Games;
Reflect the geographical diversity inherent in the regional nature of WBRC 2012’s bid proposal; and
Reflect the cultural, ethnic, and racial diversity inherent in the Chesapeake Region; and

paragraph.text: Voting members shall not be financially compensated for their service on the Regional Authority; such service shall be considered voluntary. Voting members may be reimbursed by the Regional Authority for normal and customary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties.

subsection.text: The terms of the voting members of the Regional Authority shall be as follows:

paragraph.text: The initial terms of office of the voting members shall be 2 years from the date of appointment, and all subsequent terms of office of the voting members shall be for 2 years. Each voting member shall hold office until his or her successor shall be appointed and duly qualified. Any voting member of the Regional Authority may succeed himself or herself; and

All vacancies in the membership of the voting members of the Regional Authority, whether caused by expiration of term of office, death, resignation, or otherwise, shall be filled in the same manner as that membership was originally filled. The term of any voting member, appointed to fill an unexpired term, shall be for the remainder of the term.

subsection.text: The Regional Authority shall elect from its membership a chairman, a vice chairman, a secretary, and a treasurer. Such officers shall serve for such terms as shall be prescribed by resolution of the Regional Authority or until their successors are elected and qualified. No voting member of the Regional Authority shall hold more than one office on the Regional Authority.
The Regional Authority shall hold meetings in accordance with the following:

paragraph.text: Regular meetings of the Regional Authority shall be held on such dates and at such time and place as shall be fixed by resolution of the Regional Authority;

Special meetings of the Regional Authority may be called by resolution of the Authority, by the chairman or vice chairman, or upon the written request of at least three voting members of the Regional Authority;

Written notice of all meetings shall be delivered to each voting member, not less than 3 days prior to the date of such meeting in the case of regular meetings and not less than 24 hours in the case of special meetings;
Each voting member should make all reasonable efforts to be in attendance at meetings called by the Regional Authority; and

A majority of the voting members of the Regional Authority in office shall constitute a quorum. A majority of the quorum is empowered to exercise all the rights and perform all the duties of the Regional Authority and no vacancy on the Regional Authority shall impair the right of such majority to act. If at any meeting there is less than a quorum present, a majority of those present may adjourn the meeting to a fixed time and place, and notice of such time and place shall be given in accordance with subsection (c) of this section, provided that if the notice period under subsection (c) of this section cannot reasonably be complied with, such notice, if any, of such adjourned meeting shall be given as is reasonably practical.

subsection.text: The Regional Authority shall establish rules and regulations for its own governance, not inconsistent with this Act.
The Regional Authority shall:

paragraph.text: Make provision for a system of financial accounting and controls, audits, and reports. All accounting systems and records, auditing procedures and standards, and financial reporting shall conform to generally accepted principles of governmental accounting. All financial records, reports, and documents of the Regional Authority shall be public record and open to public inspection under reasonable regulations prescribed by the Regional Authority; and

Adopt a fiscal year, establish a system of accounting and financial control, designate the necessary funds for complete accountability, and specify the basis of accounting for each such fund. The Regional Authority shall cause to be prepared a financial report on all funds at least quarterly and a comprehensive report on the fiscal operations and conditions of the Regional Authority annually.

section.text: The Regional Authority shall make every effort to comply with the local laws of each of the Signatories to this Act, regarding disclosure, appointment, and open meetings.

subsection.text: The OCOG will provide reasonable funds for the operation of the Regional Authority and the conduct of its business in accordance with the provisions of this Act.

For the purposes of this article, payment of any insurance premiums incurred by the Regional Authority under the authority granted to it by Article VIII shall not be considered operations funds referred to in subsection 1 of this article. The OCOG shall pay only such insurance premiums as are reasonable.
The OCOG shall not be responsible for any financial liability that the Regional Authority may incur under Article VIII of this Act.

The Regional Authority shall submit to the OCOG a planned budget for the Regional Authority’s next fiscal year, adopted consistent with Article V 6 (b) of this Act, no less than 90 days before the beginning of the next fiscal year.

subheading1.text: Regional Authority Oversight of the Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games; Additional Powers.

subsection.text: The Regional Authority, in recognition of its oversight responsibility over the OCOG, shall have access to:

paragraph.text: The quarterly financial statements of the OCOG;
The annual business plans of the OCOG; and
All other OCOG documents necessary to achieve its oversight purpose.

subsection.text: The Regional Authority shall have the power to enforce OCOG budgetary and planning changes when:

paragraph.text: Review by the Regional Authority of the OCOG financial statements, annual business plans, or other documents contemplated in Article VIII 1 of this Act suggests:

subparagraph.text: Economic shortfalls that would possibly trigger the Regional Authority’s liability outlined in Article VIII 3 of this Act; or
The OCOG will fail to host the Olympic Games in a manner that would satisfy the requirements of the USOC or the IOC; and

paragraph.text: Such changes are supported by a majority of the voting members of the Regional Authority, notwithstanding the quorum requirements of Article V 4 (e) of this Act.

subsection.text: The Regional Authority, in recognition of its duties as overseer of the OCOG, shall:

paragraph.text: Be bound by the terms of, cause the OCOG to perform, and guaranty performance of the OCOG’s obligations under all documents necessary and appropriate to the pursuit of the Olympic Games;
Certify the OCOG’s performance of such obligations as requested by the USOC from time to time;
Accept liability for the OCOG, if any, as far as required by all documents necessary and appropriate to the pursuit and hosting of the Olympic Games, provided, however, that:

subparagraph.text: With regard to third-party tort liabilities, the OCOG will both indemnify the State against any and all such claims and provide that the State be named as an additional insured on all appropriate insurance policies, and, in any event, nothing contained herein shall in any way modify the State’s existing liability limitation;
With regard to all other liabilities arising out of this subsection, the OCOG agrees to hold the State harmless and indemnify the State for any such losses; and
Should the State incur any liabilities, the liabilities shall count against the total limit (or cap) on the State’s liabilities as noted in section (d) of this article and Article IX 1 below; and

paragraph.text: Accept liability, if any, with the OCOG, for any financial deficit of the OCOG, or the Olympic Games, as follows:

subparagraph.text: The OCOG shall be responsible for any amount up to $25 million;
The Regional Authority shall be liable for any amount in excess of $25 million, but not to exceed an additional $175 million; and

Except as set forth in existing applicable law, the OCOG and the Regional Authority shall not be limited in their choice of funding sources for covering possible financial losses, including but not limited to the purchase of insurance, if commercially available and reasonably priced.

subsection.text: The Regional Authority, in its financial oversight and safeguard role, shall ensure that:

paragraph.text: No legacy programs, funds, or accounts shall be funded from any of the proceeds of the 2012 Olympic Games until all budgetary and operational financial obligations of the OCOG and the Regional Authority for hosting the Olympic Games are first met; and

No liability for any financial deficit resulting from the 2012 Olympic Games shall accrue to the Regional Authority (or the Signatories) until all budgetary and/or operational financial surpluses of the OCOG, if any, are applied to all outstanding financial obligations of the OCOG and the Regional Authority, if any, accrued exclusively in connection with hosting the Olympic Games.

subsection.text: The Regional Authority, in order to facilitate its oversight responsibility over the OCOG, shall have the additional powers:

paragraph.text: To sue and be sued in contract and in tort;
To complain and defend in all courts;
To implead and be impleaded;
To enter into contracts;
To hire appropriate staff; and
Any additional powers granted to it by subsequent legislation.

subsection.text: Any liability incurred by the Regional Authority, not covered by insurance under Article VIII 3 (d)(iii), shall be further indemnified by the Signatories of this Act, in proportion to the relative economic benefit currently expected to accrue to each Signatory from hosting the Olympic Games, as follows:

paragraph.text: The State of Maryland, subject to appropriation, shall be liable for 53%;
The Commonwealth of Virginia shall be liable for 19%; and
The District of Columbia shall be liable for 28%.

subsection.text: Each of the Signatories to this Act may provide for its share of any possible liability in any manner it may choose, as befits each Signatory’s independent commitment.

section.text: As appropriate to its individual jurisdiction and specific role in hosting the 2012 Olympic Games, each Signatory agrees to:

subsection.text: Ensure that necessary facilities are built and transportation infrastructure improvements take place, including government funding as appropriate;
Provide access to existing state/city-controlled facilities and other important resources as specified in WBRC 2012’s bid proposal, in accordance with applicable law and contractual obligations; and
Provide adequate security, fire protection, and other government related services at a reasonable cost to ensure for the safe and orderly operation of the Olympic Games.

section.text: None of the duties or responsibilities encompassed in this legislation shall have effect until substantially similar legislation is enacted by each of the Signatories, at which time this legislation shall immediately be effective.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Council” means the Maryland Advisory Council on Deaf and Hard of Hearing Individuals.

paragraph.text: “Deaf and hard of hearing individuals” means those residents of Maryland who have a partial or complete loss of hearing.
“Deaf and hard of hearing individuals” includes individuals who are deaf, hard of hearing, deafblind, and late–deafened.
“Deafblind” means those residents of Maryland who have concomitant vision and hearing loss.

subsection.text: “Director” means the Director of the Office.
“Office” means the Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing.
In the Office of the Governor, there is an Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing.

paragraph.text: The head of the Office is the Director.

subparagraph.text: The Director is appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The Director serves at the pleasure of the Governor and is responsible directly to the Governor.

paragraph.text: The Director shall be:

subparagraph.text: a deaf or hard of hearing person; and
knowledgeable and experienced with issues affecting deaf and hard of hearing individuals.

paragraph.text: The Director is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.
The Office shall:

subparagraph.text: advise the Governor on all matters assigned to the Office; and
carry out the Governor’s policies on the matters assigned to the Office.

paragraph.text: The Director shall:

subparagraph.text: manage the operation of the Office and establish guidelines and procedures to promote the orderly and efficient operation of the Office; and
adopt regulations necessary to carry out the provisions of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of this subtitle, the Director may establish, reorganize, or consolidate areas of responsibility in the Office as necessary to fulfill the responsibilities assigned by the Director.

subsection.text: The Office shall be given adequate staff and funding to carry out its duties.
The Office shall be responsible for promoting the general welfare of deaf and hard of hearing individuals in the State.
The responsibilities of the Office shall include:

paragraph.text: providing, advocating, and coordinating the adoption of public policies, regulations, and programs that will benefit deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
improving access to communication and to existing services and programs for deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
providing direct services to deaf and hard of hearing individuals as appropriate;
increasing public awareness of the needs and issues affecting deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
working with State and local agencies to ensure access for deaf and hard of hearing individuals to safety and emergency services;
developing a referral service for deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
serving as an information clearinghouse on the needs and issues affecting deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
working to increase access for deaf and hard of hearing individuals to educational, health, and social opportunities;
working with private organizations, the federal government, and other units of State government to promote economic development for deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
working to eliminate the underemployment and unemployment of deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
providing a network through which services provided by State and federal programs serving deaf and hard of hearing individuals can be channeled; and
promoting compliance with State, local, and federal laws and policies protecting and serving deaf and hard of hearing individuals.

subsection.text: The Office shall hold at least two public town hall meetings each year to receive public comments on:

paragraph.text: the quality of State services and programs affecting deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
the functions and operations of the Office; and
any other issues that affect deaf and hard of hearing individuals, including those specified in subsection (b) of this section.

subsection.text: The Office shall:

paragraph.text: help facilitate the appropriate delivery of State, local, and other public services to deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
advise other units of State government and the General Assembly on the needs of deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
subject to appropriations in the State budget, provide any reasonable resources that any other unit of State government requests to serve or assist deaf and hard of hearing individuals; and

to the greatest extent possible, in order to avoid any duplication of effort, coordinate with other units of the State and the federal government the services provided to deaf and hard of hearing individuals.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Advisory Council on the Deaf and Hard of Hearing.

paragraph.text: The Council consists of 18 members appointed by the Governor, with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Of the 18 Council members, at least five of the members shall be deaf and hard of hearing individuals.

subsection.text: Of the 18 Council members:

paragraph.text: one shall be the State Superintendent or a designee from the State Department of Education;
one shall be the Secretary or a designee from the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene;
one shall be the Secretary or a designee from the Department of Human Resources;
one shall be the Secretary or a designee from the Department of Transportation;
one shall be from the Commission on Civil Rights;
one shall be the Secretary or a designee from the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
one shall be the Secretary or a designee from the Department of Housing and Community Development;
one shall be the Superintendent or a designee from the Maryland School for the Deaf;
one shall be the Secretary or a designee from the Department of Aging; and
nine shall be from the general public.
The nine members from the general public shall be chosen from different geographical areas of the State.
Of the nine members from the general public:

subparagraph.text: five shall be deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
one shall be a private citizen with special knowledge or expertise relating to services to deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
one shall be a parent of a deaf or hard of hearing child;
one shall be from a private agency providing services to deaf and hard of hearing individuals; and
one shall be a person with special knowledge or expertise relating to services to individuals who are deafblind.

subsection.text: The term of a member of the Council is 3 years.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Council on October 1, 2001.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member may not serve consecutively more than two 3-year terms.
Any member who fails to attend at least 50 percent of the regularly scheduled meetings during any 12-month period shall be considered to have resigned.

section.text: The Council shall:

paragraph.text: advise the Office in carrying out its duties;
review statewide activities for deaf and hard of hearing individuals, including reviewing reports and publications of committees and commissions;
foster coordination of and support for programs for deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
study ways to maximize the use of the facilities and services available to deaf and hard of hearing individuals;
hold:

subparagraph.text: at least quarterly, regularly scheduled meetings; and

open meetings to provide direct communication, between deaf and hard of hearing individuals and private and public organizations and the general public, about programs and services for and needs of deaf and hard of hearing individuals; and

paragraph.text: assist any local governing body of a county to establish a local advisory council for deaf and hard of hearing individuals in the county for purposes of implementing the provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and other relevant State and federal laws.

section.text: On or before January 1, 2002, and annually thereafter, the Director shall submit to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of this article, to the members of the General Assembly, a report on:

paragraph.text: the activities of the Office;
the status of programs and services facilitated by the Office;
statistics on compliance with State and federal laws related to deaf and hard of hearing individuals; and
recommendations for improved delivery of services for deaf and hard of hearing individuals.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Board of Directors of the Maryland African American Museum Corporation.
“Corporation” means the Maryland African American Museum Corporation.
There is a Maryland African American Museum Corporation.

paragraph.text: The purpose of the Corporation is to plan, develop, and manage a Maryland museum of African American history and culture in Baltimore City, in cooperation with and with the active support of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, affected State units, and other public and private institutions.
The Corporation may carry out its corporate purposes without the consent of any unit of State government.
The Corporation is:

subparagraph.text: a body politic and corporate;
a public instrumentality of the State; and
an independent unit in the Executive Branch of State government.

paragraph.text: The exercise by the Corporation of the powers conferred by this subtitle is an essential public function.
There is a Board of Directors of the Corporation.
The Board shall manage the affairs of the Corporation and shall exercise all of its corporate powers.
The Board shall consist of 37 members, as follows:

subparagraph.text: the Mayor of Baltimore, serving ex officio, or the Mayor’s designee; and
thirty-six members appointed by the Governor, as follows:

sub-subparagraph.text: one representative of Morgan State University, approved by the Board of Regents of the University;

the chairman of the Commission on African American History and Culture or the chairman’s designee and two other Commission members approved by the Commission, to provide continuing coordination and cooperation between the Corporation and the Commission and to ensure consistency with the statewide programs and mandates of the Commission;
four representatives of African American historical or cultural institutions in the State; and

twenty-eight members who have expertise in African American history, culture, museums, or related areas, expertise in fund-raising, or represent the diversity of communities throughout the State that can benefit from the activities of the Corporation.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the members appointed to the Board shall represent the geographic makeup of the State and shall be racially and ethnically diverse.

The Governor may appoint to the Board up to five members from outside the State if necessary to ensure that the membership of the Board satisfies the requirements specified in paragraph (1)(ii)4 of this subsection.

subsection.text: A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: is not entitled to compensation as a member of the Board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses in accordance with the Standard State Travel Regulations.
The term of an appointed member of the Board is 4 years.
Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 2004.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the remainder of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
From among its members, the Board shall elect a chairman, a vice chairman, and a treasurer.
A majority of the members then serving on the Board is a quorum.
A vacancy in the membership of the Board does not impair the right of a quorum of the Board to exercise the rights and perform the duties of the Corporation.
The Board shall appoint an executive committee and may appoint other committees that the Board considers necessary or desirable.
The Board shall appoint an Executive Director who serves at the pleasure of the Board.
The Board shall determine the salary of the Executive Director.
The Executive Director is the chief administrative officer of the Corporation.
The Executive Director shall direct and supervise the administrative affairs and technical activities of the Corporation in accordance with the policies and procedures of the Board.
The Executive Director or the Executive Director’s designee shall:

subparagraph.text: attend each meeting of the Board, act as secretary to the Board, and keep minutes of Board proceedings;
approve each salary, per diem payment, or other expense of the Corporation, its employees, and consultants; and
perform other duties as directed by the Board in carrying out the purposes of this subtitle.
In addition to the Executive Director, the Board shall employ professional and clerical staff necessary to carry out the purposes of this subtitle.
The Board shall establish compensation, holidays, and leave for the staff.

paragraph.text: The officers and employees of the Corporation are not subject to the provisions of Division I of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern the State Personnel Management System.

subsection.text: The Attorney General shall provide legal counsel to the Corporation and legal services to the museum.
The Board may contract with any agent or consultant it considers necessary to carry out the purposes of this subtitle.

section.text: The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: adopt an official seal;
sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, in its own name;
maintain offices in the State;
appoint museum advisory boards and other advisory boards and committees;
adopt bylaws for the regulation of its affairs and the conduct of its business;
apply for and accept grants, loans, or assistance of any character from the federal government, State government, a local government, or a private source;
enter into any contract or other legal instrument;
acquire, construct, develop, manage, market, reconstruct, rehabilitate, improve, maintain, equip, lease as lessor or as lessee, repair, or operate any project in the State;

acquire, purchase, hold, lease as lessee, or use a franchise, patent, or license or any real, personal, mixed, tangible, or intangible property or any interest in that property, necessary or convenient for carrying out the purposes of the Corporation;
sell, lease as lessor, transfer, or dispose of its property or interests in property;

acquire, either directly or by or through any person, State unit, or political subdivision, by purchase or by gift or devise, any land, structure, real property, personal property, right, right-of-way, franchise, easement, or other interest in land, including land lying under water and riparian rights that the Corporation considers necessary or convenient for the construction, improvement, rehabilitation, or operation of a project, on any terms and at any price that the Corporation considers reasonable;
enter with the permission of the owner on land, water, or premises for the purpose of making surveys, soundings, borings, and examinations to accomplish any purpose authorized by this subtitle;
fix, revise, and collect rates, rentals, fees, and charges for the use of, or for services and facilities provided or made available by, the Corporation;

subparagraph.text: borrow money from any source for any corporate purpose, including working capital for its operations, reserves, or interest;
mortgage, pledge, or otherwise encumber the property and money of the Corporation; and
contract with or engage the services of any person for any financing;

paragraph.text: exercise all the corporate powers granted to Maryland corporations under the Maryland General Corporation Law; and
do all things necessary and convenient to carry out the powers granted by this subtitle.

section.text: The Corporation shall:

paragraph.text: prepare a strategic plan at least once every 5 years that establishes short-range and long-range goals, objectives, and priorities for the museum in support of its mission;
report annually to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of this article, to the General Assembly on the Corporation’s activities during the preceding year, including:

subparagraph.text: the number of students and other types of visitors served;
the number of volunteers and total hours contributed to the operation of the museum;
the amount and type of private and nonstate money donated, pledged, or otherwise provided; and
any recommendations or requests the Corporation considers appropriate to further the mission of the museum; and

paragraph.text: publish reports and any other material it considers necessary.

section.text: Except for the net earnings of the Corporation necessary to pay debt service or implement the Corporation’s museum plan, the net earnings of the Corporation shall inure to the benefit of the State and not to any person.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the Corporation is not required to pay taxes or assessments on its:

paragraph.text: properties;
activities; or
revenue derived from its properties or activities.

subsection.text: If the Corporation sells or leases land or facilities to a private entity, the land or facilities shall be subject to real property taxes.
The Board shall prepare and implement an operating and a capital budget for the management of its affairs.
The Governor may include a grant to the Corporation in the State budget.
The Corporation shall support all operating costs, including personnel and retirement costs, from any General Fund allocations, and its other income sources.
This section does not restrict the budgetary power of the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: The Corporation may provide for the creation, continuation, and administration of the funds that it requires.
As the Board directs, money in the funds and other money of the Corporation shall be deposited in a federal or State chartered depository institution that:

subparagraph.text: is insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation;
has a branch or office in the State that accepts deposits; and
has a total paid-in capital plus surplus of at least $6,000,000.

paragraph.text: A federal or State chartered trust company may be designated as a depository to receive securities that the Corporation has or owns.

subsection.text: Money that the State appropriates to the Corporation, and money that the Corporation is required by the General Assembly to raise for museum construction from sources other than the State, shall be invested in bonds or other obligations:

paragraph.text: of the United States, the State, a political subdivision of the State, or a unit of the State; or
that are guaranteed as to principal and interest by the United States, the State, a political subdivision of the State, or a unit of the State.
The Corporation shall adopt a system of financial accounting, controls, audits, and reports.
The fiscal year of the Corporation is July 1 to June 30.
The Corporation shall select an independent certified public accountant to conduct an audit under this subsection.
The accountant:

subparagraph.text: shall be licensed to practice in the State;
shall be experienced and qualified in the accounting and auditing of public bodies; and
may not have a personal interest either directly or indirectly in the fiscal affairs of the Corporation.

paragraph.text: As soon as practicable after the end of the fiscal year, the accountant shall audit the financial books, records, and accounts of the Corporation.
The accountant shall report:

subparagraph.text: the results of its audit, including an unqualified opinion on the financial position of the Corporation’s funds; and
the results of the Corporation’s financial operations.

paragraph.text: If the accountant is unable to express an unqualified opinion, the accountant shall:

subparagraph.text: state and explain in detail the reason for any qualifications, disclaimers, or opinions; and
submit recommendations on changes needed to allow an unqualified opinion in the future.

subsection.text: The books, records, and accounts of the Corporation are subject to audit by the State.

paragraph.text: Within the first 90 days of each fiscal year, the Corporation shall submit a report to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of this article, to the General Assembly.
The report shall include:

subparagraph.text: a complete operating and financial statement covering the Corporation’s operations during the preceding fiscal year; and
a summary of the Corporation’s activities during the preceding fiscal year.

subsection.text: All debts, claims, obligations, and liabilities of the Corporation, whenever incurred, shall be the debts, claims, obligations, and liabilities of the Corporation only and not of the State, other units of State government, other State instrumentalities, State officers, or State employees.
The debts, claims, obligations, and liabilities of the Corporation may not be considered a debt, claim, obligation, or liability of the State or a pledge of its full faith and credit.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Corporation is exempt from:

paragraph.text: Title 10, Subtitle 5 of this article;
Title 2, Subtitles 2, 4, and 6 and § 2-510 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
Title 3 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
Title 4, Subtitles 2 through 7 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
Title 6, Subtitle 1 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
Title 7, Subtitles 1 through 3 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
Title 8, Subtitle 1 of the State Finance and Procurement Article; and
Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: The Corporation and its officers and employees are subject to the Maryland Public Ethics Law and the State minority business enterprise laws, except as otherwise provided in this subtitle.
Before approving the final plans for the museum, the Corporation shall:

paragraph.text: submit preliminary plans to the City of Baltimore for review; and
consider comments from the City of Baltimore on the preliminary plans.

section.text: This subtitle shall be liberally construed to effect its purposes.
This subtitle may be cited as the Maryland African American Museum Corporation Act.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Council” means the Maryland Youth Advisory Council.

“High school student” means a youth who is enrolled in high school, who is a home school student, or who is enrolled in a program that leads to a high school diploma or certificate of attendance or a general equivalency diploma.
“Institution of postsecondary education” has the meaning stated in § 10–101 of the Education Article.
“Public senior higher education institution” has the meaning stated in § 10–101 of the Education Article.
“Youth” means an individual who is 14 to 22 years old.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Youth Advisory Council.
The Council consists of:

paragraph.text: the following members appointed by the President of the Senate:

subparagraph.text: six high school students, including at least three who are students in the State and who are enrolled in public high schools;
two youths who are students at institutions of postsecondary education located in the State; and
one member of the Senate;

paragraph.text: the following members appointed by the Speaker of the House of Delegates:
