subparagraph.text: six high school students, including at least three who are students in the State and who are enrolled in public high schools;
two youths who are students at institutions of postsecondary education located in the State; and
one member of the House of Delegates;

paragraph.text: the following members appointed by the Governor:

subparagraph.text: twelve youths, including at least ten high school students, at least five of whom shall be students in the State who are enrolled in public high schools; and
four youths who are students at institutions of postsecondary education located in the State;

paragraph.text: the following members selected by other youths, including:

subparagraph.text: fifteen high school students chosen by the Maryland Association of Student Councils; and
eight youths who are students at institutions of postsecondary education located in the State, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: three members selected by the University System of Maryland Student Council; and
five members selected by the Student Advisory Council to the Maryland Higher Education Commission, including:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: at least one member who is enrolled in a community college;
at least one member who is enrolled in a private college or university; and
at least one member who is enrolled in a public senior higher education institution who is not otherwise represented on the Council; and

paragraph.text: an executive board that consists of:

subparagraph.text: four members selected by the youth members appointed by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: three high school students; and
one student at an institution of postsecondary education;

subparagraph.text: four members selected by the youth members appointed by the Governor, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: three high school students; and
one student at an institution of postsecondary education; and

subparagraph.text: four members selected by the youth members chosen by other youth, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: three high school students; and
one student at an institution of postsecondary education.

subsection.text: In deciding which members to appoint or select:

paragraph.text: the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House shall, to the extent practicable, consider:

subparagraph.text: the geographic and demographic diversity of the State;
diversity in education, including nontraditional settings such as vocational and tech–oriented education; and
youths with disabilities;

paragraph.text: the Governor shall, to the extent practicable, consider:

subparagraph.text: the geographic and demographic diversity of the State;
diversity in education, including nontraditional settings such as vocational and tech–oriented education;
youths with disabilities; and
transitional youths who are not in high school or an institution of postsecondary education and not likely to attend an institution of postsecondary education; and

paragraph.text: the Maryland Association of Student Councils shall consider youths who are enrolled in schools represented by the Association as well as applicants who are enrolled in schools that are not represented by the Association.
The term of a youth member of the Council is 1 year, from September 1 through August 30 of the following year.
A youth member who is appointed or selected after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed or selected and qualifies.
A youth member may not serve more than two consecutive terms.
The member from the Senate and the member from the House serve, respectively, at the pleasure of the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House.
At the first meeting of each youth member term period, the youth members shall elect one of the youth members to serve as cochair for a term of 1 year.

A representative of the Governor’s Office for Children appointed by the Governor, the member from the Senate, and the member from the House shall serve as cochairs with the elected youth member cochair.
The Council may appoint any officers that it considers necessary.

The cochair appointed by the Governor shall, on behalf of the Governor, the President of the Senate, and the Speaker of the House, develop an initial application and application process, both of which the Council may change at its discretion.

subsection.text: The Governor’s Office for Children, in addition to the member from the Senate, or the member from the House, or both, shall provide staff support for the Council.
The Council shall:

paragraph.text: inform the Governor and the General Assembly of issues concerning youth, including offering testimony on these issues before legislative bodies;
examine issues of importance to youth, including:

subparagraph.text: education;
a safe learning environment;
employment opportunities;
strategies to increase youth participation in local and State government;
health care access and quality of care;
substance abuse and underage drinking;
emotional and physical well–being;
the environment;
poverty;
homelessness;
youth access to State and local services;
suicide prevention; and
educational accessibility issues for students with disabilities, including access to:

sub-subparagraph.text: schools;
school–related activities; and
classes;

paragraph.text: recommend one legislative proposal each legislative session concerning an issue included in item (2) of this subsection for possible introduction; and
conduct a public awareness campaign to raise awareness about the Council among Maryland youth.
The Council shall work with the State Department of Education regarding the granting of school credit for Council service.

The State Department of Education and the Maryland Higher Education Commission shall notify the head administrators of all State high schools and of all institutions of postsecondary education, respectively, of the creation of the Council so that the administrators may inform their students.

The State Department of Education shall allow up to four absences of a youth member from school per school year to be categorized as lawful absences if the absences were due to the business of the Council.
The Council shall set priorities and determine:

subparagraph.text: the function of subcommittees;
standards of conduct;
procedures; and
the use of technology to convene or conduct meetings or facilitate communications among members.

paragraph.text: The Council shall review and consider whether the procedures and rules used by the General Assembly would be appropriate for use as models for the Council.

subsection.text: The Council shall:

paragraph.text: meet at least four times each year and conduct one or two public hearings each year on issues of importance to youth;

conduct one educational meeting concerning the legislative process, to which the President of the Senate, the Speaker of the House, and the Executive Director of the Department of Legislative Services, or their designees, shall be invited to speak; and
open all meetings to the public.

subsection.text: A member of the Council:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Council; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: On or before the last day of the youth members’ terms, the Council shall report its activities to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of this article, to the General Assembly.

section.text: There is a State Drug and Alcohol Abuse Council in the Office of the Governor.

paragraph.text: The Council consists of the following voting members:

subparagraph.text: one member of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate;
one member of the Maryland House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House;
the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Juvenile Services, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Human Resources, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Budget and Management, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Housing and Community Development, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Transportation, or the Secretary’s designee;
the State Superintendent of Schools, or the Superintendent’s designee;
the Executive Director of the Governor’s Office for Children, or the Executive Director’s designee;
the Executive Director of the Governor’s Office of Crime Control and Prevention, or the Executive Director’s designee;
the Public Defender of Maryland, or the Public Defender’s designee;
two representatives of the Maryland Judiciary, a District Court judge and a circuit court judge, appointed by the Governor after nomination of the Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals; and
eight members appointed by the Governor who are representative to the extent practicable of:

sub-subparagraph.text: geographic regions of the State;
at–risk populations;
knowledgeable professionals;
current or former consumers of substance abuse prevention, intervention, and treatment services;
family members of substance abusers;
prevention and treatment providers; and
individuals who are active on substance abuse issues in their communities.

paragraph.text: The Council consists of the following nonvoting members:

subparagraph.text: the Director of the Alcohol and Drug Abuse Administration of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene;
the Director of Mental Hygiene of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene;
a representative of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, designated by the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services;
a deputy Secretary of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services; and
the President of the Maryland Addiction Directors’ Council.

subsection.text: The Governor shall appoint a chair from among the voting members of the Council.

paragraph.text: Members appointed by the Governor under § 9–2802(a)(1)(xiv) and (xv) of this subtitle:

subparagraph.text: serve for a 3–year term;
may serve for a maximum of two consecutive terms; and
serve at the pleasure of the Governor.

paragraph.text: The terms of members appointed by the Governor under § 9–2802(a)(1)(xv) of this subtitle are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Council on October 1, 2010.
A member appointed under § 9–2802(a)(1)(i) through (xiv) and (2) of this subtitle serves as long as the member holds the specified office or designation.

subsection.text: A member of the Council:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Council; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
A majority of the voting members of the Council is a quorum.

subparagraph.text: The Council may adopt procedures necessary to do business, including the creation of committees or task forces.
With the consent of the Council, the chair may designate additional individuals with relevant expertise to serve on a committee or task force.

paragraph.text: The Council may consult with State agencies to complete the duties of the Council.
The Council shall meet at least four times a year.

section.text: The purposes of the Council are to:

paragraph.text: develop a comprehensive, coordinated, and strategic approach to the use of State and local resources for prevention, intervention, and treatment of drug and alcohol abuse among the residents of the State;

promote a coordinated, collaborative, and comprehensive effort by State Executive Branch agencies to ensure the efficient and effective use of State resources for the delivery of a full continuum of drug and alcohol abuse prevention, intervention, and treatment services for all residents within their jurisdiction;

promote a coordinated, collaborative, and comprehensive effort by local alcohol and drug abuse councils and State service agencies to ensure effective and efficient use of State resources for the delivery of a full continuum of drug and alcohol abuse prevention, intervention, and treatment services for all residents within their jurisdiction;

promote a coordinated, collaborative, and comprehensive effort by State and local agencies to allocate adequate resources to address the drug and alcohol abuse prevention, intervention, and treatment services needs of individuals involved in the criminal justice system at all stages of the process, including:

subparagraph.text: services while incarcerated;
re–entry services;
parole and probation services; and
court mandated services; and

paragraph.text: promote a coordinated, collaborative, and comprehensive effort by State and local agencies to allocate adequate resources to address the drug and alcohol abuse prevention, intervention, and treatment services needs of individuals with co–occurring problems requiring specialized services, including:

subparagraph.text: mental health disorders;
homelessness;
somatic health problems;
physical and cognitive difficulties; and
child welfare involvement.

section.text: The Council shall:

paragraph.text: identify, develop, and recommend the implementation of comprehensive system improvements in alcohol and drug abuse prevention, intervention, and treatment services in the State in coordination with State and local crime prevention and health programs;

prepare and annually update a 2–year plan establishing priorities and strategies for the organization, delivery, and funding of State drug and alcohol abuse prevention, intervention, and treatment services in coordination with the identified needs of the residents of the State, including the general public and the criminal justice population, and the strategies and priorities identified in local drug and alcohol abuse council plans;

submit to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of this article, the General Assembly, on or before August 1 of each year the 2–year plan and all updates and include recommendations for the coordination and collaboration among State agencies in the funding of drug and alcohol abuse prevention, intervention, and treatment services, promising practices and programs, and emerging needs for State substance abuse prevention, intervention, and treatment services;

support the work of the local drug and alcohol abuse councils through facilitating coordination and communication among the councils, local State agencies and departments, and public and private providers and provide technical assistance as needed;

prepare annual surveys of all federal and State resources used to fund substance abuse prevention, intervention, and treatment services and review the allocation of the funds by relevant State agencies for the purpose of identifying gaps in service delivery, duplication of services, and opportunities for improved coordination and collaboration to ensure cost–effective and quality services and consistency with policy priorities established in the State plan; and
facilitate improved linkages of the court, criminal justice, and correctional systems with existing drug and alcohol abuse services.

section.text: The Alcohol and Drug Abuse Administration shall provide staff for the Council.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL DECEMBER 31, 2014 PER CHAPTERS 250 AND 251 OF 2011 //

subsection.text: There is a Commission on Maryland Cybersecurity Innovation and Excellence.

paragraph.text: The Commission consists of the following members:

subparagraph.text: one member of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate;
one member of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House;
the Secretary of Information Technology, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Business and Economic Development, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Executive Director of the Maryland Technology Development Corporation, or the Executive Director’s designee;
the Chair of the Tech Council of Maryland, or the Chair’s designee;
the President of the Fort Meade Alliance, or the President’s designee; and
the following members appointed by the Governor:

sub-subparagraph.text: five representatives of cybersecurity companies located in the State, with at least three representing cybersecurity companies with 50 employees or less;
three representatives from statewide or regional business associations;
four representatives from institutions of higher education located in the State;
one representative of a crime victims organization;
three representatives from industries that may be susceptible to attacks on cybersecurity; and
one representative of an organization that has expertise in electronic health care records.

paragraph.text: The Governor also shall invite the following representatives of federal agencies to serve on the Commission:

subparagraph.text: the Director of the National Institute for Standards and Technology, or the Director’s designee;
the Secretary of Defense, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Director of the National Security Agency, or the Director’s designee;
the Secretary of Homeland Security, or the Secretary’s designee;
the Director of the Defense Information Systems Agency, or the Director’s designee; and
the Director of the Intelligence Advanced Research Projects Activity, or the Director’s designee.

subsection.text: The members appointed by the Presiding Officers of the General Assembly shall cochair the Commission.
The University of Maryland University College shall provide staff for the Commission.
A member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Commission; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The purpose of the Commission is to provide a road map for making the State the epicenter of cybersecurity innovation and excellence.
The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: conduct a comprehensive review of and identify any inconsistencies in:

subparagraph.text: State and federal cybersecurity laws; and

policies, standards, and best practices for ensuring the security of computer systems and networks used by educational institutions and State government and other organizations that work with health care records, personal identification information, public safety, and public service and utilities;

paragraph.text: conduct a comprehensive review of the State’s role in promoting cyber innovation;
identify any federal preemption issues relating to cybersecurity;
provide recommendations for:

subparagraph.text: a comprehensive State framework and strategic plan for cybersecurity innovation and excellence;
a comprehensive State strategic plan to ensure a coordinated and adaptable response to and recovery from attacks on cybersecurity;
coordinated and unified policies to clarify the roles and responsibilities of State units regarding cybersecurity;
growth opportunities and economic development strategies and action plans; and
strategies that can be used to coordinate State and federal resources to attract private sector investment and job creation in cybersecurity;

paragraph.text: make recommendations regarding:

subparagraph.text: methods the State can use to increase cybersecurity innovation by:

sub-subparagraph.text: promoting public and private partnerships, research and development, and workforce training, education, and development;
promoting science, technology, engineering, and mathematics courses in all levels of education;
helping companies transfer research to product;
protecting intellectual properties; and
leveraging federal funds for research, development, and commercialization;

subparagraph.text: methods that the State can use to promote collaboration and coordination among cybersecurity companies and among institutions of higher education located in the State;
a unit of State government that is suitable to run a pilot program regarding cybersecurity; and
the designation of a cybersecurity policy official that would be responsible for coordinating the State’s cybersecurity policies, strategies, and activities.

subsection.text: On or before January 1, 2012, the Commission shall submit an interim report of its findings and recommendations, including recommended legislation, to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of this article, the General Assembly.

On or before September 1, 2014, the Commission shall submit a final report of its findings and recommendations, including recommended legislation, to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of this article, the General Assembly.
There is a Governor’s Office of Community Initiatives, as authorized under Executive Order 01.01.2007.25.
The Governor’s Office of Community Initiatives shall include the following units:

paragraph.text: the Governor’s Office on Service and Volunteerism, under Subtitle 2 of this title;
the Commission on Indian Affairs, under Subtitle 3 of this title;
the Commission on African American History and Culture, under Subtitle 4 of this title; and
any other unit as authorized by law or executive order.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Corps” means the Maryland Service Corps.
“Council” means the Governor’s Volunteer Council.
“Office” means the Governor’s Office on Service and Volunteerism.

section.text: There is a Governor’s Office on Service and Volunteerism within the Governor’s Office of Community Initiatives.

paragraph.text: The head of the Governor’s Office on Service and Volunteerism is the Director who shall be appointed by the Governor.
The Director serves at the pleasure of the Governor.
The Director is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.
The Office shall employ staff to carry out its duties as provided in the State budget.
In furtherance of the purposes of the Office, the Director is authorized to execute contracts and accept grants or donations from governmental or private sources.

section.text: The Office shall:

paragraph.text: encourage volunteering throughout the State by individuals, businesses, and nonprofit organizations;
promote the use of volunteers in State and local government;
identify governmental agencies where private sector involvement in volunteer programs can be of assistance and provide technical assistance in developing such programs;
provide information services to volunteer programs and government units throughout the State;
develop model programs for statewide clearinghouses, skill banks, or information centers for volunteers and projects in the State and implement such programs, if feasible;

plan and execute volunteer recognition events for State volunteers and provide technical assistance and support for recognition events in the private sector in order to increase the visibility and status of volunteers and their accomplishments;

administer the Maryland Service Corps Program, the Executive Fellows Program, and other volunteer programs as may be recommended by the Council and designated by the Governor or otherwise provided by law;
maintain liaison with national and State volunteerism groups to obtain information on federal, State, and private resources that may enhance volunteer projects within the State;
conduct studies and make recommendations to improve volunteer recruitment and training, volunteer retention, and accountability of volunteer programs; and
provide staff support to the Council.

subsection.text: The Maryland Service Corps is established for the purpose of encouraging and developing a program of full– and part–time public service that involves citizens of all ages throughout the State of Maryland in meeting the essential needs, as the Office shall identify, within the human service delivery systems in Maryland.
A project shall not be undertaken under the auspices of the Maryland Service Corps if such project shall replace regular workers or duplicate or replace an existing service in the same locality.

A member of the Corps may not participate in any partisan political activity while engaged in the performance of duties as a stipend volunteer, and the provisions of this subtitle shall be effective only to the extent that they do not conflict with any federal or State laws or regulations relating to participation in partisan political activities.
The number of stipend volunteers in the Corps shall be determined by the Director based on the needs of the community and the limits of budgetary appropriations.

A stipend volunteer in the Corps shall make a commitment of up to 1 year of service. Stipend volunteers shall receive no salary, but shall receive a stipend, as determined by the Director, based on the needs of the stipend volunteer and the limits of budgetary appropriations.

The Executive Fellows Program is established to provide an opportunity for individuals from the private sector with demonstrated leadership and managerial potential to participate in State government.

Criteria or guidelines for the recruitment, selection, and assignment of executive fellows shall be developed in consultation with representatives of the business community and appropriate State units.
A committee shall be appointed by the Governor to select qualified applicants to participate in the Executive Fellows Program.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commission” means the Commission on Indian Affairs.
“Community” means a tribe, band, group, or clan.

paragraph.text: “Indian” means an individual or community that is, or whose members are, descended from a tribe that inhabited North America before European contact.
“Indian” includes a Native American Indian, a North American Indian, an American Indian, and an aboriginal American.

section.text: There is a Commission on Indian Affairs in the Governor’s Office of Community Initiatives.

paragraph.text: The Commission consists of nine members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Of the nine Commission members:

subparagraph.text: a majority shall be members of the Indian communities of the State; and
at least three shall be members of the Indian communities that are indigenous to the State.

subsection.text: Each member shall:

paragraph.text: have a demonstrable knowledge of Indian culture and history; and
be sensitive to the problems of Indian communities.
An applicant for membership on the Commission shall submit under oath a list of the applicant’s qualifications, including:

subparagraph.text: educational history; and
employment background or other relevant experience.

paragraph.text: An applicant for membership on the Commission as an Indian member shall submit documentation or proof of Indian status under the sworn and notarized signature of the custodian of records of the membership rolls of that Indian’s community.
The Governor may require the production of any other documents to prove:

subparagraph.text: the qualifications of the applicant; or
the standing or history of the Indian community to which the applicant claims membership.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member may not serve more than 6 years consecutively.

section.text: The Commission shall elect annually a chair and a vice chair from among its members.

subsection.text: The Commission shall meet at the call of the chair, a majority of the members, or the Governor or the Governor’s designee.
A member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Commission; but
may receive reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
With the approval of the Governor, the Commission shall appoint an administrator.
The administrator may not be a member of the Commission.
The administrator serves at the pleasure of the Commission, subject to the concurrence of the Governor.

subsection.text: The administrator is a special appointment in the State Personnel Management System.
Subject to the rules and policies of the Commission and the administrative supervision of the Governor or the Governor’s designee in accordance with this title, the administrator shall:

paragraph.text: administer the activities of the Commission; and
supervise the appointment and removal of personnel whom the Commission employs.

section.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: initiate, direct, and coordinate projects that further the understanding of Indian history and culture;
survey historic buildings, sites, artifacts, archives, and repositories and publish and disseminate the results;
make a comprehensive study of the influence of indigenous Indian tribes and their influence on Maryland history and culture, including as subjects of the study:

subparagraph.text: Cherokees;
Chippewas;
Choptanks;
Creeks;
Crees;
Delawares;
Haliwas;
Lumbees;
Nanticokes;
Piscataways;
Potomacs;
Rappahannocks;
Seminoles;
Susquehannas; and
Wicomicos;

paragraph.text: study the status of all Indian communities in the State and assist them in obtaining recognition from the federal government;
study the economic and social needs of Indians in the State and make recommendations to meet these needs;
locate, preserve, and disseminate to the public information about significant buildings and sites relating to Indian history and culture in the State; and
publish an annual report and any other material the Commission considers necessary.
The Commission may seek money from the federal government, foundations, and private sources in addition to State financing.
The Commission may accept gifts, grants, donations, bequests, or endowments for any of its purposes.

subsection.text: Money received under subsection (a) of this section and income and fees derived from educational materials and activities of the Commission are not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
Money maintained under this section is subject to audit by the State, including the Legislative Auditor.

Subject to the approval of the Governor, the Commission may by regulation establish a process for an Indian community that is indigenous to the State to apply to the Commission for recognition of Maryland Indian status.

paragraph.text: If the Commission finds that a petitioning group meets the requirements for recognition, the Commission may recommend to the Governor that it be granted recognition of Maryland Indian status.
A member of the Commission may not vote or participate in deliberations on an application for recognition of Maryland Indian status made by the petitioning group to which the member belongs.
The Governor may issue an executive order providing recognition of Maryland Indian status to the petitioning group.
The executive order:

subparagraph.text: shall be submitted to the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review; and
shall take effect 30 days after it is submitted.

paragraph.text: This section does not:

subparagraph.text: create a right of ownership or any other right to land;
create a benefit or entitlement of any kind;
impair existing rights, benefits, or entitlements belonging to Indians living in the State;
impair existing judicial rulings of the State regarding Indians of the State; or
give the Commission the power to establish standards for membership in an Indian community.

paragraph.text: The power to establish standards for membership in an Indian community is reserved to the community.
An act or failure to act by the Commission under this section does not create a private cause of action under State law.

section.text: Before formal recognition of Maryland Indian status, members of the petitioning group shall submit an affidavit renouncing all tribal rights of ownership of land in the State.

paragraph.text: In accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 1 of this article, the Commission shall adopt regulations to carry out §§ 9.5–309 and 9.5–310 of this subtitle.
The regulations shall:

subparagraph.text: create the application process;
set genealogical standards; and
specify the standards to be satisfied by an Indian community applying for formal recognition of Maryland Indian status.

paragraph.text: The standards adopted under subsection (a) of this section shall be generally consistent with the standards of the United States Bureau of Indian Affairs for tribal recognition by the United States.
The standards shall take into account the special circumstances of Indians indigenous to the State.
The standards shall require:

subparagraph.text: that the petitioning group be identified from historical times until the present as Indian;

that the members of the petitioning group be descendants from an Indian tribe that existed historically and is indigenous to the State or derived from historical tribes that were indigenous to the State before 1790;
that the members of the petitioning group be descendants of an Indian tribe that historically inhabited a specific area in the State before 1790; and
that the membership of the petitioning group be composed principally of individuals who are not members of any other Indian community.

paragraph.text: The Commission may adopt regulations to establish any other standards that the Commission considers necessary.

subsection.text: In a matter within the scope of this subtitle, a person may not:

paragraph.text: knowingly and willfully falsify or conceal a material fact by trick, scheme, or device;
make a false, fictitious, or fraudulent statement or representation; or
make or use a false writing or document knowing the writing or document contains a false, fictitious, or fraudulent statement or entry.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, a person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Commission” means the Commission on African American History and Culture.
There is a Commission on African American History and Culture in the Governor’s Office of Community Initiatives.

subsection.text: The Commission consists of 21 members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The members shall:

paragraph.text: represent the entire community of the State;
know about African American culture and history;
be sensitive to the problems of minority communities; and
be connected with agencies working to integrate minority history and culture into the history of the State and American culture.
The term of a member is 4 years.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Commission on October 1, 2005, and October 1, 2011.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a member may be reappointed.
A member who has served two consecutive four–year terms may not be reappointed until at least one year has elapsed after the end of the previous term.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member for incompetence or misconduct.

section.text: The Commission shall elect annually a chair and vice chair from among its members.

subsection.text: The Commission shall meet at the call of the chair, a majority of the members, or the Governor.
A member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Commission; but
is entitled to receive reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
With the approval of the Governor, the Commission shall appoint a director.
The director may not be a member of the Commission.
The director serves at the pleasure of the Commission, subject to the concurrence of the Governor.

subsection.text: The director is a special appointment in the State Personnel Management System.
Subject to the rules and policies adopted by the Commission and the administrative supervision of the Governor in accordance with Title 8, Subtitle 3 of this article, the director shall:

paragraph.text: administer the activities of the Commission; and
supervise the appointment and removal of Commission personnel.

section.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: initiate, direct, and coordinate projects that further the understanding of African American history and culture;
receive and administer any available federal, State, or private money to plan and execute projects or educational activities that further the understanding of African American history and culture;
operate the Banneker–Douglass Museum in Annapolis to house and display photographs, objects, oral history tapes, artifacts, and other materials of African American historic and cultural significance;
locate, preserve, and disseminate to the public information about significant buildings and sites relating to African American history and culture; and
publish an annual report and any other material that the Commission considers necessary.
The Commission may seek money from the federal government, foundations, and private sources in addition to State financing.
The Commission may accept gifts, grants, donations, bequests, or endowments for any of its purposes.

subsection.text: Money received under subsection (a) of this section, income from the operation of the Banneker–Douglass Museum, and money from educational materials and activities of the Commission are not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
Money maintained under this section is subject to audit by the State, including the Legislative Auditor.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administrator” means the Administrator of the Division of State Documents.
“Committee” means the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review.
“Local government unit” means:

paragraph.text: a county;
a municipal corporation;
a special district that is established by State law and that operates within a single county;
a special district that is established by a county pursuant to public general law; or
an office, board, or department that is established in each county under State law and that is funded, pursuant to State law, at least in part by the county governing body.

subsection.text: “Mandate” means a directive in a regulation that requires a local government unit to perform a task or assume a responsibility that has a discernible fiscal impact on the local government unit.
“Register” means the Maryland Register.

paragraph.text: “Regulation” means a statement or an amendment or repeal of a statement that:

subparagraph.text: has general application;
has future effect;
is adopted by a unit to:

sub-subparagraph.text: detail or carry out a law that the unit administers;
govern organization of the unit;
govern the procedure of the unit; or
govern practice before the unit; and

subparagraph.text: is in any form, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: a guideline;
a rule;
a standard;
a statement of interpretation; or
a statement of policy.

paragraph.text: “Regulation” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a statement that:

sub-subparagraph.text: concerns only internal management of the unit; and
does not affect directly the rights of the public or the procedures available to the public;

subparagraph.text: a response of the unit to a petition for adoption of a regulation, under § 10–123 of this subtitle; or
a declaratory ruling of the unit as to a regulation, order, or statute, under Subtitle 3 of this title.

paragraph.text: “Regulation”, as used in §§ 10–110 and 10–111.1 of this subtitle, means all or any portion of a regulation.

subsection.text: “Substantively” means in a manner substantially affecting the rights, duties, or obligations of:

paragraph.text: a member of a regulated group or profession; or
a member of the public.

subsection.text: “Unit” means an officer or unit authorized by law to adopt regulations.
Except as otherwise expressly provided by law, this subtitle applies to:

paragraph.text: each unit in the Executive Branch of the State government; and
each unit that:

subparagraph.text: is created by public general law; and
operates in at least 2 counties.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a unit in the Legislative Branch of the State government;
a unit in the Judicial Branch of the State government;
the Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund;
a board of license commissioners; or
the Rural Maryland Council.

section.caption: ** TAKES EFFECT OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012 **

subsection.text: Except as otherwise expressly provided by law, this subtitle applies to:

paragraph.text: each unit in the Executive Branch of the State government; and
each unit that:

subparagraph.text: is created by public general law; and
operates in at least 2 counties.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a unit in the Legislative Branch of the State government;
a unit in the Judicial Branch of the State government;
a board of license commissioners; or
the Rural Maryland Council.

section.text: This Part II of this subtitle does not apply to a regulation of a bicounty commission that county governing bodies appoint.
A regulation is not effective unless it contains a citation of the statutory authority for the regulation.

subsection.text: “Unit counsel” means the unit counsel for the Commission on Civil Rights, the Public Service Commission, and the State Ethics Commission.
Unless a proposed regulation is submitted to the Attorney General or to the unit counsel for approval as to legality, the regulation:

paragraph.text: may not be adopted under any statutory authority; and
if adopted, is not effective.

section.text: In the preparation of a regulation, a unit shall use the term “African American” instead of “Black”, “Negro”, “Afro-American”, or similar terms.
This Part III of this subtitle applies only to a unit in the Executive Branch of the State government.

subsection.text: Except for subsection (c) of this section, this section does not apply to a regulation adopted under § 10–111(b) of this subtitle.

At least 15 days before the date a proposed regulation is submitted to the Maryland Register for publication under § 10–112 of this subtitle, the promulgating unit shall submit to the State Children’s Environmental Health and Protection Advisory Council established under § 13–1503 of the Health – General Article for review any proposed regulations identified by the promulgating unit as having an impact on environmental hazards affecting the health of children.

paragraph.text: At least 15 days before the date a proposed regulation is submitted to the Maryland Register for publication under § 10–112 of this subtitle, the promulgating unit shall submit the proposed regulation to the Committee and the Department of Legislative Services.

subparagraph.text: If the proposed regulation, either in whole or in part, submitted to the Committee and the Department of Legislative Services in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection includes an increase or decrease in a fee for a license to practice any business activity, business or health occupation, or business or health profession licensed or otherwise regulated under State law, the promulgating unit shall include clearly written explanatory reasons that justify the increase or decrease in the fee.
If a regulation submitted under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph proposes an increase in a fee for a license, the written justification also shall include information about:

sub-subparagraph.text: the amount of money needed by the promulgating unit to operate effectively or to eliminate an imbalance between the revenues and expenditures of the unit;
the most recent year in which the promulgating unit had last increased its fees;

the structure of the promulgating unit as to whether it is one that retains the license fees it receives or passes them through to a national organization or association that creates and administers a uniform licensing examination that is taken by anyone in the United States who is seeking a license to practice a particular occupation or profession or business activity issued by the promulgating unit;
measures taken by the promulgating unit to avoid or mitigate the necessity of a fee increase and the results of those measures;

special circumstances about the activities and responsibilities of the promulgating unit, including investigations of individuals licensed by the unit, that have had an adverse impact on the unit’s operating expenses;
consideration given by the promulgating unit to the hardship a license fee increase may have on individuals and trainees licensed or regulated by the unit; and

actions taken by the promulgating unit to elicit the opinions of the individuals who are licensed by the promulgating unit and the members of the public as to the effectiveness and performance of the promulgating unit.

paragraph.text: The Committee is not required to take any action with respect to a proposed regulation submitted to it pursuant to subsection (c) of this section.

Failure by the Committee to approve or disapprove the proposed regulation during the period of preliminary review provided by subsection (c) of this section may not be construed to mean that the Committee approves or disapproves the proposed regulation.
During the preliminary review period, the Committee may take any action relating to the proposed regulation that the Committee is authorized to take under §§ 10–111.1 and 10–112 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Prior to the date specified in subsection (c) of this section, the promulgating unit is encouraged to submit the proposed regulation to the Committee and to consult with the Committee concerning the form and content of that regulation.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a unit may not adopt a proposed regulation until:

subparagraph.text: after submission of the proposed regulation to the Committee for preliminary review under § 10–110 of this subtitle; and
at least 45 days after its first publication in the Register.

If the Committee determines that an appropriate review cannot reasonably be conducted within 45 days and that an additional period of review is required, it may delay the adoption of the regulation by so notifying the promulgating unit and the Division of State Documents, in writing, prior to the expiration of the 45–day period.

If notice is provided to the promulgating unit pursuant to subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, the promulgating unit may not adopt the regulation until it notifies the Committee, in writing, of its intention to adopt the regulation and provides the Committee with a further period of review of the regulation that terminates not earlier than the later of the following:

sub-subparagraph.text: the 30th day following the notice provided by the promulgating unit under this subparagraph; or
the 105th day following the initial publication of the regulation in the Register.

paragraph.text: The promulgating unit shall permit public comment for at least 30 days of the 45–day period under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection.
The unit may adopt a proposed regulation immediately if the unit:

subparagraph.text: declares that the emergency adoption is necessary;
submits the proposed regulation to the Committee and the Department of Legislative Services, together with the fiscal impact statement required under subsection (c) of this section; and
has the approval of the Committee for the emergency adoption.
Subject to subparagraphs (ii), (iii), and (iv) of this paragraph, the approval of the Committee may be given:

sub-subparagraph.text: by a majority of its members who are present and voting at a public hearing or meeting of the Committee; or

if staff of the Committee tries but is unable to contact a majority of the members of the Committee in a timely manner and immediate adoption is necessary to protect the public health or safety, by its presiding Chairman or, if its presiding Chairman is unavailable, by its cochair.

subparagraph.text: If a member of the Committee requests a public hearing on the emergency adoption of a regulation, the Committee shall hold a public hearing.

sub-subparagraph.text: If a public hearing is held on the emergency adoption of a regulation, the Committee may not approve the emergency adoption except by a majority vote of the members present and voting at the hearing or at a meeting of the Committee subsequent to the hearing.

If a vote on the emergency regulation is not taken at the public hearing or immediately thereafter, the Committee members shall be provided at least 1 week’s notice of the scheduling of any subsequent meeting to vote on the regulation.

subparagraph.text: Unless the Governor declares that immediate adoption is necessary to protect the public health or safety, the Committee may not approve the emergency adoption of a regulation earlier than 10 business days after receipt of the regulation by the Committee and the Department of Legislative Services.

paragraph.text: If there is no request for a public hearing, the staff of the Committee may poll, in person, by telephone, or in writing:

subparagraph.text: the members of the Committee; or

if staff of the Committee tries but is unable to contact a majority of the members of the Committee in a timely manner and immediate adoption is necessary to protect the public health or safety, the presiding Chairman or the cochair.
The Committee may impose, as part of its approval, any condition.
The Committee shall impose, as part of its approval, a time limit not to exceed 180 days on each request for emergency status.
If the unit does not adopt the regulation finally before the time limit expires, the status of the regulation reverts to its status before the emergency adoption.

paragraph.text: The Committee may rescind its approval by a majority of its members present and voting at a public hearing or meeting of the Committee.
The fiscal impact statement, prepared by the unit and submitted under subsection (b) of this section, shall state:

subparagraph.text: an estimate of the impact of the emergency regulation on the revenues and expenditures of the State;
whether the State budget for the fiscal year in which the regulation will become effective contains an appropriation of the funds necessary for the implementation of the emergency regulation;
if an appropriation is not contained in the State budget, the source of the funds necessary for the implementation of the emergency regulation; and
whether the emergency regulation imposes a mandate on a local government unit.

paragraph.text: If the emergency regulation imposes a mandate on a local government unit, the fiscal impact statement shall:

subparagraph.text: indicate whether the regulation is required to comply with a federal statutory or regulatory mandate;

if the information may be practicably obtained given the emergency circumstances of the regulations, include an estimate of the impact of the emergency regulation on the revenues and expenditures of local government units; and
if applicable, and if the required data is available, include the estimated effect on local property tax rates.

paragraph.text: Prior to the expiration of any period of review granted to or reserved by the Committee pursuant to § 10-111(a) of this subtitle, the Committee, by a majority vote, may oppose the adoption of any proposed regulation.

Unless waived by both of the presiding officers, at least 2 weeks prior to acting pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section with respect to any proposed regulation, the Committee shall notify the presiding officers who shall notify the appropriate standing committees that the special procedure established by this section may be exercised.

subsection.text: In its review of a proposed regulation pursuant to this section, the factors the Committee shall consider shall include whether the regulation:

paragraph.text: is in conformity with the statutory authority of the promulgating unit; and
reasonably complies with the legislative intent of the statute under which the regulation was promulgated.
Within 5 working days after the Committee votes to oppose the adoption of a proposed regulation, it shall provide written notice to the Governor and the promulgating unit of its action.
Upon receipt of such notice, and with written notice to the Committee and as otherwise required by law, the promulgating unit may:

subparagraph.text: withdraw the regulation;
modify the regulation, but only in accordance with § 10-113 of this subtitle; or
submit the regulation to the Governor with a statement of the justification for the unit’s refusal to withdraw or modify the regulation.

paragraph.text: Following the receipt of notice under paragraph (2)(iii) above, the Governor may consult with the Committee and the unit in an effort to resolve the conflict. After written notice has been provided to the presiding officers and to the Committee, the Governor may:

subparagraph.text: instruct the unit to withdraw the regulation;
instruct the unit to modify the regulation, but only in accordance with § 10-113 of this subtitle; or
approve the adoption of the regulation.

subsection.text: A proposed regulation opposed by the Committee pursuant to this section may not be adopted, and is not effective unless approved, by the Governor pursuant to subsection (c)(3) of this section.

paragraph.text: The website of the General Assembly shall include a list of all emergency regulations the Committee has received but has not approved.
For each regulation, the list shall include:

subparagraph.text: the date the Committee received the regulation;
whether a member of the Committee has requested a public hearing;
the date of any public hearing scheduled;
the date and a summary of any action the Committee has taken; and
the name and telephone number of a member of the Committee’s staff who can provide further information.

paragraph.text: A regulation shall be added to the list within 3 business days after receipt of the regulation by the Committee and the Department of Legislative Services.

The Department of Legislative Services shall maintain a list of members of the public who have requested to receive notice when the Department of Legislative Services receives proposed regulations for which the promulgating unit has requested emergency adoption.
A member of the public who requests notice under this subsection shall specify:

subparagraph.text: whether the individual wants to receive notice by United States mail or electronic mail; and
which agencies’ regulations the individual wants to receive notice of receipt.

paragraph.text: Within 2 business days of receipt of a proposed regulation, the Department of Legislative Services shall provide notice to members of the public who have requested notice, as specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection.
The Department of Legislative Services:

subparagraph.text: may impose a reasonable fee for sending notice under this subsection by United States mail; and
may not impose a fee for sending notice under this subsection by electronic mail.

paragraph.text: Upon request, a promulgating unit shall provide copies of emergency regulations to members of the public.
This subsection does not apply to the emergency adoption of a regulation.
To have a proposed regulation published in the Register, a unit shall submit to the Administrator:

subparagraph.text: the proposed regulation; and
a notice of the proposed adoption.

paragraph.text: The notice under this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: state the estimated economic impact of the proposed regulation on:

sub-subparagraph.text: the revenues and expenditures of units of the State government and of local government units; and
groups such as consumer, industry, taxpayer, or trade groups;

subparagraph.text: include a statement of purpose;
satisfy the requirements of § 2–1505.2 of this article;
comply with § 7–113(c) of the Human Services Article; and
give persons an opportunity to comment before adoption of the proposed regulation, by:

sub-subparagraph.text: setting a date, time, and place for a public hearing at which oral or written views and information may be submitted; or
giving a telephone number that a person may call to comment and an address to which a person may send comments.

subparagraph.text: The estimated economic impact statement required under paragraph (3)(i) of this subsection shall state whether the proposed regulation imposes a mandate on a local government unit.
If the proposed regulation imposes a mandate, the fiscal impact statement shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: indicate whether the regulation is required to comply with a federal statutory or regulatory mandate; and
include, in addition to the estimate under paragraph (3)(i)1 of this subsection, the estimated effect on local property tax rates, if applicable, and if the required data is available.

subsection.text: As soon as the Committee approves emergency adoption of a regulation, the Committee shall submit the regulation to the Administrator.
If a regulation under this section amends or repeals an adopted regulation, the text of the regulation under this section shall show the changes with the symbols that the Administrator requires.

Whenever a unit publishes a proposed regulation in the Register in accordance with § 10–112 of this subtitle, the unit shall publish the text of the proposed regulation on the unit’s Web site not later than 3 business days after the date that the proposed regulation is published in the Register.

Whenever a unit submits a regulation to the Committee for approval as an emergency adoption in accordance with § 10–111(b) of this subtitle, the unit shall publish the text of the regulation on the unit’s Web site not later than 3 business days after the date that the regulation is submitted to the Committee for approval of emergency adoption.
To comply with the publication requirement of this section, a unit shall:

paragraph.text: publish the text of the regulation on the unit’s home page on its Web site; or
provide a link on the unit’s home page to the text of the regulation if the text of the regulation is available elsewhere on the unit’s Web site.

subsection.text: The failure of a unit to publish the text of a regulation in a timely manner under this section may not invalidate or otherwise affect the adoption of the regulation.
In this section, “unit counsel” has the meaning stated in § 10–107 of this subtitle.

If a unit wishes to change the text of a proposed regulation so that any part of the text differs substantively from the text previously published in the Register, the unit may not adopt the proposed regulation unless it is proposed anew and adopted in accordance with the requirements of §§ 10–111 and 10–112 of this subtitle.
If the regulation is proposed anew, the changes in the text shall be shown with the symbols that the Administrator requires.

paragraph.text: The Administrator shall refuse to publish the notice of adoption of a regulation that differs from the text previously published unless the notice is accompanied by a certification from the Attorney General or the unit counsel that the provisions of subsections (b) and (c) of this section are not applicable.
The certification shall:

subparagraph.text: be prepared in the form and according to guidelines specified by the Administrator;
contain a description of the nature of each change and the basis for the conclusion; and
be published in the Register as part of the notice of adoption.

subsection.text: After adopting a regulation, a unit shall submit to the Administrator a notice of adoption, for publication in the Register.
If the text of the adopted regulation is the same or substantially similar to the proposed regulation, the notice shall:

paragraph.text: state that the texts are the same or substantially similar;
cite the date of the Register in which the proposed regulation was published; and
show each change in the text with the symbols that the Administrator requires.

subsection.text: A unit may not reset or reprint a regulation in the Code of Maryland Regulations, the permanent supplements to the Code of Maryland Regulations, or the Register without the written permission of the Committee.
Before reprinting a regulation under this section, a unit shall submit the proposed text of the regulation to the Division of State Documents for comparison with the official text.
A unit:

paragraph.text: may withdraw a proposed regulation at any time before its adoption; but
may not adopt the proposed regulation unless it is proposed anew and adopted in accordance with the requirements of §§ 10-111 and 10-112 of this subtitle.
The failure to adopt a proposed regulation within 1 year after its last publication in the Register constitutes withdrawal under this section.
The Administrator shall publish in the Register notice of a withdrawal of a proposed regulation under this subsection.
Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section or in other law, the effective date of a regulation is:

subparagraph.text: the 10th calendar day after notice of adoption is published in the Register; or
a later date that the notice sets.

paragraph.text: For calculation of the effective date under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: Article 1, § 36 of the Code does not apply;
the issue date of the Register in which the notice is published is not counted; and
each other calendar day, including Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, is counted.

subsection.text: The effective date of a regulation after its emergency adoption is the date that the Committee sets.

section.text: The Committee may exercise a power granted under this subtitle over an emergency or proposed regulation or a specific, distinct, and severable provision of an emergency or proposed regulation.

subsection.text: This Part IV of this subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the Governor;
the Department of Assessments and Taxation;
the Board of Appeals of the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
the Insurance Administration;
the Maryland Parole Commission of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services;
the Public Service Commission;
the Maryland Tax Court; or
the State Workers’ Compensation Commission.

subsection.text: If the Insurance Commissioner states in writing that, as to a particular matter, the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund need not comply with this Part IV of this subtitle, this Part IV does not apply to the Fund with respect to that matter.
This subtitle does apply to the property tax assessment appeals boards.

section.text: A political subdivision of the State or an instrumentality of a political subdivision is entitled, to the same extent as other legal entities, to be an interested person, party, or petitioner in a matter under this subtitle, including an appeal.

subsection.text: Each unit shall adopt regulations to govern procedures under this Part IV of this subtitle, including the related forms that the unit requires and the instructions for completing the forms.
To help persons deal with the unit, the unit shall supplement, so far as practicable, the regulations under this section with a description of the procedures of the unit.
An interested person may submit to a unit a petition for the adoption of a regulation.
Within 60 days after the petition is submitted, the unit shall:

paragraph.text: in writing, deny the petition and state the reasons for the denial; or
initiate the procedures for adoption of the regulation.

subsection.text: In this section, “business” means a trade, professional activity, or other business that is conducted for profit.

paragraph.text: Before a unit adopts a proposed regulation, the unit shall evaluate whether the proposed regulation has any impact on businesses.
To evaluate the impact, the unit shall:

subparagraph.text: on the basis of the sizes of the businesses that the proposed regulation might affect, divide those businesses into any classes that the unit considers appropriate for the proposed regulation; and
particularly consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the costs that the proposed regulation would impose on each class; and
the difficulty of compliance for each class.

subsection.text: On the basis of the evaluation, the unit may adopt 1 or more regulations that apply differently to classes of businesses.

paragraph.text: A person may file a petition for a declaratory judgment on the validity of any regulation, whether or not the person has asked the unit to consider the validity of the regulation.
A petition under this section shall be filed with the circuit court for the county where the petitioner resides or has a principal place of business.

subsection.text: A court may determine the validity of any regulation if it appears to the court that the regulation or its threatened application interferes with or impairs or threatens to interfere with or impair a legal right or privilege of the petitioner.
The unit that adopted the regulation shall be made a party to the proceeding under this section.
Subject to § 10-128 of this subtitle, the court shall declare a provision of a regulation invalid if the court finds that:

paragraph.text: the provision violates any provision of the United States or Maryland Constitution;
the provision exceeds the statutory authority of the unit; or
the unit failed to comply with statutory requirements for adoption of the provision.

subsection.text: Unless a regulation expressly states otherwise, its provisions are severable.

The finding of a court that a provision of a regulation is invalid invalidates only any other provision of the regulation that the court finds then is so incomplete that it cannot be carried out in accordance with the purpose of the regulation.
This section applies only to a unit in the Executive Branch of the State government.
Whenever a court of final appeal declares all or any part of a regulation invalid and unconstitutional:

paragraph.text: the unit that adopted the regulation shall have notice of that fact published in the Register; and
the Administrator shall publish notice of that fact in the permanent supplements or otherwise in the Code of Maryland Regulations.

subsection.text: In this Part VI the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Adopting authority” means the individual or entity charged under law with adopting regulations for a unit.
“Committee” means the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review.
“Evaluation report” means the document prepared by a unit of State government in accordance with this part that results from the unit’s review of its regulations.
“Regulation” has the meaning stated in § 10-101(g) of this subtitle and is limited to those regulations in effect at the time any action is required or taken under this part.
“Stakeholder” means a person that has an interest in or is impacted by an existing regulation.
“Unit” means each unit in the Executive Branch of State government that is authorized by law to adopt regulations.
“Work plan” means a unit’s proposal for the evaluation of its regulations.

section.text: This part does not apply to a regulation of a bi-county or multicounty commission or authority or to any other entity not a part of the Executive Branch of State government.
The purposes of this part are to:

paragraph.text: establish a system of executive and legislative evaluation of regulations that will:

subparagraph.text: determine whether the regulations of a unit:

sub-subparagraph.text: continue to be necessary for the public interest;
continue to be supported by statutory authority and judicial opinions; and
are obsolete or otherwise are appropriate for amendment or repeal; and

subparagraph.text: assist the Executive Branch in being accountable and responsive to the public interest; and

paragraph.text: assure that the evaluation takes place in a timely and orderly manner.

Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the adopting authority for each unit shall every 8 years, beginning on or after October 1, 2001, submit to the Governor and to the Committee a schedule of regulations to be reviewed under this part during the following 8 years.

subparagraph.text: To the extent possible and reasonable, an adopting authority shall schedule related regulations to be reviewed concurrently.

Unless good cause exists for publishing a larger group of regulations concurrently, the largest group of regulations that an adopting authority may schedule for review concurrently shall be a subtitle.

paragraph.text: At the time that a unit’s regulations are scheduled for review under this part, an adopting authority may certify to the Committee and the Governor that the review of a regulation or group of related regulations would not be effective or cost-effective and is exempt from the review process under this subtitle because the regulation or group of related regulations was:

subparagraph.text: adopted to implement a federally mandated or federally approved program; or
initially adopted or comprehensively amended during the preceding 8 years.

paragraph.text: An adopting authority issuing a certificate of exemption shall provide the Governor and Committee with written justification for the certificate of exemption.

If there is more than one adopting authority for a regulation or group of related regulations for which an exemption is to be certified, each adopting authority shall sign the certificate of exemption and written justification required under this subsection.

subsection.text: At any time during a review cycle, the Governor or Committee may ask that an adopting authority review a regulation or group of regulations for which a certificate of exemption has been issued, notwithstanding the claim of exemption.

Based on the schedules submitted by the adopting authorities under § 10-132.1 of this subtitle, the Governor shall, by an executive order consistent with this part, provide for the review and evaluation of the regulations of each unit in accordance with this part.

The executive order shall provide that a review and evaluation of the regulations of all units be undertaken every 8 years, beginning on July 1, 1995 and is repeated during each 8-year period thereafter.
The executive order under subsection (b) of this section shall schedule the evaluations in such a manner that:

paragraph.text: a deadline is established for each unit to complete its evaluation; and
the deadlines of the various units are staggered across the entire 8-year period.
The executive order shall provide that, on written request from a unit, the Governor may alter the deadline for that unit.
If the Governor approves a request to alter a deadline, the unit shall notify the Committee.

subsection.text: At least 1 year before the commencement of the review and evaluation of its regulations, each unit shall prepare a work plan and submit the work plan to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of this article, the Committee.
The work plan shall:

paragraph.text: include a description of the procedures and methods to be used by the unit, which may include:

subparagraph.text: procedures for inviting public comment, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: the publication of notices in the Maryland Register;
the publication of notices in newspapers of general circulation in the State;
the posting of a notice on the unit’s website or on a statewide website created for units to post notices of regulations review;
the mailing of notices; and
the holding of public hearings at various locations around the State;

subparagraph.text: procedures for ensuring the participation of stakeholders in the review process;
procedures for ensuring the participation in the review process of other units affected by the regulations; and
procedures for gathering and reviewing:

sub-subparagraph.text: recent scientific information related to the regulations being reviewed;
similar regulations adopted or repealed by other states or the federal government; and
other appropriate information;

paragraph.text: identify the individual or individuals in the unit who will coordinate the evaluation and communicate with the Committee; and
establish the schedule the unit will follow to complete its evaluation report in a timely manner.
Within 30 days after receipt of the work plan by the Committee, it shall:

subparagraph.text: advise the unit in writing of any part of the work plan with which it disagrees;
submit to the unit in writing any changes it recommends to the work plan; and
in the event of a disagreement, attempt to meet with the head of the unit.

paragraph.text: The head of the unit and the Committee shall attempt to resolve any disagreements within 30 days after the Committee acts under this subsection.
Pursuant to the work plan adopted under § 10-134 of this subtitle, each unit shall complete an evaluation report on or before the deadline established by the executive order.
Consistent with the requirements of § 10-132(1)(i) of this subtitle, the evaluation report shall contain:

subparagraph.text: a list of any stakeholders invited to review the regulations and a summary of their participation in and input into the review process;
a list of any affected units invited to review the regulations and a summary of their participation in and input into the review process;
a description of the process used to solicit public comment, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: any notice published in the Maryland Register;
any notice published in newspapers of general circulation;
any notice posted on the unit’s website or on a statewide website created for units to post notices of regulations review;
any mailing by the adopting authority; and
any public hearing held;

subparagraph.text: summaries of:

sub-subparagraph.text: all comments received from stakeholders, affected units, or the public; and
the adopting authority’s responses to those comments;

subparagraph.text: a description of any interunit conflict reviewed and the resolution or proposed resolution of that conflict;
a summary of any relevant scientific data gathered;
a summary of any relevant information gathered related to the regulations of other states or the federal government;
a summary of any other relevant information gathered;
a summary of any proposed amendments to the unit’s regulations and the reason that the amendments are being proposed;
a summary of any proposed repeal of those regulations and the reason that the repeal is being proposed; and
any proposed reorganization of those regulations and the reason that the reorganization is being proposed.

paragraph.text: On completion of its evaluation report, a unit shall:

subparagraph.text: provide a copy to the Committee which shall immediately provide copies thereof to the standing committees designated by the presiding officers for their review and comment;
provide sufficient copies to the State Library Resource Center for distribution to designated depository libraries in accordance with § 23-303 of the Education Article; and
publish a notice in the Maryland Register that the evaluation report is available for public inspection and comment for 60 days.

paragraph.text: The unit may hold a public hearing on the evaluation report at the discretion of the head of the unit.
The Committee shall review the evaluation report.
During the review, the Committee may solicit public comment through written comments or public hearings.
During the 60-day review period established under subsection (b)(1) of this section, the Committee may submit to the unit comments on and recommendations for change in the unit’s evaluation report.
Within 30 days after the termination of the 60-day review period, the unit shall:

subparagraph.text: notify the Committee of the unit’s agreement or disagreement with the Committee’s recommendations; and
attempt to resolve any disagreements.

paragraph.text: If the Committee submits no comments or recommendations under this subsection, or if any disagreements have been resolved by the termination of the period provided in subsection (d)(2) of this section, the evaluation report is deemed approved.

If a unit other than those referred to in § 10–137 of this subtitle, disagrees with a Committee recommendation and the disagreement has not been resolved by the termination of the period provided under § 10–135(d)(2) of this subtitle, the unit, within 30 days thereafter, shall submit the evaluation report to the Governor with an explanation of the disagreement and a statement of justification for the unit’s position.
After receipt of the report and accompanying justification and after consulting with the presiding Chairman of the Committee, the Governor shall:

subparagraph.text: approve the evaluation report either as proposed by the unit or with such modifications as the Governor deems appropriate; or
instruct the unit to modify the evaluation report and, under this section, to submit a revised report to the Governor and to the Committee.

subsection.text: The unit shall provide the Committee, subject to § 2–1246 of this article, with a copy of an evaluation report approved by the Governor and any other written action taken by the Governor under this section.
This section applies to the Comptroller, the Treasurer, the Attorney General, and the Board of Public Works.

Within 30 days of the receipt by one of the units referred to in subsection (a) of this section of a Committee comment or recommendation under § 10–135(d) of this subtitle with which that unit disagrees, the Comptroller, the Treasurer, the Attorney General, or the Board of Public Works, as the case may be, shall, after consultation with the Committee, resolve the disagreement.
The unit involved shall promptly notify the Committee of any resolution of a disagreement under this section and provide the Committee with a copy of the approved evaluation report.

Within 120 days after an evaluation report is approved pursuant to § 10-135(d)(3), § 10-136(a)(2)(i), or § 10-137 of this subtitle, the unit shall propose for adoption any amendments to or repeal of its regulations that were summarized in the unit’s evaluation report as approved.
The amendments or repeal shall be proposed in the manner provided under Part III of this subtitle.

section.text: This Part VI of this subtitle may be cited as the “Regulatory Review and Evaluation Act”.
The purpose of this subtitle is to:

paragraph.text: ensure the right of all persons to be treated in a fair and unbiased manner in their efforts to resolve disputes in administrative proceedings governed by this subtitle; and
promote prompt, effective, and efficient government.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agency” means:

paragraph.text: an officer or unit of the State government authorized by law to adjudicate contested cases; or
a unit that:

subparagraph.text: is created by general law;
operates in at least 2 counties; and
is authorized by law to adjudicate contested cases.

subsection.text: “Agency head” means:
