paragraph.text: an individual or group of individuals in whom the ultimate legal authority of an agency is vested by any provision of law; or
the secretary of the State department that is responsible for State programs that are administered by the Montgomery County Department of Health and Human Services.
“Contested case” means a proceeding before an agency to determine:

subparagraph.text: a right, duty, statutory entitlement, or privilege of a person that is required by statute or constitution to be determined only after an opportunity for an agency hearing; or
the grant, denial, renewal, revocation, suspension, or amendment of a license that is required by statute or constitution to be determined only after an opportunity for an agency hearing.

paragraph.text: “Contested case” does not include a proceeding before an agency involving an agency hearing required only by regulation unless the regulation expressly, or by clear implication, requires the hearing to be held in accordance with this subtitle.

subsection.text: “License” means all or any part of permission that:

paragraph.text: is required by law to be obtained from an agency;
is not required only for revenue purposes; and
is in any form, including:

subparagraph.text: an approval;
a certificate;
a charter;
a permit; or
a registration.

subsection.text: “Office” means the Office of Administrative Hearings.
“Presiding officer” means the board, commission, agency head, administrative law judge, or other authorized person conducting an administrative proceeding under this subtitle.
This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the Legislative Branch of the State government or an agency of the Legislative Branch;
the Judicial Branch of the State government or an agency of the Judicial Branch;
the following agencies of the Executive Branch of the State government:

subparagraph.text: the Governor;
the Department of Assessments and Taxation;
the Insurance Administration except as specifically provided in the Insurance Article;
the Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund;
the Maryland Parole Commission of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services;
the Public Service Commission;
the Maryland Tax Court;
the State Workers’ Compensation Commission;
the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund; or
the Patuxent Institution Board of Review, when acting on a parole request;

paragraph.text: an officer or unit not part of a principal department of State government that:

subparagraph.text: is created by or pursuant to the Maryland Constitution or general or local law;
operates in only 1 county; and
is subject to the control of a local government or is funded wholly or partly from local funds;

paragraph.text: unemployment insurance claim determinations, tax determinations, and appeals in the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation except as specifically provided in Subtitle 5A of Title 8 of the Labor and Employment Article; or
any other entity otherwise expressly exempted by statute.

subsection.text: This subtitle does apply to:

paragraph.text: the property tax assessment appeals boards; and
as to requests for correction of certificates of death under § 5–310(d)(2) of the Health – General Article, the office of the Chief Medical Examiner.

subsection.text: A public hearing required or provided for by statute or regulation before an agency takes a particular action is not an agency hearing under § 10–202(d) of this subtitle unless the statute or regulation:

paragraph.text: expressly requires that the public hearing be held in accordance with this subtitle; or
expressly requires that any judicial review of the agency determination following the public hearing be conducted in accordance with this subtitle.

Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, this subtitle does apply to a contested case that arises from a State program administered by the Montgomery County Department of Health and Human Services in the same manner as the subtitle applies to a county health department or local department of social services.

For purposes of this subtitle, the Office of the Attorney General, after consultation with the County Attorney for Montgomery County, shall determine if the Montgomery County Department of Health and Human Services administers a State program.

This subsection is not intended to extend or limit the authority of the Montgomery County Department of Health and Human Services to administer State programs in the manner of a county health department or local department of social services.

section.caption: ** TAKES EFFECT OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012 **

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the Legislative Branch of the State government or an agency of the Legislative Branch;
the Judicial Branch of the State government or an agency of the Judicial Branch;
the following agencies of the Executive Branch of the State government:

subparagraph.text: the Governor;
the Department of Assessments and Taxation;
the Insurance Administration except as specifically provided in the Insurance Article;
the Maryland Parole Commission of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services;
the Public Service Commission;
the Maryland Tax Court;
the State Workers’ Compensation Commission;
the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund; or
the Patuxent Institution Board of Review, when acting on a parole request;

paragraph.text: an officer or unit not part of a principal department of State government that:

subparagraph.text: is created by or pursuant to the Maryland Constitution or general or local law;
operates in only 1 county; and
is subject to the control of a local government or is funded wholly or partly from local funds;

paragraph.text: unemployment insurance claim determinations, tax determinations, and appeals in the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation except as specifically provided in Subtitle 5A of Title 8 of the Labor and Employment Article; or
any other entity otherwise expressly exempted by statute.

subsection.text: This subtitle does apply to:

paragraph.text: the property tax assessment appeals boards; and
as to requests for correction of certificates of death under § 5–310(d)(2) of the Health – General Article, the office of the Chief Medical Examiner.

subsection.text: A public hearing required or provided for by statute or regulation before an agency takes a particular action is not an agency hearing under § 10–202(d) of this subtitle unless the statute or regulation:

paragraph.text: expressly requires that the public hearing be held in accordance with this subtitle; or
expressly requires that any judicial review of the agency determination following the public hearing be conducted in accordance with this subtitle.

Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, this subtitle does apply to a contested case that arises from a State program administered by the Montgomery County Department of Health and Human Services in the same manner as the subtitle applies to a county health department or local department of social services.

For purposes of this subtitle, the Office of the Attorney General, after consultation with the County Attorney for Montgomery County, shall determine if the Montgomery County Department of Health and Human Services administers a State program.

This subsection is not intended to extend or limit the authority of the Montgomery County Department of Health and Human Services to administer State programs in the manner of a county health department or local department of social services.

section.text: A political subdivision of the State or an instrumentality of a political subdivision is entitled, to the same extent as other legal entities, to be an interested person, party, or petitioner in a matter under this subtitle, including an appeal.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a board, commission, or agency head authorized to conduct a contested case hearing shall:

subparagraph.text: conduct the hearing; or
delegate the authority to conduct the contested case hearing to:

sub-subparagraph.text: the Office; or
with the prior written approval of the Chief Administrative Law Judge, a person not employed by the Office.

paragraph.text: A hearing held in accordance with § 4-608(f) or § 5-610(f) of the Business Occupations and Professions Article may not be delegated to the Office.
With the written approval of the Chief Administrative Law Judge, a class of contested case hearings may be delegated as provided in paragraph (1)(ii)2 of this subsection.
This subsection is not intended to restrict the right of an individual, expressly authorized by a statute in effect on October 1, 1993, to conduct a contested case hearing.

subsection.text: An agency may delegate to the Office the authority to issue:

paragraph.text: proposed or final findings of fact;
proposed or final conclusions of law;
proposed or final findings of fact and conclusions of law;
proposed or final orders or orders under Title 20 of this article; or
the final administrative decision of an agency in a contested case.

subsection.text: Promptly after receipt of a request for a contested case hearing, an agency shall:

paragraph.text: notify the parties that the authorized agency head, board, or commission shall conduct the hearing;
transmit the request to the Office so that the Office shall conduct the hearing in accordance with the agency’s delegation; or
request written approval from the Chief Administrative Law Judge to appoint a person not employed by the Office to conduct the hearing.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, an agency’s delegation and transmittal of all or part of a contested case to the Office is final.

If an agency has adopted regulations specifying the criteria and procedures for the revocation of a delegation of a contested case, delegation of authority to hear all or part of a contested case may be revoked, by the agency head, board, or commission, in accordance with the agency’s regulations, at any time prior to the earlier of:

subparagraph.text: the issuance of a ruling on a substantive issue; or
the taking of oral testimony from the first witness.

paragraph.text: The Office shall:

subparagraph.text: conduct the hearing; and

except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection or as otherwise required by law, within 90 days after the completion of the hearing, complete the procedure authorized in the agency’s delegation to the Office.

paragraph.text: The time limit specified in paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection may be extended with the written approval of the Chief Administrative Law Judge.
The Office shall adopt regulations to govern the procedures and practice in all contested cases delegated to the Office and conducted under this subtitle.

Unless a federal or State law requires that a federal or State procedure shall be observed, the regulations adopted under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall take precedence in the event of a conflict.

subsection.text: Each agency may adopt regulations to govern procedures under this subtitle and practice before the agency in contested cases.
Regulations adopted under this section may include procedures and criteria for requesting and conducting expedited hearings.
Each agency and the Office may adopt regulations that:

paragraph.text: provide for prehearing conferences in contested cases; or
set other appropriate prehearing procedures in contested cases.

subsection.text: To assist the public in understanding the procedures followed by an agency or the Office in contested cases, an agency or the Office may develop and distribute supplemental explanatory materials, including the related forms that the agency or Office requires and instructions for completing the forms.
An agency may not:

paragraph.text: grant the right to practice law to an individual who is not authorized to practice law;
interfere with the right of a lawyer to practice before an agency or the Office; or
prohibit any party from being advised or represented at the party’s own expense by an attorney or, if permitted by law, other representative.

subsection.text: Subsection (a) of this section may not be interpreted to require the State to furnish publicly provided legal services in any proceeding under this subtitle.
An agency shall give reasonable notice of the agency’s action.
The notice shall:

paragraph.text: state concisely and simply:

subparagraph.text: the facts that are asserted; or
if the facts cannot be stated in detail when the notice is given, the issues that are involved;

paragraph.text: state the pertinent statutory and regulatory sections under which the agency is taking its action;
state the sanction proposed or the potential penalty, if any, as a result of the agency’s action;
unless a hearing is automatically scheduled, state that the recipient of notice of an agency’s action may have an opportunity to request a hearing, including:

subparagraph.text: what, if anything, a person must do to receive a hearing; and
all relevant time requirements; and

paragraph.text: state the direct consequences, sanction, potential penalty, if any, or remedy of the recipient’s failure to exercise in a timely manner the opportunity for a hearing or to appear for a scheduled hearing.

subsection.text: The notice of agency action under this section may be consolidated with the notice of hearing required under § 10-208 of this subtitle.
For purposes of this section, publication in the Maryland Register does not constitute reasonable notice to a party.
An agency or the Office shall give all parties in a contested case reasonable written notice of the hearing.
The notice shall state:

paragraph.text: the date, time, place, and nature of the hearing;
the right to call witnesses and submit documents or other evidence under § 10-213(f) of this subtitle;
any applicable right to request subpoenas for witnesses and evidence and specify the costs, if any, associated with such a request;
that a copy of the hearing procedure is available on request and specify the costs associated with such a request;
any right or restriction pertaining to representation;
that failure to appear for the scheduled hearing may result in an adverse action against the party; and
that, unless otherwise prohibited by law, the parties may agree to the evidence and waive their right to appear at the hearing.

subsection.text: The notice of hearing may be consolidated with the notice of agency action required under § 10-207 of this subtitle.
For purposes of this subtitle, publication in the Maryland Register does not constitute reasonable notice to a party.

Where a licensing statute provides for service other than by regular mail, notice under this subtitle may be sent by regular mail to the address of record of a person holding a license issued by the agency if:

paragraph.text: the person is required by law to advise the agency of the address; and
the agency has been unsuccessful in giving notice in the manner otherwise provided by the licensing statute.

subsection.text: Upon a showing that the person neither knew nor had reasonable opportunity to know of the fact of service, a person served by regular mail under subsection (a) of this section shall be granted a hearing.
A person holding a license shall be deemed to have had a reasonable opportunity to know of the fact of service if:

paragraph.text: the person is required by law to notify the agency of a change of address within a specified period of time;
the person failed to notify the agency in accordance with the law;
the agency or the Office mailed the notice to the address of record; and
the agency did not have actual notice of the change of address prior to service.

section.text: Unless otherwise precluded by law, an agency or the Office may dispose of a contested case by:

paragraph.text: stipulation;
settlement;
consent order;
default;
withdrawal;
summary disposition; or
dismissal.

subsection.text: In accordance with subsection (b) of this section, a hearing may be conducted by telephone, video conferencing, or other electronic means.

paragraph.text: For good cause, a party may object to the holding of a hearing by telephone, video conferencing, or other electronic means.

If a party establishes good cause in opposition to the holding of a hearing by telephone or other similar audio electronic means, the hearing shall be held in person or by video conferencing or other similar audiovisual electronic means.
If a party establishes good cause in opposition to the holding of a hearing by video conferencing or other similar audiovisual electronic means, the hearing shall be conducted in person.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, a contested case hearing conducted by the Office shall be open to the public.
Hearings conducted by the Office are not subject to Subtitle 5 of this title.

paragraph.text: In a contested case, a party or witness may apply to the agency for the appointment of a qualified interpreter to assist that party or witness, if the party or witness is deaf or, because of a hearing impediment, cannot readily understand or communicate the spoken English language.
On application of the party or witness the agency shall appoint a qualified interpreter.

In selecting a qualified interpreter for appointment, the agency may consult the directory of interpreters for manual communication or oral interpretation to assist deaf persons that is maintained by the courts of the State.
An interpreter appointed under this section shall be allowed the compensation that the agency considers reasonable.
Subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, the compensation shall be paid by the agency.

If the agency has the authority to tax for services and expenses as a part of the costs of a case, the agency may tax the amount paid to an interpreter as a part of these services and expenses in accordance with the federal Americans with Disabilities Act.
Each party in a contested case shall offer all of the evidence that the party wishes to have made part of the record.
If the agency has any evidence that the agency wishes to use in adjudicating the contested case, the agency shall make the evidence part of the record.

subsection.text: The presiding officer may admit probative evidence that reasonable and prudent individuals commonly accept in the conduct of their affairs and give probative effect to that evidence.
Evidence may not be excluded solely on the basis that it is hearsay.
The presiding officer may exclude evidence that is:

paragraph.text: incompetent;
irrelevant;
immaterial; or
unduly repetitious.

subsection.text: The presiding officer shall apply a privilege that law recognizes.
On a genuine issue in a contested case, each party is entitled to:

paragraph.text: call witnesses;
offer evidence, including rebuttal evidence;
cross-examine any witness that another party or the agency calls; and
present summation and argument.

subsection.text: The presiding officer may receive documentary evidence:

paragraph.text: in the form of copies or excerpts; or
by incorporation by reference.
The agency or the Office may take official notice of a fact that is:

subparagraph.text: judicially noticeable; or
general, technical, or scientific and within the specialized knowledge of the agency.

paragraph.text: Before taking official notice of a fact, the presiding officer:

subparagraph.text: before or during the hearing, by reference in a preliminary report, or otherwise, shall notify each party; and
shall give each party an opportunity to contest the fact.

subsection.text: The agency or the Office may use its experience, technical competence, and specialized knowledge in the evaluation of evidence.
Findings of fact must be based exclusively on the evidence of record in the contested case proceeding and on matters officially noticed in that proceeding.

In a contested case, the Office is bound by any agency regulation, declaratory ruling, prior adjudication, or other settled, preexisting policy, to the same extent as the agency is or would have been bound if it were hearing the case.

section.text: All or part of proceedings in a contested case shall be transcribed if any party:

paragraph.text: requests the transcription; and
pays any required costs.

In the case of a single decision maker, if the final decision maker in a contested case has not personally presided over the hearing, the final decision may not be made until each party is given notice of the proposed decision in accordance with § 10-220 of this subtitle and an opportunity to:

subparagraph.text: file exceptions with the agency to the proposed decision; and
present argument to the final decision maker that the proposed decision should be affirmed, reversed, or remanded.

paragraph.text: In the case of a decision-making body, if a majority of the officials who are to make a final decision in a contested case have not personally presided over the hearing, the officials may not make the final decision until each party is given notice of the proposed decision in accordance with § 10-220 of this subtitle and an opportunity to:

subparagraph.text: file exceptions to the proposed decision with the agency; and
present argument to a majority of the officials who are to make the final decision.

paragraph.text: If a party files exceptions or presents argument under paragraph (1) or (2) of this subsection, the official or officials who are to make the final decision shall:

subparagraph.text: personally consider each part of the record that a party cites in its exceptions or arguments before making a final decision; and
except as otherwise provided by law or by agreement of the parties, make the final decision within 90 days after the exceptions are filed or the argument is presented, whichever is later.

subsection.text: The final decision shall identify any changes, modifications, or amendments to the proposed decision and the reasons for the changes, modifications, or amendments.

section.text: The standard of proof in a contested case shall be the preponderance of evidence unless the standard of clear and convincing evidence is imposed on the agency by regulation, statute, or constitution.
The presiding officer hearing a contested case shall make a record that includes:

paragraph.text: all motions and pleadings;
all documentary evidence that the agency or Office receives;
a statement of each fact of which the agency or Office has taken official notice;

any staff memorandum submitted to an individual who is involved in the decision making process of the contested case by an official or employee of the agency who is not authorized to participate in the decision making process;
each question;
each offer of proof;
each objection and the ruling on the objection;
each finding of fact or conclusion of law proposed by:

subparagraph.text: a party; or
the presiding officer;

paragraph.text: each exception to a finding or conclusion proposed by a presiding officer; and
each intermediate proposed and final ruling by or for the agency, including each report or opinion issued in connection with the ruling.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a presiding officer may not communicate ex parte directly or indirectly regarding the merits of any issue in the case, while the case is pending, with:

subparagraph.text: any party to the case or the party’s representative or attorney; or
any person who presided at a previous stage of the case.

paragraph.text: An agency head, board, or commission presiding over a contested case may communicate with members of an advisory staff of, or any counsel for, the agency, board, or commission who otherwise does not participate in the contested case.

subsection.text: If, before hearing a contested case, a person receives an ex parte communication of a type that would violate subsection (a) of this section if received while conducting a hearing, the person, promptly after commencing the hearing, shall disclose the communication in the manner prescribed in subsection (c) of this section.
An individual who is involved in the decision making process and who is personally aware of an ex parte communication shall:

paragraph.text: give notice to all parties;
include in the record of the contested case:

subparagraph.text: each written communication received;
a memorandum that states the substance of each oral communication received;
each written response to a communication; and
a memorandum that states the substance of each oral response to the communication; and

paragraph.text: send to each party a copy of each communication, memorandum, and response.

subsection.text: A party may rebut an ex parte communication if the party requests the opportunity to rebut within 10 days after notice of the communication.

paragraph.text: To eliminate the effect of an ex parte communication that is made in violation of this section, the presiding officer or, if the presiding officer is a multimember body, the individual board or commission member, may:

subparagraph.text: withdraw from the proceeding; or
terminate the proceeding without prejudice.

paragraph.text: An order to terminate the proceeding without prejudice shall state the last date by which a party may reinstitute the proceeding.

subsection.text: If the Office conducts a hearing under this subtitle, the Office shall prepare proposed findings of fact, conclusions of law, or orders in accordance with the agency’s delegation under § 10-205 of this subtitle.
The Office shall send its proposed findings, conclusions, or orders:

paragraph.text: to the parties and the agency directly; or
if the agency’s delegation under § 10-205 of this subtitle requires, to the agency for distribution by the agency to the parties.
Within 60 days after receipt of the Office’s proposed findings, conclusions, or order under subsection (b)(2) of this section, the agency shall:

subparagraph.text: review the Office’s proposed findings, conclusions, or order;
issue the proposed decision, which may include the Office’s proposed findings, conclusions, or order with or without modification; and
send the proposed decision and a copy of the Office’s proposed findings, conclusions, or order to the parties.

paragraph.text: The time limit specified in paragraph (1) of this subsection may be extended by the agency head, board, or commission with written notice to the parties.

subsection.text: A proposed decision or order, including proposed decisions or orders issued for contested case hearings subject to this subtitle but not conducted by the Office, shall:

paragraph.text: be in writing or stated on the record;
contain separate findings of fact and conclusions of law;
include an explanation of procedures and time limits for filing exceptions; and

if the Office conducted the hearing and the agency’s proposed decision includes any changes, modifications, or amendments to the Office’s proposed findings, conclusions, or orders, contain an explanation of the reasons for each change, modification, or amendment.

subsection.text: A final decision or order in a contested case that is adverse to a party shall be in writing or stated on the record.

paragraph.text: A final decision or order in a contested case, including a remand of a proposed decision, shall contain separate statements of:

subparagraph.text: the findings of fact;
the conclusions of law; and
the order.

paragraph.text: A written statement of appeal rights shall be included with the decision.
If the findings of fact are stated in statutory language, the final decision shall state concisely and explicitly the facts that support the findings.
If, in accordance with regulations, a party submitted proposed findings of fact, the final decision shall state a ruling on each proposed finding.

subsection.text: The final decision maker promptly shall deliver or mail a copy of the final decision or order to:

paragraph.text: each party; or
the party’s attorney of record.
Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a party who is aggrieved by the final decision in a contested case is entitled to judicial review of the decision as provided in this section.

An agency, including an agency that has delegated a contested case to the Office, is entitled to judicial review of a decision as provided in this section if the agency was a party before the agency or the Office.

subsection.text: Where the presiding officer has final decision-making authority, a person in a contested case who is aggrieved by an interlocutory order is entitled to judicial review if:

paragraph.text: the party would qualify under this section for judicial review of any related final decision;
the interlocutory order:

subparagraph.text: determines rights and liabilities; and
has immediate legal consequences; and

paragraph.text: postponement of judicial review would result in irreparable harm.

subsection.text: Unless otherwise required by statute, a petition for judicial review shall be filed with the circuit court for the county where any party resides or has a principal place of business.

paragraph.text: The court may permit any other interested person to intervene in a proceeding under this section.

If the agency has delegated to the Office the authority to issue the final administrative decision pursuant to § 10-205(a)(3) of this subtitle, and there are 2 or more other parties with adverse interests remaining in the case, the agency may decline to participate in the judicial review. An agency that declines to participate shall inform the court in its initial response.
The filing of a petition for judicial review does not automatically stay the enforcement of the final decision.

Except as otherwise provided by law, the final decision maker may grant or the reviewing court may order a stay of the enforcement of the final decision on terms that the final decision maker or court considers proper.
Judicial review of disputed issues of fact shall be confined to the record for judicial review supplemented by additional evidence taken pursuant to this section.
The court may order the presiding officer to take additional evidence on terms that the court considers proper if:

subparagraph.text: before the hearing date in court, a party applies for leave to offer additional evidence; and
the court is satisfied that:

sub-subparagraph.text: the evidence is material; and
there were good reasons for the failure to offer the evidence in the proceeding before the presiding officer.

paragraph.text: On the basis of the additional evidence, the final decision maker may modify the findings and decision.
The final decision maker shall file with the reviewing court, as part of the record:

subparagraph.text: the additional evidence; and
any modifications of the findings or decision.

paragraph.text: The court shall conduct a proceeding under this section without a jury.
A party may offer testimony on alleged irregularities in procedure before the presiding officer that do not appear on the record.
On request, the court shall:

subparagraph.text: hear oral argument; and
receive written briefs.

subsection.text: In a proceeding under this section, the court may:

paragraph.text: remand the case for further proceedings;
affirm the final decision; or
reverse or modify the decision if any substantial right of the petitioner may have been prejudiced because a finding, conclusion, or decision:

subparagraph.text: is unconstitutional;
exceeds the statutory authority or jurisdiction of the final decision maker;
results from an unlawful procedure;
is affected by any other error of law;
is unsupported by competent, material, and substantial evidence in light of the entire record as submitted; or
is arbitrary or capricious.

subsection.text: A party to a contested case may timely seek civil enforcement of an administrative order by filing a petition for civil enforcement in an appropriate circuit court.

Unless otherwise required by statute, a party shall file a petition for civil enforcement of an administrative order in the circuit court for the county where any party resides or has a principal place of business.
In an action seeking civil enforcement of an administrative order, a party shall name, as a defendant, each alleged violator against whom the party seeks to obtain civil enforcement.
A party may file an action for civil enforcement of an administrative order if another party is in violation of the administrative order.
A party in an action for civil enforcement of an administrative order may request, and a court may grant, one or more of the following forms of relief:

paragraph.text: declaratory relief;
temporary or permanent injunctive relief;
a writ of mandamus; or
any other civil remedy provided by law.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a case that arises under Title 16 of the Transportation Article unless a right to appeal to the Court of Special Appeals is specifically provided; or
a final judgment on actions of the Inmate Grievance Office.
A party who is aggrieved by a final judgment of a circuit court under this subtitle may appeal to the Court of Special Appeals in the manner that law provides for appeal of civil cases.
An agency that was a party in the circuit court may appeal under paragraph (1) of this subsection.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Business” means a trade, professional activity, or other business that is conducted for profit.
“Nonprofit organization” means an organization that is exempt or eligible for exemption from taxation under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: This section applies only to:

paragraph.text: an agency operating statewide;
a business that, on the date when the contested case or civil action is initiated:

subparagraph.text: is independently owned and operated; and
has less than 50 employees, including, if a corporation owns 50% or more of the stock of the business, each employee of the corporation; and

paragraph.text: a nonprofit organization.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in this section, an agency or court may award to a business or nonprofit organization reimbursement for expenses that the business or nonprofit organization reasonably incurs in connection with a contested case or civil action that:

paragraph.text: is initiated against the business or nonprofit organization by an agency as part of an administrative or regulatory function;
is initiated without substantial justification or in bad faith; and
does not result in:

subparagraph.text: an adjudication, stipulation, or acceptance of liability of the business or nonprofit organization;
a determination of noncompliance, violation, infringement, deficiency, or breach on the part of the business or nonprofit organization; or
a settlement agreement under which the business or nonprofit organization agrees to take corrective action or to pay a monetary sum.

paragraph.text: To qualify for an award under this section when the agency has initiated a contested case, the business or nonprofit organization must make a claim to the agency before taking any appeal.
The agency shall act on the claim.
An award under this section may include:

subparagraph.text: the expenses incurred in the contested case;
court costs;
counsel fees; and
the fees of necessary witnesses.

paragraph.text: An award under this section may not exceed $10,000.
The court may reduce or deny an award to the extent that the conduct of the business or nonprofit organization during the proceedings unreasonably delayed the resolution of the matter in controversy.

subsection.text: An award under this section shall be paid as provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: If the agency denies an award under this section, the business or nonprofit organization may appeal, as provided in this subtitle.
An agency may appeal an award that a court makes under this section.

subsection.text: Upon a finding by the Governor that there is an imminent threat within a time certain of a loss or denial of federal funds to the State because of the operation of any section of this subtitle or of Title 9, Subtitle 16 of this article, the Governor by executive order may suspend the applicability of part or all of this subtitle or of Title 9, Subtitle 16 of this article to a specific class of contested cases.
A suspension under this section is effective only so long as, and to the extent, necessary to avoid a denial or loss of federal funds to the State.
The executive order shall explain the basis for the Governor’s finding and state the period of time during which the suspension is to be effective.
The Governor shall declare the termination of a suspension when it is no longer necessary to prevent the loss or denial of federal funds.
An executive order issued under this section shall be:

paragraph.text: presented to the Legislative Policy Committee; and
published in the Maryland Register pursuant to § 7-206(a)(2)(viii) of this article.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“License” means all or any part of permission that:

subparagraph.text: is required by law to be obtained from a unit;
is not required only for revenue purposes; and
is in any form, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: an approval;
a certificate;
a charter;
a permit; or
a registration.

paragraph.text: “Unit” means an officer or unit that is authorized by law to:

subparagraph.text: adopt regulations subject to Subtitle 1 of this title; or
adjudicate contested cases under this subtitle.

subsection.text: If, at least 2 calendar weeks before a license expires, the licensee makes sufficient application for renewal of the license, the license does not expire until:

paragraph.text: the unit takes final action on the application; and
either:

subparagraph.text: the time for seeking judicial review of the action expires; or
any judicial stay of the unit’s final action expires.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a unit may not revoke or suspend a license unless the unit first gives the licensee:

subparagraph.text: written notice of the facts that warrant suspension or revocation; and
an opportunity to be heard.

paragraph.text: A unit may order summarily the suspension of a license if the unit:

subparagraph.text: finds that the public health, safety, or welfare imperatively requires emergency action; and
promptly gives the licensee:

sub-subparagraph.text: written notice of the suspension, the finding, and the reasons that support the finding; and
an opportunity to be heard.

section.text: In this subtitle, “unit” means an officer or unit that is authorized by law to:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations subject to Subtitle 1 of this title; or
adjudicate contested cases subject to Subtitle 2 of this title.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the Governor;
the Department of Assessments and Taxation;
the Board of Appeals of the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
the Insurance Administration;
the Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund;
the Maryland Parole Commission of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services;
the Public Service Commission;
the Maryland Tax Court; or
the State Workers’ Compensation Commission.

subsection.text: If the Insurance Commissioner states in writing that, as to a particular matter, the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund need not comply with this subtitle, this subtitle does not apply to the Fund with respect to that matter.

section.caption: ** TAKES EFFECT OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012 **

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the Governor;
the Department of Assessments and Taxation;
the Board of Appeals of the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
the Insurance Administration;
the Maryland Parole Commission of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services;
the Public Service Commission;
the Maryland Tax Court; or
the State Workers’ Compensation Commission.

subsection.text: If the Insurance Commissioner states in writing that, as to a particular matter, the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund need not comply with this subtitle, this subtitle does not apply to the Fund with respect to that matter.

section.text: A political subdivision of the State or an instrumentality of a political subdivision is entitled, to the same extent as other legal entities, to be an interested person, party, or petitioner in a matter under this subtitle, including an appeal.

subsection.text: An interested person may submit to a unit a petition for a declaratory ruling with respect to the manner in which the unit would apply a regulation or order of the unit or a statute that the unit enforces to a person or property on the facts set forth in the petition.
Each unit shall adopt regulations that set:

paragraph.text: the form for a petition under this section; and
procedures for the submission, consideration, and disposition of the petition.

subsection.text: A unit may issue a declaratory ruling.
A declaratory ruling binds the unit and the petitioner on the facts set forth in the petition.
A declaratory ruling under this section is subject to review in a circuit court in the manner that Subtitle 2 of this title provides for the review of a contested case.

section.text: Before a State agency issues a license or permit to an employer to engage in an activity in which the employer may employ a covered employee, as defined in § 9-101 of the Labor and Employment Article, the employer shall file with the State agency:

paragraph.text: a certificate of compliance with the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act; or
the number of a workers’ compensation insurance policy or binder.

subsection.text: It is essential to the maintenance of a democratic society that, except in special and appropriate circumstances:

paragraph.text: public business be performed in an open and public manner; and
citizens be allowed to observe:

subparagraph.text: the performance of public officials; and
the deliberations and decisions that the making of public policy involves.

paragraph.text: The ability of the public, its representatives, and the media to attend, report on, and broadcast meetings of public bodies and to witness the phases of the deliberation, policy formation, and decision making of public bodies ensures the accountability of government to the citizens of the State.
The conduct of public business in open meetings increases the faith of the public in government and enhances the effectiveness of the public in fulfilling its role in a democratic society.

subsection.text: Except in special and appropriate circumstances when meetings of public bodies may be closed under this subtitle, it is the public policy of the State that the public be provided with adequate notice of the time and location of meetings of public bodies, which shall be held in places reasonably accessible to individuals who would like to attend these meetings.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Administrative function” means the administration of:

subparagraph.text: a law of the State;
a law of a political subdivision of the State; or
a rule, regulation, or bylaw of a public body.

paragraph.text: “Administrative function” does not include:

subparagraph.text: an advisory function;
a judicial function;
a legislative function;
a quasi–judicial function; or
a quasi–legislative function.

subsection.text: “Advisory function” means the study of a matter of public concern or the making of recommendations on the matter, under a delegation of responsibility by:

paragraph.text: law;
the Governor or an official who is subject to the policy direction of the Governor;
the chief executive officer of a political subdivision of the State or an official who is subject to the policy direction of the chief executive officer; or
formal action by or for a public body that exercises an administrative, judicial, legislative, quasi–judicial, or quasi–legislative function.

subsection.text: “Board” means the State Open Meetings Law Compliance Board.

paragraph.text: “Judicial function” means the exercise of any power of the Judicial Branch of the State government.
“Judicial function” includes the exercise of:

subparagraph.text: a power for which Article IV, § 1 of the Maryland Constitution provides;
a function of a grand jury;
a function of a petit jury;
a function of the Commission on Judicial Disabilities; and
a function of a judicial nominating commission.

paragraph.text: “Judicial function” does not include the exercise of rulemaking power by a court.

subsection.text: “Legislative function” means the process or act of:

paragraph.text: approving, disapproving, enacting, amending, or repealing a law or other measure to set public policy;
approving or disapproving an appointment;
proposing or ratifying a constitution or constitutional amendment; or
proposing or ratifying a charter or charter amendment.

subsection.text: “Meet” means to convene a quorum of a public body for the consideration or transaction of public business.

paragraph.text: “Public body” means an entity that:

subparagraph.text: consists of at least 2 individuals; and
is created by:

sub-subparagraph.text: the Maryland Constitution;
a State statute;
a county or municipal charter;
an ordinance;
a rule, resolution, or bylaw;
an executive order of the Governor; or
an executive order of the chief executive authority of a political subdivision of the State.

paragraph.text: “Public body” includes:

subparagraph.text: any multimember board, commission, or committee appointed by the Governor or the chief executive authority of a political subdivision of the State, or appointed by an official who is subject to the policy direction of the Governor or chief executive authority of the political subdivision, if the entity includes in its membership at least 2 individuals not employed by the State or the political subdivision;
any multimember board, commission, or committee that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is appointed by:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: an entity in the Executive branch of State government, the members of which are appointed by the Governor, and that otherwise meets the definition of a public body under this subsection; or
an official who is subject to the policy direction of an entity described in item A of this item; and

sub-subparagraph.text: includes in its membership at least 2 individuals who are not members of the appointing entity or employed by the State; and

subparagraph.text: The Maryland School for the Blind.

paragraph.text: “Public body” does not include:

subparagraph.text: any single member entity;
any judicial nominating commission;
any grand jury;
any petit jury;
the Appalachian States Low Level Radioactive Waste Commission established in § 7–302 of the Environment Article;
except when a court is exercising rulemaking power, any court established in accordance with Article IV of the Maryland Constitution;
the Governor’s cabinet, the Governor’s Executive Council as provided in Title 8, Subtitle 1 of this article, or any committee of the Executive Council;
a local government’s counterpart to the Governor’s cabinet, Executive Council, or any committee of the counterpart of the Executive Council;
except as provided in paragraph (1) of this subsection, a subcommittee of a public body as defined under paragraph (2)(i) of this subsection;
the governing body of a hospital as defined in § 19–301 of the Health – General Article; and
a self–insurance pool that is established in accordance with Title 19, Subtitle 6 of the Insurance Article or § 9–404 of the Labor and Employment Article by:

sub-subparagraph.text: a public entity, as defined in § 19–602 of the Insurance Article; or
a county or municipal corporation, as defined in § 9–404 of the Labor and Employment Article.

subsection.text: “Quasi–judicial function” means a determination of:

paragraph.text: a contested case to which Subtitle 2 of this title applies;
a proceeding before an administrative agency for which Title 7, Chapter 200 of the Maryland Rules would govern judicial review; or
a complaint by the Board in accordance with this subtitle.

subsection.text: “Quasi–legislative function” means the process or act of:

paragraph.text: adopting, disapproving, amending, or repealing a rule, regulation, or bylaw that has the force of law, including a rule of a court;
approving, disapproving, or amending a budget; or
approving, disapproving, or amending a contract.

subsection.text: “Quorum” means:

paragraph.text: a majority of the members of a public body; or
any different number that law requires.

section.text: There is a State Open Meetings Law Compliance Board.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of 3 members, at least one of whom shall be an attorney admitted to the Maryland Bar, appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
From among the members of the Board, the Governor shall appoint a chairman.
The term of a member is 3 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on July 1, 1991.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.
A member may not serve for more than 2 consecutive 3-year terms.

subsection.text: A majority of the full authorized membership of the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall meet at a time and place to be determined by the Board.
Each member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; and
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Office of the Attorney General shall provide staff for the Board.
The Board shall receive, review, and resolve complaints from any person alleging a violation of the provisions of this subtitle and issue a written opinion as to whether a violation has occurred.
The Board shall receive and review any complaint alleging a prospective violation of the provisions of this subtitle as provided under § 10-502.6 of this subtitle.
The Board shall study ongoing compliance with the provisions of this subtitle by public bodies and make recommendations to the General Assembly for improvements in this subtitle.

The Board, in conjunction with the Office of the Attorney General and other interested organizations or persons, shall develop and conduct educational programs on the requirements of the open meetings law for the staffs and attorneys of:

paragraph.text: public bodies;
the Maryland Municipal League; and
the Maryland Association of Counties.
On or before October 1 of each year, the Board shall submit an annual report to the Governor and the General Assembly in accordance with § 2-1246 of this article.
The report shall include a description of:

subparagraph.text: the activities of the Board;
the opinions of the Board in any cases brought before it;
the number and nature of complaints filed with the Board, including a discussion of complaints concerning the reasonableness of the notice provided for meetings; and
any recommendations for improvements to the provisions of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Any person may file a written complaint with the Board seeking a written opinion from the Board on the application of the provisions of this subtitle to the action of a public body covered by this subtitle.
The complaint shall:

paragraph.text: be signed by the person making the complaint; and
identify the public body, specify the action of the public body, the date of the action, and the circumstances of the action.

On receipt of the written complaint, and except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the Board shall promptly send the complaint to the public body identified in the complaint and request that a response to the complaint be sent to the Board.

subparagraph.text: The public body shall file a written response to the complaint within 30 days of its receipt of the complaint.
On request of the Board, the public body shall include with its written response to the complaint a copy of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a notice provided under § 10–506 of this subtitle;
a written statement made under § 10–508(d)(2)(ii) of this subtitle; and
minutes and any tape recording made by the public body under § 10–509 of this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: The Board shall maintain the confidentiality of minutes and any tape recording submitted by a public body that are sealed in accordance with § 10–509(c)(3)(ii) of this subtitle.
If the public body identified in the complaint no longer exists, the Board shall promptly send the complaint to the official or entity that appointed the public body.
The official or entity that appointed the public body shall, to the extent feasible, comply with the requirements of paragraph (2) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: If after 45 days, a written response is not received, the Board shall decide the case on the facts before it.

subsection.text: The Board shall:

paragraph.text: review the complaint and any response; and

if the information in the complaint and response is sufficient to permit a determination, issue a written opinion as to whether a violation of the provisions of this subtitle has occurred or will occur not later than 30 days after receiving the response.

If the Board is unable to reach a determination based on the written submissions before it, the Board may schedule an informal conference to hear from the complainant, the public body, or any other person with relevant information about the subject of the complaint.
An informal conference scheduled by the Board is not a “contested case” within the meaning of § 10–202(d) of this title.
The Board shall issue a written opinion not later than 30 days following the informal conference.
If the Board is unable to render an opinion on a complaint within the time periods specified in subsection (d) or (e) of this section, the Board shall:

subparagraph.text: state in writing the reason for its inability; and
issue an opinion as soon as possible but not later than 90 days after the filing of the complaint.

paragraph.text: An opinion of the Board may state that the Board is unable to resolve the complaint.

subsection.text: The Board shall send a copy of the written opinion to the complainant and to the affected public body.

paragraph.text: On a periodic basis, the Board may send to any public body in the State any written opinion that will provide the public body with guidance on compliance with the provisions of this subtitle.
On request, a copy of a written opinion shall be provided to any person.
The opinions of the Board are advisory only.
The Board may not require or compel any specific actions by a public body.

subsection.text: A written opinion issued by the Board may not be introduced as evidence in a proceeding conducted in accordance with § 10–510 of this subtitle.

On receipt of an oral or written complaint by any person that a meeting required to be open under the provisions of this subtitle will be closed in violation of this subtitle, the Board acting through its chairman, a designated Board member, or any authorized staff person available to the Board may contact the public body to determine the nature of the meeting that will be held and the reason for the expected closure of the meeting.

When at least 2 members of the Board conclude that a violation of this subtitle may occur if the closed meeting is held, the person acting for the Board under subsection (a) of this section immediately shall inform the public body of the potential violation and any lawful means that are available for conducting its meeting to achieve the purposes of the public body.

The person acting for the Board shall inform the person who filed the complaint under subsection (a) of this section of the result of any effort to achieve compliance with this subtitle under subsection (b) of this section.
The person acting for the Board shall file a written report with the Board describing the complaint, the effort to achieve compliance, and the results of the effort.

The filing of a complaint under subsection (a) of this section and action by a person acting for the Board under subsections (b), (c), and (d) of this section may not prevent or bar the Board from considering and acting on a written complaint filed in accordance with § 10-502.5 of this subtitle.
Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, this subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a public body when it is carrying out:

subparagraph.text: an administrative function;
a judicial function; or
a quasi-judicial function; or

paragraph.text: a chance encounter, social gathering, or other occasion that is not intended to circumvent this subtitle.

subsection.text: The provisions of this subtitle apply to a public body when it is meeting to consider:

paragraph.text: granting a license or permit; or
a special exception, variance, conditional use, zoning classification, the enforcement of any zoning law or regulation, or any other zoning matter.

subsection.text: If a public body recesses an open session to carry out an administrative function in a meeting that is not open to the public, the minutes for the public body’s next meeting shall include:

paragraph.text: a statement of the date, time, place, and persons present at the administrative function meeting; and
a phrase or sentence identifying the subject matter discussed at the administrative function meeting.

section.text: Whenever this subtitle and another law that relates to meetings of public bodies conflict, this subtitle applies unless the other law is more stringent.
Except as otherwise expressly provided in this subtitle, a public body shall meet in open session.

subsection.text: Before meeting in a closed or open session, a public body shall give reasonable advance notice of the session.
Whenever reasonable, a notice under this section shall:

paragraph.text: be in writing;
include the date, time, and place of the session; and
if appropriate, include a statement that a part or all of a meeting may be conducted in closed session.

subsection.text: A public body may give the notice under this section as follows:

paragraph.text: if the public body is a unit of the State government, by publication in the Maryland Register;
by delivery to representatives of the news media who regularly report on sessions of the public body or the activities of the government of which the public body is a part;
if the public body previously has given public notice that this method will be used:

subparagraph.text: by posting or depositing the notice at a convenient public location at or near the place of the session; or
by posting the notice on an Internet website ordinarily used by the public body to provide information to the public; or

paragraph.text: by any other reasonable method.

subsection.text: A public body shall keep a copy of a notice provided under this section for at least 1 year after the date of the session.
Whenever a public body meets in open session, the general public is entitled to attend.

A public body shall adopt and enforce reasonable rules regarding the conduct of persons attending its meetings and the videotaping, televising, photographing, broadcasting, or recording of its meetings.

paragraph.text: If the presiding officer determines that the behavior of an individual is disrupting an open session, the public body may have the individual removed.
Unless the public body or its members or agents acted maliciously, the public body, members, and agents are not liable for having an individual removed under this subsection.

subsection.text: This section applies only to the Executive and Legislative branches of State government.

paragraph.text: On request and to the extent feasible, a unit that holds a public hearing shall provide a qualified interpreter to assist deaf persons to understand the proceeding.
The request must be submitted in writing or by telecommunication at least 5 days before the proceeding begins.
Whether providing an interpreter is feasible shall be determined, in each instance, by the unit involved.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of subsection (d) of this section, a public body may meet in closed session or adjourn an open session to a closed session only to:

paragraph.text: discuss:

subparagraph.text: the appointment, employment, assignment, promotion, discipline, demotion, compensation, removal, resignation, or performance evaluation of appointees, employees, or officials over whom it has jurisdiction; or
any other personnel matter that affects 1 or more specific individuals;

paragraph.text: protect the privacy or reputation of individuals with respect to a matter that is not related to public business;
consider the acquisition of real property for a public purpose and matters directly related thereto;
consider a matter that concerns the proposal for a business or industrial organization to locate, expand, or remain in the State;
consider the investment of public funds;
consider the marketing of public securities;
consult with counsel to obtain legal advice;
consult with staff, consultants, or other individuals about pending or potential litigation;
conduct collective bargaining negotiations or consider matters that relate to the negotiations;
discuss public security, if the public body determines that public discussion would constitute a risk to the public or to public security, including:

subparagraph.text: the deployment of fire and police services and staff; and
the development and implementation of emergency plans;

paragraph.text: prepare, administer, or grade a scholastic, licensing, or qualifying examination;
conduct or discuss an investigative proceeding on actual or possible criminal conduct;
comply with a specific constitutional, statutory, or judicially imposed requirement that prevents public disclosures about a particular proceeding or matter; or

before a contract is awarded or bids are opened, discuss a matter directly related to a negotiating strategy or the contents of a bid or proposal, if public discussion or disclosure would adversely impact the ability of the public body to participate in the competitive bidding or proposal process.

subsection.text: A public body that meets in closed session under this section may not discuss or act on any matter not permitted under subsection (a) of this section.
The exceptions in subsection (a) of this section shall be strictly construed in favor of open meetings of public bodies.

paragraph.text: Unless a majority of the members of a public body present and voting vote in favor of closing the session, the public body may not meet in closed session.
Before a public body meets in closed session, the presiding officer shall:

subparagraph.text: conduct a recorded vote on the closing of the session; and
make a written statement of the reason for closing the meeting, including a citation of the authority under this section, and a listing of the topics to be discussed.

paragraph.text: If a person objects to the closing of a session, the public body shall send a copy of the written statement required under paragraph (2) of this subsection to the Board.
The written statement shall be a matter of public record.
A public body shall keep a copy of the written statement made under paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection for at least 1 year after the date of the session.

subsection.text: This section does not:

paragraph.text: require any change in the form or content of the Journal of the Senate of Maryland or Journal of the House of Delegates of Maryland; or
limit the matters that a public body may include in its minutes.
Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, as soon as practicable after a public body meets, it shall have written minutes of its session prepared.
A public body need not prepare written minutes of an open session:

subparagraph.text: if live and archived video or audio streaming of the open session is available; or
if the public body votes on legislation and the individual votes taken by each member of the public body who participates in the voting are posted promptly on the Internet.

paragraph.text: The information specified under paragraph (2) of this subsection shall be deemed the minutes of the open session.
The written minutes shall reflect:

subparagraph.text: each item that the public body considered;
the action that the public body took on each item; and
each vote that was recorded.

paragraph.text: If a public body meets in closed session, the written minutes for its next open session shall include:

subparagraph.text: a statement of the time, place, and purpose of the closed session;
a record of the vote of each member as to closing the session;
a citation of the authority under this subtitle for closing the session; and
a listing of the topics of discussion, persons present, and each action taken during the session.
A session may be tape recorded by a public body.
Except as otherwise provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection, the written minutes and any tape recording of a closed session shall be sealed and may not be open to public inspection.

paragraph.text: The written minutes and any tape recording shall be unsealed and open to inspection as follows:

subparagraph.text: for a meeting closed under § 10–508(a)(5) of this subtitle, when the public body invests the funds;
for a meeting closed under § 10–508(a)(6) of this subtitle, when the public securities being discussed have been marketed; or

on request of a person or on the public body’s own initiative, if a majority of the members of the public body present and voting vote in favor of unsealing the written minutes and any tape recording.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, written minutes of a public body are public records and shall be open to public inspection during ordinary business hours.

A public body shall keep a copy of the written minutes of each session and any tape recording made under subsections (b)(2) or (c)(3)(i) of this section for at least 1 year after the date of the session.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to the action of:

subparagraph.text: appropriating public funds;
levying a tax; or
providing for the issuance of bonds, notes, or other evidences of public obligation.

paragraph.text: This section does not authorize a court to void an action of a public body because of any violation of this subtitle by another public body.
This section does not affect or prevent the use of any other available remedies.

If a public body fails to comply with § 10-505, § 10-506, § 10-507, § 10-508, or § 10-509(c) of this subtitle any person may file with a circuit court that has venue a petition that asks the court to:

subparagraph.text: determine the applicability of those sections;
require the public body to comply with those sections; or
void the action of the public body.

paragraph.text: If a violation of § 10-506, § 10-508, or § 10-509(c) of this subtitle is alleged, the person shall file the petition within 45 days after the date of the alleged violation.

If a violation of § 10-505 or § 10-507 of this subtitle is alleged, the person shall file the petition within 45 days after the public body includes in the minutes of an open session the information specified in § 10-509(c)(2) of this subtitle.

If a written complaint is filed with the Board in accordance with § 10-502.5 of this subtitle, the time between the filing of the complaint and the mailing of the written opinion to the complainant and the affected public body under § 10-502.5(g) of this subtitle may not be included in determining if a claim against a public body is barred by the statute of limitations set forth in paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection.

subsection.text: In an action under this section, it is presumed that the public body did not violate any provision of this subtitle, and the complainant has the burden of proving the violation.
A court may:

paragraph.text: consolidate a proceeding under this section with another proceeding under this section or an appeal from the action of the public body;
issue an injunction;
determine the applicability of this subtitle to the discussions or decisions of public bodies;

if the court finds that a public body willfully failed to comply with § 10-505, § 10-506, § 10-507, or § 10-509(c) of this subtitle and that no other remedy is adequate, declare void the final action of the public body;
as part of its judgment:

subparagraph.text: assess against any party reasonable counsel fees and other litigation expenses that the party who prevails in the action incurred; and
require a reasonable bond to ensure the payment of the assessment; and

paragraph.text: grant any other appropriate relief.
A person may file a petition under this section without seeking an opinion from the State Open Meetings Law Compliance Board.
The failure of a person to file a complaint with the Board is not a ground for the court to either stay or dismiss a petition.

section.text: A member of a public body who willfully participates in a meeting of the body with knowledge that the meeting is being held in violation of the provisions of this subtitle is subject to a civil penalty not to exceed $100.
This subtitle may be cited as the “Open Meetings Act”.
In this subtitle, “political subdivision” means:

paragraph.text: a county;
a municipal corporation in the State;
an unincorporated town in the State;
a school district in the State; or
any special district in the State.

section.text: The State, a political subdivision, or a unit of the State or of a political subdivision may keep only the information about a person that:

paragraph.text: is needed by the State, the political subdivision, or the unit to accomplish a governmental purpose that is authorized or required to be accomplished under:

subparagraph.text: a statute or other legislative mandate;
an executive order of the Governor;
an executive order of the chief executive of a local jurisdiction; or
a judicial rule; and

paragraph.text: is relevant to accomplishment of the purpose.

subsection.text: In this Part II of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means a principal department of the Executive Branch of the State government.
“Division” means the Records Management Division of the Department of General Services.
“Form” means a document that has a standard format for the systematic and repetitive collection, maintenance, or transmission of information.
“Independent unit” means a unit of the State government that is not in a department.
“Plan” means a forms management plan for a department or independent unit.
The head of each department and each independent unit shall designate, from among its staff, a forms management officer for the department or independent unit.
The forms management officer shall:

paragraph.text: subject to the approval of the Division:

subparagraph.text: keep a current plan for the management of the forms that the unit uses; and
administer the plan; and

paragraph.text: submit the plan, including each revision, to the Division.

subsection.text: The plan shall:

paragraph.text: ensure that the forms management officer approves the use of a form by the department or independent unit only if the form:

subparagraph.text: is needed for the effective or efficient operation of the department or independent unit;
requests information that is needed for or relevant to a lawful purpose of the department or independent unit;
does not impose an undue burden on the individual who is to complete the form;
is as brief, as plainly written, as well designed, and as easily completed as possible; and
does not duplicate unnecessarily:

sub-subparagraph.text: another form of the department or independent unit; or
a form of another department or independent unit;

paragraph.text: require a register of the forms that the forms management officer approves;
require identification of each form in accordance with a standard identification system of the Division;
provide for the most economical system by which to prepare, reproduce, and use a form; and
require the forms management officer:

subparagraph.text: to review periodically each form that has been approved to determine whether the officer still approves the form; and
if not, to remove the form from the register.

subsection.text: In addition to any duties set forth elsewhere, the Division shall:

paragraph.text: develop a standard identification system to identify forms;
help each department and independent unit to:

subparagraph.text: develop a proposed plan; and
coordinate the proposed plan with other plans;

paragraph.text: review each proposed plan;
approve each proposed plan that meets the requirements of this section; and
monitor and help in the administration of each plan to ensure compliance.
In the preparation of a form that requires identification of individuals by race, a department or independent unit shall include the following racial categories:

subparagraph.text: American Indian or Alaska Native;
Asian;
Black or African American;
Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander; and
White.

paragraph.text: A form that requires identification of individuals by race shall include instructions that multiracial respondents may select all applicable racial categories.

subparagraph.text: Respondents shall select their own answers, except when it is not possible for the respondent to do so.
In the event that a respondent is not able to select an answer, an observer, such as a family member or friend, may select the answer on behalf of the respondent.

paragraph.text: A form that requires identification of individuals by race shall include a separate question about whether a respondent is of Hispanic or Latino origin, with the question preceding the racial category question.

section.text: A department or independent unit may use only the forms that are listed on its register of approved forms.

subsection.text: On or before July 31 of each year, each department or independent unit shall submit to the Division an annual report on its activities as to the management of its forms during the previous fiscal year.

On or before September 1 of each year, the Division shall submit, subject to § 2-1246 of this article, to the General Assembly an annual report that consolidates the reports of the departments and independent units.
In this Part III of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Applicant” means a person or governmental unit that asks to inspect a public record.
“Custodian” means:

paragraph.text: the official custodian; or
any other authorized individual who has physical custody and control of a public record.

“Metadata” means information, generally not visible when an electronic document is printed, describing the history, tracking, or management of the electronic document, including information about data in the electronic document that describes how, when, and by whom the data is collected, created, accessed, or modified and how it is formatted.
“Metadata” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a spreadsheet formula;
a database field;
an externally or internally linked file; or
a reference to an external file or hyperlink.

subsection.text: “Official custodian” means an officer or employee of the State or of a political subdivision who, whether or not the officer or employee has physical custody and control of a public record, is responsible for keeping the public record.
“Person in interest” means:

paragraph.text: a person or governmental unit that is the subject of a public record or a designee of the person or governmental unit;
if the person has a legal disability, the parent or legal representative of the person; or

as to requests for correction of certificates of death under § 5–310(d)(2) of the Health – General Article, the spouse, adult child, parent, adult sibling, grandparent, or guardian of the person of the deceased at the time of the deceased’s death.

Except as otherwise provided in this Part III, “personal information” means information that identifies an individual including an individual’s address, driver’s license number or any other identification number, medical or disability information, name, photograph or computer generated image, Social Security number, or telephone number.
“Personal information” does not include an individual’s driver’s status, driving offenses, 5–digit zip code, or information on vehicular accidents.
“Public record” means the original or any copy of any documentary material that:

subparagraph.text: is made by a unit or instrumentality of the State government or of a political subdivision or received by the unit or instrumentality in connection with the transaction of public business; and
is in any form, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: a card;
a computerized record;
correspondence;
a drawing;
film or microfilm;
a form;
a map;
a photograph or photostat;
a recording; or
a tape.

paragraph.text: “Public record” includes a document that lists the salary of an employee of a unit or instrumentality of the State government or of a political subdivision.
“Public record” does not include a digital photographic image or signature of an individual, or the actual stored data thereof, recorded by the Motor Vehicle Administration.

“Telephone solicitation” means the initiation of a telephone call to an individual or to the residence or business of an individual for the purpose of encouraging the purchase or rental of or investment in property, goods, or services.
“Telephone solicitation” does not include a telephone call or message:

subparagraph.text: to an individual who has given express permission to the person making the telephone call;
to an individual with whom the person has an established business relationship; or
by a tax–exempt, nonprofit organization.

subsection.text: In this Part III of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Applicant” means a person or governmental unit that asks to inspect a public record.
“Custodian” means:

paragraph.text: the official custodian; or
any other authorized individual who has physical custody and control of a public record.

subsection.text: “Official custodian” means an officer or employee of the State or of a political subdivision who, whether or not the officer or employee has physical custody and control of a public record, is responsible for keeping the public record.
“Person in interest” means:

paragraph.text: a person or governmental unit that is the subject of a public record or a designee of the person or governmental unit;
if the person has a legal disability, the parent or legal representative of the person; or

as to requests for correction of certificates of death under § 5–310(d)(2) of the Health – General Article, the spouse, adult child, parent, adult sibling, grandparent, or guardian of the person of the deceased at the time of the deceased’s death.

Except as otherwise provided in this Part III, “personal information” means information that identifies an individual including an individual’s address, driver’s license number or any other identification number, medical or disability information, name, photograph or computer generated image, Social Security number, or telephone number.
