subsection.text: In this subtitle, a unit of the State government includes the Montgomery County government to the extent that Montgomery County administers a State program under Title 3, Subtitle 4 of the Human Services Article.

section.text: This subtitle shall be construed broadly, to ensure that injured parties have a remedy.
This subtitle does not:

paragraph.text: limit any other law that:

subparagraph.text: waives the sovereign immunity of the State or the units of the State government in tort; or
authorizes the State or its units to have insurance for tortious conduct;

paragraph.text: waive any right or defense of the State or its units, officials, or employees in an action in a court of the United States or any other state, including any defense that is available under the 11th Amendment to the United States Constitution; or
apply to or waive any immunity of a bicounty unit, county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision or any unit, official, or employee of any of those agencies or subdivisions.

section.text: The provisions governing the tort immunity of a member or employee of a board of supervisors of a soil conservation district are found in § 5-517 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article.

subsection.text: In this section, “tort claim” means a tort claim filed in State court against the Montgomery County government relating to the administration of a State program under Title 3, Subtitle 4 of the Human Services Article.
A tort claim shall be considered, defended, settled, and paid in the same manner as any other claim covered by the Montgomery County Self-Insurance Fund.
Liability for a tort claim may not exceed the insurance coverage granted to units of State government under Title 9 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

paragraph.text: The State Treasurer is not liable under § 9-107(c) of the State Finance and Procurement Article for a tort claim.
For tort claims, the duties, responsibilities, and liabilities of the Treasurer under this subtitle shall be assumed by the Montgomery County Self-Insurance Fund.

Subject to the exclusions and limitations in this subtitle and notwithstanding any other provision of law, the immunity of the State and of its units is waived as to a tort action, in a court of the State, to the extent provided under paragraph (2) of this subsection.
The liability of the State and its units may not exceed $200,000 to a single claimant for injuries arising from a single incident or occurrence.

subsection.text: Immunity is not waived under this section as described under § 5-522(a) of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article.

paragraph.text: The Treasurer may pay from the State Insurance Trust Fund all or part of that portion of a tort claim which exceeds the limitation on liability established under subsection (a)(2) of this section under the following conditions:

subparagraph.text: the tort claim is one for which the State and its units have waived immunity under subsections (a) and (b) of this section;
a judgment or settlement has been entered granting the claimant damages to the full amount established under subsection (a)(2) of this section; and
the Board of Public Works, with the advice and counsel of the Attorney General, has approved the payment.

paragraph.text: Any payment of part of a settlement or judgment under this subsection does not abrogate the sovereign immunity of the State or any units beyond the waiver provided in subsections (a) and (b) of this section.

section.text: State personnel shall have the immunity from liability described under § 5-522(b) of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a claim that is asserted by cross-claim, counterclaim, or third-party claim.
A claimant may not institute an action under this subtitle unless:

paragraph.text: the claimant submits a written claim to the Treasurer or a designee of the Treasurer within 1 year after the injury to person or property that is the basis of the claim;
the Treasurer or designee denies the claim finally; and
the action is filed within 3 years after the cause of action arises.

subsection.text: A claim under this subtitle shall:

paragraph.text: contain a concise statement of facts that sets forth the nature of the claim, including the date and place of the alleged tort;
demand specific damages;
state the name and address of each party;
state the name, address, and telephone number of counsel for the claimant, if any; and
be signed by the claimant, or the legal representative or counsel for the claimant.

subsection.text: The Treasurer may:

paragraph.text: consider a claim for money damages under this subtitle or delegate wholly or partly this responsibility to other State personnel; and
contract for any support services that are needed to carry out this responsibility properly.
In this section, “structured settlement” means a plan for the payment of a settlement or judgment to a claimant for damages in periodic installments.

Unless a contract with a private insurer provides otherwise, the Treasurer or designee may compromise and settle a claim for money damages after the Treasurer or designee consults with the Attorney General.
The State may enter into a structured settlement to the extent permitted in § 12-104(a)(2) of this subtitle.
If a structured settlement is entered into, the State and the claimant shall select the investment company by mutual agreement.
The acceptance of a settlement by a claimant is, as to that claimant:

subparagraph.text: final; and
a complete release of each claim arising from the same cause of action against:

sub-subparagraph.text: the State;
each of its units; and
all State personnel.

subsection.text: A claim under this subtitle is denied finally:

paragraph.text: if, by certified mail, return receipt requested, under a postmark of the United States Postal Service, the Treasurer or designee sends the claimant, or the legal representative or counsel for the claimant written notice of denial; or
if the Treasurer or designee fails to give notice of a final decision within 6 months after the filing of the claim.

subsection.text: In an action under this subtitle, service of the complaint and accompanying documents is sufficient only if made on the Treasurer.
Unless full representation is provided under a contract of insurance, the Attorney General shall defend an action under this subtitle against the State or any of its units.

section.text: Counsel may not charge or receive fees that exceed:

paragraph.text: 20% of a settlement made under this subtitle; or
25% of a judgment made under this subtitle.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Tort Claims Act”.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise expressly provided by a law of the State, the State, its officers, and its units may not raise the defense of sovereign immunity in a contract action, in a court of the State, based on a written contract that an official or employee executed for the State or 1 of its units while the official or employee was acting within the scope of the authority of the official or employee.
In an action under this subtitle, the State and its officers and units shall have the immunity from liability described under § 5-522(d) of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article.

section.text: A claim under this subtitle is barred unless the claimant files suit within 1 year after the later of:

paragraph.text: the date on which the claim arose; or
the completion of the contract that gives rise to the claim.

section.text: Except as provided in Title 5 of the Education Article, to carry out this subtitle, the Governor shall include in the budget bill money that is adequate to satisfy a final judgment that, after the exhaustion of the rights of appeal, is rendered against the State or any of its officers or units.
This subtitle does not apply to a contract of the Legislative or Judicial Branch of State government, or any of their agencies, officers, or units.
This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the Public Service Commission;
a local board of elections;
the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners or a county board of education; or
any other county officer or unit.

Except as otherwise provided in this Part II of this subtitle, the Attorney General shall appear in a civil action or special proceeding against a State officer or State employee to represent the officer or employee if:

subparagraph.text: the action or proceeding is in a court of the State or of the United States;
the officer or employee submits to the Attorney General a written request for representation;
the Attorney General or a person whom the Attorney General designates investigates the facts on which the action or proceeding is based;
the Attorney General does not find the officer or employee ineligible for representation under subsection (b)(1) of this section; and
the officer or employee enters into an agreement as required by § 12-305 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General may provide this representation by a deputy attorney general, assistant attorney general, special counsel, or other private counsel.
The Attorney General shall decline to represent a State officer or State employee if, on the basis of the investigation, the Attorney General finds that:

subparagraph.text: the officer or employee was not acting within the scope of employment of the officer or employee;
the act or omission was malicious; or
the act or omission was grossly negligent.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General may decline to represent a State officer or State employee who otherwise is eligible for representation if the officer or employee:

subparagraph.text: retains other counsel; or
is covered by insurance that requires the carrier to provide counsel.

paragraph.text: Subject to the requirements of this section, the Attorney General has sole discretion in undertaking to represent the State officer or State employee.

A decision of the Attorney General not to represent an officer or employee is inadmissible in any legal action or special proceeding. Reference to the decision may not be made in any hearing or trial.

subsection.text: This section does not:

paragraph.text: deprive a State officer or State employee of any right to retain counsel, at the expense of the officer or employee; or
prevent the appearance of the Attorney General to protect the interests of the State, even if the officer or employee does not request the appearance.

section.text: Before a State officer or State employee may be represented under this Part II of this subtitle, the Attorney General shall have the officer or employee enter into an agreement that:

paragraph.text: enables the Attorney General to require, from the officer or employee, reimbursement of court costs, reasonable counsel fees, and other expenses in representing the officer or employee if:

subparagraph.text: it is determined judicially that:

sub-subparagraph.text: the defense of sovereign immunity is not available to the officer or employee;
the injuries arose out of an act or omission of the officer or employee; and

the act or omission was malicious or grossly negligent or, when the act or the omission was made, the officer or employee was not performing a duty within the scope of the employment of the officer or employee; and

subparagraph.text: the officer or employee did not give the Attorney General complete information or gave the Attorney General information that is false or misleading;

paragraph.text: authorizes collection of the reimbursement, as a debt due to the State;
states that:

subparagraph.text: this representation of the officer or employee does not constitute an obligation for the State to pay a settlement, if the claim is settled, or a judgment, if judgment is rendered against the officer or employee;
the State and its units are not responsible for payment of the judgment; and
the officer or employee is entitled to submit to the Board of Public Works an application for payment of a settlement or judgment;

paragraph.text: provides that:

subparagraph.text: the Attorney General may not compromise or settle the claim against the officer or employee without the written consent of the officer or employee;
if the officer or employee will not consent, the Attorney General may withdraw the appearance in accordance with the appropriate court rules; and
the State is not responsible for any costs after the withdrawal; and

paragraph.text: includes any other provisions that the Attorney General considers necessary.

subsection.text: Representation under this Part II of this subtitle includes the right to assert a counterclaim or to assert or defend against a third party claim for the officer or employee.
The representation does not deprive any State officer, State employee, or unit of the State government of any sovereign immunity that is available to the officer, employee, or unit.

section.text: Information that the Attorney General obtains under § 12-304(a)(1)(iii) of this subtitle is confidential and inadmissible as evidence in any legal action or special proceeding. Reference to the information may not be made in any hearing or trial.

subsection.text: If an action or special proceeding against a State officer or State employee in which the Attorney General has declined representation under § 12-304(b)(1) of this subtitle results in final judgment, the court or jury shall find whether:

paragraph.text: the defense of sovereign immunity is available to the officer or employee;
the officer or employee was acting within the scope of the employment of the officer or employee;
the alleged act or omission was malicious; and
the alleged act or omission was grossly negligent.

subsection.text: A jury shall make the findings by written, special verdict.
A court shall require reimbursement from the person who brings an action or proceeding against a State officer or State employee if:

paragraph.text: judgment is rendered for the officer or employee; and
the court finds that the action or proceeding was instituted:

subparagraph.text: in bad faith; or
without substantial justification.

subsection.text: Reimbursement shall consist of reasonable counsel fees and other costs and reasonable expenses incurred by the officer or employee in defending against the action or proceeding.
Reimbursement shall be paid:

paragraph.text: to the officer or employee; or
if the State or any of its units already has reimbursed the officer or employee, to the State or the unit.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to the extent that a State officer or State employee is reimbursed under § 12-309 of this subtitle.

The State is liable to a State officer or State employee for reimbursement of court costs, counsel fees, and other reasonable expenses that the officer or employee incurs in defending an action or proceeding if:

paragraph.text: the Attorney General declined representation under § 12-304(b)(1) of this subtitle; and
it is determined judicially that:

subparagraph.text: the defense of sovereign immunity is available to the officer or employee; or

injuries arose from an act or omission of the officer or employee and, when the act or the omission was made, the officer or employee was acting within the scope of employment and the act or omission was not malicious and was not grossly negligent.

subsection.text: Reimbursement under this section shall be subject to the provisions of Subtitle 5 of this title.

section.text: The Attorney General may not represent or appoint or provide counsel to represent a State officer or State employee:

paragraph.text: in any investigation of the officer or employee by a criminal law enforcement agency; or
in any criminal action against the officer or employee in a court of the State or the United States.

section.text: Subject to the limitations in this Part III of this subtitle, the Board of Public Works may approve reimbursement of a State officer or State employee or otherwise pay for reasonable counsel fees that the officer or employee incurred:

paragraph.text: in connection with a criminal investigation into conduct as an officer or employee if the investigation has concluded and criminal charges have not been filed against the officer or employee; or

in defending against criminal charges that related to conduct as an officer or employee if final disposition of all of the charges does not result in a plea of nolo contendere, a guilty plea, or a finding of guilt.

subsection.text: The Board of Public Works may not provide reimbursement or payment under this Part III of this subtitle unless:

paragraph.text: the State officer or State employee submits to the Board a written application for reimbursement; and
the Attorney General certifies that:

subparagraph.text: the applicant retained counsel;
the applicant gave the Attorney General written notice promptly after counsel was retained; and
after review of the evidence and other information, the Attorney General or a designee appointed under this section made the following determinations:

sub-subparagraph.text: in connection with the matter under criminal investigation, the applicant discharged the public responsibilities in good faith, did not engage in unlawful conduct, and was reasonable in retaining counsel and incurring the counsel fees for which reimbursement is sought; or
in connection with the matter that was the subject of criminal charges, the applicant discharged the public responsibilities in good faith and incurred reasonable counsel fees.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding subsection (a)(2)(ii) of this section, the Board of Public Works may approve reimbursement to an applicant who fails to give the Attorney General notice promptly after counsel is retained if the Board determines that the failure is for good cause.

If the Attorney General believes that it would be inappropriate for the Attorney General to make the determinations under subsection (a)(2)(iii) of this section, the Attorney General or the Board of Public Works may designate other counsel to carry out that duty.
The determinations of the Attorney General or designee under this section are not subject to judicial review.

section.text: As a condition to providing reimbursement under this Part III of this subtitle, the Board of Public Works or the Attorney General may require an applicant:

paragraph.text: to answer questions under oath; and
to provide any information on the matter that was under criminal investigation or the subject of criminal charges.

section.text: If the officer or employee is awarded money in an action for false arrest, malicious prosecution, or other cause that arises from the investigation or charges, the State is subrogated to the extent of any reimbursement under this Part III of this subtitle.
In this subtitle, “State personnel” means:

paragraph.text: a regular employee of the State whose compensation:

subparagraph.text: is provided by a State appropriation; or
is paid wholly or partly from State funds;

paragraph.text: an employee who is under the jurisdiction of the Department of Budget and Management;
an officer, warrant officer, or enlisted member of the organized militia;
an employee of the Maryland Port Administration, as described in § 6–204(n) of the Transportation Article;
a member or employee of a board of trustees for a community college;
except in Montgomery County, an employee of a county health department;
a member or employee of the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners or of a county board of education;
a member of the Board of Visitors of the Maryland School for the Deaf;
a member or employee of a board of supervisors for a soil conservation district;
a person who, as a volunteer, is providing a service to or for the State;
a person who, for or under contract with a unit of the State or a local government, performs an emergency service during a state of emergency under Title 14 of the Public Safety Article;
any other individual who, with or without compensation, holds a position that requires the exercise of discretion and of a part of the sovereignty of the State;
any other State officer or State employee; and
a Montgomery County employee who administers a State program under Title 3, Subtitle 4 of the Human Services Article.

section.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: the State is a unique body because:

subparagraph.text: the State is a sovereign political body that the people have established directly for the sole purpose of providing for their government; and
the revenue of the State derives principally from taxes on the people, rather than from commercial enterprise;

paragraph.text: State personnel who are acting within the scope of public duties and responsibilities are carrying out a governmental program under law and, thus, are discharging a part of the purpose and sovereignty of the State;
decisions of courts throughout the United States have created new grounds for personal liability of a public officer or public employee who is discharging a public duty;
those decisions have resulted in:

subparagraph.text: increased difficulties in recruiting or retaining qualified individuals for public positions that involve the exercise of discretion or dealing with the general public; and
increased difficulties and expense in protecting these individuals through public, liability insurance; and

paragraph.text: as a matter of State policy, it is essential to protect from liability State personnel who are acting within the scope of public duties and responsibilities and without malice or gross negligence.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not affect any immunity or other defense that is available to State personnel or the State.
Payment of a settlement or judgment under this subtitle does not abrogate the sovereign immunity of the State, any of its units, or State personnel.

section.text: Subject to the limitations in this subtitle, the Board of Public Works may:

paragraph.text: pay wholly or partly a settlement or judgment against the State or any State personnel; and
include, in the payment, counsel fees and costs.

subsection.text: The application requirements enumerated in subsection (b)(5) of this section do not apply to claims relating to:

paragraph.text: courthouse security;
service of process;
the transportation of inmates to or from court proceedings;
personnel and other administrative activities;

activities, including activities relating to law enforcement functions, arising under a multijurisdictional agreement under the supervision and direction of the Maryland State Police or other State agency; or
any other activities, except for activities relating to performing law enforcement functions or detention center functions.

subsection.text: The Board of Public Works may not pay a settlement or judgment against State personnel unless:

paragraph.text: the State personnel submits to the Board a written application that sets forth each reason of the State personnel for believing the settlement or judgment is a responsibility of the State;
the Board or a hearing officer that the Board appoints holds a hearing on the application;
as to a judgment, it was rendered by a court of competent jurisdiction;
as to an applicant for whom the Attorney General appeared under Subtitle 3 of this title, the Attorney General files a written report and recommendation;
as to an application on behalf of a sheriff or deputy sheriff of a county or Baltimore City for any claim:

subparagraph.text: with respect to any settlement, the county solicitor or county attorney files a written report and recommendation and the Attorney General files a written report and recommendation; or
with respect to any judgment, the Attorney General files a written report and recommendation;

paragraph.text: on the bases of the hearing and any report and recommendation, the Board finds that:

subparagraph.text: when the act or omission was made, the applicant was performing a duty within the scope of the employment of the applicant;
the act or omission was not malicious; and
the act or omission was not grossly negligent; and

paragraph.text: if there is any question whether the applicant is State personnel for purposes of this subtitle, the Board finds that, regardless of the method, source, or amount of compensation, the applicant is State personnel.

section.text: Payments under this subtitle shall be made in accordance with the provisions of Subtitle 5 of this title.

paragraph.text: The Board of Public Works may approve payment of a settlement, a judgment, or counsel fees under Subtitles 3 and 4 of this title with or without a hearing, and direct payment from:

subparagraph.text: money appropriated for that purpose in the State budget;
money appropriated to the State Insurance Trust Fund for that purpose; or
the General Emergency Fund.

paragraph.text: The Board of Public Works may approve payment of a settlement, a judgment, or counsel fees under Subtitles 3 and 4 of this title with or without a hearing, and direct payment from any tax which has been appropriated in the State budget to the subdivision represented by the sheriff or deputy sheriff on whose behalf the payment is to be made, or direct payment from the subdivision’s share of any income tax collected by the State Comptroller, in connection with any settlement or judgment paid on behalf of any sheriff or deputy sheriff for any claim except those claims relating to:

subparagraph.text: courthouse security;
transportation of prisoners;
service of process;
personnel and other administrative activities;

activities, including activities relating to performing law enforcement functions, arising under multijurisdictional agreements under the supervision and direction of the Maryland State Police or other State agency; or
any other activities, except activities relating to performing law enforcement functions or detention center functions.

paragraph.text: The Board may direct that payment be made in lump sum or in installments.
If the Board disapproves payment in whole or in part, the Board shall state in writing its reasons for disapproval.
Decisions under this title are not subject to judicial review.
Nothing in this section shall be construed as a waiver of sovereign immunity of the State, any of its units, or State personnel.
If the Board directs payment under paragraph (2) of this subsection, such payment shall be collected in the manner provided by § 7-222 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: The Board of Public Works may delegate to affected units, in consultation with the Attorney General, authority to pay, from the funds of that unit available for the purpose, settlements, judgments, and counsel fees that do not exceed $10,000 in a particular case.
The Great Seal of Maryland is the State seal.
The reverse of the State seal shall be used officially. The obverse has not been used officially.

On the obverse of the Great Seal of Maryland is an equestrian figure of the Lord Proprietary, arrayed in complete armour and bearing a drawn sword in his hand. The caparisons of the horse are adorned with the family coat of arms. On the ground below is represented a sparse growth of grass on sandy soil, with a few small blue and yellow flowers. On the circle, surrounding the obverse of the seal, is the Latin inscription “Caecilius Absolutus Dominus Terrae Mariae et Avaloniae Baro de Baltemore”, meaning “Cecil Absolute Lord of Maryland and Avalon Baron of Baltimore” (Avalon refers to Lord Baltimore’s first settlement in the new world, in Newfoundland).

On the reverse of the Great Seal of Maryland is Lord Baltimore’s hereditary coat of arms. The 1st and 4th quarters represent the arms of the Calvert family described in heraldic language as a paly of 6 pieces, or (gold) and sable (black) a bend counterchanged. The 1st and 4th quarters are the left-hand top quarter and the right-hand bottom quarter. The 2nd and 3rd quarters show the arms of the Crossland family, which Cecil inherited from his grandmother, Alicia, wife of Leonard Calvert, the father of George, 1st Lord Baltimore. This coat of arms is in quarters also, argent (silver) and gules (red) a cross bottony (boutonne, with a button or a three-leaf clover at the end of each radius of the cross) counterchanged. Above the shield is placed an Earl’s coronet (indicating that though only a baron in England, Calvert was an earl or count palatine in Maryland). Above that, a helmet set full faced and over that the Calvert crest, (2 pennons, the dexter or the right one or (gold), the other sable (black) staffs gules (red) issuing from the ducal coronet). The supporters of the shield are a plowman and a fisherman with their hands on the shield, designated respectively by a spade held in the right hand of the plowman and a fish held in the left hand of the fisherman (the fish is heraldic and cannot, therefore, be identified as to any species). The plowman wears a high-crowned, broad-brimmed beaver hat; the fisherman wears a knitted cap (somewhat resembling a stocking cap). The motto in Italian on a ribbon at the feet of the plowman and fisherman is the motto of the Calvert family “Fatti maschii parole femine” loosely translated as “Manly deeds, womanly words”. Behind and surrounding both shield and supporters is an ermine-lined mantle and on the circle around this part of the seal are the words “Scuto bonae voluntatis tuae coronasti nos” (5th Psalm, 12th verse: “With favor wilt thou compass us as with a shield”) and the date 1632. The date refers to the year the charter was granted.

section.text: The Secretary of State shall have custody of the State seal.

subsection.text: The Governor may have the State seal:

paragraph.text: to affix it to a certified copy of a law or resolution;
to affix it to a communication from the State to the United States, another state, or a foreign country; or
as needed for any other purpose for which law provides.

subsection.text: The Governor may not affix the State seal to a document or allow the State seal to be affixed to a document that the Executive Branch of the State government issues, unless the Governor signs the document.

section.text: The Secretary of the Senate and the Chief Clerk of the House may have the State seal to affix it to a bill, as required by law.
The Maryland flag is the State flag.

subsection.text: The State flag is quartered.

The 1st and 4th quarters are paly of 6 pieces, or and sable, a bend dexter counterchanged. Thus, the 1st and 4th quarters consist of 6 vertical bars alternately gold and black with a diagonal band on which the colors are reversed.

The 2nd and 3rd, quarterly, are argent and gules, a cross bottony countersigned. Thus, the 2nd and 3rd quarters are a quartered field of red and white, charged with a Greek cross, its arms terminating in trefoils, with the coloring transported, red being on the white ground and white on the red, and all being as represented upon the escutcheon of the State seal.

section.text: Only a gold cross bottony may be used as an ornament on the top of a flagstaff that carries the State flag.

subsection.text: The flag of the United States and the State flag shall be flown from the State House as provided in this section.
When the General Assembly is in session, the flags shall be flown continuously.
When the General Assembly is not in session, the flags shall be flown:

paragraph.text: continuously on each day that the Governor designates as a public occasion; and
on any other day when the weather permits, between sunrise and sunset.

subsection.text: The State flag shall be flown with the black stripe on the diagonal bands of the 1st quartering at the top of the flagstaff, as shown in the illustration of the State flag in “Chronicles of Colonial Maryland”.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Flag to honor and remember members of the armed forces who died in the line of duty” means:

subparagraph.text: a flag created by Honor and Remember, Inc.; or
the flag designated by the United States Congress as the official symbol to honor and remember members of the armed forces who died in the line of duty.

paragraph.text: “POW/MIA flag” means the POW/MIA flag of the National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, each year, the POW/MIA flag and a flag to honor and remember members of the armed forces who died in the line of duty shall be flown on the State House grounds on:

subparagraph.text: the third Saturday in May, for Armed Forces Day;
May 30, for Memorial Day;
the day that the United States Congress designates for the observance of Memorial Day if other than May 30;

the Saturday and Sunday that are closest to May 30, unless the United States Congress designates another day for the observance of Memorial Day, in which case, the Saturday and Sunday that are closest to the day designated by the United States Congress;
July 4, for Independence Day;
the third Friday in September, for POW/MIA Recognition Day;
November 11, for Veterans’ Day;
the day that the United States Congress designates for the observance of Veterans’ Day if other than November 11; and

the Saturday and Sunday that are closest to November 11, unless the United States Congress designates another day for the observance of Veterans’ Day, in which case, the Saturday and Sunday that are closest to the day designated by the United States Congress.

paragraph.text: If the United States Congress designates a flag as the official symbol to honor and remember members of the armed forces who died in the line of duty, the flag designated by Congress shall be flown in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection.

section.text: A flag of the United States or a State flag that is displayed on State property and purchased with State money must be manufactured in the United States.

subsection.text: The Baltimore Checkerspot Butterfly (Euphydryas phaeton) is the State insect.
The Maryland Blue Crab (Callinectes sapidus) is the State crustacean.

section.text: The Baltimore Oriole (Icterus galbula) is the State bird.
The Chesapeake Bay retriever is the State dog.
The striped bass or rockfish (Morone saxatilis) is the State fish.
The black-eyed susan (Rudbeckia hirta) is the State flower.

subsection.text: The Governor may designate a citizen of the State as its Poet Laureate.

paragraph.text: The Poet Laureate:

subparagraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, is entitled to reimbursement for any expenses incurred in the performance of duties as Poet Laureate.

paragraph.text: Reimbursement under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: shall be paid from the General Emergency Fund of the Board of Public Works; and
may not exceed $1,000 in any 1 fiscal year.

subsection.text: The poem “Maryland! My Maryland!”, which James Ryder Randall composed in 1861, and the tune of “Lauriger Horatius” are the State song.
The words of the State song are:

row.entry: The despot’s heel is on thy shore,
His torch is at thy temple door,
That flecked the streets of Baltimore,
And be the battle queen of yore,
Hark to an exiled son’s appeal,
My mother State! to thee I kneel,
For life and death, for woe and weal,
And gird thy beauteous limbs with steel,
Thou wilt not cower in the dust,
Thy beaming sword shall never rust,
And all thy slumberers with the just,
Come! ’tis the red dawn of the day,
With Ringgold’s spirit for the fray,
With fearless Lowe and dashing May,
Come! for thy shield is bright and strong,
Come! for thy dalliance does thee wrong,
Come to thine own heroic throng,
And chaunt thy dauntless slogan song,
Dear Mother! burst the tyrant’s chain,
Virginia should not call in vain,
She meets her sisters on the plain--
I see the blush upon thy cheek,
For thou wast ever bravely meek,
But lo! there surges forth a shriek
From hill to hill, from creek to creek--
Thou wilt not yield the vandal toll,
Thou wilt not crook to his control,
Better the fire upon thee roll,
Better the blade, the shot, the bowl,
The Old Line’s bugle, fife, and drum,
She is not dead, nor deaf, nor dumb--
Huzza! she spurns the Northern scum!
She breathes! she burns! she’ll come! she’ll come!

subsection.text: Jousting is the State sport.
Lacrosse is the State team sport.
Center Stage in Baltimore City is the State theater.
Olney Theatre in Montgomery County is the State summer theater.

section.text: The white oak (Quercus alba) is the State tree.
The Ecphora gardnerae gardnerae (Wilson) is the State fossil shell.
The Skipjack is the State boat.
The diamondback terrapin (Malaclemys terrapin) is the State reptile and official mascot of the State’s flagship university at College Park.
Square dancing is the State folk dance.
Milk is the State drink.
The Astrodon johnstoni is the State dinosaur.
The calico cat is the State cat.
The Thoroughbred horse is the State horse.
The Patuxent River stone is the State gem.
Smith Island cake is the State dessert.
Walking is the State exercise.
The Governor annually shall proclaim April 13 as John Hanson’s birthday and dedicate that day to the statesman.
The Governor annually shall proclaim May 1 as Law Day U.S.A.

subsection.text: In recognition of the cultural and human values of poetry and poetic expression, the Governor annually shall proclaim October 15 as Poetry Day.
The proclamation shall urge cultural, educational, patriotic, and religious organizations to observe Poetry Day properly.

section.text: Each year, the Governor shall issue a proclamation encouraging the citizens of the State of Maryland, the media, government departments and agencies, and business and recreational facilities to observe a moment of silence at 3 p.m. on Memorial Day to unite in remembrance and commemorate the heroic acts and efforts of Marylanders who have served and died in the United States armed forces.

In recognition of the economic and cultural contributions of the many Marylanders for whom the lunar new year holds special significance, the Governor annually shall proclaim the day designated as new year on the Asian lunar calendar as Asian Lunar New Year Day.
The Governor annually shall proclaim June 20 as Maryland Charter Day.
The Governor annually shall proclaim December 17 as Annapolis Charter Day.
The Governor annually shall proclaim the second Saturday in May as Negro Baseball League Day.

subsection.text: The Governor shall proclaim the first Sunday in June each year as the day to honor the fire, rescue, and emergency services workers of the State who made the ultimate sacrifice in the performance of their duties.
The Governor shall order the State flag to be flown at half–staff on the first Sunday in June each year.

On the first Sunday in June each year, memorial plaques containing the names of the fire, rescue, and emergency services workers who made the ultimate sacrifice shall be placed by the Maryland Fire–Rescue Services Memorial Foundation, Inc., on the Maryland Fire–Rescue Services Memorial in the City of Annapolis.

section.text: The Governor annually shall:

paragraph.text: proclaim April 3 as Crime Victim and Advocate Commemorative Day to honor the individuals in the State who have become crime victims and the advocates who serve those victims; and
take appropriate steps to publicize Crime Victim and Advocate Commemorative Day.

subsection.text: In recognition of the historical contributions that women have made to the State, the Governor shall proclaim the month of March each year as Women’s History Month.
The proclamation shall urge educational and cultural organizations to observe Women’s History Month properly with appropriate programs, ceremonies, and activities.
In recognition of the historical contributions that Black Americans have made to the State, the Governor shall proclaim the month of February each year as Black History Month.
The proclamation shall urge educational and cultural organizations to observe Black History Month properly with appropriate programs, ceremonies, and activities.

In recognition of the contributions that Hispanic Americans have made to the State, the Governor shall proclaim the month from September 15 to October 15, both inclusive, each year as Hispanic Heritage Month.
The proclamation shall urge educational and cultural organizations to observe Hispanic Heritage Month properly with appropriate programs, ceremonies, and activities.

section.text: Subject to the limitations in this title, the State gives the consent for the acquisition of land that Congress needs under Article I, § 8, Clause 17 of the United States Constitution to exercise jurisdiction over that land.

subsection.text: With respect to land that the United States or any of its units leases or otherwise holds in the State, the State reserves jurisdiction and authority over the land and over persons, property, and transactions on the land to the fullest extent that is permitted by the United States Constitution and that is not inconsistent with the governmental purpose for which the land is held.

This section does not affect the jurisdiction and authority of the State over land or persons, property, and transactions on land that the United States or its unit has acquired on or before May 31, 1943 to the extent that the State ceded jurisdiction under:

paragraph.text: Chapter 193, §§ 3 and 4, of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1874;
Chapter 395, §§ 13 and 14, of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1874;
Chapter 67, § 21, of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1900;
Chapter 743, §§ 2 and 3, of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1906;
Chapter 194 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1908; or
any other act that gave consent for the acquisition of property and ceded jurisdiction with respect to that property.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, for the purpose of enforcing the civil or criminal laws of the State, the Governor may enter into agreements with the United States to establish full or partial concurrent jurisdiction by the State and the United States over any lands in the State held by the United States.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, and for as long as the United States shall own such land, the State cedes exclusive jurisdiction to the United States over all that certain tract or parcel of land situate in the State of Maryland, Anne Arundel County, being a portion of the Fort George G. paragraph.text: Notwithstanding the grant of exclusive jurisdiction ceded by the State in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the State shall retain the right to:

subparagraph.text: serve all civil and criminal process of the courts of this State; and
enforce and ensure compliance with all applicable environmental and Public Service Commission laws and regulations.

section.text: The United States shall record the deeds and other title documents with respect to land that the United States acquires in the land records for the county where the land is located.

subsection.text: Condemnation of private property by the United States shall be in accordance with Title 12 of the Real Property Article.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, this title does not authorize acquisition, by condemnation, of any tract of land that exceeds 10 acres.
The United States may condemn more than 10 acres on which to build an arsenal, coastal defense, fort, or magazine, including the barracks for staff.

subsection.text: In this section, “navigational aid” means a beacon, lighthouse, or other aid to navigation.
This title does not authorize acquisition of more than 5 acres to be used for a navigational aid.

If the land that is needed for a navigational aid is under navigable waters in the State and an agent of the United States submits to the Governor an application that describes the site, the Governor may:

paragraph.text: cede jurisdiction over the land; and
convey any title that the State holds in the land.

section.text: Any land that is within the George Washington Memorial Parkway and was transferred to the United States under Chapter 378 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1941, reverts to the State if the United States ceases to use the land for park purposes.
Jurisdiction ceded to the United States ceases if the United States ceases to hold land acquired under:

paragraph.text: Chapter 394 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1910;
Chapter 59, §§ 36A and 36B, of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1950; or
Chapter 158 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1953.

The General Assembly of Maryland, recognizing that our system of representative government is dependent upon the people maintaining the highest trust in their government officials and employees, finds and declares that the people have a right to be assured that the impartiality and independent judgment of those officials and employees will be maintained.
It is evident that this confidence and trust is eroded when the conduct of the State’s business is subject to improper influence or even the appearance of improper influence.

subsection.text: For the purpose of guarding against improper influence, the General Assembly enacts this Maryland Public Ethics Law to require certain government officials and employees to disclose their financial affairs and to set minimum ethical standards for the conduct of State and local business.
The General Assembly intends that this title, except its provisions for criminal sanctions, be liberally construed to accomplish this purpose.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated unless:

paragraph.text: the context clearly requires a different meaning; or
a different definition is adopted for a particular provision.

subsection.text: “Advisory body” means:

paragraph.text: a governmental unit designated by the Court of Appeals, for the purpose of issuing advisory opinions as to questions arising under Subtitles 5 and 6 of this title regarding a State official of the Judicial Branch;
the Joint Ethics Committee, for questions arising under Subtitle 5 of this title regarding a State official of the Legislative Branch; or
the Ethics Commission, for all other questions.

subsection.text: “Bicounty commission” means:

paragraph.text: the Maryland–National Capital Park and Planning Commission;
the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission; or
the Washington Suburban Transit Commission.

subsection.text: “Board” means an executive unit comprised of at least two members, all of whom:

paragraph.text: are appointed; and
serve on a part–time basis.

subsection.text: “Business entity” means a person engaged in business, whether profit or nonprofit, regardless of form.

paragraph.text: “Compensation” means money or any other valuable thing, regardless of form, received or to be received by a person from an employer for services rendered.

For purposes of Subtitle 7 of this title, if lobbying is only a portion of a person’s employment, “compensation” means a prorated amount that is based on the time devoted by the person to lobbying compared to the time devoted to other employment duties.
“Employee” means an individual who is employed:

subparagraph.text: by an executive unit;
by the Legislative Branch; or
in the Judicial Branch.

paragraph.text: “Employee” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a public official; or
a State official.

subsection.text: “Employer” means an entity that pays or agrees to pay compensation to another entity for services rendered.
“Entity” means:

paragraph.text: a person; or
a government or instrumentality of government.

subsection.text: “Entity doing business with the State” means:

paragraph.text: a regulated lobbyist;
an entity regulated by the executive unit of the applicable official or employee; or
an entity that is a party to one or a combination of sales, purchases, leases, or contracts to, from, or with the State, or any unit of the State, involving consideration:

subparagraph.text: of at least $5,000 on a cumulative basis during the calendar year for which a statement required by Subtitle 6 of this title is filed, regardless of when the consideration is to be paid; and

which shall include, as of the award or execution of a contract or lease, the total consideration committed to be paid under the contract or lease, to the extent ascertainable when awarded or executed, regardless of the period over which payments are to be made.

subsection.text: “Ethics Commission” means the State Ethics Commission.
“Executive action” means an act for which the Executive Branch of State government is responsible and that is taken by an official or employee of that branch.

paragraph.text: “Executive unit” means a department, agency, commission, board, council, or other body of State government that:

subparagraph.text: is established by law; and
is not in the Legislative Branch or the Judicial Branch of State government.

paragraph.text: “Executive unit” includes:

subparagraph.text: a county health department unless the officials and employees of the department are expressly designated as “local officials” in § 15–807 of this title;
the office of the sheriff in each county;
the office of the State’s Attorney in each county; and
the Liquor Control Board for Somerset County.

subsection.text: “Financial interest” means:

paragraph.text: ownership of an interest as the result of which the owner has received within the past 3 years, is currently receiving, or in the future is entitled to receive, more than $1,000 per year; or

subparagraph.text: ownership of more than 3% of a business entity by:

sub-subparagraph.text: an official;
an employee; or
the spouse of an official or employee; or

subparagraph.text: ownership of securities of any kind that represent, or are convertible into, ownership of more than 3% of a business entity by:

sub-subparagraph.text: an official;
an employee; or
the spouse of an official or employee.

subsection.text: “General Assembly” includes a member, committee, or subcommittee of the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: “Gift” means the transfer of anything of economic value, regardless of form, without adequate and lawful consideration.
“Gift” does not include the solicitation, acceptance, receipt, or regulation of a political contribution that is regulated in accordance with:

subparagraph.text: the Election Law Article; or
any other State law regulating:

sub-subparagraph.text: the conduct of elections; or
the receipt of political contributions.

paragraph.text: “Governmental unit” means a department, agency, commission, board, council, or other body of State government that is established by law.
“Governmental unit” includes an executive unit.
“Honorarium” means the payment of money or anything of value for:

subparagraph.text: speaking to, participating in, or attending a meeting or other function; or
writing an article that has been or is intended to be published.

paragraph.text: “Honorarium” does not include payment for writing a book that has been or is intended to be published.

subsection.text: “Immediate family” means an individual’s spouse and dependent children.

paragraph.text: “Interest” means a legal or equitable economic interest that is owned or held wholly or partly, jointly or severally, or directly or indirectly, whether or not the economic interest is subject to an encumbrance or condition.
“Interest” does not include:

subparagraph.text: an interest held in the capacity of agent, custodian, fiduciary, personal representative, or trustee, unless the holder has an equitable interest in the subject matter;
an interest in a time or demand deposit in a financial institution;
an interest in an insurance policy, endowment policy, or annuity contract by which an insurer promises to pay a fixed amount of money in a lump sum or periodically for life or a specified period; or
a common trust fund or a trust that forms part of a pension or a profit–sharing plan that:

sub-subparagraph.text: has more than 25 participants; and
is determined by the Internal Revenue Service to be a qualified trust or college savings plan under the Internal Revenue Code.

subsection.text: “Joint Ethics Committee” means the Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics.

paragraph.text: “Legislative action” means an official action or nonaction relating to:

subparagraph.text: a bill, resolution, amendment, nomination, appointment, report, or other matter within the jurisdiction of the General Assembly; or
a bill presented to the Governor for signature or veto.

paragraph.text: “Legislative action” includes the following actions:

subparagraph.text: introduction;
sponsorship;
consideration;
debate;
amendment;
passage;
defeat;
approval; or
veto.

subsection.text: “Legislative unit” means:

paragraph.text: the General Assembly;
either house of the General Assembly;

a standing committee of the General Assembly, provided that the presiding officer of the House of Delegates or Senate shall be deemed an ex officio member of any standing committee of the presiding officer’s chamber; or
a county or regional delegation of members of the General Assembly that is recognized by a presiding officer of the General Assembly.
“Lobbying” means performing any act that requires registration under § 15–701 of this title.
With respect to Subtitle 8 of this title, “lobbying” means performing acts, of a nature comparable to acts requiring registration under Subtitle 7 of this title, before the local government involved.

“Local official”, subject to § 15–807 of this title, means an official, officer, or employee of a county or municipal corporation that the governing body of the county or municipal corporation determines is subject to Subtitle 8, Part I of this title.

“Local official”, subject to § 15–807 of this title, includes each member and employee of a board of license commissioners that the applicable governing body determines is subject to Subtitle 8, Part I of this title.

subsection.text: “Member of household” means:

paragraph.text: if sharing an individual’s legal residence, the individual’s:

subparagraph.text: spouse;
child;
ward;
financially dependent parent; or
other financially dependent relative; or

paragraph.text: an individual’s spouse, child, ward, parent, or other relative, over whose financial affairs the individual has legal or actual control.

subsection.text: “Municipal corporation” means a municipality governed by Article XI–E of the Maryland Constitution.
“Official” means either a State official or a public official.
“Political contribution” means contributions as defined in § 1–101 of the Election Law Article.
“Principal political party” means the State Democratic Party or the State Republican Party.
“Procurement contract” has the meaning provided in § 11–101 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
“Public official” means an individual determined to be a public official in or pursuant to § 15–103 of this subtitle.
“Qualifying relative” means a spouse, parent, child, brother, or sister.
“Regulated lobbyist” means an entity that is required to register with the Ethics Commission pursuant to § 15–701(a) of this title.
“Respondent” means any of the following that is the subject of a complaint before the Ethics Commission:

paragraph.text: an official;
an employee;
a candidate for office as a State official;
an entity subject to Subtitle 7 of this title; or
an entity subject to § 15–508 of this title.

subsection.text: “School board” means a county board of education or, in Baltimore City, the Board of School Commissioners.
“School system” means the educational system under the authority of a school board.
“State official” means:

paragraph.text: a constitutional officer or officer–elect in an executive unit;
a member or member–elect of the General Assembly;
a judge or judge–elect of a court under Article IV, § 1 of the Constitution;
a judicial appointee as defined in Maryland Rule 16–814;
a State’s Attorney;
a clerk of the circuit court;
a register of wills; or
a sheriff.

subsection.text: “Superintendent” means a county superintendent as defined in § 1–101 of the Education Article.
The determination of whether an individual is a “public official” for the purposes of this title shall be made in accordance with the provisions of this section.
Except as provided in subsection (f) of this section, the following individuals in executive units are public officials:

paragraph.text: an individual who receives compensation at a rate equivalent to at least State grade level 16, or who is appointed to a board, if the Ethics Commission determines under § 15-208 of this title that:

subparagraph.text: the individual, acting alone or as a member of an executive unit, has decision making authority or acts as a principal advisor to one with that authority:

sub-subparagraph.text: in making State policy in an executive unit; or
in exercising quasi-judicial, regulatory, licensing, inspecting, or auditing functions; and

subparagraph.text: the individual’s duties are not essentially administrative and ministerial;

paragraph.text: any other individual in an executive unit, if the Ethics Commission determines that the individual, acting alone or as a member of the executive unit, has decision making authority or acts as a principal advisor to one with that authority in drafting specifications for, negotiating, or executing contracts that commit the State or an executive unit to spend more than $10,000 in a year;
a member, appointee, or employee of the Maryland Stadium Authority;
a member, appointee, or employee of the Canal Place Preservation and Development Authority; and
a member of the Emergency Medical Services Board.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (f) of this section, an individual in the Legislative Branch is a public official if the individual:

paragraph.text: receives compensation at a rate equivalent to at least State grade level 16; and
is designated a public official by order of the presiding officers of the General Assembly.

Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection or in subsection (f) of this section, an individual in the Judicial Branch is a public official if the individual receives compensation at a rate equivalent to at least State grade level 16.
For the purposes of paragraph (1) of this subsection, “individual in the Judicial Branch” includes an individual who is:

subparagraph.text: employed in the office of a clerk of court;
paid by a county to perform services in an orphans’ court or circuit court;
employed by the Attorney Grievance Commission;
employed by the State Board of Law Examiners; or
employed by the Court of Appeals Standing Committee on Rules of Practice and Procedure.

paragraph.text: The Ethics Commission may exclude the individuals in a position in the Judicial Branch from inclusion as public officials under paragraph (1) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: upon the recommendation of the State Court Administrator; and
if the Ethics Commission determines that the position does not have policy, policy advice, quasi-judicial, or procurement functions.

subsection.text: A member of a bicounty commission is a public official.
The following are not public officials:

paragraph.text: a State official;
an individual employed on a contractual basis unless the individual is:

subparagraph.text: employed on a full-time basis for more than 6 months; and
designated pursuant to subsection (b)(1) or (c) of this section; and

paragraph.text: a part-time or full-time faculty member at a State institution of higher education:

subparagraph.text: as to subsection (b)(2) of this section, only when the individual is acting in the capacity of a faculty member; and
as to any other provision of this section, unless the individual also:

sub-subparagraph.text: is employed in another position that causes the individual to be designated as a public official; or

directly procures, directly influences, or otherwise directly affects the formation or execution of any State contract, purchase, or sale, as established by regulations adopted by the Ethics Commission and approved by the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review.

section.text: This title shall be administered and implemented by the following three ethics agencies:

paragraph.text: the Joint Ethics Committee, acting as an advisory body as to the application of Subtitle 5 of this title to members of the General Assembly;

the Judicial Disabilities Commission or another body designated by the Court of Appeals, acting as an advisory body as to the application of Subtitles 5 and 6 of this title to State officials of the Judicial Branch; and
in all other matters, the Ethics Commission.

subsection.text: If another provision of law relating to conflicts of interest, financial disclosure, or lobbying is more stringent than this title, that provision shall apply.
Title 3, Subtitle 1 of the Public Safety Article does not apply to activities carried out by the Ethics Commission under this title.

section.text: There is a State Ethics Commission.

paragraph.text: The Ethics Commission consists of five members.
The Governor shall appoint:

subparagraph.text: with the advice and consent of the Senate, three members, at least one of whom shall be a member of the principal political party of which the Governor is not a member;
one member nominated by the President of the Senate; and
one member nominated by the Speaker of the House.

paragraph.text: The Governor may reject a nominee of the President or of the Speaker only for cause.
If the Governor rejects a nominee under paragraph (3) of this subsection, the appropriate presiding officer shall nominate another individual.
A vacancy shall be filled in a manner consistent with this subsection.

subsection.text: A member of the Ethics Commission may not:

paragraph.text: hold elected or appointed office in, be an employee of, or be a candidate for office in:

subparagraph.text: the federal government;
this State’s government;
a municipal corporation, county, or multicounty agency of the State; or
a political party; or

paragraph.text: be a regulated lobbyist.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the Ethics Commission shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 5 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms in effect for members of the Commission on October 1, 1995.
A member may serve no more than two consecutive 5-year terms.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves for the rest of the term.
At the end of a term, a member may continue to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Governor may remove a member for:

subparagraph.text: neglect of duty;
misconduct in office;
a disability that makes the member unable to discharge the powers and duties of office; or
a violation of this title.

paragraph.text: Before removing a member, the Governor shall give the member:

subparagraph.text: written notice of the charges; and
an opportunity to reply to the charges.

subsection.text: The Ethics Commission shall elect a chairman from among its members.

paragraph.text: The term of the chairman is 1 year.
The chairman may be reelected.
A majority of the authorized membership of the Ethics Commission is a quorum.
The Ethics Commission may act only on the affirmative vote of at least a majority of its authorized membership.

subsection.text: The Ethics Commission shall meet at the call of the chairman or a majority of the members then serving.
Each member of the Ethics Commission is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement for reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in the discharge of official duties.
The Ethics Commission:

subparagraph.text: shall appoint to serve at its pleasure:

sub-subparagraph.text: an executive director;
a general counsel; and
a staff counsel; and

subparagraph.text: shall have other staff, including such counsel as may be required to advise persons who are subject to the jurisdiction of the Ethics Commission, in accordance with the State budget.

paragraph.text: The general counsel and the staff counsel of the Ethics Commission shall be individuals admitted to practice law in the State.

subsection.text: The Ethics Commission may ask the Attorney General or Comptroller for professional assistance to assist in the performance of the Commission’s functions.
The Ethics Commission shall:

paragraph.text: except as otherwise expressly provided in this title, administer the provisions of this title;
prescribe and provide forms for each document required by this title;
retain as a public record each document filed with the Ethics Commission for at least 4 years after receipt;
periodically review the adequacy of public ethics laws;

review each statement and report filed in accordance with Subtitle 6 or Subtitle 7 of this title and notify officials and employees submitting documents under Subtitle 6 of this title of any omissions or deficiencies; and
publish and make available to persons subject to this title, and to the public, information that explains the provisions of this title, the duties imposed by it, and the means for enforcing it.
The Ethics Commission shall adopt by regulation model provisions for local governments that relate to:

subparagraph.text: conflicts of interest;
financial disclosure; and
regulation of lobbying.

paragraph.text: Model provisions adopted under paragraph (1) of this subsection may be:

subparagraph.text: adopted by any local jurisdiction; or
in accordance with Subtitle 8 of this title, imposed on a local jurisdiction.

paragraph.text: The Ethics Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: compile annually an alphabetized list of entities doing business with the State, as defined in § 15-102 of this title, during the preceding calendar year; and
make information from the list available to individuals required to file a statement under Subtitle 6 of this title.

paragraph.text: The list prepared under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be available for public inspection by March 1 of each year.

On request of the Ethics Commission, an official or a unit of State government, in a timely manner, shall provide the Commission with any information necessary for the Commission to perform its duties under this subsection.
The Ethics Commission shall provide a training course of not less than 2 hours on the requirements of the Public Ethics Law for an individual who:

subparagraph.text: fills a vacancy after September 30, 1999 in a position that has been identified as a public official position pursuant to § 15-103 of this title; or
serves in a position identified after September 30, 1999 as a public official position pursuant to § 15-103 of this title.

paragraph.text: An individual specified in paragraph (1) of this subsection shall complete a training course provided by the Ethics Commission within 6 months of filling a vacancy or a position being identified as a public official position.
The training requirement under this subsection does not apply to an individual who:

subparagraph.text: is a public official only as a member of a commission, task force, or similar entity; or
has completed a training course provided by the Ethics Commission while serving in another public official position.

The Ethics Commission shall provide a training course for regulated lobbyists and prospective regulated lobbyists at least twice each year regarding the provisions of the Maryland Public Ethics Law relevant to regulated lobbyists. One such course shall be conducted in the month of January.

A regulated lobbyist, other than the employer of a regulated lobbyist as described in § 15-701(a)(6) of this title, shall attend a training course provided under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph at least once in any 2-year period during which a lobbyist has registered with the Ethics Commission.

paragraph.text: At the time of a person’s initial registration as a regulated lobbyist, the Ethics Commission shall provide the person with information relating to the provisions of the Maryland Public Ethics Law relevant to regulated lobbyists.

subsection.text: Subject to § 2-1246 of this article, the Ethics Commission shall submit to the General Assembly:

paragraph.text: an annual report on its activities; and
based on its investigations and studies, other special reports with recommendations for legislation as may be appropriate.

section.text: The Ethics Commission may adopt regulations to implement this title.

subsection.text: The Ethics Commission and staff counsel each may:

paragraph.text: administer oaths; and
issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses to testify or to produce other evidence.

subsection.text: A subpoena issued under subsection (a) of this section may be judicially enforced.

With advice from the Secretary of Budget and Management and in accordance with § 15-103 of this title, the Ethics Commission shall determine whether an individual in an executive unit is a public official for the purposes of this title.
The Secretary of Budget and Management shall provide advice under subsection (a) of this section to the Ethics Commission:

paragraph.text: annually; and
at any other time on request of the Ethics Commission.

subsection.text: The Ethics Commission may exempt from this title or may modify the requirements of this title as to a board, member of a board, or a municipal corporation if the Ethics Commission finds that, because of the nature of the board or the size of the municipal corporation, the application of this title to that board, member, or municipal corporation:

paragraph.text: would be an unreasonable invasion of privacy;
would significantly reduce the availability of qualified individuals for public service; and
is not necessary to preserve the purposes of this title.

subsection.text: Subject to § 15-502(d) of this title, the Ethics Commission may grant an exemption to a board or member of a board only on written request of the executive unit involved.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this title, the records of the Ethics Commission in any matter in which an exemption is granted under this title shall be available for public inspection.

paragraph.text: There is a Lobbyist Registration Fund.
The Fund includes all fees collected under Subtitle 7 of this title.
The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund.
Any balance remaining in the Fund at the end of any fiscal year shall revert to the General Fund of the State.
The Treasurer shall separately hold, and the Comptroller shall account for, the Fund.
The Fund shall be invested and reinvested in the same manner as other State funds.
Expenditures from the Fund shall be made in accordance with an appropriation approved by the General Assembly in the annual budget.

subsection.text: The Fund shall be used to defray the expenses of administering Subtitle 7 of this title.
On written request of an entity subject to this title, the appropriate advisory body shall issue an advisory opinion regarding the application of this title.
On written request of any other entity, the appropriate advisory body may issue an advisory opinion.

section.text: The Ethics Commission shall issue an advisory opinion required under § 15-301(a) of this subtitle not more than 60 days after receiving a request, or more promptly if circumstances require.

subsection.text: Each advisory opinion shall be:

paragraph.text: in writing; and
published in the Maryland Register.
Before an advisory opinion may be made public, the advisory body shall delete:

subparagraph.text: the name of the entity that is the subject of the opinion; and
to the fullest extent possible, any other information that may identify the entity.

paragraph.text: The identity of the entity that is the subject of the opinion may not be revealed.

subsection.text: If the Ethics Commission issues an advisory opinion regarding a State official of the Legislative Branch as to a question arising under Subtitle 6 of this title, and if requested by the State official, the Joint Ethics Committee shall issue an advisory opinion on the matter in accordance with this subtitle.
The opinion of the Joint Ethics Committee prevails to the extent of any inconsistency.

paragraph.text: Any entity may file with the Ethics Commission a written complaint alleging a violation of this title.
A complaint filed under this subsection shall be:

subparagraph.text: signed; and
made under oath.

subsection.text: The Ethics Commission on its own motion may issue a complaint alleging a violation of this title.
The Ethics Commission promptly shall transmit to the respondent a copy of the complaint.
For further action after the filing of a complaint, the Ethics Commission promptly shall refer the complaint to:

paragraph.text: the Commission on Judicial Disabilities, if the complaint concerns a judge of a court established under Article IV, § 1 of the Maryland Constitution;
the Joint Ethics Committee, if the complaint concerns:

subparagraph.text: a State official of the Legislative Branch; and
a violation of Subtitle 5 of this title; or

paragraph.text: the staff counsel, if the complaint concerns any other entity.

subsection.text: On request of the Commission on Judicial Disabilities or the Joint Ethics Committee, the Ethics Commission shall provide any information or assistance that is not prohibited by law.

As to a complaint retained by the Ethics Commission under § 15-402(b) of this subtitle, the staff counsel shall collect and refer to the Ethics Commission evidence relating to each violation of this title alleged in the complaint.

paragraph.text: Prior to submitting the evidence to the Ethics Commission, the staff counsel shall notify the complainant and the respondent.
The Commission shall dismiss the complaint in a signed order if:

subparagraph.text: the respondent, within 15 days after receiving the notice, takes any action that may be available to cure each alleged violation; and
it finds that dismissal is not contrary to the purposes of this title.

paragraph.text: If the complaint is dismissed under this subsection, the Ethics Commission shall promptly send a copy of the order to the complainant and the respondent.

subsection.text: If the Ethics Commission determines that the evidence submitted by the staff counsel does not merit further proceedings, the Ethics Commission shall:

paragraph.text: dismiss the complaint in a signed order; and
promptly send a copy of the order to the complainant and the respondent.

subsection.text: If a complaint is not dismissed under subsection (b) or (c) of this section, the Ethics Commission shall proceed to a hearing on the complaint.

paragraph.text: A hearing on a complaint shall be conducted under Title 10, Subtitle 2 (Administrative Procedure Act - Contested Cases) of this article to the extent that subtitle is consistent with this title.
In preparation for the hearing, the respondent may use the subpoena power of the Ethics Commission.

subsection.text: At the hearing, the staff counsel:

paragraph.text: shall present to the Ethics Commission all available evidence relating to each alleged violation of this title; and
may recommend any disposition of the complaint that appears appropriate to the staff counsel.

subsection.text: The respondent may be represented by counsel.
After the Ethics Commission considers all of the evidence presented at the hearing, it shall make findings of fact and conclusions of law with respect to each alleged violation.
If the Ethics Commission determines that the respondent has not violated this title, the Ethics Commission shall:

paragraph.text: dismiss the complaint in a signed order; and
promptly send a copy of the order to the complainant and the respondent.

subsection.text: If the Ethics Commission determines that the respondent has violated any provision of this title, the Ethics Commission may:

paragraph.text: issue an order of compliance directing the respondent to cease and desist from the violation;
issue a reprimand; or
recommend to the appropriate authority other appropriate discipline of the respondent, including censure or removal, if that discipline is authorized by law.

subsection.text: If the Ethics Commission determines that a respondent has violated Subtitle 7 of this title, the Ethics Commission may:

paragraph.text: require a respondent who is a regulated lobbyist to file any additional reports or information that reasonably relates to information required under §§ 15-703 and 15-704 of this title;
impose a fine not exceeding $5,000 for each violation; or
subject to subsection (e) of this section, suspend the registration of a regulated lobbyist.
If the Ethics Commission determines it necessary to protect the public interest and the integrity of the governmental process, the Ethics Commission may issue an order to:

subparagraph.text: suspend the registration of an individual regulated lobbyist if the Ethics Commission determines that the individual regulated lobbyist:

sub-subparagraph.text: has knowingly and willfully violated Subtitle 7 of this title; or
has been convicted of a criminal offense arising from lobbying activities; or

subparagraph.text: revoke the registration of an individual regulated lobbyist if the Ethics Commission determines that, based on acts arising from lobbying activities, the individual regulated lobbyist has been convicted of bribery, theft, or other crime involving moral turpitude.

paragraph.text: If the Commission suspends the registration of an individual regulated lobbyist under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the individual regulated lobbyist may not engage in lobbying for compensation for a period, not to exceed 3 years, that the Commission determines as to that individual regulated lobbyist is necessary to satisfy the purposes of this subsection.
If the Commission revokes the registration of an individual regulated lobbyist under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the individual regulated lobbyist may not engage in lobbying for compensation.
If the Ethics Commission initiates a complaint based on a violation or conviction described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Ethics Commission shall initiate the complaint within 2 years of:

subparagraph.text: the Ethics Commission’s knowledge of the violation; or
the date the conviction becomes final.

paragraph.text: The termination or expiration of the registration of an individual regulated lobbyist does not limit the authority of the Ethics Commission to issue an order under this subsection.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, an individual whose registration as an individual regulated lobbyist is revoked or suspended under subsection (e) of this section may apply to the Ethics Commission for reinstatement.

The Ethics Commission may reinstate the registration of an individual whose registration as a regulated lobbyist has been revoked or suspended under subsection (e) of this section if the Commission determines that reinstatement of the individual would not be detrimental to the public interest and the integrity of the governmental process, based on:

subparagraph.text: the nature and circumstances of the original misconduct or violation leading to revocation or suspension;
the individual’s subsequent conduct and reformation; and
the present ability of the individual to comply with the provisions of the ethics law.
